DOC.HEAD: Diplomatic Efforts Follow Reported Attacks in Cambodia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 2nd, `Khmer Rouge' to UPDATE with Army radio report confirming attack in Battambang. Picks up 3rd pvs, `The non-communist' SUBS graf 14 `The Khmer' to conform. Edits thereafter to trim.
DOC.TEXT: Diplomatic efforts began Wednesday in Bangkok, Beijing and Paris to try to resolve the 11-year-old Cambodian war following reports of guerrilla attacks in Phnom Penh and Cambodia's second-largest city. Khmer Rouge guerrillas claimed they attacked the Cambodian capital with grenades Saturday night, forcing the premier and president to flee toward Vietnam. But the claim could not be confirmed, and previous communist Khmer Rouge claims have been exaggerated. Khmer Rouge army radio however said Wednesday the guerrillas held Battambang, Cambodia's second city, for four hours last weekend and still controlled a position that had defended Route 5, the major highway leading from the city across country to Phnom Penh. It said the 5th military region's command at the provincial office building was destroyed and the Bek Chan airfield was ``utterly damaged'' with the control tower and two planes destroyed. The non-communist resistance forces of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, allies of the Khmer Rouge, said they launched a series of grenade attacks on Phnom Penh between Dec. 5 and 10, wounding 16 Vietnamese and two Cambodian policemen. The Cambodian government's SPK news agency on Tuesday did not mention any attack. Igor Rogachev, a Soviet deputy foreign minister, arrived in Beijing on Tuesday for talks on Cambodia with Chinese Foreign Ministry officials. Rogachev will likely dicuss an Australian proposal calling for the Vietnam-backed government in Phnom Penh to be replaced by an interim U.N. administration until free elections can be held, said Soviet Embassy spokesman Yuri Lysenko. The Soviets back the pro-Vietnamese government while China arms the guerrillas. The French Foreign Ministry on Tuesday scheduled a meeting in Paris on Jan. 15-16 for the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council to discuss Cambodia, and the Australian plan could be on the agenda. The meeting ``will permit an examination of all the proposals advanced in recent weeks concerning Cambodia and a study of all means that might bring an end to armed conflicts on the ground,'' the ministry said. ``It comes at a time when it appears possible to envisage an increased role for the United Nations in the settlement process.'' The Austalian plan would require backing from all five permanent members of the Security Council: the United States, Soviet Union, China, Britain and France. Indonesia's foreign minister, Ali Alatas, arrived in Thailand on Tuesday in hopes of meeting representatives of Cambodia's Vietnamese-installed government and the three guerrilla groups to hear their views on the Australian plan and on efforts. Indonesia has been the host of several regional peace conferences. The conflict has raged since Vietnamese troops in late 1978 ended the brutal 3{-year reign of Pol Pot's Khmer Rouge, which killed hundreds of thousands of Cambodians while trying to create a primitive agrarian society. Fears of a battlefield victory by the Khmer Rouge, the strongest of three guerrilla groups, have risen since September, when Vietnam said it withdrew all troops. A Thai military intelligence officer, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Tuesday: ``The Khmer Rouge are clearly ... moving deeper and deeper. They want to sabotage the credibility of the government.'' The Khmer Rouge said earlier they had attacked and set ablaze Battambang on Friday and Saturday. A Western diplomat in Thailand said the Battambang attack ``was more psychological than strategic.'' The reported attack in Phnom Penh, if confirmed, would be the most serious in the civil war. The Khmer Rouge broadcast said resistance forces lobbed five grenades Saturday into the center of Phnom Penh near the office of the Central Committee of the Communist Party, killing or wounding some Vietnamese and ``lackey puppets.'' Another broadcast said the guerrillas attacked the city and suburbs with 32 grenades and plastic explosives, killing or wounding some Vietnamese soldiers and others who were drinking near a hotel. Vietnamese secret agents and Cambodian policemen were killed in the suburbs, it said. The Cambodian government's SPK news agency, monitored in Bangkok, did not mention any attack. It said Sunday's National Day celebrations took place in ``total security'' and that Saturday and Monday also were peaceful. In Washington, State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler said she had no information about the reported guerrilla offensive. In reply to a question, she again defended U.S. policy as supporting a role for the Khmer Rouge in any transitional government, but added: ``We abhor the Khmer Rouge. The Khmer Rouge, we have said, are absolutely horrible.'' The guerrillas said their attacks prevented Premier Hun Sen from meeting in Phnom Penh with Australian Deputy Foreign Secretary Michael Costello for talks on a peace plan. It said Hun Sen went from Ho Chi Minh City to Cambodia's eastern Svay Rieng province, bordering Vietnam, to meet the envoy. Costello said after arriving in Bangkok on Tuesday that as far as he knew, the venue was changed from Phnom Penh to Svay Rieng on Saturday and that he first heard of the change Sunday. He could not confirm the grenade attack. SPK said Hun Sen invited Costello to meet him in Svay Rieng because the premier was already there on an inspection tour. It said Hun Sen told Costello he agreed to a U.N. role in an interim administration only if the U.N. seat held by the guerrillas first is vacated.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed in Crash of Army UH-60 Blackhawk Helicopter
DOC.TEXT: An Army UH-60 Blackhawk helicopter crashed during desert exercises Tuesday, killing all four soldiers aboard, a base spokesman said. The helicopter crashed at 3:32 p.m. about 14 miles east of the main post of the sprawling Mojave Desert base, said Capt. Gary Cleland. The names of the soldiers were withheld pending notification of families. All were assigned to the 4th Battalion, 1st Aviation Regiment of the 1st Infantry Division from Fort Riley, Kan. The 1st Infantry Division has been taking part in a three-week field training exercise that began Jan. 3, Cleland said. ``No further details on the accident are available at this time,'' Cleland said. The accident was being investigated by local Army officials and personnel from the Army Safety Center at Fort Rucker, Ala. A Blackhawk crew includes two pilots and a crew chief and can carry a load of 2,640 pounds or 11 combat-equipped troops.

DOC.HEAD: Frog Importer Has Contest Organizers Jumping Over His Big Amphibians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: An amphibian importer has spawned a controversy by entering giant frogs in the annual Frog Jump Jubilee, making some people hopping mad because the jumbo jumpers can stretch 3 feet and weigh up to 15 pounds. Organizers say Andy J. Koffman, 40, has created a ``superfrog crisis'' with his bid to enter 10 oversized amphibians from Africa in the whimsical competition started by Mark Twain's story, ``The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County.'' Imagine basketball players 40 or 50 feet tall. That's about the human equivalent of the frogs Koffman wants to enter in the contest to be held in May in Angels Camp, Calif. ``I'll apply for a green card for these guys if I have to,'' Koffman said Sunday. ``This is what America is all about.'' Koffman, a licensed importer of exotic birds, reptiles and amphibians from Africa for nearly 13 years, says he is the sole successful importer of the Goliath frog, a denizen of swift-flowing rivers in Cameroon and Equatorial Guinea. He said he had imported 50 of the frogs, which can measure 3 feet in length. He sold 30 of them to the Cincinnati Zoo, the Lincoln Park Zoo in Chicago, the Brookfield Zoo in Chicago, a Japanese importer for zoos there, a zoo in the Netherlands and a wholesaler in Florida. The other 20, ranging from 3 pounds to 8 pounds, occupy a pond in his basement. He says he is preparing to import some 15 pounders. Until now, virtually all the entrants have been California bullfrogs, with the biggest about a pound, said Diane Baumann, interim manager for the 39th Agricultural District Association, which has run the event since it was started in 1928 at the Calaveras County Fair. ``We have had some imports from Africa, but they were always about the same size,'' she said in a telephone interview Sunday night. The nine-member association board of directors is meeting Friday to discuss the issue, ``probably in executive (closed) session due to the possibility of litigation,'' she said. Concerns include fairness, safety and survival of the competition, Baumann said. ``It's like racing a draft horse against thoroughbreds; entirely different species,'' Baumann said. The contest record of 21 feet, 5} inches for three hops was set by Rosie the Ribiter in 1986. Koffman says his superfrogs can easily exceed that in a single bound. Baumann also said some feared one of the Goliaths might leap out of the arena _ ``unfortunately, our stage is only about 35 feet deep'' _ and hit a spectator. Moreover, unlike their much smaller relatives, the monster frogs have sharp teeth and might gobble up their competitors, she said. Koffman says he feeds his 20 frogs about 100 goldfish a week, varying their diet with occasional mice and crickets. ``They do have a voracious appetite,'' he said. ``They'll eat anything that moves.'' He said he once dissected a frog in Africa and found what looked like an entire colony of army ants in the stomach. ``What this guy did was, he found one of these columns of ants and got in front and opened his mouth and let the whole colony walk in,'' Koffman said. ``They'll eat birds, baby chicks.'' He keeps the frogs in a 1,500-gallon pond about 12 feet square, with logs and plants around the perimeter and an island in the center. Air and water are kept at a constant 80 degrees Fahrenheit, the walls of the room are padded and lined with plastic and the water is kept slightly alkaline. Koffman said he grew up as a doctor's son in East Tawas, Mich., went from home aquariums to owning four pet stores by age 18, earned a degree in business administration at the University of Michigan and became an importer of exotic creatures.

DOC.HEAD: State GOP: Duke Risks Censure in Senate Race
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: David Duke hitched his white supremacy line to the Louisiana Republican Party in 1989 and shocked loyal regulars with a state House victory. Now, he wants a ride to Capitol Hill on the Grand Old Party. Four Louisiana Republicans are battling for the state endorsement Saturday in the race against U.S. Sen. Bennett Johnston, three-term Democratic darling of the powerful oil and gas lobby. Duke should not expect the party's backing at the New Orleans convention, said William Nungesser, chairman of the Louisiana GOP. In December caucuses, the former grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, pulled in only a few non-binding delegate pledges. ``Caucuses are a party-insider type of situation. The votes that really count are the votes that come on Election Day,'' Duke said. But he said he'll run as a Republican with or without a GOP blessing. That move could bring down the wrath of the Louisiana party, which at times has appeared almost ambivalent about Duke, Nungesser said. ``David Duke's past is horrible. No reasonable person should be ready to forgive him based on his own statements. Any reasonable, rational person should not believe he's changed just because he says he has,'' Nungesser said. He predicted that a previously failed attempt to censure Duke would be revived if he runs against Johnston without party backing. ``It will prove once again he's got his own agenda,'' Nungesser said. The Oct. 6 election is an open primary, a candidate free-for-all without regard to party. If no one wins a majority, the top two vote-getters enter a runoff. Duke, 39, has been a thorn in the GOP side since the polished, handsome advocate of Caucasian purity switched his registration from Democrat to Republican. A few weeks later, he claimed a 227-vote victory for a seat in the Louisiana Legislature by defeating John Treen, brother of Louisiana's first Republican governor since Reconstruction, David Treen. Duke left the Klan in 1980, accused of trying to sell a membership list to a rival faction, and now leads his own group, the National Association for the Advancement of White People. Since campaigning for the state House, Duke's racist, anti-Semitic points of view have been cloaked in euphemism, critics charge. Duke, in turn, says he champions equal rights for everyone, including whites. Welfare reform, elimination of minority set-asides and birth control programs for teen-agers are his platform. Duke's election spurred Republican National Committee Chairman Lee Atwater to denounce him as a ``charlatan.'' Duke ignored the declaration, saying the Republicans hadn't helped him anyway. Even presidents Bush and Reagan endorsed opponent John Treen last year. Duke said he doesn't expect the state party's support this ear. ``No matter who they endorse, I am planning on running. I hope other candidates will run,'' Duke said. He said he has the best chance to dislodge Johnston. ``I think his support is extremely soft. I think he's very, very vulnerable,'' Duke said. ``I think my candidacy would assure his defeat. I would appeal to his traditional voters, a majority of the white blue-collar vote, along with some conservative Republicans,'' Duke said. Johnston counters that the Republican Party is under siege. ``There's almost a battle going on for the soul of the Republican Party. There are those like David Treen who say that Duke should be censured and in effect, declared an illegitimate Republican, and there are others who more or less welcomed him into the party,'' Johnston said. Beth Rickey, a New Orleans member of the GOP state central committee, is not confident her party will take a bold stand against Duke. The committee rejected her earlier censure attempt, saying it had inadequate procedural grounds. ``There's a lot of embarrassment. The perception is that they are weak and wimpy and have not done anything,'' Ms. Rickey said. Duke's effect on the Legislature was limited _ none of his bills passed. But public sentiment was favorable when a move to block his seating fizzled. Lawmakers who live as many as 300 miles away from Duke's nearly all-white district in suburban New Orleans said they got calls pressing them to let Duke take the oath of office. Duke had finally achieved a degree of mainstream credibility. It was something that eluded him since the 1970s when he was known as the Nazi of Louisiana State University. Duke joined the KKK in high school and is largely credited with shifting the organization's focus from night-riding lynchmen to an unmasked family group, knee-deep in white culture and wrapped in the American flag. Duke says he earns his living as an author and has acknowledged writing under a pseudonymn a sex manual called ``Finders Keepers'' and a street-fighting manual for blacks called ``African Atto.''

DOC.HEAD: Hunger Strike by Iran-Supported Inmate Increases Tension
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report. Anis Naccache is pronounced ah-NEES nah-KAHSH.
DOC.TEXT: A four-month hunger strike by the leader of an Iranian-directed team that failed in a 1980 bid to assassinate an exile leader in Paris is raising concern about possible terrorist attacks in France. Anis Naccache, supported by Iran's president and foreign minister, says France promised to free him in the deal that won the release in May 1988 of all French hostages that were held by pro-Iranian groups in Lebanon. Serving a life sentence, Naccache could only get out of prison if pardoned by President Francois Mitterrand, who has said he might do so, but has not made clear when or under what circumstances. Naccache, a Lebanese Moslem, has lost 59 pounds since he started his fast on Sept. 8 and weighs only 105 pounds, said his lawyer, Jacques Verges. Naccache is refusing food but is drinking liquids and is fed intravenously from time to time by doctors at the Fresne prison outside Paris. Naccache has lost his immune defenses to disease, Verges said. ``If tomorrow someone goes into his cell and sneezes in his nose, he could very well die from it,'' Verges said on French television. It is widely believed that if Naccache dies in prison, his friends will strike back. ``The death of Anis Naccache, if it comes brutally at the end of his hunger strike, will by all evidence be serious for France, which would find itself confronted by an increased terrorist menace easy to predict,'' the conservative newspaper Le Figaro wrote Saturday. The hunger strike seems to have hardened Mitterrand's stand. ``He cannot hope to free himself with a hunger strike,'' the president said Friday. ``If Anis Naccache decides to die in prison and we do not have the means to stop him, this will be his responsibility.'' A year ago, Mitterrand called on Iran to provide proof that Naccache's freedom really had been promised in the hostage deal negotiated by the conservative government of Premier Jacques Chirac. Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani and Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati have said it was promised but apparently have not given Mitterrand any evidence. Chirac denied Naccache's release was part of the agreement, and Mitterrand said: ``I have no reason to doubt the word of Mr. Chirac.'' During the uncomfortable two-year period of ``cohabitation'' in French government, the conservative premier and Socialist president were not sharing many secrets. The hostage deal came at the peak of the hotly contested 1988 election campaign in which Mitterrand won re-election by defeating Chirac, and the Socialists regained control of the government. But the former premier suggested that Mitterrand should consider including Naccache in the annual Bastille Day pardon on July 14, 1989, ``because we are in a period of tension and should not add to the reasons that might make us targets of terrorism.'' Naccache was one of three prisoners whose freedom was demanded by a group calling itself the Committee for Solidarity with Arab and Middle East Political Prisoners, which claimed responsibility for bombings in 1985 and 1986 that killed 13 people and injured more than 250 in Paris. Investigators say they believe the committee was a front for Hezbollah, a pro-Iranian Shiite extremist organization in Lebanon that denies involvement in terrorism and hostage-taking. In an accident of the court calendar that is sure to increase the pressure, 10 people charged in the 1985-86 bombings will come to trial Jan. 29. The alleged leader of the group, Fouad Ali Saleh of Tunisia, gave a hint of what is to come at a pre-trial hearing Friday, shouting in court, ``Hezbollah will massacre you!'' and ``The West will die at the hand of Islam, prepare your caskets!'' When Prosecutor Jacques Fourvel tried to interrupt, Saleh yelled out, ``Shut up, you! Jews and Christians have no right to talk when a Moslem is speaking. Islam will be your death. God will crush you, murderer, son of a pig, executioner! You eat like a pig, you have ripped up the Koran!'' Naccache's hunger strike and the upcoming trial were cited as possible reasons last month when France put stiff anti-terrorist security checks into effect, especially at airports and border crossings. Fears were spurred by the seizure of 485 pounds of explosives in Valencia, Spain, apparently en route for France. Spanish police said at least three men arrested with the explosives were Hezbollah members. Naccache and four other men were convicted in the July 1980 attack on Shahpour Bakhtiar, Iran's prime minister before the 1979 Islamic revolution. Bakhtiar escaped injury and still lives in Paris, but a policeman and a bystander were killed. Both defense and prosecution said at the trial that Naccache and his team were acting on orders from senior Iranian officials.

DOC.HEAD: Official Says Ceausescus Looted Museums
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Romania
DOC.TEXT: The Ceausescus looted public museums of thousands of valuable artworks during their authoritarian rule and turned the country's Culture Ministry into ``a corpse,'' says the new head of the department. ``It was a simple matter of greed,'' Culture Minister Andrei Plesu said in an interview Monday. Dictator Nicolae Ceausescu ``had to possess these works,'' he added. Plesu, a respected art historian and philosopher, had been banished to the provinces under the rule of Ceausescu and his wife, Elena. The Ceausescus were ousted last month, found guilty of ``grave crimes'' and executed Dec. 25. The official, appointed by the provisional government, spoke in a chilly and gloomy conference hall of his department, known under Ceausescu as The Council of Culture and Socialist Education. Plesu said ministry employees had just begun work on an inventory of paintings, sculptures and other art objects reclaimed from dozens of houses and vacation homes used by the Ceausescus and their relatives. ``He stole from our patrimony objects of art and used them in his own house,'' said Plesu, 40, estimating that thousands of valuable works by Romanian and foreign artists were claimed by the Ceausescus. ``There were houses full of such objects,'' Plesu said. He said he believed Flemish masters were among the artists whose paintings were taken illegally. Ceausescu's hunger for art appeared to be common knowledge in Romania. Bogdan Lazaroae, a 21-year-old student, said the art museum in his home city of Sibiu, 150 miles northwest of Bucharest, had been forced to contribute a Rembrandt to the Ceausescu collection. Plesu, forced last year to move from Bucharest to a Bacau district town near the border to Soviet Moldavia after signing a letter critical of the state writers' union, said the dictator had no sense of art. Plesu described the organization preceding his ministry as ``an institution organized against culture'' that suppressed most artistic expression not complimentary to the Ceausescus. ``I have to revive a corpse,'' he said of his ministry. Much of the culture budget of past years was spent on Cintarea Romaniei _ a nearly continuous fest of music, literature and dance designed to pay homage to the Ceausescus and their narrow vision of what constitued art. The festival has been discontinued, and Plesu announced Saturday that the ministry would more than double last year's budget of $55 million to $135 million to infuse new life in cultural activities forced underground under the Ceausescu leadership. Plesu said Monday there had been no wholesale purge of his ministry but main culprits of past excesses had been retired, while the more than 30-member censor's section had been dissolved. Plesu said the cuts had reduced the staff of 180 to about 140, and he planned to prune it to 90. Those remaining need time to adapt to the gentler post-Ceausescu era, he said. ``I needed three days to teach my secretary normal behavior,'' he said. ``She was sullen, she was running around like mad if I said one word, as if it had been a command.''

DOC.HEAD: Cult Leader, Family Hid Out With Large Arms Cache
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 6 grafs after 8th graf, `They were...,' to UPDATE with report that Avery may have bought own murder weapon. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `Freud said...'
DOC.TEXT: A cult leader facing murder charges in the slayings of an Ohio family hid out in Southern California for a month, carrying an assortment of guns and storing ammunition and paramilitary gear, authorities said Monday. Jeffrey Lundgren, 39, a defrocked lay minister of the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints in Ohio; his wife, Alice, 38, and their son, Damon, 19, were expected to be arraigned Tuesday in Municipal Court on fugitive charges, said San Diego County Deputy District Attorney John Hewicker. Extradition proceedings were expected to follow later. ``They already have said in their first meeting with investigators that they would fight extradition,'' Hewicker said. The Lundgrens were arrested Sunday outside a motel in National City about five miles south of San Diego by U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms agents and police. A cache of weapons, ammunition and paramilitary equipment including gas masks were found in a motel room and a storage locker in nearby Chula Vista. Three other Lundgren children _ Kristen, 10, Caleb, 9, and Jason, 15 _ were taken into protective custody, ATF spokeswoman April Freud said Monday, declining to elaborate on their whereabouts. ATF agents continued the hunt in Southern California for the last two of the 13 suspects in the killings of Dennis Avery, his wife, Cheryl; and their three young daughters. Law enforcement officers looked for Kathryn Renee Johnson, 36, and Daniel David Craft, 25, who probably were with Lundgren last week, Freud said. ``They were believed to have left San Diego Saturday and they are in the Southern California area,'' she said. In Cleveland, meanwhile, The Plain Dealer reported that Avery had purchased three weapons for Lundgren three days before his death. Charles E. Wallace, assistant special agent in charge for Ohio for the U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, said one of the weapons purchased by Avery, a .45-caliber pistol, may have been the murder weapon. Avery visited a Chagrin Falls, Ohio, gun store last April 15 and picked out a rifle and two pistols, Wallace told the Plain Dealer in a story published in Tuesday's editions. The following day, Avery returned to the store with LuFdyren, who signed federal weapons purchase transaction forms, Wallace said. Avery charged the $1,300 cost to his credit card, Wallace said. Wallace said ballistics tests must be conducted to determine whether one of the pistols was the murder weapon. Autopsies showed each of the victims was shot several times with a .45-caliber weapon. One of the weapons seized near San Diego matched a description of one of the pistols purchased by Avery the day before he died, Wallace said. Freud said Lundgren had been in the San Diego area for at least a month before his arrest, but didn't know where he'd been staying or if his family had been with him then. Mrs. Lundgren checked into the motel Wednesday night with the three children, saying she'd been arguing with her husband. Searches of the motel room and the locker uncovered numerous weapons, including two assault rifles, 1,000 rounds of ammunition, an assortment of knives, several gas masks and gas containers, 40 pounds of powder for reloading ammunition and other types of paramilitary equipment and camping gear, Freud said. ``He seems to have packaged up all his weapons and ammunition and taken them with him, along with his personal effects,'' she said. ``It appeared that he kept four firearms with him and kept the other firearms and various types of paramilitary equipment stashed somewhere else. ``We now will be trying to trace the weapons, trying to determine who purchased them and the most recent documentation of who the owners might have been,'' Freud said. She said authorities were still trying to determine why Lundgren was in San Diego since his only tie to the city was Navy service there 15 years ago. Lundgren broke away from the Reorganized Church and persuaded other members to follow him. The group once lived on a 15-acre farm near Kirtland, Ohio, where bodies believed to be those of the Averys were unearthed last week. Investigators believe the Averys were killed in April and buried in a common barn under the barn near the Cleveland-area town the day before Lundgren and his followers fled to a farm near Holden, Mo. Lundgren and 12 followers were indicted in the killings. Authorities were led to the National City motel by telephone calls made from a pay phone to another location under surveillance, said Steven C. LaTourette, a prosecutor in Lake County, Ohio. LaTourette has said that the Averys apparently were killed in a sacrificial ritual that would allow the cult to relocate to the wilderness. But Dale Luffman, president of the northeast Ohio chapter of the Reorganized Church, said the slayings may have resulted from disputes over money, sex or fear the Averys would leave the cult. Lundgren was stripped of his credentials as a lay minister with the church in 1987 after he began preaching radical doctrines. He and others who followed him left the church and eventually settled on the farm near Kirtland. The Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints, based in Independence, Mo., has roots and some beliefs in common with the Salt Lake City-based Mormon Church but is separate.

DOC.HEAD: `Born on the Fourth of July' Nation's No. 1 Movie
DOC.TEXT: The heavyweight Vietnam drama ``Born on the Fourth of July'' was tops at the nation's box offices last weekend, and the lighthearted ``Little Mermaid'' became the strongest first-run animated film ever. ``Back to the Future Part II,'' meanwhile, passed the $100 million mark at the turnstiles not only in the United States but overseas. In Japan, the time-travel sequel with Michael J. Fox is expected to outperform ``Batman'' and ``Ghostbusters II'' combined. According to figures released Monday by Exhbitor Relations Co., ``Born on the Fourth of July'' leaped to No. 1, grossing $11 million in the film's first weekend of wide release. The movie starring Tom Cruise as the paraplegic war veteran Ron Kovic passed ``The War of the Roses'' for the top position. ``The War of the Roses,'' directed by Danny DeVito and featuring Michael Douglas and Kathleen Turner, collected $7 million for second place and has now made more than $53 million in five weeks. The cop thriller ``Tango & Cash,'' with Kurt Russell and Sylvester Stallone, sold $6.6 million worth of tickets to finish third. In fourth place was Steven Spielberg's ``Always,'' starring Richard Dreyfuss and Holly Hunter, with $4.61 million. Next was ``The Little Mermaid,'' with $4.59 million. While the Disney movie has yet to prove itself a longterm moneymaker such as ``Snow White'' and ``Bambi,'' it has now made a record of more than $56.1 million. The previous record for first-run animated movie was last year's ``Oliver & Co.,'' which collected $53.3 million worth of tickets for Disney. In sixth place last weekend was the ensemble drama ``Steel Magnolias'' with $4.5 million. The sequel ``Back to the Future Part II'' was seventh with $3.7 million. ``National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation'' fell almost 60 percent to eighth on $3.3 million. ``Look Who's Talking'' was ninth with $2.6 million and ``Blaze'' was 10th with $2.3 million. In limited release, ``Glory'' had the best per-screen average, $21,297, for a weekend total of $170,376. ``The Music Box'' averaged $18,905 per screen for a total of $56,714. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Monday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations: 1. ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' Universal, $11 million (weekend gross), 1,310 screens, $8,415 per screen, $12.2 million (total gross), three weeks in release. 2. ``The War of the Roses,'' 20th Century Fox, $7 million, 1,525 screens, $4,594 per screen, $53.5 million, five weeks. 3. ``Tango & Cash,'' Warner Bros., $6.6 million, 1,556 screens, $4,257 per screen, $31.1 million, three weeks. 4. ``Always,'' Universal, $4.61 million, 1,124 screens, $4,105 per screen, $20.6 million, three weeks. 5. ``The Little Mermaid,'' Disney, $4.59 million, 1,521 screens, $3,014 per screen, $56.1 million, eight weeks. 6. ``Steel Magnolias,'' Tri-Star, $4.5 million, 1,369 screens, $3,289 per screen, $50.9 million, eight weeks. 7. ``Back to the Future Part II,'' Universal, $3.7 million, 1,760 screens, $2,125 per screen, $100.7 million, seven weeks. 8. ``National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation,'' Warner Bros., $3.3 million, 1,846 screens, $1,802 per screen, $62.5 million, six weeks. 9. ``Look Who's Talking,'' Tri-Star, $2.6 million, 1,445 screens, $1,795 per screen, $118.8 million, 13 weeks. 10. ``Blaze,'' Disney, $2.3 million, 909 screens, $2,485 per screen, $13.3 million, four weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Granddaughter of Brigham Young Dies at 102
DOC.TEXT: Naomi Young Schettler, a granddaughter of early Mormon Church leader Brigham Young, has died at a local nursing home after a brief illness with the flu. She was 102. Mrs. Schettler recently celebrated her 102nd birthday with family and friends at the nursing home, telling them, ``Well, I made it to 102.'' She died Friday. The eldest daughter and last survivor of 15 children born to Joseph Don Carlos and Alice Naomi Dowden Young, she was born Dec. 30, 1887, in Salt Lake City When she was 4, she saw her father, an architect for the Salt Lake Temple, place a statute of the Angel Moroni on top of the church building. Mrs. Schettler taught in all auxiliaries of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. She was a co-founder of the Granddaughters of Brigham Young Association and was one of the original members of the Lindsay Gardens Camp of the Daughters of Utah Pioneers. She ``loved to share a rich story about her heritage. Her real joy was people. She loved people, and she took great pride in her family,'' said Sister Mary Ambrose Naughton, executive director of St. Joseph Villa nursing home where Mrs. Schettler lived. She survived three husbands, the last of whom, Orson Schettler, died in 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Militancy Again Worrisome for Egyptians
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: A flurry of violent incidents involving Moslem militants, including an apparent attempt to assassinate a Cabinet member, is reminding officials that religious extremism remains a powerful force in Egyptian politics. Most worrisome was the Dec. 16 explosion of a truck bomb minutes before Interior Minister Zaki Badr's motorcade passed. While the bomb was crudely done, apparently the work of an amateur, it marked the first time such a weapon was used in Egypt. ``Why this new method?'' asked newspaper editor Ibrahim Nafei, a confidant of President Hosni Mubarak. ``Does this mean the plot was hatched abroad and executed here in this primitive way?'' Even Mubarak, normally a paragon of measured calm, professed concern that the attack bore evidence of the kind of fanatical conspiracy that killed his predecessor, Anwar Sadat, eight years ago. ``It was not an individual operation,'' the president said. Egypt has cause for concern. Experts estimate there are 150,000 Islamic activists in Egypt gathered under the umbrella label of the Islamic Group. At least 10 percent are thought to consider violence acceptable to attain their fundamentalist goals. Generally, they and hundreds of thousands more in the older, more moderate but still outlawed Moslem Brotherhood demand implementation of Sharia, Islam's 1,350-year-old legal and ethical code. The government claims 90 percent of the law already encompasses Sharia and that it's working to change the rest. The Brotherhood was born in Egypt in 1928 and has spread through the Arab world. It turned to violence in the late 1940s in Egypt, assassinating a prime minister, and was punished brutally for it. Each of the next two decades saw spurts of religiously based violence and government suppression. Bloodied by vicious reprisals under President Gamal Abdel Nasser, the Brotherhood disavowed violence in the 1960s. But Sadat, Nasser's successor, began a crackdown shortly before his death and the repression has continued, though the Brotherhood itself largely has been left alone. What is causing concern among many watchers of the fundamentalist scene is the introduction of the booby-trapped truck. A researcher who follows religious activism for a Western embassy said he did not think it was the work of Jihad, or Holy War, which masterminded the October 1981 assassination of Sadat and was implicated in a failed coup attempt that followed. ``I don't think it was Jihad, because Jihad would have done it right. They have some military experience. But this could incite others to follow suit, and it means there's an escalation in the confrontation,'' said the official, who refused to be identified by name or nationality. Militant violence in Egypt normally finds expression in random street disturbances, as it did in the coup attempt that followed Sadat's murder. Several such outbreaks have occurred since early December in the southern town of Assiut, leading to clashes with police that have injured dozens and have led to hundreds of arrests. In the week before the apparent attack on Badr, nearly 500 people were rounded up in Assiut after a fight between police and militants carrying chains, knives and firearms. Ten police officers and 30 militants were wounded, many by gunfire, in the fight that began after police besieged a mosque where the activists had sought refuge. The same type of disturbance occurred Jan. 2, when security police at Assiut dispersed with tear gas 130 worshipers who tried to march from a fundamentalist mosque to protest downtown. Those reactions to Moslem militancy are typical of security forces since Badr, a career police officer, took charge of domestic security in 1986. A Moslem, he ranks among the country's staunchest campaigners against Islamic militants. He often uses emergency laws to detain and re-arrest suspects. The Western researcher said most Moslem militant leaders are in prison. ``But the bitterness is spreading,'' he said. ``Some people have been detained 10 times in the past year.'' Some experts estimate that during certain periods last year, jails held as many as 6,000 militant fundamentalists at a time. That the apparent attempt on Badr's life closely followed the Assiut conflicts aroused skepticism among some people, even non-fundamentalists. ``It's obviously a government ploy,'' said Ahmed Fouad, an apolitical Moslem agricultural engineer. ``The limited extent of damage to the car, and the fact no one was hurt, shows it couldn't have been real. It obviously was done to give Badr justification for more arrests.'' Police arrested a man fleeing the pickup truck as the rear part of it blew up. The relatively small explosion reportedly was caused by gunpower electrically detonated by batteries connected to a key near the ignition. Egypt's attorney general banned news stories about the investigation. But reports published before the blackout named the suspect as Gamal Mohammed Mustafa, 26, a medical student at Assiut University who hails from Fayoum. Like Assiut, Fayoum is a southern Egypt town known for Moslem fundamentalist agitation. Security sources said 17 other students, mostly Mustafa's friends who live in Assiut but who hail from the Fayoum area, were arrested after the assassination attempt. The sources said Mustafa had been arrested previously, in connection with an attack on a mixed-sex party at Assiut University in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Khmer Rouge Rebels Claim Grenade Attack on Cambodian Capital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with government news agency making no mention of attack in Cambodia, saying celebrations took place peacefully. Picks up 3rd pvs, `The guerrillas...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: Khmer Rouge guerrillas said Tuesday they attacked Cambodia's capital with grenades and plastic explosives, killing soldiers and policemen and sending the president and premier fleeing to Vietnam. The reported attack Saturday could not be verified and some previous Khmer Rouge claims have proved exaggerated. If true, the siege would be the most serious in Phnom Penh, which has been largely spared in the 11-year-old war between the guerrillas and the Vietnamese-installed government. The government's SPK news agency, in a report Tuesday monitored in Bangkok, did not mention any attack, saying Sunday's National Day celebrations took place in ``total security.'' Saturday and Monday also were peaceful, it said. The guerrillas earlier said they attacked and set ablaze the second-largest city, Battambang, on Friday and Saturday. A Western diplomat in Thailand confirmed Tuesday that the town was attacked but said ``the effect was more psychological than strategic.'' The Khmer Rouge army radio said resistance forces lobbed five grenades into the city center near the office of the Central Committee of the Communist Party, killing or wounding some Vietnamese and ``lackey puppets.'' ``Vietnamese and puppet leaders fled in panic to save their own skins,'' said the broadcast, monitored in Bangkok. It said the attack took place ``at 0200 on the night of January 6.'' Phnom Penh authorities on Sunday celebrated National Day, the 11th anniversary of the overthrow of Khmer Rouge rule. Vietnam invaded Phnom Pehn on Dec. 25, 1978, and drove out the Khmer Rouge government on Jan. 7, 1979. Another Khmer Rouge army broadcast said the guerrillas, aided by citizens and government officials, attacked the city center and suburbs Saturday with ``32 grenades and TNT plastic explosives, killing or wounding some Vietnamese soldiers and puppets who were drinking near a hotel. ``A number of Vietnamese secret agents and puppet policemen called A3 were also killed by blasts from the grenades and plastic explosives in the suburbs,'' it said. It said Vietnam ``immediately sent (Premier) Hun Sen and (President) Heng Samrin as well as some other leaders to Ho Chi Minh City.'' Ho Chi Minh, Vietnam's major southern city, is about 34 miles east of Cambodia's border province of Svay Rieng. The broadcast said Hun Sen was sent from Ho Chi Minh City to Svay Rieng for his scheduled talks with Australia's deputy foreign secretary, Michael Costello. ``The Vietnamese dared not allow Hun Sen to see Costello in Phnom Penh because of security reasons,'' it said. The official government news agency, SPK, said Monday that Costello held talks with Hun Sen in Svay Rieng Sunday and Monday. It is rare for such talks to be held outside the capital. Costello's visit was part of a tour to promote Australia's proposal for the United Nations to govern Cambodia before a general election. (In Paris, diplomatic sources said Monday that representatives of the U.N. Security Council's five permanent members will meet there Jan. 15-16 to consider ways to bring peace to Cambodia.) The Khmer Rouge broadcast said Phnom Penh authorities imposed tougher martial law measures after ``a number of grenade attacks.'' It said they feared that guerrillas operating in Phnom Penh would step up activities in coordination with forces outside the city. The communist Khmer Rouge has about 30,000 fighters and is the largest of three guerrilla groups in a resistance coalition. The Khmer Rouge killed hundreds of thousands of people when it ruled Cambodia from 1975 until Vietnam invaded in late 1978 and replaced it with the Heng Samrin government. Fears of a possible return to power of the Khmer Rouge have increased as they have made major battlefield advances since Vietnam in September made what it called the withdrawal of its last troops from Cambodia. The Khmer Rouge radio said the guerrillas would keep fighting and attacking the capital until an international authority verified Vietnam withdrawal and a coalition government including the Heng Samrin government and the three guerrilla groups is formed. The Khmr Rouge seized the gem-mining town of Pailin in western Battah"bng province bordering Thailand on Oct. 22. They claimed they hit Battambang town starting at midnight Friday, attacking the 5th Military Region's command there and in Banteay Meanchey and western Pursat province. An airfield was among the targets reported hit in Battambang. Fighting still raged at dawn Saturday, said a guerrilla radio broadcast Sunday. In an interview broadcast over state radio Sunday, Cambodia's defense minister Gen. Tea Banh admitted that guerrillas are advancing in areas near the Thai border, and said his forces are abandoning some places to concentrate defenses in major towns and roads. ``The enemies have been gradually advancing in their attacks against a number of our positions along the border. To be sincere, we have lost some positions,'' he said. ``We cannot stay in every village,'' Tea Banh said. ``We have to abandon some and keep some strategic ones.'' He did not mention fighting in Phnom Penh or in Battambang town.

DOC.HEAD: Author, Illustrator Win Prestigious Children's Awards
DOC.TEXT: Author Lois Lowry won the 1990 John Newbery medal for children's writing and illustrator Ed Young captured the Randolph Caldecott medal at the American Libary Association's mid-winter meeting. Ms. Lowry's ``Number the Stars'' won for the most distinguished contribution to American literature for children published in 1989. Young was selected for his illustrations in ``Lon Po Po: A Red-Riding Hood Story from China.'' The awards, announced Monday, are administered by the Association for Library Service to Children, a division of the American Library Association.

DOC.HEAD: Children's Group Sees Progress Fighting Infant Mortality
DOC.TEXT: Thirty of the 50 states are improving their infant mortality rates enough to meet a federal goal of reducing nationwide deaths this year to nine per 1,000 live births, according to a study by the Children's Defense Fund. The Washington-based organization, which lobbies on children's issues, also said only five states have made sufficient progress to meet the goal of the U.S. surgeon general of reducing the proportion of low birthweight babies to 5 percent. Babies born with low birthweight are 20 times more likely than other infants to die in infancy and face greater risk of lifelong disabilities, the report said. The report said 10 babies died for every 1,000 live births in the United States in 1988. That placed the United States 19th among nations, behind Singapore, Hong Kong, Spain and Ireland, it said. The fund ranked the 50 states and the District of Columbia on their improvement in 10 areas of caring for children and the adequacy of the states' investments in programs benefiting children. Six received grades of 50 percent or more _ Vermont 65, Maine 60, Massachusetts and Minnesota 55, and Connecticut and Delaware 50. New Mexico received the lowest grade, credited with 10 points of a possible 100. Other scores included California and South Carolina 45 percent; Illinois, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Washington and Wisconsin 40 percent; Alabama, Alaska, Iowa, Michigan, North Dakota and Virginia 35 percent. Others were Arkansas, Florida, Hawaii, Maryland, Nevada, Ohio, Tennessee and West Virginia 30 percent; the District of Columbia, Indiana, Kentucky, Louisiana, Montana, Nebraska, North Carolina, Oklahoma, Oregon, Texas, Utah and Wyoming 25 percent. Arizona, Georgia, Mississippi and Missouri received 20 percent and Colorado, Idaho, Kansas and South Dakota 15 percent. The ratings measured progress in prenatal care, reducing the proportion of infants born with low birthweights, child poverty, births to unmarried women, teen birth rates, establishment of paternity, child poverty, housing affordability, high school graduation and youth employment. Only Alabama, New Hampshire and Vermont demonstrated adequate progress on six of the 10 measures, the fund said. Arizona and Maryland each showed no progress, deterioration or inadequate progress in nine of the 10 areas, it said. The report credited New Mexico with the largest percentage reduction in infant mortality between 1978 and 1988, a drop of 42.6 percent from 14.1 to 8.1 per 1,000 live births. Rhode Island was second with a 38.2 percent reduction, from 13.6 to 8.4. States not making enough progress to meet the goal set by the surgeon general were Alabama, Alaska, Colorado, Delaware, the District of Columbia, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Illinois, Indiana, Louisiana, Maryland, Michigan, Mississippi, Montana, New York, North Carolina, Oregon, Pennsylvania, South Carolina and Tennessee. The five states keeping up with the goal for reducing low birthweight were Alaska, Minnesota, New Hampshire, North Carolina and Utah. The study also rated the adequacy of state spending on Medicaid coverage for pregnant women and babies, Medicaid coverage for children, nutrition supplements, early education supplements, child care quality, child support enforcement, improvement in benefits under the aid to families with dependent children program, adequacy of such benefits compared with housing costs, improving student-teacher ratios and youth employment initiatives. It said five states _ Iowa, Maine, Massachusetts, Minnesota and Vermont _ made sufficient investments in seven of those 10 areas. It said Idaho, New Mexico and South Dakota had not invested sufficiently in any. The report called on President Bush to take several steps to improve the lot of children in the United States. It said the president should support child care legislation, extend Medicaid coverage to pregnant women and families below 200 percent of the federal poverty level, expand food supplements for all eligible pregnant women, infants and children by 1994, immunize all children against preventable childhood diseases and reauthorize Head Start with enough to serve all eligible children with quality programs by 1994. It estimated the cost of these steps at $3.85 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Experts See Little Impact on Drug Trafficking From Noriega Arrest
DOC.TEXT: The fall of Manuel Antonio Noriega will have little impact on drug trafficking and money laundering, say experts who contend drug lords changed operations three years ago when the United States reversed its support of the Panamanian dictator. ``In terms of any impact on the flow of drugs or money through the banking system, the impact of Noriega's arrest will be nil,'' said Rensselaer Lee III, a consultant and lecturer who specializes in Latin American drug trafficking issues. ``I'm talking about the total flow of drugs, the total flow of money.'' Scott B. MacDonald, an international economist who has written two books on the drug trade, refers to the trafficking as the mythical ``Hydra,'' a many-headed monster reptile: ``Cut off one head and another head grows in another place.'' Drug traffickers have looked elsewhere since Panama's usefulness as a money-laundering center was dimmed in 1987, and the Central American nation was never a major transit point for drugs anyway, the experts say. ``They pretty much gutted the banking system in terms of total asset size,'' MacDonald said, referring to the impact of the U.S. campaign against Noriega's regime. ``The assets drained out of the country. Legitimate business wanted to get out of Panama, and the people who stayed in Panama doing business came under greater scrutiny.'' With Noriega gone, what little money-laundering activity is left can be expected to move to the places others went before, he said, citing Anguilla in the Caribbean; Montserrat, a British crown Caribbean colony; and Paraguay and Uruguay as new money-laundering centers. The routes for shipping drugs also have changed, he said. Drugs now go ``through Bolivia, Argentina, Paraguay, Uruguay and Europe,'' he said. ``Some of it still goes to North America, but Europe is increasingly considered an open market. The perception is that North America is becoming a saturated market.'' Drug traffickers, who also move their product through Brazil and Guatemala, are looking forward to changes in the European community in 1992, when the borders will open, making their work easier on that continent, he said. But this was all happening before the Jan. 3 arrest of Noriega, touted by the Bush administration as a blow against drug trafficking. The downfall of Noriega _ who was indicted by federal grand juries in February 1988 _ ``inconveniences the Colombians no doubt some, but nothing that's going to make any noticeable difference to America's drug problems,'' said Peter Reuter of The Rand Corp. ``No one ever said that Panama was the exclusive, or even the dominant laundry,'' Reuter said. ``Laundries are available in a lot of places.'' The Drug Enforcement Administration is pleased Panama may become an ally rather than an enemy in the drug war, but doesn't expect the drug trade to collapse or even show signs of distress because of Noriega's arrest. ``No single event, no matter how significant it is, will result in the immediate impact on availability of drugs in the United States,'' said Frank Shults of the DEA. ``At this point, we are not in a position to speculate on the long-term possibilities. ``There are numerous financial centers throughout the world,'' Shults said. ``Drug traffickers are very flexible in their ability to move their money. They will no doubt exploit whatever markets they are able to.'' Panama was a transit point for the drugs themselves, but ``not by any means a substantial amount,'' he said. However, he said, ``this was a major sanctuary for the traffickers to use, and a haven for money laundering. They are out looking for other markets.'' MacDonald said Noriega's ouster and arrest has had one important impact: ``With Noriega gone, the one man in Panama who would very much allow the narco trafficantes safe haven is gone. I think that is crucial. It means that the Medellin (cocaine cartel) people cannot suddenly disappear into Panama and not have to worry about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Don Henley and Glenn Frey have settled a decade-old feud and will reunite the Eagles, the popular band that epitomized California rock music in the 1970s, according to a trade publication. The singer-songwriters will regroup this spring to record an album, the Hollywood Reporter said Monday. The album likely would be followed with a concert tour, the newspaper said. It wasn't clear if other former Eagles members would reunite with Henley and Frey. Joe Walsh, Don Felder and Timothy B. Schmit were in the band when the Eagles broke up in 1981. Henley, 42, was touring in Japan on Monday in support of his Geffen Records ``The End of Innocence'' album. Frey, 41, records for MCA Records. The nature of the feud wasn't disclosed. Telephone calls placed Monday to Irving Azoff and Larry Solters, the Eagles' old management team, weren't returned. The Eagles won three Grammy Awards, including best record in 1977 for ``Hotel California.'' They won the group pop vocal Grammy in 1975 for ``Lyin' Eyes'' and the group rock vocal Grammy in 1979 for ``Heartache Tonight.''

The Rev. Jeb Stuart Magruder, a former aide to President Nixon who spent seven years in prison for the Watergate scandal, said his life bottomed out when he started treating Nixon like God. Magruder, executive minister of the First Community Church of Columbus, Ohio, was a special assistant to Nixon and deputy campaign director for the Committee for the Reelection of the President in 1972. He helped cover up the Watergate scandal. ``After I left Washington, my life was a shambles. My marriage fell apart. There was so much pain,'' Magruder, 54, told 100 worshipers Monday at Westminster College. Watergate came about because ``we started to treat Nixon not as president but as God,'' he said. Magruder said it's possible to come back after a crisis, but it's not easy. ``I am reminded of one of the shortest speeches Winston Churchill ever gave,'' he said. ``When Churchill was asked how England would survive the German threat, he told them in six words, `Never, never, never, never give up.' That is a philosophy I live by and it works.''

Dixie Carter of CBS-TV's ``Designing Women'' says working on a prime-time series is a ``piece of cake'' compared to the years she spent on the popular daytime soap ``Edge of Night.'' ``Soap acting is the toughest acting there is,'' said the actress in the this week's TV Guide magazine. ``It's positively Herculean, that is when it's not totally terrifying.'' Ms. Carter, who will be co-host at next week's Soap Opera Awards, made her TV debut in 1974 as Assistant District Attorney Brandy Henderson on the soap when it was recorded live. ``I was always fretting about something. What if the door gets stuck? What if my tears are too facile? What if I can't remember my speech in front of the jury?'' ``In comparison, a sitcom is a piece of cake,'' she said.

Singer-songwriter Prince will be honored during the American Music Awards presentations this month with a special Award of Achievement for his contributions to music. A tribute to Prince will occur during the Jan. 22 ABC-TV awards show from the Shrine Auditorium. Prince, 30, is the second Award of Achievement recipient. Michael Jackson got it last year. An inscription on Prince's trophy said the musician ``through his writing and performing, his recordings and motion pictures and his discovery and support of new musical stars, has been a major influence on the look and sounds of the 1980s.'' Prince is perhaps best known for his ``Purple Rain'' album and motion picture, as well as music for the film ``Batman.''

Comedian-activist Dick Gregory and two other people declined to post bail and were being held in jail after being arrested at an anti-drug paraphernalia demonstration at a convenience store, police said. The protest was their second Monday at the Smoke Connection, where pipes for cocaine and marijuana and other items are sold. In the first protest, Gregory was among seven people arrested and released after received citations for trespassing. Late Monday, police said Gregory, 57; the Rev. George Clements, 57, of Chicago; and Robert Brown, 54, of Milwaukee returned to the store to continue the protest. They were being held after declining to pay bail, authorities said. The three were expected to appear in Municipal Court today. The sale of drug paraphernalia currently is legal in Wisconsin although lawmakers have passed a measure that could outlaw such sales. The bill awaits the signature of Gov. Tommy G. Thompson. In the first demonstration, protesters included Clements and the Rev. Michael Pfleger, two Chicago priests who oppose the sale of drug paraphernalia and have participated in similar demonstrations.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers See Panama Aid Limited by Budget Problems
DOC.TEXT: Panama may be looking for far more money to rebuild its crippled economy than the United States can afford, according to lawmakers who visited the Central American country. Panamanian Vice President Ricardo Arias Calderon suggested an initial one-year aid contribution of $1.5 billion to help repair damage caused by the Dec. 20 American invasion, a House member said Monday. ``Obviously, we can and should help ease the immediate suffering caused by the invasion,'' said Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass., who called destruction in poor neighborhoods of Panama City ``terrible.'' ``We should provide medical supplies, shelter, food and other basic human needs,'' Studds said. ``But beyond that, our abilities are limited, and we should say so.'' Arias Calderon's $1.5 billion estimate would be 10 percent of the total U.S. budget for aiding dozens of nations, and it's unlikely the United States can come up with such an amount in direct cash assistance. Several Democratic lawmakers who took a two-day trip to Panama last week said they are not inclined to cut domestic programs to send aid, and sought to pressure President Bush to justify the new spending and find the money. ``In the days ahead, the president, whose invasion this was, will have a responsibility to explain to the American people how much aid is necessary, what it will accomplish, and how it will be paid for,'' Studds said in a statement. ``These are important questions because I, for one, am not about to take money away from American schools or housing or medical research to send to Panama.'' Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., said it was more likely that U.S. aid will be in the hundreds of millions of dollars, spread over several years, and that some aid will come in the form debt forgiveness and loan guarantees rather than cash aid. Some aid may also have to come from other countries, he said. A 30-member House delegation met with Panamanian government and business leaders Thursday and Friday to assess how much aid is needed to restore what had been one of the region's healthiest economies, crippled by economic sanctions in the effort to force dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega from power. ``The invasion and the current occupation by American troops have turned a Panamanian problem, the burden of having a corrupt and cruel ruler, into an American problem,'' said Rep. Don Edwards, D-Calif., a member of the visiting group. No formal aid proposal has been made, and Deputy Treasury Secretary John E. Robson insisted Monday that no dollar amounts were discussed when a high-level executive branch delegation met with the same leaders last week in Panama City. But Edwards said Arias Calderon suggested the $1.5 billion figure as a ``first installment'' in a long-term rebuilding package. He acknowledged that Panamanians support the U.S. action, but added: ``It is entirely possible ... that some of this good will will dissipate when the Panamanians find out that Uncle Sam will not provide all the billions it will take to repair the damage, rebuild the hundreds of destroyed houses and bring the economy to a high level.'' Robson said a joint Treasury-State Department task force was working on proposals for aiding Panama but declined to discuss specific steps that might be taken. He said Panamanians realize their first priority must be to restore investor confidence. He hinted that the administration will rely heavily on private-sector efforts to rebuild the Panamanian economy, suggesting U.S. aid would be used to leverage private investment. ``The underpinning of the Panamanian economic recovery plan rests on the private sector,'' Robson said at a news conference. He added the United States may look in part to ``other governments that have an interest in Panama'' for direct aid.

DOC.HEAD: Congressmen Travel Far to Find `Problems in Paradise'
DOC.TEXT: A congressional committee's eight-day trip to Hawaii comes in the dead of winter, but the congresswoman who arranged the excursion denies it's another political junket to a warm, tropical locale. ``We do have problems in paradise,'' Rep. Patricia Saiki, D-Hawaii, said after the first hearing in Hawaii on Monday by the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries. The memorandum from the chairman of the committee says the purpose of the trip is to examine national ocean and coastal policy. One day's itinerary, however, details a different type of January excursion. ``9:30 a.m. Depart hotel for Sand Point Container Yard to tour Matson Navigation Facilities _ approximately two hours. ``11:30 a.m. Return to hotel. Afternoon free. ``5:30 p.m. Depart hotel for cocktails and dinner John Dominis Restaurant. Dress: Aloha Casual.'' Saiki, who persuaded the committee chairman and a handful of her panel colleagues to make the trip, bristles at a suggestion that it's a respite for members of Congress while the rest of the nation shivers through the winter. ``Personally I'm tired and distressed by describing this visit as a junket. I think it's a bum rap,'' Saiki said in a telephone interview from her Hawaii office. The congresswoman said the panel is looking at ``these really heavy duty issues that affect the economy and environment'' in Hawaii, including fishing rights, ocean mining and the territorial seas. ``The agenda is a very full one and the committee members are working. They're getting an earful from my people of Hawaii and how the decision-making affects us.'' Saiki said the temperate Pacific setting for the hearings should not dissuade observers that they are significant. Saiki and three lawmakers from the 43-member committee, two spouses and two other House members are on the fact-finding mission that began Friday with departure from Andrews Air Force Base near Washington aboard a naval DC-9 military aircraft. Rep. Walter B. Jones, D-N.C., the panel's chairman, said in a Dec. 15 memo that the Defense Department assigned Navy personnel to escort the delegation aboard the military plane to Honolulu. The Pentagon had no immediate comment on the trip Monday. There was no immediate estimate available on the cost of the trip. The itinerary for Jan. 5-13 includes a two-hour tour of Pearl Harbor, a visit to a geophysical monitoring station in Mauna Loa and morning hearings Monday and today on ``U.S. Oceans and Coastal Management Issues in the Pacific.'' The remainder of the proposed itinerary is heavy on free time and evening receptions. On Sunday, the schedule called for Hawaii Gov. John D. Waihee III to toast the lawmakers at a cocktail reception at his mansion. Dress was coat and tie. The next day called for dinner at the Halekulani Hotel, with Matson Navigation as the host and dress described as ``aloha casual.'' Tonight, the lawmakers were to dine Japanese-style at a evening sponsored by the Western Pacific Regional Fishery Management Council. Dress, again, was ``aloha casual.'' According to committee staff, the delegation includes Jones, Saiki and Reps. Thomas J. Manton, D-N.Y., and William O. Lipinski, D-Ill. Manton's wife, Diane, and Lipinski's wife, Rose Marie, also made the trip. Joining the delegation were Rep. Daniel K. Akaka, D-Hawaii, and Rep. Eni F.H. Faleomavaega, D-American Samoa, a non-voting delegate to Congress. Among the topics for the hearings and meetings were reauthorization of the Coastal Zone Management Act, the 200-mile fishing zone and regulation of tuna in that area, mineral resources leasing in a 100-mile zone and the territorial seas of the United States, a staff member said Monday. Scheduled witnesses included Waihee, legislators from American Samoa and Guam and private individuals. After tours Friday morning in Kona, the schedule includes: ``12:30 p.m. Return to hotel. ``Afternoon-Evening free. ``Optional luau at hotel.''

DOC.HEAD: Met Opera Presents Radiant `Cosi'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will stand for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: Simplicity can be spectacular and a long opera can seem short when it's Mozart's wonderful ``Cosi fan tutte,'' performed as radiantly as it was at its first Metropolitan Opera's presentation of this season. ``Cosi'' on Monday night was conducted by James Levine and the orchestral music sang as sweetly as the singers. The main foursome, Carol Vaness and Tatiana Troyanos as sisters and Thomas Hampson and Jerry Hadley as the naval officers they're engaged to, have voices of about equal weight _ medium robust _ and are all attractive looking. All voices blended well. The voices of Miss Vaness and Hadley have rare beauty. Hampson's baritone is attractive and sounds easily produced. Miss Troyanos' mezzo-soprano is confident and she displayed a comic touch, getting laughs where some mezzos don't but maybe going too far in lurching around the stage with a butterfly net. ``Cosi'' isn't heavy with plot. An elderly cynic bets the men that their ladies can be proved inconstant. The men dress like a vision of Ali Baba and, as ``Albanians,'' woo each other's fiancees. Bass Richard Van Allan performed the cynic _ who wins the bet _ as elegant and worldly wise. He sang well but weakened toward the end of the opera. ``Cosi'' is light hearted but Miss Vaness and Hadley each have one serious aria in Act 2. Both sang with affecting emotion. Margaret Price was scheduled to sing Fiordiligi but was ill and replaced by Miss Vaness. Dawn Upshaw was scheduled to sing the maid. Her announced replacement, Hei-Kyung Hong, became ill. Betsy Norden sang the maid, pert and clear-voiced. The simple sets, new in 1982, are inside a frame smaller than the Met Opera stage. Side panels are turned to show trees for park scenes or wallpaper for scenes inside a room. Back panels slide in and out. Furniture is carried in and out by stagehands in peaked caps like elves. The two men ``leave for war'' and return in a small boat of the type in which Washington crossed the Delaware. Lighting by Gil Wechsler is cheerfully bright. Some think ``Cosi,'' with only six characters and very occasional chorus of townspeople, shouldn't be performed in a house as big as the Met. If that idea were followed, the Met audience would be greatly deprived.

DOC.HEAD: Campaign 1990: Polaroids, A Guitar Player And A Burro
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: A Polaroid camera is the weapon of choice for the leftist Sandinista Front on the 1990 campaign trail. Their foes have picked a guitar player and a burro to drive home their political pitch. Just seven weeks before election day and after a Christmas hiatus punctuated by the U.S. invasion of Panama, Nicaragua's political parties are at it again. The candidates are kissing babies, pressing the flesh and slinging mud at each other in a crescendo of politicking that will climax with the Feb. 25 balloting. A billboard showing President Daniel Ortega hugging one of his children has popped up on a Managua street corner. Ortega, running for re-election with Vice President Sergio Ramirez, is now visiting cities for the second time in the campaign. Peasants at rallies fight over who will have their picture taken next to Ortega. A Polaroid camera clicks, the print slides out and the peasant goes home with a portrait of himself standing right next to the smiling president. For its party, the opposition coalition has hired composer Pompilio Amaya, who delights crowds at rallies with his songs, accompanied by his a guitar. Then there's Pancho the Burro, who wears a cap with the coalition's acronym written on it and is paraded before rallies. Publisher Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, the opposition presidential candidate, fell in her home last week and fractured a knee. She is laid up in a Houston hospital for at least another 10 days. But her running mate, Virgilio Godoy of the Liberal Independent Party, is on the campaign trail and became hoarse over the weekend from his many public speeches. Godoy, a lawyer and college professor, is a more polished speaker than Mrs. Chamorro, whose political experience is limited. Ortega has tactfully avoided targeting Mrs. Chamorro's perceived lack of great intellectual capacity. Mrs. Chamorro is the widow of Pedro Joaquin Chamorro, a civic leader whose image is in a constant tug-of-war between the Sandinistas and the 14-party National Opposition Union. Nicaraguans might construe any personal attack on Mrs. Chamorro as an attack on her late husband _ a political taboo. Real issues abound: the dismal state of the economy and how to correct it, the U.S.-backed Contra rebels, the draft, regional guerrilla movements and relations with Washington and Moscow. Neither the Sandinistas nor the opposition has changed the substance of its message over Christmas. The Sandinistas blame the United States for nearly all the country's ills; the opposition blames the Sandinistas. The Sandinistas also claim the opposition is getting U.S. funding. The Americans and the opposition both deny it, though Mrs. Chamorro has visited with U.S. officials. The frenzy of political graffiti that gripped the city a few months back has subsided. Perhaps that is partly because the Supreme Electoral Council, the final arbiter of the election process, has begun urging Nicaraguans to respect each other and partly because there are few walls left to scrawl on. But street artists, ever resourceful, have claimed the ground. Their messages can now be seen on the pavement of highways, driveways and sidewalks. Even utility poles bear civic messages favoring political parties. The U.S. invasion of Panama on Dec. 20 has given the Sandinistas an unforeseen campaign coup: it has allowed them to whip up nationalist sentiment and gather it around the party. It also has given them fuel for further identifying the opposition coalition as a puppet of Washington and the Sandinista Front as the only hope for a sovereign Nicaragua. Yet the Sandinista campaign slogan, ``Everything Will Be Better,'' is falling on increasingly cynical ears. Prices for staples keep increasing; salaries barely keep up. The opposition coalition _ hemmed together from parties ranging from conservatives to communists _ has problems of its own. The parties' only common denominator is that they hate the Sandinistas enough to stick together _ at least until an electoral victor is declared. That raises the question of how harmonious a government the alliance could form. Most polls released over the past few months show Ortega ahead of Mrs. Chamorro, who has the advantage of owning the opposition newspaper La Prensa to help in her campaign. The Sandinistas have Barricada, the Front's official paper; and the pro-government daily El Nuevo Diario. Other poll results show Ortega and Mrs. Chamorro in a neck-to-neck race. A telling item in any of the polls, however, is the percentage of undecideds, who constitute nearly as many people as those those who say they will vote for Ortega or for Mrs. Chamorro.

DOC.HEAD: Judiciary's Failure Contributes to Abuses
With PM-Salvador
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Although many thousands of suspected government opponents have been murdered by military men _ in the ``death squads'' or independent of them _ not a single officer has been convicted of human rights abuses in 10 years of civil war. No military man had been indicted until March 1989, when a major, a 2nd lieutenant and seven soldiers were accused of killing 10 peasants in the hamlet of San Francisco in September 1988. That case since has bogged down. ``The government's near paralysis in the San Francisco killings is merely the latest in a long line of failures to hold members of the armed forces accountable for political violence,'' the New York-based Lawyers Committee for Human Rights said in a report last year. ``In thousands of cases, dating back to the 1980 assassination of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero, the Salvadoran military has refused to assist prosecutions. In many cases senior military officers have blatantly interfered with investigations or prosecutions, preventing them from being carried out,'' the report said. President Alfredo Cristiani, who announced Sunday that military men committed the Nov. 16 massacre of six Jesuit priests and two women, contends the era of impunity is over. He did not specify who was implicated in the crime, their numbers or their ranks, but he announced a blue-ribbon commission would assist the investigation ``to deduce responsibilities and make sure justice is done.'' He promised punishment would be meted out ``down to the last person implicated.'' ``El Salvador's judicial system is dangerously close to collapse,'' said the Laywers Committee. That appraisal is shared by U.S. authorities, including Ambassador William Walker, who says flat out, ``The judiciary does not work.'' The few cases that get prosecuted are those that receive wide publicity, affect U.S. public opinion and cause a stir on Capitol Hill. ``High profile cases are prosecuted for political reasons, rather than reasons of justice,'' said a Western diplomat. ``But that they get prosecuted at all is progress.'' The Jesuit slayings shocked El Salvador and the world and prompted calls in the U.S. Congress for reappraisal of U.S. aid. The virtually bankrupt nation has received $4 billion in economic and military assistance from Washington during the past 10 years. ``There are consequences of human rights violations in the future,'' Vice President Dan Quayle said during a visit to El Salvador in February 1989. ``Democracy means human rights and decency. You cannot have one without the other. Our commitment and our support are conditioned on this process and this system.'' Of the many cases unsuccessfully prosecuted, several stand out. The most glaring could be the case of Romero's assassination on March 24, 1980. After a decade of political manipulation, the case is virtually closed, with no one convicted or punished in connection with it. The previous Christian Democratic administration of President Jose Napoleon Duarte said it knew who planned the killing and who carried it out. It claimed the opposition-controlled legislature impeded prosecution to protect implicated members of the Republican Nationalist Alliance, known as Arena, including party founder Roberto D'Aubuisson. D'Aubuisson and Arena, which won last year's presidential election, deny any involvement in the archbishop's murder. On Jan. 3, 1981, two U.S. land reform advisers and the head of the Salvadoran land reform insitute were murdered in the Sheraton Hotel. Two triggermen, both National Guard corporals, eventually were convicted and sentenced. But the two officers they both named as the instigators of the crime were not convicted. About 50 residents of the town of Armenia were massacred July 30, 1981, by civil guardsmen, according to church and human rights groups. Whether the implicated soldiers should be covered by a 1987 amnesty is still being considered by the courts, and no one has been convicted in the slayings. On Feb. 22, 1983, about 70 Indian peasants of the Las Hojas agricultural cooperative were killed by troops of the 6th military detachment in the western province of Sonsonate. Those implicated, including three officers, were absolved under the 1987 amnesty. From 1984 to 1987, rights abuses steadily decreased. Humanitarian organizations were alarmed when they rose in 1988. The situation continued to degenerate in 1989. The trend established in the first six months of 1989 indicated the number of politically motivated murders easily would surpass those in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: The bodyslamming behemoths of professional wrestling are entertainers and not athletes, according to the Legislature. The state Assembly voted 44-4 Monday to approve a bill that would reduce the regulation on those growling, scowling giants by removing professional wrestling from the jurisdiction of the state Athletic Commission. The bill, passed by the state Senate in February, awaits action by Gov. Thomas H. Kean. Supporters including the World Wrestling Federation say the measure will reduce the overhead of promoting a wrestling exhibition in New Jersey, and therefore make it easier for fans to see warriors such as Hulk Hogan and Rowdy Roddy Piper in person. But wrestlers paid a price for the victory by admitting the contests are less than spontaneous. The World Wrestling Federation, which asked for the bill, first admitted that professional wrestling was more entertainment than sport in a Trenton legislative hearing in early 1989. The federation described wrestling as ``an activity in which participants struggle hand-in-hand primarily for the purpose of providing entertainment for spectators rather than conducting a bonafide athletic contest.'' The statement was blasted by several New Jersey professional wrestlers who insisted that theirs is not a cream puff job. But the federation's position won out, partly because it wants easier access to the lucrative New Jersey market, which includes the Atlantic City casinos.

Forget those beatnik bongos and cable car bells, says a band that insists the sound of an accordion best distills the essence of San Francisco. Musicians with Those Darn Accordions! revival band serenaded Mayor Art Agnos outside City Hall on Monday as the city weighed a proposal to proclaim the humble, pleated bellows the city's official musical instrument. ``There should be an official city instrument because we have official city songs and we need an instrument to play them on.
