It should be the accordion because of its rich history here and because it was invented here,'' said Tom Torriglia, a band member leading the effort. Besides, said Torriglia of the instrument, ``It's a good way to meet girls.''

DOC.HEAD: Baker to Hold Arms Talks in Moscow Next Month
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III will hold talks in Moscow next month to try to clear the way for a new treaty with the Soviet Union sharply reducing long-range nuclear missiles, Bush administration officials disclosed. Baker also is considering a visit to Prague after the Feb. 6-7 meeting to demonstrate U.S. support for the peaceful transition in Czechoslovakia from a hard-line Communist government to a more moderate regime, the officials told The Associated Press on Monday. He may stop in other East and Central European countries as well, said the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The trip to Moscow is one of three sessions Baker intends to hold with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze before a June U.S.-Soviet summit meeting in Washington. The projected centerpiece of the summit is a treaty to slash U.S. and Soviet arsenals of long-range bombers, submarines and missiles by 30 percent to 50 percent. The most complex of the three obstacles Baker will try to overcome with Shevardnadze concerns how long-range air-launched cruise missiles carried by bombers should be counted against a treaty limit of 6,000 strategic warheads. The two other issues are the kind of data from missile tests that could be disguised and where surplus, or non-deployed missiles, would be stored. Even settling those three issues would not wrap up the new Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty that President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev would like to sign at the Washington summit. For instance, the two sides are in sharp disagreement at the negotiating table in Geneva over sea-launched cruise missiles. Bush, at the Malta summit last month, resisted Gorbachev's efforts to curb the elusive weapon, which is carried on submarines and surface vessels. The Soviets still are trying to slow down or trim the U.S. Strategic Defense Initiative, which would place nuclear weapons into space as part of a defense against a ballistic missile attack. However, the Soviets may be willing to set aside those two disputes, which would mean that resolving the three other problems would be a major step toward completing the pact. A stop in Prague would be scheduled by Baker after his talks in Moscow and before his arrival Feb. 13 in Ottawa for an East-West conference on Bush's ``open skies'' proposal, the officials said. The 16 NATO countries and the seven members of the Warsaw Pact meet in the Canadian capital to discuss allowing unarmed aircraft to fly over their territory in search of suspected military activity. Baker visited East Germany last month, demonstrating support for the reformist Communist government. He also went to Poland and Hungary with Bush in July. Czechoslovakia's shift to a more moderate system has occurred without the strife evident in Romania, East Germany and Bulgaria. Baker may be prepared to offer U.S. aid if it is requested. State Department spokeswoman Margaret D. Tutwiler, asked about Baker's travel plans, said only that he would be going to the Soviet Union ``later this year.''

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Not Rejecting Capital Gains Tax Cut Out of Hand
DOC.TEXT: Democratic leaders in Congress aren't rushing to embrace President Bush's renewed bid for a cut in capital gains taxes, but neither are they rejecting it out of hand. ``We'll have to see what the specific proposals are,'' said a spokesman for Senate Majority Leader George J. Mitchell, D-Maine, who led last year's successful fight against a reduction. Mitchell, his spokesman said, has not ruled out supporting a cut. Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, ``pledged late last year to consider a capital gains cut as part of a package of saving and investment incentives,'' Bentsen spokesman Jack DeVore said Monday. Bush, who campaigned for president in 1988 on a pledge to reduce taxes on capital gains, renewed the battle in a speech Monday to the American Farm Bureau in Orlando, Fla. A reduction, he said, would boost investment and create jobs. ``For us to reap the full benefits of a competitive economy, we must cut the capital-gains tax rate,'' Bush told a cheering audience. ``Passage of our capital-gains proposal, which would apply to the sale of farmland, will be one of my top priorities in this legislative year.'' Bush listed enactment of clean-air and anti-crime legislation among his priorities. ``It is past time for Congress to tend to some of the unfinished business,'' Bush said. With the backing of one of every four Democrats and an almost solid bloc of Republicans, the House last year approved a Bush-supported cut in taxes on capital gains, profits from the sale of investments. The proposal died in the Senate when Republicans fell nine votes short of the 60 needed to cut off a Democratic filibuster against it. Democratic leaders in the House and Senate opposed the cut on three counts. They cited estimates that 80 percent of the benefit would go to those with incomes over $100,000 a year; they said the reduction would strike a major blow against the landmark 1986 tax overhaul that ended preferential treatment of capital gains; and they rejected Bush's contention that a reduction would generate so much investment that government revenues would actually increase. In his brief remarks on the issue Monday, Bush mentioned neither the revenue implications nor the 1986 tax law. But on the third point, he said: ``I am sick and tired of the demagogues who call this a tax cut for the rich. It means jobs, it means savings and it is good for all Americans.'' A Mitchell spokesman noted that the majority leader supported a lower capital gains tax when Congress was debating the 1986 overhaul. Mitchell ``has said he will continue to support one if it meets three criteria: If it doesn't adversely affect the budget deficit, if it is targeted and if it is part of a fair and progressive tax structure,'' the spokesman said. That third condition could mean that Bush and Mitchell will continue to be at odds over capital gains. Mitchell's definition of a ``fair and progressive tax structure'' has been one that would mean a higher income tax rate for high-income Americans _ the kind of tax increase that the administration has vowed to oppose. Bush is expected to provide details of his capital gains proposal in the budget that he will send to Congress on Jan. 29. Some key Republicans are expecting the new plan to provide a greater tax benefit for longer-held assets, rather than to give the same incentive to all property. Present law fully taxes capital gains at the same rates that apply to wages and other income. In his budget last year, Bush recommended that 45 percent of capital gains from selected assets _ specifically excluding farmland and timber, for example _ be excluded from tax. The House voted instead for a plan that, for 2\ years, would have excluded from tax 30 percent of the gain on a broader list of assets, including farmland and timber. After that time, only the gain caused solely by inflation would have been taxed. Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, tried to block approval of the cut last year. Spokesman Jim Jaffe said Monday that Rostenkowski is wary of any new proposed reduction, but expects it would take a unified Democratic effort to defeat it.

DOC.HEAD: Engineer Solves Toilet Stench Mystery for Forest Service
With PM-Diaper Ban, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Briar Cook is savoring the sweet smell of success. The U.S. Forest Service engineer has solved the longstanding problem of getting the stench out of the stalls at wilderness restrooms. Delighted administrators in Washington, D.C., have formally declared 1990 ``The Year of the Sweet-Smelling Toilet,'' and plan to retrofit all 12,000 toilets in use on Forest Service land nationwide. Another 300 new latrines built annually will incorporate Cook's breakthrough findings, which followed years of research at a Forest Service lab northeast of Los Angeles. ``The public today expects a higher level of service and more amenities, and part of that is a good-smelling toilet,'' said Richard Woodrow, the Forest Service's acting director of recreation. ``Well, we're going to give it to them.'' Within three years, officials say, Americans won't find a single smelly latrine in any of their 134 national forests. Costs are estimated at up to $1,500 each for the retrofitted toilets. Cook's other research projects at the San Dimas Technology and Development Center have included ways to bear-proof garbage cans, but he says he considers toilets his best work. ``Our society is funny about toilets _ no one wants to talk about them,'' he said. ``But the odor problem affects a lot of people. As an engineer, I view it as a challenge.'' Cook found that the basic design of national forest toilets prevented adequate ventilation. He also determined that vent stacks were being clogged by undiscovered spider webs. Through tests in a wind tunnel, Cook showed that a wider vent stack stretching much higher above the roof line greatly improves the expulsion of odors. Solar-powered fans also help pull the fetid air from the chamber, he found. As for why no one else noticed the contributing spider web problem, Cook said: ``Nobody likes these little cabanas, so why would they go crawling around inside them? It's in and out, as fast as possible. Nobody ever bothered to look in that stack.'' The problem of ridding forestland toilets of their odor had stumped many before Cook. Gripes about smelly toilets have been common since the first national forest outhouse was installed in the early 1900s, Woodrow said. For decades, restroom odor has been the No. 1 complaint received by rangers from California to New Hampshire, he said, leading to a common conclusion. ``We figured that toilets stink, period. Take it or leave it,'' Woodrow said. But the tenacious Cook proved them wrong. He said he hopes ultimately to share his design with the National Park Service, the Army Corps of Engineers and other public lands managers, all plagued with pungent potties. ``It's a universal problem,'' Cook said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 37,951.46, down 343.50 points, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Parade Float `Head' of Elvis Angers Graceland Managers
LaserPhoto MX1
DOC.TEXT: Two disc jockeys brought a 15-foot replica of Elvis Presley's head to Graceland, the dead singer's former residence, on the day he would have turned 55. Graceland managers were not pleased. The head, which had been part of a float in the Tournament of Roses Parade, briefly joined fans gathered outside the white-columned residence Monday. Presley died of heart disease at the mansion on Aug. 16, 1977. About 1,500 people representing 40 Presley fan clubs from around the world came to Memphis to mark the birthday, said Patsy Andersen, fan club liaison for the Graceland Division of Elvis Presley Enterprises. Some fans cut a cake and sang happy birthday. The disc jockeys who brought the replica head, Brian Phelps and Marc Thompson of station KLOS in Los Angeles, were permanently banned from Graceland last year for using hidden microphones to broadcast from inside the residence, Graceland spokesman Todd Morgan said. Carey Curelop, program manager for the radio station, said the disc jockeys brought the head to Memphis as a ``peace offering.'' But Graceland managers told the announcers to take the head and move on. Morgan said the parade float had been ``a beautiful tribute'' to Presley. ``They've taken that and changed it and turned it into something distasteful. It's really sad,'' Morgan said. The disc jockeys took the flatbed truck carrying the head to a nearby parking lot and broadcast for about an hour, Curelop said from Los Angeles. The head was part of a float sent to the Rose Parade by the state of Mississippi. It was taken to Jackson, Miss., after the stop in Memphis, Curelop said. Presley was born in Tupelo, Miss.

DOC.HEAD: Commercial Banks Seeing More Bad Loans
DOC.TEXT: Commercial banks already reeling from soft real estate markets in the Northeast and other regions are beginning to suffer from a increase in sour consumer loans, a regulator says. ``We are concerned about a significant rise in non-performing consumer loans at banks around the country,'' said Comptroller of the Currency Robert L. Clarke, the chief regulator of nationally chartered banks. Clarke, in a speech to the Institute of International Bankers on Monday, said his agency had not determined whether the problem is confined to one region or if it is a risk to the entire banking system. However, statistics compiled by a banking trade group show consumer loan problems concentrated in New York and several New England states, the same areas where lackluster real estate markets are causing banks loan problems. ``We are analyzing the data and trying to determine precisely what this implies for the overall condition of the national banking system,'' Clarke said. He delivered his speech in New York City. A copy was released in Washington. On other topics, Clarke predicted the trend toward bank consolidation would continue. He said about 11,000 banks would exist at the end of 1992, compared with 12,600 now and 14,400 in 1980. He also said more banks would be owned by foreigners in coming years. The American Bankers Association, a trade group representing commercial banks, reported last month that the number of consumers 30 days or more behind on their loans soared to a 10-year high in the July-September quarter. Nationally, 2.88 percent of the loans surveyed at 800 banks were delinquent on Sept. 30, compared with 2.3 percent three months earlier. The delinquency rate was greater than 4 percent in four states: Connecticut, 6.05 percent; Vermont, 5.35 percent; Massachusetts, 4.8 percent; and New York, 4.44 percent. The economies of some Northeastern states have been in the doldrums, in part because the 1987 stock market crash depressed employment in the financial service industry, including brokerage firms, banks and insurance companies. At the same time that consumer lending is becoming more chancy, Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. statistics show that banks are becoming more involved in it. Loans to individuals grew by 5.2 percent from the third quarter of 1988 to the same period of 1989, according to the FDIC. That's slightly higher than the 4.2 percent growth rate for all banks' assets, but far below the 13.1 percent growth for real estate loans. Loans to individuals represented 12 percent of banks' $3.2 trillion in assets at the end of the third quarter. Consumer loans made up 5.9 percent of all bad assets. Economist Paul Getman of the Wefa Group, a Bala Cynwyd, Pa., consulting company, said banks face a growing problem with what he called ``property'' risk. Because home prices have been falling in some regions, more consumers are discovering that the outstanding balance on home equity loans exceeds the equity in their house. The same is true of auto loans when consumers find after several years that they owe more money than their car is worth. ``Once consumers figure this out, they just hand the keys over to the bank, whether it's a car, a mobile home ... or a house,'' he said. However, Getman said the souring of consumer loan portfolios, while a matter of concern, is not nearly as severe as the problem posed by bad real estate loans. ``Unless you have an outright recession and the unemployment rate shoots up, I don't think consumer loans will become a major problem,'' he said. On credit cards, ``banks (charge such high interest rates) that they can easily see delinquency rates double and still make money.''

DOC.HEAD: US to be Asked for $10 Billion for Third World, Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Governments of major industrial countries are moving toward agreement to send at least $25 billion _ including about $10 billion from the United States _ to help Third World and East European countries. But agreement in the International Monetary Fund may be harder to duplicate in Congress, where deficit-conscious lawmakers would have a hard time diverting money from domestic programs that have been taking cuts for years. ``There'll be trouble getting Congress to approve,'' a congressional aide who follows the issue closely said Monday. ``A lot of congressmen will resist giving all that money to foreigners while their own favorite programs are being cut at home. Some of them don't make the distinction that the money is only being lent out and we get interest back on it.'' The aide, who spoke on condition of anonymity, recalled the last U.S. contribution of $8.5 billion to the fund was approved by a narrow margin in 1983. But the widespread feeling that Eastern Europe must be helped will carry much weight with in Congress, he said. The IMF works out agreements with borrowing countries on new policy programs. They usually include a large dose of austerity for the people in the borrowing nation. When agreements are reached the fund lends heavily to support them. Its most recent accord, due for final approval this month, will provide Poland's new non-Communist leadership with $710 million this year. Poland, in turn, has moved toward a market economy, ending price controls and promising to sell or shut down government industries that are running heavy losses. Lower-level officials in Washington are trying to set the exact figure of the total contribution this week and resolve the question of Japan's share. If they fail, Canadian Finance Minister Michael W. Wilson is expected to call together Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and other leaders to make the decision at the end of this month. The fund now has resources worth about $117 billion but much of it is in the form of unconvertible Third World currencies that borrowers do not need.

DOC.HEAD: Senator's Attempted PR Offensive Fizzles Quickly
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Donald Riegle, one of five lawmakers embroiled in the Lincoln Savings and Loan controversy, won't be able to use a television interview in his campaign to limit political damage from the issue. Riegle, D-Mich., and Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., were both planning media campaigns to combat the fallout from their involvement with Charles H. Keating Jr., head of the failed thrift. Riegle, D-Mich., planned to use a 30-minute news interview program, in which he discussed his involvement in the affair, as part of the media campaign, hoping to broadcast the entire program on cable television. But WXYZ-TV in Detroit, on which the program was broadcast Dec. 10, said Monday it would not give permission to Riegle to use the program. Karolyn Wallace, a spokeswoman for Riegle, said the senator's broadcast plans on cable were being canceled because of the station's response. Riegle, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, DeConcini and the other senators are facing ethics investigations in connection with their dealings with the failing thrift amid allegations they intervened with regulators on behalf of the bank's president. DeConcini is shelling out $190,000 for newspaper advertisements and television commercials in his state to tell his version of the affair. ``I have decided to take my case directly to the people of Arizona,'' DeConcini said last Friday. ``I do this not as a criticism of the press, but because I do not believe that the facts have been adequately heard and understood.'' The other three senators are defending themselves in a variety of forums but have yet to pay for newspaper or broadcast access to voters, according to spokesmen. The center of Riegle's counterattack was to have been the 30-minute television interview last Dec. 10 on which the senator responded to questions about his involvement with Keating. The program was ``a fair presentation ... a tough and frank discussion'' of the issue said Ms. Wallace. But WXYZ-TV News Director Bob Rowe said Monday his station would not give permission for a rebroadcast of the program, saying if permission were given the program ``becomes a political tool and we have to be unbiased.'' On the program Riegle was questioned by two reporters and a moderator. Riegle had planned to pay for the rebroadcast out of campaign funds, Ms. Wallace said. The other three senators involved in the affair are Sens. John McCain of Arizona, John Glenn of Ohio and Alan Cranston of California. All except McCain are Democrats. At the center of the controversy are two meetings they had on Keating's behalf with federal regulators. The five received a total of more than $1.3 million in campaign contributions from Keating, who headed the Irvine, Calif., thrift, and his associates. The government seized control of Lincoln on April 14, 1989, and the cost to taxpayers is expected to reach a record $2 billion. The senators, dubbed the ``Keating Five'' by critics, deny wrongdoing in their involvement with him and his savings and loan. They have said their actions were normal constituent services and were not influenced by Keating's campaign donations. Riegle, who later returned the money he received from Keating and his associates, began granting interviews on the subject in November to home state reporters, saying he wanted to set the record straight. Glenn has held lengthy news conferences and interviews, including meetings with newspaper editorial boards in Ohio, but has no plans to advertise, spokeswoman Rebecca Bell said. Cranston has attended public meetings at which questions were raised about his involvement in the Lincoln case ``and he took them as they came,'' spokeswoman Victoria Lion said. ``He has been very accessible to the press.'' McCain ``has not considered advertising,'' spokesman Scott Celley said. ``He's found no absence of opportunity to tell his side of the story.''

DOC.HEAD: Fuel Shipments Blocked By Government During December Cold Snap
DOC.TEXT: Prices of home heating oil would not have risen as sharply last month if the government had allowed energy companies to use foreign-flagged vessels to carry fuel to the Northeast from other U.S. ports, officials said. Suppliers were unable to shift some cargoes of home heating oil from other parts of the country at the height of the December cold snap because the Customs Service refused to waive a Jones Act ban on the use of foreign vessels between domestic ports. The Customs Service acted on the advice of the Transportation Department's Maritime Administration, which argued that waivers were not justified because U.S. vessels were available to transport the fuel, Walter Oates, a spokesman for the maritime agency, said Monday. ``It's our mandate to promote the U.S.-flagged industry,'' he said. The Energy Department, which intervened in support of the waiver applications, contended that while some U.S. vessels technically were available to carry home heating oil, they could not meet the companies' delivery schedules. The shipments would not have eliminated fuel shortages that hit parts of the Northeast and Midwest during the second half of December, but the extra supplies might have kept prices from rising so high, industry and government officials said. ``It absolutely would have made a difference,'' said Edwin Rothschild, energy policy director of Citizen Action, a national consumer organization. Home heating oil prices soared from about 80 cents a gallon in late November to as much as $1.40 a gallon in some areas by the end of the year _ far beyond the increases consumers usually see when the winter heating season arrives. ``Having the extra supply that was restricted ... would have helped,'' said Phil Chisholm, executive vice president of the Petroleum Marketers Association of America, a trade group of petroleum product suppliers. Chisholm's group was among several industry and consumer groups scheduled to testify today at a House Energy and Commerce subcommittee hearing on the December heating fuel crisis. Some state officials have called for a federal investigation of the oil industry, which they accuse of engineering the price rise. Rep. Philip Sharp, D-Ind., who heads the subcommittee, warned consumers not to expect any immediate price relief from Washington. Indications Monday were that the price may be dropping this month as fast as it rose in December. ``It's extremely unlikely that there would be a reinstatement of major price controls that we had in the past decade,'' Sharp said, adding that Congress lacked the resources to fully explore allegations of price fixing. The oil industry says the main reason for the price increases and localized shortages of home heating oil and propane was the unusual spell of severe cold last month. They also acknowledge that company fuel inventories were significantly lower than usual. The problem has eased in recent days as the weather warmed. In an attempt to relieve a supply squeeze that hit particularly hard in the Northeast, energy companies in December submitted 11 applications to the federal government for permission to use foreign-flagged ships to move fuel between U.S. ports, according to an Energy Department official who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Of the 11 applications, six were withdrawn because the foreign-flagged vessels in question were hired by some other company or were otherwise made unavailable before the government acted on the waiver request, the Energy Department official said. A waiver was granted to Bay State Gas Co. of Canton, Mass., to use a Danish-flagged ship to carry 100,000 barrels of propane. Requests from three other companies to move home heating oil with foreign vessels were turned down, Oates said.

DOC.HEAD: Witnesses Against Noriega May Face Credibility Problems
DOC.TEXT: A convicted drug smuggler who says he was Manuel Antonio Noriega's go-between with the Medellin cartel is a key witness in the cocaine trafficking case against the deposed Panamanian dictator. Floyd Carlton Caceres, who is serving a nine-year prison term for drug smuggling, has testified he arranged for the cartel to pay Noriega $200,000 for each planeload of cocaine protected during flights through Panama. Carlton is one of several convicted drug traffickers likely to testify against Noriega, who is accused of taking $4.6 million bribes and other payoffs to give Colombian drug lords a ``safe haven'' in Panama for cocaine shipments to the United States. Like most convicted criminals who become prosecution witnesses, Carlton's credibility will be sharply tested if he testifies at a trial of Noriega in Miami. But legal experts note testimony from such disreputable witnesses is commonplace in drug trials and prosecutors have been able to persuade jurors to accept it, particularly if supported by other evidence. The credibility of unsavory witnesses is ``not an unsurmountable problem'' especially ``if you have more than one person saying the same thing or describing things that lead to the same conclusion,'' said a former federal prosecutor who spoke on condition of anonymity. Other witnesses expected to testify against Noriega are Jose Blandon, a former Panamanian diplomat and one-time confidant of the general and convicted smugglers Ramon Milian Rodriguez and Steven M. Kalish. Blandon, who broke with Noriega in 1988, told the Senate and a federal grand jury about a dispute between Colombian drug lords and Noriega that was mediated by Cuban leader Fidel Castro. Blandon testified the 1984 meeting took place after Panamanian authorities raided a drug processing plant, arresting 23 Colombians and Lt. Col. Julian Melo, secretary general of Noriega's staff. The raid occurred while Noriega was in Paris. Blandon said the outraged Colombians claimed they had paid Melo $5 million to protect the processing plant. Soon after Noriega met with Castro, the Colombians and Melo were freed and equipment and $3 million seized during the raid were returned to the Colombians, Blandon said. Both Castro and Noriega have denounced Blandon's story as a lie. But his testimony would dovetail with that of Carlton to show that Noriega protected the Medellin cartel's operations in Panama. Blandon has not been accused by federal prosecutors of involvement in drug trafficking and his Miami attorney, Atlee Wampler, dismissed attempts by defense lawyers in public statements to question Blandon's reliability. Blandon attended some key meetings as Noriega's de facto secretary of state, but ``he had absolutely no involvement in any shape with drug trafficking,'' Wampler said. ``He was never involved, that's why defense lawyers want to discredit him.'' Support for the accounts of Carlton and Blandon could also come from further testimony by Kalish and Rodriguez. Both have previously described the protection Noriega gave the drug traffickers, including armored-car transport of money and the use of military airfields. Prosecutors could get even more corroboration if any of the five Noriega co-defendants in custody decides to plead guilty and become a government witness to get a reduced sentence. An attorney for one of those co-defendants, Luis del Cid, indicated Monday his client was considering testifying against his former boss. ``There was a very preliminary exchange of amenities where the possibility of some settlement was discussed,'' defense attorney Samuel Burstyn said of discussions with federal prosecutors in Miami. ``We're desirous of exploring all options, but no offers have been made on either side and there are no deals,'' he said. Del Cid, 46, who surrendered Dec. 25 to U.S. forces, was one of Noriega's liaisons with drug traffickers and also served as a courier, according to the indictment. He is accused of arranging for the transportation of payments to Noriega from the drug cartel. If he became a government witness, del Cid presumably could directly corroborate Carlton about one episode described in the indictment. At Noriega's direction, Carlton delivered $200,000 to del Cid at the headquarters of the Panamanian Defense Forces, the indictment alleges. The payment was to cover the price that Noriega and Carlton agreed they would charge the Colombians to protect the next shipment of cocaine through Panama, the indictment said. Shortly after the payment was delivered to del Cid, Carlton is alleged to have flown 400 kilograms of cocaine to a Panamanian airstrip from the farm of Medellin cartel leader Pablo Escobar Gaviria.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Consumer Complaints, On-Time Arrivals Down in November
With BC-Airline-Statistics
DOC.TEXT: The Transportation Department says consumer complaints from air travelers fell slightly in November, although airline delays increased a bit among the major air carriers. The department said Monday that it received 1,125 complaints in November from air travelers, compared with 1,143 the previous month. During the month, the 12 largest airlines reported that 78 percent of their flights arrived on time, compared with 79.5 percent in October. American Airlines had the best on-time performance in November with its flights arriving within 15 minutes of the scheduled arrival time 85.5 percent of the time. Trans World Airlines had the second best record at 81.8 percent followed by Southwest Airlines at 81.4 percent. USAir had the worst on-time record among the 12 air carriers with 68.4 percent of its flights arriving on time. Mishandled baggage complaints were virtually unchanged from October to November with 6.99 complaints reported for every 1,000 passengers.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Assails Soviets for Backing Angolan Offensive
DOC.TEXT: The State Department is accusing the Soviet Union of playing a key role in supporting a military offensive by the Angolan government against U.S.-backed rebels. Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler called Monday on Angola's MPLA government and its Soviet allies to stop the offensive immediately and concentrate on the peace process. ``We are very concerned about the dangerous escalation of offensive military action by the MPLA against UNITA-controlled territory in southeastern Angola,'' she said. ``That this offensive action is receiving close support from the substantial number of Soviet military advisers at the front line is increasing our concern.'' The UNITA rebels are believed to receive more than $40 million annually from the United States. Meanwhile, an Angola peace conference scheduled to start Wednesday has been postponed indefinitely, U.S. officials said. The presidents of eight African nations had been scheduled to go to the Angolan capital of Luanda for the conference. Ms. Tutwiler tempered her criticism of the Angolans by noting that President Jose Eduardo Dos Santos has indicated interest in discussing seriously some key issues in the 14-year civil war. She urged the MPLA government to take its proposals to Zaire's President Mobutu Sese Seko, who has led a peace effort. According to U.S. officials, after several weeks of logistical preparations, MPLA forces launched an attack Dec. 23 against UNITA-controlled areas along the Kuzumbia River. There had been high hopes in June for a peace settlement, but a cease-fire agreement broke down in August and there has been intermittent fighting since. Efforts to revive the cease-fire and promote direct negotiations have not prospered. U.S. officials were unable to give a reason for the postponement of the Jan. 10 Angola peace summit. A year ago, the State Department was praising Moscow for helping to promote steps toward peace in southern Africa, including an agreement that calls for the gradual withdrawal of all Cuban forces from Angola by 1991. But a senior government official, insisting on anonymity, said Monday that the administration is disappointed about the Soviet role in Angola over the past year. The official said Soviet aid to Angola in 1989 totaled about $600 million, a slight reduction from the 1988 figure. He said the administration thought the Soviets would reduce their aid further as a means of ``nudging the Angolans toward negotiations.'' The Angolans seem to have a more favorable view of an election process than before but have not accepted the idea of negotiating with UNITA, the official said. One of the most divisive issues has been the Angolan government's refusal to allow UNITA participation in multi-party elections.

DOC.HEAD: OAS Calls Incident in Panama a Law Violation
DOC.TEXT: The Organization of American States, which criticized the U.S. invasion of Panama last month, says the incursion by U.S. troops into the Nicaraguan ambassador's residence there was a violation of international law. After 3{ hours of debate Monday night, the OAS permanent council approved a resolution criticizing the action by a 19-0 vote. The United States and six other countries, mostly from the English-speaking Caribbean countries, abstained. U.S. Ambassador Luigi Einaudi, saying the United States has apologized for the Dec. 29 incident and taken steps to guard against a recurrence, said the resolution served no purpose other than ``anti-U.S.-propaganda.'' Einaudi said he did not oppose the resolution because the United States supports the laws that spell out the inviolability of diplomatic missions. The key paragraph of the resolution declares that the ``serious events that transpired are, as has been recognized, a violation of the privileges and immunities recognized under international law.'' The session was far less tendentious than the one shortly before Christmas when 20 OAS nations criticized the United States for its invasion of Panama. The U.S. cast the lone opposition vote, but some countries abstained. The troops entered the residence nine days after the invasion as part of their effort to restore order. According to Einaudi, efforts by the troops have led to the confiscation of 75,000 weapons. But Nicaraguan delegate Victoria Castillo dismissed Einaudi's explanations and said the incursion was a ``deliberate provocation.'' She called on the United States to provide ``just and immediate'' reparations for the damage done to the residence. This, she said, ``would make it possible to believe that the United States has indeed recognized its error and is disposed not to commit such an error again.'' The incident has generated uneasiness among some U.S. career diplomats, who believe that what happened in Panama could serve as a precedent for the penetration of an American Embassy somewhere by radical forces. ``It puts in jeopardy American diplomatic missions all over the world,'' said Perry Shankle, a former president of the American Foreign Service Association. The day after the incident, President Bush called it a ``screw up'' but criticized the Nicaraguan ambassador for having ``automatic weapons up to his eyeballs'' in the house. There were 12 AK-47 rifles, among other weapons, in the residence. The Nicaraguan ambassador to Panama, Antenor Ferrey, flew here for the meeting and called for strong action against the United States. If no such action is taken, he said, diplomats ``will be thought of as cannon fodder by those who can only understand the use of force.'' Einaudi said, however, that the U.S. troops made efforts to confirm independently the address of the Nicaraguan ambassador and had concluded he lived elsewhere after a check of the diplomatic lists. Once the troops realized their mistake, he said, they withdrew after returning all weapons. He said there were no arrests and he denied that any damage was done to the residence. Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega retaliated by expelling 20 U.S. diplomats from Managua.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Tries Again to Launch Space Shuttle Columbia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Launch scheduled at 7:35 a.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: Weather remained a threat today as NASA once again fueled space shuttle Columbia for a satellite rescue mission. The winged spaceship, grounded Monday by low clouds, was scheduled to lift off with its five astronauts during a 58-minute launch opportunity that was starting at 7:35 a.m. The period is determined by the location of the science laboratory that the space travelers hope to retrieve before it falls back to Earth, perhaps in March. Meterologists said there was a 70 percent chance the weather would be favorable at launch time, but a cold front moving through central and south Florida threatened to shroud the launch area in clouds. After assessing the weather late Monday, shuttle managers directed technicians to once more pump 524,000 gallons of liquid hydrogen and oxygen into Columbia's huge external fuel tank. Launch director Bob Sieck conducted a stop-and-go countdown and waited until the last possible minute before scrubbing the launch Monday. ``It looks like we will have to call it a day,'' Sieck told the astronauts when it became apparent the skies would not be clear enough. It had been fairly clear over the launch pad. But a 30-mile-wide bank of clouds approaching from the west at 6,000 feet would have made an emergency landing difficult for commander Dan Brandenstein, who would have to land the spaceship on a concrete runway near the pad. The flight is the first of a record 10 shuttle missions the space agency has scheduled in 1990. Planned for 10 days, it is the second longest flight yet in the program. The astronauts' first task will be to deploy a Navy communications satellite during the second day. From the beginning of the trip, Brandenstein and pilot Jim Wetherbee were to execute a series of intricate maneuvers to gradually track down over several days a satellite which has orbited Earth for nearly six years. The target is Long Duration Exposure Facility (LDEF), which is the size of a small school bus and is packed with 57 experiments containing a wealth of scientific and technological information from its long exposure to space. Once the satellite is caught, mission specialist Bonnie Dunbar will reach out with the shuttle's remote 50-foot arm to snare the 21,400-pound package, which is 30 feet long and 14 feet in diameter. ``It will be like hunting a speck in the sky,'' Brandenstein said in a recent interview. ``But NASA has plenty experience doing this type of rendezvous, and Jim and I have practiced it to perfection in the simulator.'' The satellite is 202 miles up but atmospheric drag has been pulling it to Earth at the rate of about half a mile a day. The rate will increase as it gets closer. If the satellite can't be retrieved, trackers estimate it will fall into the atmosphere and burn up about March 9, its experiments lost forever. Once the satellite is secure in the shuttle cargo bay, Brandenstein, Wetherbee, Dunbar and mission specialists Marsha Ivins and David Low will concentrate on experiments for the rest of the flight. The emphasis will be on materials processing and tests of how the human body adapts to weightlessness. The 10-day mission's schedule is to be 10 hours shorter than ninth shuttle flight, in November 1983, and is a stepping stone for even longer ones. Columbia is being modified to stay aloft 16 days, starting with a 1993 flight. Scientists are eager to examine LDEF primarily to learn how various materials and systems have withstood the long stay in orbit. The information will help in designing a permanent manned space station and other long-term spacecraft such as those planned for the ``Star Wars'' missile defense system.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection in Ike Turner Trial Begins
DOC.TEXT: Jury selection is under way in the trial of rhythm and blues musician Ike Turner on felony charges of drug and weapons violations stemming from a traffic stop last May. Turner, 57, is charged with possession for sale of ``rock'' or crystallized cocaine, transporting cocaine and illegally carrying a concealable weapon. Other charges include driving under the influence of a controlled substance and possession of drug paraphernalia, both misdemeanors. Selection of jurors began Monday in Superior Court. Turner was arrested May 22 by sheriff's deputies who reported he failed to stop his car at a stop sign. Officers said they found a .38-caliber revolver and cocaine inside the car. Turner, ex-husband of singer Tina Turner, has been arrested previously on cocaine-related charges. In October 1986, Turner admitted he had used cocaine every day for at least 15 years but said he was following a rehabilitation program. In August 1987, he was arrested after officers said they discovered 56 grams of rock cocaine in a container inside his car. Turner played rhythm and blues in the 1950s, performing with the Ikettes. He later formed the Ike and Tina Turner Revue with his wife. They split up in 1976 after nearly 16 years of marriage.

DOC.HEAD: Rosie's Diner to Move From N.J. to Michigan
DOC.TEXT: The diner where television viewers saw ``the quicker picker-upper'' sop up spills will be picked up and moved to Michigan. Ralph Corrado, 57, sold Rosie's Diner to Jerry Berta, a ceramic sculptor from Michigan who stopped inside by chance in December on his way to a New York City art show. Corrado said the diner will close for good Sunday and he will retire. The vintage dining car restaurant achieved a modicum of fame between 1970 and 1975, when Procter & Gamble featured it in a series of four commercials for its Bounty paper towels. In the ads, actress Nancy Walker portrayed the waitress Rosie, who wields the paper towels against the counter spills of clumsy truck drivers. Corrado renamed the diner for Rosie. Until three years ago, the diner was open 24 hours a day, seven days a week, but Corrado said it got to be too much. Berta refused to say how much he paid for the diner, which he calls a classic of the dining car genre, built in 1945 by the Paramount Dining Car Co. ``I bought it because I got tired of driving out East to eat in diners, and this is my favorite diner in the country,'' said the Rockford, Mich., artist, who works out of a studio and gallery that was formerly a diner. The diner will be divided in two and placed on trucks for the trip at an as yet undetermined time. Berta said he plans to hire someone with restaurant experience to manage the diner in Michigan.

DOC.HEAD: Tadeusz Brzezinski, Former Polish Consul-General, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Tadeusz Brzezinski, the Polish government-in-exile's consul-general in Montreal during World War II and the father of former U.S. national security adviser Zbigniew Brzezinski, has died of pneumonia at age 94. Brzezinski, who died Sunday at a nursing home, was consul-general from 1938 until the Communist takeover of his homeland at the end of World War II. He became a prominent member of the Montreal Polish community, serving as president of the Polish-Canadian Congress from 1952 to 1962. In 1975, he helped create the World Polish Congress. Until his retirement in 1968, Brzezinski worked for the Quebec Cultural Affairs Department, establishing cultural centers across the province. Brzezinski was born in 1896, in Zloczow, then part of the Austro-Hungarian Empire and now in the Soviet Union. As a volunteer in the Polish independence movement from 1918 to 1920, Brzezinski saw action in the battle of Lvov and against Soviet forces in the final Warsaw campaign of 1920. He then served as a Polish diplomat for the nascent Polish Republic in Germany, France, the Soviet Ukraine and Canada. While in Leipzig, Germany, before World War II, Brzezinski became involved in efforts to rescue European Jews from Nazi concentration camps. In 1978, his efforts on behalf of the Jewish people were recognized by Israeli prime minister Menachem Begin. Brzezinski, husband of the late Leonia Roman, is survived by two sons _ Zbigniew, formerly national security adviser under President Jimmy Carter, and Lech, an engineer in Montreal. He is also survived by seven grandchildren. A memorial Mass was planned Thursday at St. Wojciech Mission Church in Montreal. Funeral arrangements were not immediately announced.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange plunged Tuesday, while the dollar rose against the Japanese yen. The dollar closed at 144.97 yen, up 0.45 yen from Monday's close of 144.52 yen. It opened lower at 144.25 yen and ranged between 144.25 yen and 145.25 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average shed 343.50 points, or 0.90 percent, ending at 37,951.46, the lowest since Dec. 12, when the index recorded 37,803.53. Dealers said the Nikkei's plunge Tuesday was prompted by many factors, such as political uncertainties in the Soviet Union, a decline in bond prices and a stock plunge in Argentina. ``Market players were discouraged by the news reports about the Soviet Union and Argentina and stepped off to the sidelines soon after the morning session started,'' said Masayoshi Yano, a dealer with Nikko Securities Co. The Soviet government daily Izvestia reported Monday that violence has been developing along the Soviet-Iranian border, with protesters from Soviet Azerbaijan destroying border posts. In another part of Azerbaijan, the official Soviet news agency Tass said acts of sabotage, hostage-taking, and sniper fire were continuing in the disputed district of Nagorno-Karabakh. In Argentina, the country's leading stocks plunged by 53 percent Monday when the market reopened for the first time in more than a week. The fall was due in part to the shortage of australs in circulation, analysts said. On Jan. 1, the government unilaterally converted several billion dollars worth of short-term certificates of deposit to 10-year bonds. Also, the yen's weakness on the foreign exchange market Monday as well as falling bond prices in the futures market discouraged Japanese investors, Nikko Securities' Yano said. The futures bond price made a sharp 0.99-yen one-day drop to 101 yen. ``Investors remained cautious trying to watch bond price movements and the international situation,'' he said. In currency dealings, the dollar strengthened during morning trading here following a cut in the prime rate by major U.S. banks overnight, traders said. As domestic and international political uncertainties developed, market players discarded the yen and bought the dollar as a safer investment tool, said Toru Kanai, a currency analyst with New Japan Securities Co. ``Until the election here, the yen won't be very attractive to many investors,'' he said. A major parliamentary election is expected later in February, but the government has not finalized the schedule. ``The prime rate cut in the United States didn't make the dollar much weaker, and today everybody's selling the yen here,'' he said. But Kanai said the Bank of Japan intermittently conducted dollar-selling to support the yen, which should keep the dollar within the 145-146 yen range. The central bank does not comment on its monetary actions. The dollar's overnight slip followed its similar downswing in the New York market Monday after many banks cut their prime lending rate by a half-percentage point to 10 percent. The prime-rate cut reflects more liberal credit policies by the Federal Reserve Bank and will lower borrowing costs for businesses and consumers.

DOC.HEAD: Vt. Governor Wants No More Disposable Diapers, But Many Trash Plan
LaserPhoto MR2
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Madeleine Kunin wants Vermont to become the first state to ban all disposable diapers, but her plan is being trashed by some including day-care operators who want no part of a mountain of cloth. ``The time has come to be responsible and to find the way to say yes _ yes to required statewide recycling, to bans on certain polluting products, to changes in lifestyle,'' Kunin said in her state of the state speech last week. Only Nebraska has banned disposable diapers, but it allows the sale of diapers that are biodegradable, even though such products aren't believed to break down in the depths of oxygen-starved dumps. Kunin, whose proposal would ban disposable diapers by 1993, noted that while the usable life of a disposable diaper may be a few hours, they won't decompose in dumps for hundreds of years _ or several generations of babies later. Environmental groups have quickly supported the plan by Kunin, who last year made the state the first to ban the sale of vehicles that use ozone-depleting chemicals in their air conditioning. That ban starts with 1993 models. ``They are a large part of the waste stream,'' said Ned Farquhar of the Vermont Natural Resources Council. ``The throw-away society is wasting energy and materials, not just with diapers, but with a lot of similar products. We need to ban things to keep people from using them.'' The piles of discarded diapers make up about 2 percent of the nation's waste, and about 85 percent of all parents use disposable diapers exclusively, according to industry estimates. Vermont officials estimate that 43.5 million disposable diapers end up in the state's dumps every year. Opponents of a ban argue that the governor's plan won't have much impact in solving the state's mounting garbage disposal problem. Representatives of the health and day-care industries also say they are not ready to handle such a ban. ``There has been a tendency to pass into law programs on the basis of trendy catchwords, rather than science or careful consideration of all the different issues,'' said William Gilbert, a lobbyist representing the American Paper Institute. Gilbert said that mandating cloth diapers would add two to three more loads of hot-water washings weekly for families with babies, raising its own questions about environmental damage. Day-care centers, especially in rural parts of the state where there are no cloth diaper services, fear how they would be affected. ``If a ban went into effect today, it would create real havoc,'' said Lea Hatch, a day-care regulator for the state. But she added that centers in areas with access to diaper services already are beginning to offer that option to parents in lieu of disposables. Bethany Carleton, head of the Vermont Health Care Association, also said disposable diapers help prevent skin problems better than cloth ones. ``There are definitely reasons people don't want to go back to cloth,'' she said. Vermonters also are debating the wisdom of a ban in general. Windsor County Sen. John Carroll, a Republican who has joined the Democratic governor in the proposal, said he could understand the reluctance to a mandate. But he added, ``I think this needs to be talked about a lot more carefully than it has been. I think this is the year to do it. Now is time to take advantage of public awareness of the crisis in solid waste.'' David Wilson, a former state secretary of administration, said bans don't serve the environmental movement well. ``They engender public resentment of what are otherwise sound environmental policies,'' Wilson said. ``The public has a strong reaction to mandates. When you do try to mandate, you may be throwing the baby out with the bathwater.''

DOC.HEAD: Rhode Island State Landfill Can't Get Enough of Garbage
With PM-Diaper Ban, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `Truk-Away' in 11th graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: One Rhode Island dump can't get enough of trash, so it's may give a special deal for garbage. The state's price of $59 a ton to dump at the Central Landfill in Johnston prompted companies to haul trash out of state. Rhode Island officials, facing an $8 million shortfall in projected revenues of $22 million from commercial dumping, are considering a price reduction, said Michael Carroll, associate director of finance for the state Solid Waste Management Corp. But the issue isn't as simple as making the price competitive. The quasi-public corporation still needs enough money to carry out its legislative mandate of developing a complete waste disposal system, from incinerators to recycling. When state officials in August raised the ``tipping'' fee at Central Landfill to $59 a ton from $10, they thought it would be competitive with landfills in neighboring states. State officials had surveyed the dump market within 100 miles of Rhode Island. What went wrong? ``We didn't get current information,'' Carroll said. With some new landfills and incinerators opening, ``Massachusetts has a glut and they were able to take in some of the Rhode Island trash.'' At the same time, cities and towns by law must pay only $13 per ton, increasing 7.5 percent a year. Trash haulers say they started bypassing the dump for reasons other than just price. Some blame the state's mandatory recycling rules that took effect this year. The recycling laws require that no more than 20 percent of a load brought to the landfill be recyclable. Using out-of-state incinerators ``is about break-even with dumping it at the Central Landfill,'' said David Wilson, vice president of Truk-Away of Rhode Island Inc. But if it means avoiding the $500 fine for a load with too much recyclable material, it's worth it, he said. ``As long as 20 percent by weight is the criteria now for violating the law, lowering the rates wouldn't make any difference,'' he said. ``When the rate went up, it made everybody look into recycling faster.'' That raises the important question: If the state's stressing recycling to lengthen the life of a dump, how does it reach the delicate balance of enough revenue to run the recycling program while not attracting too much trash so it runs out of room? ``We haven't gotten that far,'' Carroll said.

DOC.HEAD: Buchwald Victory: Triumph for Writers Or Opening for Bogus Claims?
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Art Buchwald's victory over Paramount Pictures about rights to ``Coming to America'' was hailed as a triumph for writers, but the studio feared the court decision could mean a rash of bogus lawsuits. ``I am very, very happy,'' Buchwald said in a telephone interview after a judge ruled Monday that Paramount must pay him for the script idea he claimed was the basis for the hit Eddie Murphy movie ``Coming to America.'' ``This thing is not only an important thing for me,'' Buchwald said. ``I think it's really important for writers.'' Superior Court Judge Harvey A. Schneider ruled that ``Coming to America'' was ``based upon a material element of, or was inspired by'' a synopsis Buchwald wrote entitled ``King for a Day.'' ``The evidence is overwhelming that for two years Paramount considered `King for a Day' to be a project that was being developed for Eddie Murphy,'' the judge ruled. Monetary damages in the $5 million lawsuit were not decided, but the judge disallowed any punitive award. Paramount promised an appeal, while writers predicted their battles would be a bit easier against Hollywood studios. ``I am delighted that the little man kicked the big guy,'' said Billy Wilder, a Buchwald ally and the director and co-writer of Paramount's 1950 classic ``Sunset Boulevard.'' ``It's a very important decision for all writers,'' said David Rintels, an award-winning screenwriter (``Day One,'' ``Sakharov'') who served as an expert witness on Buchwald's behalf. ``It upholds the sanctity of contracts and it affirms that a writer's original ideas have value.'' Buchwald's story, like 1988's ``Coming to America,'' was about a member of African royalty who comes to the United States, lives in a ghetto, works at a fast-food restaurant and finds a bride to take home to his native land. The Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist filed the lawsuit last year, alleging the studio breached a 1983 contract to purchase his script idea. Buchwald's attorney, Pierce O'Donnell, said that his client and Buchwald's writing partner, producer Alain Bernheim, stood to receive between $5 million and $10 million. The judge's decision allows an inspection of Paramount's financial records on the movie, O'Donnell said. Paramount claims the film, which has gross profits of more than $300 million, has no net profits. ``If you believe that,'' Buchwald quipped, ``then there's a wonderful S&L I'd like to sell you.'' Paramount, meanwhile, began preparing for another round in court. ``We don't agree with the judge's decision on the contract claim. However, we are pleased he threw out the claim for punitive damages,'' it said in a statement. ``We are confident that the appellate court will find that `Coming to America' was created without any contribution from Art Buchwald.'' Robert Draper, an attorney for Paramount, said Buchwald's script idea and Murphy's movie were entirely different: ``It's like `Godzilla' and `Cinderella.''' The only similarity, he said, was that the main characters in each version were black. Draper said that the judge's interpretation of the ``based upon'' concept _ a crucial point in the ruling _ was too broad. ``Under the interpretation of `based upon' that was adopted, just about anything could be found to be based upon anything else,'' Draper said. Paramount's lawyers had said during the court proceedings that a ruling in favor of Buchwald could trigger an onslaught of groundless lawsuits. Neither Murphy nor his manager, Bob Wachs, responded to telephone messages for comment. A spokeswoman for Arsenio Hall, who developed the movie with Murphy and co-starred in it, also did not respond to a telephone request for comment. Buchwald said his dispute was solely a breach-of-contract claim against Paramount and not an allegation of plagiarism against Murphy. Buchwald also said the ordeal cured him of one ambition: ``I have decided not to write any movies for the next 10 years.''

DOC.HEAD: Hawaii Governor Asks State Control Over Expanded U.S. Coastal Waters
With PM-Aloha Casual, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. coastal areas from three miles to 12 miles off shore are in a legal never-never land that Congress needs to clarify, Gov. John Waihee says. He recommended Monday that the adjacent state be given jurisdiction of the expanded coastal area, along with the revenues that might be generated there. Waihee appeared before the U.S. House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries at the state Capitol during a hearing on U.S. oceans and coastal management issues in the Pacific. The committee is on an eight-day trip to Hawaii to examine fishing rights, ocean mining and the territorial seas. The itinerary is heavy on free time and evening receptions, however. But the representatives bristle at suggestions that the excursion is a political junket. Three panel members made the trip from Washington, D.C., joining two Hawaii congressmen. The hearing was to resume today. Waihee said Monday that federal laws have established a reasonably effective state-federal management process for the coastal zone out to three miles. Those rules should be extended to the 12-mile limit, if the adjacent state, territory or commonwealth agrees, he said. The governor recommended that states draw up plans to manage the new zone. As for the nearly $1 billion in annual federal revenues from offshore oil and gas leases in the three- to 12- mile zone, Waihee suggested that revenues from new production over the next 10 years be divided 50-50 between federal and the adjacent state. After the period, he said, the money should go the state upon completion of a management program. Hawaii has no offshore oil and gas leases, but it does have mineral-rich manganese crusts on seamounts near the islands.

DOC.HEAD: Wide Implications Seen From Cordless-Phone Eavesdropping Case
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Supreme Court's refusal to ban eavesdropping of conversations on cordless telephones has implications for all phone users, a civil-liberties lawyer says. The court, without comment, on Monday let stand a ruling that Scott County law enforcement agents acted lawfully when they monitored cordless-phone conversations by the Scott Tyler family of Dixon without a warrant. One of every four American homes has a cordless phone, according to industry estimates, but the ruling could affect people using standard cord telephones who, knowingly or not, talk with someone using a cordless phone, said Randall Wilson of the Iowa Civil Liberties Union. ``I'm sure the justices had some very good reasons for refusing to hear the case,'' said Wilson, who helped represent Tyler. ``But for now it means that every American will have to live in fear that some of his or her phone calls will not be private. ``I think the message for Americans will continue to be that if you purchase modern conveniences, such as cordless phones or baby monitors or other radio devices, it means purchasing them at the expense of your constitutional rights.'' Tyler said he will refile the case before the high court in its next session, beginning Oct. 1. Wilson, however, was doubtful the court would take another look at the case. Tyler said he received a cordless phone as a Father's Day gift in 1983 from his children. Whenever the phone was in use, Rich and Sandra Berodt, who lived a few blocks away, discovered their cordless phone would making ringing and dialing noises. Based on at least one phone conversation they listened to, the Berodts suspected Tyler was involved in illegal drug dealing. They contacted the county sheriff's department. Authorities encouraged the Berodts to continue the eavesdropping and supplied them with recording equipment so conversations on the Tylers' phone could be taped. The suspicion of drug-dealing proved unfounded, but over several months authorities relied on the tapes to charge Tyler with criminal theft and conspiracy. The tapes, however, were barred as evidence at his trial. Tyler was convicted in late 1984 on charges stemming from his bilking two food companies out of $35,000. He was sentenced to 10 years in prison but released after 123 days. Tyler and his family later sued the Berodts, Scott County, Sheriff Forest Ashcraft and a sheriff's investigator, contending the warrantless phone monitoring violated the family's Fourth Amendment privacy rights. U.S. District Judge Harold D. Vietor in Davenport dismissed the lawsuit, and the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the ruling, which the Supreme Court let stand. Vietor had noted that the technology of cordless phones makes conversations on them more susceptible to interception. ``Because there was no justifiable expectation of privacy, the interceptions did not violate the Fourth Amendment,'' he ruled. The amendment generally bars searches and seizures without warrants. Police have been barred since a landmark 1967 high court ruling from secretly listening to conversations over traditional phones without court warrants. Tyler, who has waged a crusade over the eavesdropping issue, said he won't put his campaign on hold. ``I and millions of Americans still believe this is just simply wrong. ... ``As it now stands, information gained from a cordless phone could be used diabolically by police agencies, divorce lawyers, banking institutions, et cetera,'' Tyler said in a telephone interview _ on a standard cord phone.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Noriega to be Moved Soon
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials plan to move Manuel Noriega out of state for security reasons, according to a published report today, but his lawyers said they know nothing about such a move. Quoting an anonymous source involved in the shift, The New York Times reported that the deposed Panamanian leader probably would be taken to the federal penitentiary in Atlanta. He was being held early today in a holding cell in the U.S. courthouse here, sources who spoke on condition of anonymity told The Associated Press. U.S. marshals and Noriega's attorneys refuse to disclose his whereabouts. ``Up until now they (U.S. marshals) have not intimated in any way that they're going to remove him'' from Miami, defense attorney Steven Kollin said late Monday. ``However they have told us, frankly, that they may have to move him from the place where he is being held now to a more suitable place for their security purposes. ``If this is not in the southern district of Florida or not suitable so that we can have access for meetings with our client, we will file the appropriate motions,'' he told the AP. Another Noriega attorney, Frank Rubino, also said he had not been informed of an imminent move. Both attorneys said they have met daily with their client. Federal officials believe the Metropolitan Correctional Center, a federal prison south of Miami, does not offer adequate security to hold Noriega, the Times said. Officials considered federal prisons in Leavenworth, Kan., and Marion, Ill., but Atlanta's was first choice because it is closest to Miami, the newspaper reported. Rubino and Kollin don't expect to make their first motions in the drug-trafficking case for 30 days. But when they do, they likely will challenge the court's jurisdiction, the way Noriega was brought to this country after U.S. invasion of Panama and requests for government documents. An attorney for a pilot accused of flying drug money for Noriega, meanwhile, asked for disclosure of secret information obtained from U.S. electronic surveillance in Panama. The motion by Michael O'Kane, representing Panamanian pilot Daniel Miranda, asked the court to compel release of classified information from a telecommunications monitoring operation at the U.S. Southern Command. The indictment charges that Miranda flew $800,000 in drug money from Florida to Panama in 1983. Lawyers for other co-defendants said they have begun talks with prosecutors but no deals have been struck. ``We're desirous of exploring all options, but no offers have been made on either side and there are no deals,'' said Samuel Burstyn, attorney for Luis del Cid, a former close aide to Noriega.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Of Late Filipino Leader To be Entombed After 20 Months
DOC.TEXT: The remains of Ferdinand Marcos' mother will be entombed in a refrigerated mausoleum this month _ nearly two years after her death, the family mortician said today. Before the Sept. 28 death in Hawaii of the ousted and exiled president, the Marcos family had insisted it would not bury his mother, Josefa Edralin Marcos, unless he was permitted to return home for the funeral. President Corazon Aquino, who came to power in the popular uprising that ousted Marcos in February 1986, cited security reasons for refusing to allow Marcos to return and later banning his burial in the Philippines. Mrs. Marcos, who died May 4, 1988, will be kept in the encasement indefinitely until both mother and son are allowed to be buried together in the Philippines, said the mortician, Francisco Malabed. Marcos, who died at age 72, was entombed in Hawaii on Oct. 15. Malabed said the family asked him to prepare for the funeral and entombment Jan. 21 in Ilocos Norte province, 220 miles north of the capital. Malabed said the decision was made by Marcos' brother Pacifico and sister Fortuna. Mrs. Marcos will be placed in a mausoleum similar to that of her son's in Honolulu, Malabed said. He said the funeral will take place in the back of the Marcos home in Batac town, where the former president grew up. The funeral plans could not be immediately confirmed with the Marcos family.

DOC.HEAD: Sea Creatures Dying in Record Numbers After Florida's Cold Snap
DOC.TEXT: More than half of an unprecedented number of dead manatees found in Florida waterways during the past nine days may be victims of the Christmas cold snap, state officials said. The carcasses of 41 of the endangered marine mammals have been discovered in the new year, the state's Department of Natural Resources reported Monday. There were only 15 manatees found dead last year in all of January, said Dr. Bruce Ackerman, marine mammal researcher at the department's Florida Research Institute. ``It's the worst winter die-off we've had since we've been counting,'' he said. ``They are literally coming in so fast we can't keep our records up.'' Ackerman's department has been documenting manatee deaths since 1974. Most of the carcasses have been found in the waters off Brevard County. Violet Stewart, an institute spokeswoman, said 27 of the gentle sea cows have been found there. ``It appears that the water over there got particularly cold,'' she said. ``We had some reports of water temperatures down into the 40s.'' She said marine biologists estimate that 25 to 30 of the deaths are cold-related, although precise causes will take time to determine. ``They are finding that manatees died with this cold snap and they sank,'' Ms. Stewart said. ``As they decay they rise to the surface, so they are just now being recovered.'' Ackerman said that since manatees are tropical, they have no layer of blubber like seals and whales. ``They lose their ability to digest food and gradually become more run-down,'' he said. ``When they get run-down, they lose the ability to swim to a warmer place.'' Last year, there were a record 165 manatee deaths. Biologists estimate that Florida has only 1,200 of the endangered creatures left.

DOC.HEAD: San Diego Mayor Won't Seek Third Term in 1992
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Maureen O'Connor concluded her State of the City address with a surprise: She won't seek re-election when her term expires in 1992. ``Only a mayor leaving the office to another can outline, without a hidden agenda, the honest path the city must follow to meet her destiny head on,'' she said Monday. A two-term limit for elected officials is among those proposals, which the Democrat said she would like to see be put before voters in a special mail election in May. She also proposed plans to fight illiteracy and to protect the environment, including proposals to clean up San Diego Bay. O'Connor, 42, the city's first woman mayor, won a 1986 special election. She won re-election in 1988. She said after her address that she had no plans to leave San Diego and after leaving the post would continue to promote her hometown as a hub for international trade.

DOC.HEAD: Politicians Disagree Over U.S. Naval Presence
DOC.TEXT: President Virgilio Barco was assailed by the opposition and reported to have even angered his own foreign minister by backing a Bush administration plan to station U.S. warships off the coast in an attempt to snare drug traffickers. News reports Monday said Foreign Minister Julio Londono Paredes planned to resign over the issue, but Colombia's ambassador in Washington, Victor Mosquera Chaux, later said Londono told him he was not quitting. Protests over the planned U.S. operation were not unexpected because Barco's 5-month-old war with Colombia's powerful cocaine barons, seen as courageous elsewhere, has received relatively little support at home. The issue is also sensitive after the U.S. invasion of Panama last month, which drew criticism from Colombians and other Latin Americans, who are sensitive to Washington's use of military force in the region as an instrument of policy. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, traveling with President Bush on a trip to Orlando, Fla., said two ships were on maneuvers in the Atlantic but that future deployment near Colombia would depend on talks with the Barco government. The carrier John F. Kennedy and guided missile cruiser Virginia left Thursday from Norfolk, Va. Bush has looked at sending U.S. warships off Colombia's Caribbean coast to help monitor and interdict narcotics traffickers, Pentagon sources have said. A diplomat with the U.S. Embassy said Monday that Barco had not sent a protest note or objected in any other way, officially or unofficially, to an increase of Caribbean patrols. The official asked to remain anonymous so he would not become a target of the cocaine gangs. Officials of both countries said Monday that such an operation would not constitute a blockade. The Colombian Embassy in Washington issued a statement denying the United States sought to set up a blockade in Colombia's coastal waters and saying the Bush administration gave assurances it will not interfere with Colombian-flagged ships, even on the high seas, without the permission of Colombia's Defense Ministry. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said, ``A blockade would mean shutting down everything, and that, obviously, is not our intention.'' A U.S. Embassy statement last week said the Navy patrols were merely an exercise in increased vigilance, not a new policy, and would take place in international waters. Adding to the confusion about Colombia's official position was a report Sunday by the Bogota daily El Tiempo that Barco's office issued a statement saying Colombia would not contribute warships to the U.S. effort. Julio Carlos Gonzalez, a spokesman for Barco, said the El Tiempo story was not based on any Barco statement because none had been issued. La Prensa, a Bogota daily with access to presidential advisers, said Monday that the debate within the Colombian government appearerd to stem from a dispute between president and foreign minister. Radio Caracol, quoting an unidentified, high-ranking source in the government, said Londono was preparing his resignation Monday afternoon. Mosquera Chaux later denied the report, speaking in an interview with Radio Caracol from Washington. Monday was a holiday in Colombia and government offices were not open for official comment. There was also no immediate comment on what bearing possible U.S. interdiction efforts could have on a regional drug summit is scheduled for Feb. 15 in Cartagena, Colombia, that is to be attended by Bush. Protests to the possible stationing of U.S. warships in the Caribbean came from the opposition Conservative Party and the leftist Patriotic Union Party. Neither has been supportive of Barco's attempt to crush drug traffickers. Colombia's congress should be called into emergency session ``to emphatically reject the air and sea maneuvers implemented by the United States,'' the president of the Conservative Party's central committee, Rodrigo Barraza, said in a broadcast interview. The interview was broadcast by the radio network Caracol. The Patriotic Union's presidential candidate for elections next May, Bernardo Jaramillo Ossa, said in a Caracol interview that the U.S. action in the Caribbean shows that Colombia apparently is just a step away from a U.S. invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors in Reputed Mob Boss Trial to be Sequestered
DOC.TEXT: Jurors in the assault and conspiracy trial of reputed mob boss John Gotti will be sequestered for the duration of the case. State Judge Edward McLauglin told the first pool of 300 prospective jurors brought Monday into his courtroom he made the decision because he was responsible for the jurors' ``well-being and comfort.'' ``You are going to be guests of the state for the entire trial,'' he said. He said the trial will last about three weeks and will be in session Monday through Saturday. He said the jury will be locked away in hotels for the rest of each day and on days the trial is not held. McLaughlin said the defense would be given the jurors' names but not the addresses of their homes or places of business. Assistant District Attorney Jeffrey Schlanger had requested that the jurors' names be kept confidential, noting it took three trials to reach a verdict in 1988 in a federal racketeering and narcotics case involving Gotti's brother, Gene, because jurors were accosted and intimidated. About three-fourths of the initial pool were excused when they said they were unable to sit on a sequestered jury for three weeks. The remaining 77 were given questionnaires about their personal histories and opinions. Three more groups of 300 will be brought in as prospective jurors. The judge said he planned to hold a hearing today on the admissibility of tape recordings of a conversation at Rikers Island between reputed gang members about the May 1986 shooting of John F. O'Connor, vice president and business manager of the Carpenters Union Local 608. Gotti, 48, and Anthony Guerrieri, 60, are charged with ordering O'Connor shot in retaliation for vandalism at a mob-controlled restaurant.

DOC.HEAD: Research Shows Seven Shuffles Cut Fair Deal
DOC.TEXT: If the deck isn't shuffled seven times, you may be getting a raw deal. Two mathematicians _ one of whom also is a magician _ have discovered that it takes exactly seven ordinary shuffles to mix a deck of cards thoroughly. Fewer shuffles are not enough and more do not significantly improve the mix, according to a story today in The New York Times. The research was conducted by magician-mathematician Persi Diaconis, who is also a statistician at Harvard University, and his colleague, Dave Bayer, who is a mathematician and computer scientist at Columbia University. The two made the discovery after studying results from elaborate computer calculations and careful observations of card games. It confirms the intuition of many gamblers, bridge enthusiasts and casual players that most shuffling is inadequate. Most people shuffle just three or four times, which Diaconis says produces an order that ``is far from random.'' Casino gamblers and even bridge players often take advantage of the non-randomness of insufficiently shuffled cards, Diaconis said. By knowing what the deck looked like at the end of the last hand, they can predict the distribution of the next hand. Diaconis said that the non-randomness of insufficiently shuffled cards is so common that when computers were first introduced to mix cards at bridge tournaments nearly 20 years ago, players were puzzled and outraged by the random hands the computers dealt. By saying that the deck is perfectly mixed after seven shuffles, the researchers mean that every arrangement of the 52 cards is equally likely or that any card is as likely to be in one place as in another. The cards get more randomly mixed after seven shuffles, but seven times is a transition point, the first time randomness is close. Additional shuffles don't appreciably change things.
