In Las Vegas casinos, cards are shuffled from four to seven times, at the discretion of casino owners, said Richard Ingram, a Law Vegas enforcement agent for the state gambling control board. Diaconis said his research showed that when dealers shuffle several decks of cards at once, they need to shuffle more. Two decks should be shuffled nine times, he said, and six decks 12 times. At Trump Plaza in Atlantic City, N.J., blackjack dealers shuffle eight decks twice at the beginning of each game, said Howard Dreitzer, senior vice president of casino operations. ``We've tested these shuffles and feel that they are random,'' he said, adding that ``no one has ever complained.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Fall Below 38,000 Mark, Dollar Gains
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index plunged below the 38,000-point mark today amid uncertainties over domestic politics and overseas developments, and the dollar gained against the Japanese yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues fell 343.50 points, or 0.90 percent, closing at 37,951.46, the lowest since Dec. 12, when the index closed at 37,803.53. The index lost more than 500 points by midafternoon but rebounded somewhat as institutional investors picked up issues that had fallen earlier, said Takahiro Makita, a dealer with Yamaichi Securities Co. Makita said investors were discouraged by rumors about a politician's possible arrest in an alleged insider trading case, falling bond prices, the weakening yen, news about bombings in restive Soviet Azerbaijan, and the 53 percent plunge in Argentina's stock market Monday, when it reopened for the first time in more than a week. A drop in future bond prices ignited fears of higher interest rates, which discourage stock investment. ``Such discouraging elements sent Japanese market players off to the sidelines and made trading inactive,'' Makita said. Volume on the first section was estimated at 500 million shares, unchanged from the previous day. ``To begin with, the market has been unstable ahead of the election. Such nervous trading could occur repeatedly until then,'' Makita added. Elections for the lower house of Parliament are expected in mid-February, although the government has made no official announcement. With the insider trading rumor and Soviet developments also affecting the yen, the dollar closed at 144.97 yen, up 0.45 yen from Monday's 144.52-yen finish, despite central bank intervention to support the Japanese currency. The dollar opened at 144.25 yen, its low for the day, and ranged as high as 145.25 yen. The dollar had gained 0.37 yen on Monday. Today's gain also came despite a cut in the prime lending rate by major U.S. banks. Lower interest rates tend to make a country's currency less attractive to investors. ``The yen is getting weak because nobody wants to buy it now,'' said Akio Nakanishi, a trader with Daiwa Bank. ``The rumor came a little before the morning closing at 11 a.m. (9 p.m. EST Monday) and market players sold the yen all at once,'' he added. ``I thought the rumor was a little bit strange ... but it really affected the market,'' Nakanishi said, adding that investors felt the dollar was a safer investment tool. The rumor concerned Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, a former minister of international trade and industry said to be close to a company president who allegedly offered stocks in a transaction that brought a $828,000 profit for an aide to former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone. The Bank of Japan sold a few million dollars to support the yen and check the dollar's rise, Nakanishi said. The central bank does not comment on its currency market activities. About $11 billion traded hands in spot trading, up from Monday's $6.49 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Interest Tab Grows Daily in Weapons Plant Settlement
DOC.TEXT: The federal government's debt to neighbors of a contaminated Ohio weapons plant is getting bigger while bureaucrats juggle accounts and try to figure out which one to tap. ``We're talking about an additional $20,000 a day in interest, attorney Stanley Chesley, who won the court-ordered settlement, said Monday. ``They're up to $2 million and they'll owe another $20,000 tomorrow and the day after that.'' That's in addition to the minimum $73 million agreed to in the settlement. At a meeting Monday with Henry Gill, the Energy Department lawyer who handled the case filed by neighbors of the government-owned uranium processing plant at Fernald, Ohio, Chesley said he asked to get the settlement money in the bank as soon as possible. The settlement was approved in September and U.S. District Judge Arthur Spiegel ordered the Energy Department to deposit the money in Cincinnati banks by Oct. 15. But that deadline slipped because of a government appeal that subsequently was dropped. However, the government has been unable to figure out the mechanics of complying with the settlement, said Gill. The government lawyer said special legislation may be needed to authorize payment.
DOC.HEAD: Industry Critic Hails USTR `Retreat'
DOC.TEXT: American cigarette makers may lose the U.S. government as an ally in quest of foreign markets to replace declining domestic sales, says an industry critic, Rep. Chester Atkins, D-Mass. That's the meaning of the U.S. Trade Representative's recent decision to handle a market-opening industry petition through GATT, the 100-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, Atkins told a Monday gathering sponsored by the American Cancer Society. The petition of the U.S. Cigarette Export Association had asked the USTR to press Thailand to open its markets to American cigarettes and brand promotion under threat of trade retaliation, similar to recent efforts gaining entry into the Japanese, South Korean and Taiwanese markets. ``For the first time, USTR has failed to deliver for the cigarette industry'' because ``America's dark secret of cigarette exports has been exposed in the sunlight of public scrutiny,'' Atkins said. Submitting part of the Thailand petition for negotiations by GATT changes the deadline from May until Nov. 25 for action on the industry demands, USTR spokeswoman Janet Roell said Monday, confirming the action. USTR asked GATT to handle negotiations with Thailand on grounds that its import ban and higher taxes on foreign tobacco content violate GATT rules, Ms. Roell said.
DOC.HEAD: FAA May Require That Infants, Toddlers Have Tickets
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Aviation Administration says it will revise safety requirements for infants and toddlers traveling on airliners. FAA Administrator James Busey said Monday that the agency's eventual action, which could be two years away, may mean that adults traveling with children under age 2 will have to buy tickets for the youngsters and, perhaps, have them secured in FAA-approved child seats. Current FAA quidelines allow a child under age 2 to ride for free on an adult's lap. A representative of the Association of Flight Attendants, which strongly supports putting children under age 2 in some sort of restraints, commented after Busey's announcement that ``it's ludicrous that there are FAA regulations in place to restrain carry-on baggage while babies are allowed to fly around the cabin during a crash.'' If Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Dole approves the FAA proposal to write rules for the airlines' youngest passengers, a formal notice will be printed in the Federal Register. The public will then have 90 days to comment. An FAA spokesman said hearings may be held.

DOC.HEAD: Ethnic Turkish Immigrants Say No Rush to Return to Bulgaria
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of ethnic Turks who fled from Bulgaria last year are not flocking back over the border despite the new Bulgarian leadership's decision to restore rights for the minority group. ``The relaxation of restrictions in Bulgaria on the rights of the Turkish minority may eventually affect the situation, but we have seen no sign of it so far,'' said Unal Erkan, the governor of Edirne, a western border town. Some of the 320,000 ethnic Turks who streamed from Bulgaria to Turkey last summer have returned, but most appear to be watching and waiting to see if Bulgaria's new reform-minded Communist leaders make good on their promise to end a forced assimilation campaign. Ethnic Turks had to change their Moslem names to Slavic ones and were forbidden to speak Turkish or practice Islamic rites under meaures instituted six years ago by hard-line Communist leader Todor Zhivkov, who was ousted in November. The new government in Sofia announced on Dec. 29 that it would rescind the policies affecting the 1.2-million-strong minority. The action, however, has prompted protests and work stoppages in the country of 9 million. The demonstrations have been led by members of Bulgaria's Slavic majority suspicious of the loyalties of the ethnic Turks. ``The separation of Turk and Bulgarian and discrimination against us will never stop,'' said Fikret Gocgeldi, a 34-year-old bus driver who took part in last summer's exodus and now lives in Edirne, which lies near Turkey's border with Bulgaria and Greece. The Kapikule border gate in Edirne was nearly deserted, with only a family of four waiting to depart. It was a far cry from the scene last summer, when cars packed with possessions jammed the border gate. Hundreds of thousands of ethnic Turks streamed into Turkey after the Bulgarian government provided them with passports following bloody demonstrations for minority rights in May. About 4,000 people were entering Turkey daily until the government in Ankara imposed a visa requirement in August to stem the tide. Thousands of ethnic Turks subsequently returned to their native land, citing a lack of housing and jobs in Turkey and separation from family members who had to wait a long time for visas. By Monday, the returnees numbered 96,500, border officials said. But, they added, only about 100 were returning daily, compared with a 1,000 a month ago, and about 50 ethnic Turks were still coming in each day. At the train station in Edirne, 20 ethnic Turks, most of them elderly, were waiting for the train to Bulgaria. ``This is no place for older people. I cannot enter any job, I am only free to enter the mosque,'' said Kadir Mehmet, 60. Since last summer, the immigrants have become settled in Turkey. In Edirne, the ethnic Turks have been moved from tents to small, prefabricated houses set up on a treeless, windswept lot. Despite the harsh living conditions, they appear determined to stay. The rest of the immigrants have dispersed throughout Turkey, with about one-fourth of the group settling in the western city of Bursa and the second-largest group going to Istanbul. Most leaders of the immigrant community have expressed support publicly for the policies of the new Bulgarian authorities, apparently following the lead of the Turkish government. Foreign Minister Mesut Yilmaz has denounced the protest demonstrations in Bulgaria but praised the country's government for reiterating its promise to restore ethnic rights. Yilmaz has said Turkey believes the demonstrations against the restoration of minority rights were prompted by local officials loyal to the ousted Zhivkov regime. He has expressed hope for their replacement.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle Preparing For Latin America Talks
LaserPhoto CD1
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle says his trip to Central America in the wake of U.S. military intervention in Panama will test his diplomatic skill. President Bush said Friday that Quayle would be sent for face-to-face talks with leaders, some of whom have been critical of the action that removed Panama's Gen. Manuel Noriega from power and brought him to Miami to face drug charges. Quayle said Monday he will go on the mission in a few weeks, but he did not specify a date. It has not been determined which countries he will visit, but it is expected he will attend the presidential inauguration in Honduras Jan. 27. ``I will be interested to hear what they have to say, privately,'' Quayle told reporters. ``What they say privately sometimes is not the same as what they say in public. This mission at the request of the president will be one of strong consultation that shows sensitivity toward Latin American countries.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``In terms of any impact on the flow of drugs or money through the banking system, the impact of Noriega's arrest will be nil. I'm talking about the total flow of drugs, the total flow of money.'' _ Rensselaer Lee III, a consultant and lecturer who specializes in Latin American drug trafficking issues, analyzing the effect of the fall of Manuel Noriega.

``I needed three days to teach my secretary normal behavior. She was sullen, she was running around like mad if I said one word, as if it had been a command.'' _ Andrei Plesu, Romania's new culture minister, on learning to adjust to gentler times heralded in after the execution of former leaders Nicolae and Elena Ceausescu.

``If you believe that, then there's a wonderful S&L I'd like to sell you.'' _ Art Buchwald, columnist who successfully sued Paramount Pictures over a script idea he claimed was the basis for the Eddie Murphy movie ``Coming to America, on Paramount's claim that the movie _ which has gross profits of more than $300 million _ has no net profits.

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Visits With Children at Crisis Shelter
DOC.TEXT: For former President Reagan, it was more than just another stop after another speech. And for the children he met at the Casa de Los Ninos crisis shelter, it likely left an indelible impression. One small girl remarked proudly, ``I've seen him on TV before.'' Another child said meeting the former president ``was neat.'' When one child asked him if being president had been fun, Reagan said, ``The job wasn't invented just for having fun, but I must say I enjoyed it.'' When another asked him, ``Do you like us?'' he replied, ``If I didn't I wouldn't be here. I've heard about you and now I'm here to see you.'' And when the children proudly gave him notes and drawings they had made, he responded with jelly beans for the kids, and advice that he ate them ``instead of smoking, and they're a lot better for you than smoking.'' Sister Kathleen Clark, the shelter's founding director, gave Reagan a book about the non-sectarian, non-profit center established in 1973 that currently handles about 1,000 children from infancy to age 11 each year. Reagan signed autographs for the children after being greeted by two sisters with a bouquet of daisies. Two other youngsters held up a banner to greet him. One of the, 9-year-old Michael Fiscella, admitted he was ``nervous.'' But as he showed up, about 15 people across the street from the shelter held signs and hurled criticism of the Reagan and Bush administrations' policies in Central America. After touring the shelter Monday, Reagan told reporters he was pleased Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega is in American custody and will face trial in the United States. But he declined further comment about the deposed Panamanian general, saying he did not want to harm chances for a fair trial or the case American prosecutors have against Noriega. As for the protesters, Reagan said, ``I'm sorry that they're so ignorant about that situation.'' Earlier, the 79-year-old former president delivered a private speech to a microcomputer trade group.

DOC.HEAD: First Living-Donor Transplant Recipient Leaves Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Alyssa Smith, the nation's first recipient of a living-donor liver transplant, has been released from the University of Chicago Medical Center, where the historic surgery was performed. The 22-month-old infant, who recently suffered from the flu, will stay nearby at the Ronald McDonald House for a week before going home to Schertz, Texas, near San Antonio, hospital spokesman John Easton said Monday night. At Ronald McDonald House, Alyssa will join her mother, Teresa Smith, who donated part of her liver to her daughter for the Nov. 27 operation, he said. ``Alyssa continues to progress well,'' Easton said. ``But we won't think it is a big deal until she returns home to Texas.'' The nation's second living-donor transplant recipient, 16-month-old Sarina Jones of Millington, Tenn., was listed in serious condition at the hospital, Easton said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Accused of Gambling Away Armored Car Heist Reportedly Ready to Surrender
DOC.TEXT: The son of a former Delaware prosecutor gambled away $651,000 stolen in a Philadelphia armored car heist and now wants to surrender, according to published reports. ``I stole the money because I thought I could quadruple it through gambling _ and then I would give half to the company I stole it from,'' said a letter apparently written by Edward Leigh Hunt Jr., a federal fugitive. Hunt was a guard on the armored truck that was robbed in January 1988. ``I used my gambling system, but I lost it all,'' said the letter, postmarked in suburban Inglewood and sent to The News Journal in Wilmington, Del. ``We're still looking for him,'' an FBI official in Los Angeles said, according to the Los Angeles Times today. The letter states that Hunt wishes to surrender to authorities at the Los Angeles Chamber of Commerce on Jan. 20, the second anniversary of the robbery. Enclosed was a photograph showing a picture of a shaggy-haired Hunt emerging from a swimming pool at a hotel or apartment. Federal agents who have been looking for Hunt since the 1988 robbery say they're pretty sure the letter is legitimate. ``As far as we're concerned at this point, they both look valid _ the letter and the photo,'' said FBI Agent John Kundts in Philadelphia. People familiar with Hunt identified the handwriting as his, according to News Journal editors. ``I have a good story for your newspaper,'' Hunt wrote in his letter dated Dec. 20. ``I am one of the most wanted criminals in the United States,'' he said, describing the crime. ``For this crime I was featured twice on the national TV show, `America's Most Wanted.''' The 26-year-old said he planned to surrender because he missed his family and wanted to come clean. He said he was sorry about the crime. The fugitive's father, Edward Leigh Hunt, Sr., a deputy attorney general in Delaware from 1973 to 1975, said he was sure the photograph was of his son. Police initially believed Hunt had been abducted, but he soon became the primary suspect. A federal grand jury in Philadelphia indicted Hunt on April 26, 1988, on interstate theft. ``Absent any information to the contrary, we would certainly intend to be there at the appointed hour,'' Kundts said of Hunt's apparent offer to surrender. Susan Pasternak, a spokeswoman at the Los Angeles Area Chamber of Commerce, said Monday she had no idea why the fugitive would want to surrender there. ``And the 20th is a Saturday,'' she said ``We're normally closed on Saturdays.''

DOC.HEAD: Sources Say Government Preparing to Lift Martial Law
DOC.TEXT: Chinese leaders were preparing today to end martial law in Tiananmen Square, the cradle of the crushed pro-democracy movement, and possibly lift the restrictions elsewhere in the capital, sources said. The end of the 7-month-old emergency would be mainly symbolic because troops already have been withdrawn from city streets. It would not mean greater freedom of dissent, because most activities banned under martial law, such as anti-government demonstrations and speeches, are illegal under other laws. However, Communist authorities hope it will reassure foreign governments and the World Bank that stability has been restored and that soft loans should be restored. The loans were frozen in June after troops cleared the city center of pro-democracy protesters, killing hundreds of unarmed civilians. Authorities also hope that an end to martial law will reassure foreign tourists, few of whom have come since martial law was imposed. The action was to be announced at midnight (11 a.m. EST), said Chinese sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. It may be directed in particular at the United States, where it would enable President Bush to tell critics that his softening of sanctions against China had a positive effect. A Western diplomat in Hong Kong linked it to U.S. National Security Advisor Brent Scowcroft's controversial December visit to Beijing. When Premier Li Peng announced martial law in central Beijing on May 20 for the first time in the 40-year history of the People's Republic, he said it was necessary to stem massive pro-democracy protests led by students. However, the protests were not halted until the army came into the city shooting on June 3-4, bent on dispersing students camped out in Tiananmen, a massize square that is the symbolic seat of power in China. Martial law forbids marches, strikes, class boycotts, public speeches, distributing pamphlets, spreading rumors and other ``destructive activity.'' It also gives soldiers and police authority to take any measures necessary to maintain order. However, a law passed in November outlaws all but pro-government demonstrations and authorizes security forces to stop illegal protests. In addition, the constitution prohibits ``disruption of the socialist system,'' giving the government broad authority to curb any dissent. Chinese sources said the government canceled plans to lift martial law in December after the popular uprising in Romania ousted hard-line Communist leader Nicolae Ceausescu. Students at several Beijing campuses put up illegal posters ridiculing Ceausescu and Chinese leaders, and tried to demonstrate on campus. Tens of thousands of soldiers were brought into Beijing in response and were put on top alert. They remained mostly out of sight, in keeping with a gradual reduction of the military profile in the city since the summer. On Oct. 31, authorities withdrew troops from key intersections and replaced them in Tiananmen Square with People's Armed Police, a special force that guards government installations. Soldiers remain billeted inside the Museum of Revolutionary History on the east side of the square, and have been seen drilling inside the former imperial palace grounds north of the square. They also remain camped in dozens of military compounds in and around the city. Plainclothes police also have been seen in greater numbers on campuses.

DOC.HEAD: Cosmonauts Take 3-Hour Space Walk to Install Equipment
DOC.TEXT: During a three-hour space walk, cosmonauts at the Mir orbiting complex installed equipment to improve their craft's navigation system, the official Tass news agency said today. Cosmonauts Alexander Viktorenko and Alexander Serebrov were in good health after completing the mission early today, Tass said, adding that installation of the two ``stellar transducers'' was a success. Radio Moscow said the new sensors were required because of the docking last month of another research module that changed the configuration of the Mir complex to an L-shape. That made a new orientation system necessary, it said. Viktorenko and Serebrov have been aboard the Mir complex since September, when they remanned it after it had been left empty for six months while new experiments were being prepared. Radio Moscow said the cosmonauts have four more space walks on their schedule before they return to Earth in mid-February.

DOC.HEAD: Winds Whip Western States
DOC.TEXT: More heavy rain and high wind battered the Northwest today after a series of Western storms derailed a 35-car train, knocked down giant trees and sheared roofs from buildings, causing millions of dollars in damage. Heavy snow, meanwhile, coated parts of the mid-Atlantic region today. The Western storms were blamed for at least three deaths. Sustained hurricane-force winds sweeping over the Rockies blew trucks off roads. ``The air just screamed down out of the mountains,'' said meteorologist Jim Wirshborn. In Washington, Oregon and Idaho, forecasters said the latest storm was not expected to be as severe as its predecessors. The National Weather Service said the storm came ashore along the central Oregon coast early this morning, with gusts up to 64 mph at Cape Blanco. Urban flood warnings were issued this morning for Vancouver, Wash., and Portland, Ore., because of wind-strewn debris clogging drains. ``This place looks like Hurricane Hugo struck us,'' said Carol Cubbage of West Linn, Ore. On one street, 14 huge trees toppled, smashing three houses in a row. ``It has been years since I've seen Douglas fir trees that big that were literally uprooted,'' said Gary Donnelly, a spokesman for Pacific Power & Light Co. ``Some of them were 4 and 5 feet in diameter.'' Throughout the Northwest, parked cars, mobile homes and buildings were damaged by falling trees. Several highways were closed temporarily Monday because of tipped over trailers, debris and mudslides. By Monday afternoon, 25,000 damage claims for an estimated $12.5 million had been filed with four major Northwest insurance carriers, the Western Insurance Information Service said. ``The damage is widespread,'' said spokeswoman Marianne Macina. The region was buffeted by sustained winds of up to 70 mph. A 130 mph gust was clocked on Rattlesnake Hill, north of Pasco, Wash., near the Hanford nuclear reservation. More than 5,000 customers remained without electricity in Washington state and Oregon. Mapleton, about 15 miles inland from the Oregon coast, received 8.1 inches of rain from Saturday to Monday. At least six small airplanes that were parked at regional airports in Prosser, Walla Walla and Pullman, Wash., were damaged or destroyed by winds. Scores of windows were blown out of buildings and dozens of large trees were toppled Monday at Washington State University at Pullman and eight miles away at the University of Idaho in Moscow. Officials estimated damage at up to $100,000 at each university. In southwest Portland, a power outage Monday caused a spill of an estimated 128,000 gallons of sewage into Fanno Creek, while about 150,000 gallons of sewage spilled from a treatment plant in Toledo into Yaquina Bay before the spill was stopped. High winds without rain whipped across the Rockies and were expected to continue through the week. In Colorado, gusts reached 110 mph in Boulder and 108 mph near Fort Collins on Monday, the weather service said. The wind tore roofs from buildings in Fort Collins, Boulder and Colorado Springs, and blew semi tractor-trailers off roads in Colorado Springs and Boulder. Strong winds in southeastern Wyoming blew off part of a high school gymnasium roof Monday, a day after a strong gust knocked a nearly empty 35-car freight train off its tracks. No injuries were reported. In northwestern Wyoming, a storm dumped more than 1 foot of snow in the mountains by late Monday. Cheyenne Central High School students taking a physical education class were in the gym at about 2 p.m. when the wind ripped a 4-by-4-foot hole in the roof. No injuries were reported. The storms were blamed for the death of a 21-year-old man who died Monday when his car slammed into a truck stopped in a dust cloud on a road near Big Springs, Neb. An 11-year-old girl was struck and killed Sunday by a falling tree in Yachats, Ore. A 23-year-old man died in a car crash on a rain-slickened road in Benton County, Ore. On the East Coast, fist-size snowflakes coated parts of Virginia, West Virginia and Pennsylvania with at least 4 inches of snow _ up to 9 inches in the mountains. Lesser snowfall was reported in New York's Catskills mountains.

DOC.HEAD: Khmer Rouge Guerrillas Claim Attack On Capital Drives Leaders To Vietnam
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf `The agency said...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with Australian envoy arriving in Bangkok, denies meeting Hun Sen was moved due to attack. Picks up 10th pvs, `The guerrillas earlier...'
DOC.TEXT: Khmer Rouge guerrillas claimed today that they sent Cambodia's president and premier fleeing to Vietnam with a grenade attack on the capital in which soldiers and policemen were killed. The reported attack Saturday would be the most serious in Phnom Penh, largely spared in the 11-year-old war between the guerrillas and the Vietnamese-installed government. It could not be verified and some previous communist Khmer Rouge claims have proven exaggerated. Also today, the non-communist resistance forces of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, allies of the Khmer Rouge, said their agents exploded a grenade a day in the capital between Dec. 5 and 10, wounding 16 Vietnamese and two Cambodian policemen. A statement said one attack occurred near Premier Hun Sen's house and others in front of the Royal Palace and the Ministry of Defense. The government's SPK news agency, monitored in Bangkok today, did not mention any attack but stressed that Sunday's National Day celebrations took place in ``total security.'' It said Saturday and Monday also were peaceful. National Day marks the anniversary of the 1979 downfall of the Khmer Rouge, which was driven out by invading Vietnamese troops after a 3{-year reign of terror in which it tried to turn the country into a primitive agrarian commune, killing hundreds of thousands of Cambodians. SPK denied reports that a lack of security in the capital had forced Hun Sen to go to the eastern province of Svay Rieng to meet with Australia's deputy foreign secretary, Michael Costello, on Sunday and Monday. The agency said Hun Sen was making an inspection tour of the province bordering Vietnam and had invited Costello to meet him there. Costello told reporters upon arriving in Bangkok today that the meeting took place and was arranged for Svay Rieng ``well before'' the alleged Khmer Rouge attacks. He could not confirm the attacks. The guerrillas earlier had said they attacked and set ablaze Cambodia's second-largest city, Battambang, Friday and Saturday. A Western diplomat in Thailand confirmed today that the town was attacked but said ``the effect was more psychological than strategic.'' Khmer Rouge army radio said resistance forces had lobbed five grenades in the center of Phnom Penh near the office of the Central Committee of the Communist Party, killing or wounding some Vietnamese and ``lackey puppets.'' It said the attack took place at 2 a.m. Saturday. Another Khmer Rouge army broadcast said the guerrillas, aided by citizens and government officials, attacked the capital's center and suburbs Saturday with ``32 grenades and TNT plastic explosives, killing or wounding some Vietnamese soldiers and puppets who were drinking near a hotel.'' ``A number of Vietnamese secret agents and puppet policemen ... were also killed by blasts from the grenades and plastic explosives in the suburbs,'' it said. The broadcast claimed Vietnam ``immediately sent Hun Sen and (President) Heng Samrin as well as some other leaders to Ho Chi Minh City.'' The city, formerly Saigon, is about 35 miles east of the border at Svay Rieng. The broadcast said Hun Sen later went to Svay Rieng for his scheduled talks with Costello. ``The Vietnamese dared not allow Hun Sen to see Costello in Phnom Penh because of security reasons,'' it said. SPK said Monday that Hun Sen had agreed with Australia's proposal for a U.N. role in an interim administration in Cambodia before a general election _ but only if the U.N. seat held by the guerrilla coalition is first vacated. The Khmer Rouge fields about 30,000 fighters and is the largest of three guerrilla groups in a resistance coalition. Fears of a possible return to power of the Khmer Rouge have increased as they have made major battlefield advances since Vietnam in September made what it called the withdrawal of its last troops from Cambodia. The Khmer Rouge radio said the guerrillas would keep fighting and attacking the capital until an international authority verifies Vietnam's withdrawal and a coalition government including the Heng Samrin government and the three guerrilla groups is formed. In Paris on Monday, diplomatic sources said representatives of the U.N. Security Council's five permanent members would meet there on Jan. 15 to consider ways to bring peace to Cambodia. The Khmer Rouge seized the rich gem-mining town of Pailin in western Battambang province bordering Thailand on Oct. 22. They claimed they hit Battambang town starting at midnight Friday, attacking military posts there and in Banteay Meanchey and western Pursat province. Fighting still raged at dawn Saturday, said a guerrilla radio broadcast Sunday. In an interview broadcast over state radio Sunday, Cambodia's defense minister Gen. Tea Banh admitted that guerrillas are advancing in areas near the Thai border, and said his forces are abandoning some places to concentrate defenses in major towns and roads. ``To be sincere, we have lost some positions,'' he said. ``We cannot stay in every village. We have to abandon some and keep some strategic ones.'' He did not mention fighting in Phnom Penh or in Battambang.

DOC.HEAD: Semiconductor Makers Cutting 1-Megabit Memory Chip Production
DOC.TEXT: Leading Japanese semiconductor makers said today that they plan 10 percent to 15 percent cuts in production of key 1-megabit memory chips because of falling prices and lower demand. Demand for 1-megabit dynamic random-access memory chips, or DRAMs, has fallen in recent months, in large part because of stagnant sales of personal computers in the United States, company officials said. A 1-megabit chip, currently a mainstay of the computer industry, can store about 1 million binary units of information, the equivalent of about four newspaper pages. An official at NEC Corp., the world's largest semiconductor maker, said his company has decided to reduce production from 6 million chips to about 5 million chips a month in the first quarter of this year. ``With the price for a 1-megabit DRAM falling from around $24 last summer to $9.70 today, NEC has decided to downshift production,'' he said. Although computer sales in Japan have remained stronger than in the United States, prices of 1-megabit DRAMs also have fallen here, from $14 to about $10.50. The semiconductor industry is known for its sharp business cycles. During a 1985-86 industry recession, Japanese makers, suffering from overcapacity, lost an estimated $4 billion and began a series of price cuts that led to charges of dumping overseas. An Oki Electric official said his company plans to reduce its production of 1-megabit DRAMs this quarter from 3.5 million chips to fewer than 3 million chips a month. Hitachi's production has fallen from 4 million chips to about 3.8 million chips a month, while Mitsubishi Electric's monthly production has fallen from about 5 million chips to between 4 million and 4.5 million chips, company officials said. A Hitachi official said further cuts were possible if the market continues to weaken. Fujitsu officials declined to comment on their production plans. A Toshiba Corp. official said production in the first quarter will fall from the current 9 million chips a month to below 8 million chips but could pick up again in the second quarter in response to a resurgence in demand. But the Mitsubishi Electric official, who like the other officials spoke on condition of anonymity, predicted that a recovery of the DRAM market would not occur until later, possibly after the end of summer. Japan produced 85 percent of the world's 1-megabit DRAM chips in 1988, according to Dataquest, a U.S. research firm. U.S. firms accounted for 8 percent of production, South Korean companies 4 percent and European makers 3 percent, it said. The figures do not include International Business Machines, which produces memory chips mainly for its own use.

DOC.HEAD: Hospital Negligence Caused Deadly Needle Prick, AIDS Doctor Contends
LaserPhoto NY11
DOC.TEXT: The case of a young physician who claims she contracted AIDS because of a hospital's negligence is one that cannot be won, no matter what the jury decides in her $175 million lawsuit, her lawyer told the court. ``This nightmare will end with her death,'' Diane Wilner, attorney for Dr. Veronica Prego, said in opening arguments. ``Ultimately, there can be no happy ending.'' Prego, appearing drawn and distraught, watched quietly Monday as Wilner described her to the state court jury as a promising young doctor whose life and career hopes were prematurely ended when she pricked her finger with an AIDS-tainted needle on Jan. 12, 1983. Prego, now 32, was a 25-year-old medical-school graduate working under a licensed physician in preparation for a hospital internship when she was cleaning up after a supervising intern, Dr. Joyce Fogel, at the Kings County Hospital. The lawyer said Prego reached into a tangle of gauze and bed linens in which Fogel had left a bloody, infected needle. ``As she was picking up the remaining garbage, she got stuck by a needle,'' Wilner said. ``That needle is the instrument of death.'' Prego is suing the city's Health and Hospitals Corp., the hospital and Fogel and another doctor, charging their negligence caused her to contract acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Testimony was scheduled to continue today. Stanley D. Friedman, the lawyer for the health agency, did not dispute that Prego had been pricked by a needle, but questioned her memory of the details and said the accident was caused by her carelessness, not Fogel's. Friedman maintains Prego, not Fogel, withdrew the blood from the AIDS patient, who died a few days later, and then carelessly ``grabbed'' a handful of soiled hospital waste holding the infected needle. ``Do we have to train somebody not to grab?'' he asked. ``She wasn't requested to pick up anything by anybody.'' Prego, who graduated from medical school in her native Argentina, argues that the hospital failed to provide proper containers for soiled needles. The agency claims the hospital was in the forefront of following precautions against a disease that doctors knew little about in the early 1980s. Prego tested positive for HIV _ the AIDS virus _ in 1985 when she agreed to take part in a study. Two years later, she came down with AIDS and nearly died, Wilner said. Prego, who refuses to talk to reporters about her case, intends to testify. The trial is expected to take at least a month.

DOC.HEAD: Prague Thinks Soviet Troops Should Leave By Year's End
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union's estimated 80,000 troops in Czechoslovakia, deployed after the 1968 Warsaw Pact invasion, should pull out by the end of this year, a foreign ministry spokesman said today. ``I suggest that the Soviet troops should withdraw from Czechoslovakia by the end of 1990,'' spokesman Lubos Dobrovsky was quoted by the state news agency CTK as telling journalists. The spokesman was not immediately available to confirm the comment. Czechoslovakia's new foreign minister, former dissident Jiri Dienstbier, returned from Moscow last month saying the Soviets and Czechoslovaks will open talks this month on withdrawing the Soviet troops in Czechoslovakia. They entered the country during the Soviet-led invasion that crushed the ``Prague Spring'' reforms in August 1968 and have since remained under agreements that the new coalition government in Czechoslovakia considers null and void. The agreements were signed in August and October of 1968 after the invasion, which has now been condemned by the Soviet Union and the four other Warsaw Pact nations who took part. Czechoslovakia considers the agreements were ``null and void from the very beginning,'' Dobrovsky was quoted as saying by CTK, which gave no further details of his comments.

DOC.HEAD: Army Says Female MP Rushed to Scene When Firing Started
DOC.NOTE: EDS: adds graf of additional material from LA Times story
DOC.TEXT: Military officials say a female captain praised for leading a unit into combat in Panama was a half-mile away at the start of the fight but gave the critical orders and rushed to the scene when the firing began. The Los Angeles Times had published a Saturday story that the Army said news accounts of Capt. Linda Bray's involvement in the battle _ at a Panamanian Defense Forces kennel _ ``later repeated by White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, were grossly exaggerated.'' In an interview Monday, Gen. William McClain said Bray had been in her tactical command center, directing her troops by radio, and that she went to the scene as soon as she was aware fighting had broken out. ``Her job was to direct her forces and to accomplish her objective and that's what she did,'' McClain said. ``If she's in radio contact, and gave the order for the warning shot to be fired, that's leading your troops.'' Bray's involvement as commander of the 988th Military Police Co. got front-page attention last week, based on accounts from Panama followed by Fitzwater's praise at the White House. President Bush spoke Friday of her ``heroic performance.'' The incident prompted calls for the removal of restrictions on women in combat, and Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., said she would propose legislation to that end. Various news accounts, including one carried by The Associated Press, quoted soldiers as saying Bray had led her unit into battle, storming the gates of the kennel in an armored jeep. News accounts of the battle's duration have ranged from a half-hour or so up to three hours. An account of the incident released by the Pentagon runs from 1 a.m. until daylight, but doesn't directly address the exact time of the firefight. Pentagon spokeswoman Maj. Kathy Wood made available a description of the mission involving Bray, which states that she ordered a warning shot to be fired 30 seconds after a Spanish-speaking U.S. officer announced over a loudspeaker that the occupants of the PDF barracks should surrender. The captain then ordered machine-gun fire against the side of the building, away from its occupants, and the PDF fired on the military police unit, the account said. After the Spanish-speaking officer used the loudspeaker to bluff that the military police had artillery, the PDF forces retreated from the building and continued to fire at the MPs from a nearby wooded area, the account said. Bray ordered flares to light the area and then ordered her officers to clear the area around the building, it said. The area was declared more secure at daylight and Bray's troops were ordered to pull back, the account said. At one point, Wood added, Bray ordered the driver of her armored jeep to run over the barracks' gate so that she could get closer to her troops. The Times story said, ``It was not clear how the inflated account of Bray's exploits began.'' It said she was interviewed extensively by her superiors after questiosn were raised about the initial press accounts and denied being the source of the more elaborate reports of her unit's action.

DOC.HEAD: More Wind, Rain for Northwest; Snow, Freezing Rain in East
DOC.TEXT: Snow and freezing rain slapped the East Coast from southern New England to the Appalachians today. The Pacific Northwest got more wet, windy weather. Charleston, W.Va., got 7 inches of new snow, but was expected to melt today as temperatures rose into the 50s. Up to 4 inches of snow was expected today in the Catskills and New York's lower Hudson Valley. Winter weather advisories for snow mixed with freezing rain were posted in inland Massachusetts and Rhode Island, and in much of Connecticut and Pennsylvania. Continued high winds and up to 3 inches of rain were expected today in Northern California, the Oregon coast and western Montana. Wind gusts to 64 mph were reported early today along the central Oregon coast, while winds of up to 50 mph were forecast in Wyoming and Colorado. An urban flood warning for today was called in Portland, Ore., and Vancouver, Wash. Drainage was slowed by debris from weekend wind storms. High wind warnings were posted for the upper Yellowstone Valley of south-central Montana and northeast Colorado. In Colorado, winds gusted Monday to 108 mph at Masonville, near Fort Collins, and to 104 mph at the Winter Park ski area. Gusty winds damaged trees and utility lines from southwest Wyoming to Pullman, Wash. Advisories for blowing and drifting snow were called for Colorado's northern and central mountains. Rain continued today over northeastern North Carolina and eastern Virginia. Rain mixed with snow extended from Maryland to southern New England. Rain also fell on parts of Iowa, western Oregon and northwest California. Michigan and Wisconsin expected several inches of snow today. New high temperatures for Jan. 8 set on Monday included 45 in Duluth, Minn.; 46 in Eau Claire, Wisc. and St. Cloud, Minn.; 58 in Ely, Nev.; 64 in Reno, Nev.; 68 in Stockton, Calif.; 69 in Sacramento, Calif., and 86 in Ft. Lauderdale and Miami, Fla. Monday's highest temperature in Lower 48 states was 87 in West Palm Beach, Fla. Scotts Bluff, Neb.'s Jan. 8 record high of 62 degrees _ set 93 years ago _ was tied near noon. Three hours later, a cold front moved through, dragging the mercury to 43 degrees. Other reports at 3 a.m. EST today: _EAST: Albany, N.Y. 26 cloudy; Atlanta 39 foggy; Boston 36 cloudy; Buffalo 37; Charleston, S.C. 49 cloudy; Chattanooga 34 fair; Cincinnati 39 partly cloudy; Cleveland 37 partly cloudy; Detroit 37 cloudy; Hatteras 42 cloudy; Jacksonville 47 partly cloudy; Key West 69 fair; Knoxville 32 fair; Macon 40 fair; Miami 68 fair; New York 36 partly cloudy; Philadelphia 32 fair; Pittsburgh 31 partly cloudy; Portland, Maine 33 cloudy; Richmond 32 foggy; Tampa 53 fair; Washington, D.C. 34 fair. _CENTRAL: Birmingham 33 fair; Bismarck 31 cloudy; Chicago 40 cloudy; Denver 45 fair; Des Moines 39 cloudy; Fort Worth 50; Indianapolis 41 cloudy; Kansas City 49 cloudy; Little Rock 49 partly cloudy; Louisville 44 cloudy; Memphis 45 partly cloudy; Nashville 39 fair; New Orleans 44 foggy; North Platte 42 fair; Oklahoma City 49 partly cloudy; Omaha 41 partly cloudy; Rapid City 39 windy; St. Louis 50 cloudy; Minneapolis-St. Paul 36 partly cloudy; Sault Ste. Marie 30 foggy; San Antonio 42 fair. _WEST: Albuquerque 43 fair; Anchorage -1 partly cloudy; Boise 44 cloudy; Casper 29 fair; Fairbanks -28 fair; Great Falls 38 cloudy; Honolulu 71 cloudy; Las Vegas 42 fair; Los Angeles 54 foggy; Medford 39 foggy; Pendleton 50 cloudy; Phoenix 50 fair; Portland, Ore. 56 rain; Reno 33 fair; Salt Lake City 37 cloudy; San Diego 54 foggy; San Francisco 55 cloudy; Seattle 45 rain; Spokane 38 rain. _INTERNATIONAL: Calgary 28 partly cloudy; Montreal 23 partly cloudy; Ottawa 28 cloudy; Regina 21 foggy; Toronto 34 cloudy; Winnipeg 16 cloudy; San Juan 74.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Faults Timing of Dispatch of Ships
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 6 grafs new with Sen. Kerry remarks on TV; picks up at pvs 2nd graf, The aircraft
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Senate narcotics and terrorism subcommittee said today the Bush administration used bad judgment in dispatching ships to Colombia to fight drugs so soon after it invaded Panama. However, Sen. John Kerry, D-Mass., said he believes it is appropriate for the U.S. Navy to play a role off the Colombian coast at the right time. Reacting to opposition from Latin American nations, the administration said Monday is it postponing plans to position ships off the Colombian coast. ``Now it's on hold and I think that's appropriate,'' Kerry said on the ``CBS This Morning'' show. ``I think clearly the administration made a mistake in moving unilaterally and I think also the timing immediately post-Panama was difficult.'' He said is was ``very complicated'' from the standpoint of internal Colombian politics for the United States to be making such moves at the present time. ``On the other hand I don't think it's inappropriate for the United States to seek to implement better surveillance of flights and of traffic within the region,'' said Kerry. ``I just think the process has to be worked out more effectively.'' The aircraft carrier USS John F. Kennedy and the cruiser USS Virginia maneuvered in the Atlantic off the Florida coast Monday in a visible symbol of the diplomatic circling occurring in Washington and Bogota. Administration officials said their future deployment near Colombia would depend on talks with that country's government. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said the administration was still considering use of the Navy to combat drug shipping but she said a blockade is not among the options. ``A blockade would mean shutting down everything, and that, obviously, is not our intention,'' she said. Colombian officials had accused the United States of moving toward a naval and air blockade over the weekend after reports that the carrier group had left port and was preparing to take part in sea-based actions against drug trafficking. But a statement issued Monday by the Colombian Embassy said the United States had said it would not interfere with Colombian flag ships, even on the high seas, without the permission of Colombian Defense Ministry. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater, traveling with President Bush on a trip to Orlando, Fla., said no agreement had been reached in preliminary discussions and praised the Colombian government for its cooperation on earlier occasions. Meanwhile, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney plans to unveil the administration's plans for military involvement in the anti-drug battle next week. In Denver, Cheney told reporters that although U.S. laws limit the role the military can play in drug enforcement in this country ``we do have the capability ... to help identify drug traffickers trying to smuggle drugs to the United States.'' Cheney said that U.S. ships can interdict vessels suspected of carrying drugs from Latin America in international waters but that the United States will not take naval action without the cooperation of other nation's in the region.

DOC.HEAD: Cases Could Affect Affirmative Action Programs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 10th graf, Shurberg, of, to correct town to Rocky Hill sted Rock Hill
DOC.TEXT: All federal affirmative action programs, from education to employment, could be affected as the Supreme Court studies special preferences given to TV and radio stations owned by women and minorities. ``We can count heads at the Supreme Court, and we're confident these FCC policies will fall,'' said Alan Shurberg, a computer consultant involved in one of two cases the court accepted for review Monday. ``Government will be left with a colorblind standard,'' Shurberg said. The justices said they would use a Florida case to review the Federal Communications Commission's policy of treating ownership by women and minorities as a favorable factor when awarding licenses. The court also voted to review, in a Connecticut case, the commission's policy of allowing any station facing a license revocation to sell its license, at a reduced price, to a minority-owned company. Different three-judge panels of the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here upheld the licensing preferences policy, but struck down the so-called distress sale program. ``Those of us concerned about diversity in society are concerned about what the court may do with these cases,'' said Andrew Jay Schwartzman of the Washington-based Media Access Project. The court's decisions, he said, could be worded broadly enough to affect government programs beyond the broadcasting industry. ``But exploring the importance of minority ownership in the mass media _ and the significant role diversity in the media plays _ is a good way for the court to review those issues,'' he said. Shurberg, of Rocky Hill, Conn., said he hoped the high court would use the two cases to ``put an end to all affirmative action.'' He said his confidence was boosted by recent Supreme Court decisions that have curtailed what steps governments may take to make up for past discriminatory practices. Decisions in the two cases are expected by July. The federal government, as have state and local governments, for years has adopted numerous programs aimed at giving special help to members of groups traditionally made the targets of bias. For example, those companies doing business with the federal government must certify that they make good-faith efforts to integrate their workforces. Another example is Congress' setting aside a fixed percentage of all federal public works contracts for minority-owned companies. In other action, the court: _Agreed to decide in a Minnesota case whether governors may withhold National Guard troops the federal government wants to send on training missions in foreign countries. _Refused in a case from New York to force a revival of the ``fairness doctrine,'' under which the federal government could require radio and television stations to present all sides of controversial issues. _Let stand a ruling in an Iowa case that people have no constitutionally protected right of privacy in the conversations they have while using cordless telephones. _Refused to reinstate a $9.4 million award, won and then lost, by the family of a Texas woman whose husband hired her killer through an ad in Soldier of Fortune magazine. _Agreed to decide in a case stemming from a 1972 Idaho silver mine disaster that killed 91 people whether labor unions may be sued in state courts for failure to assure safe conditions. _Turned down the appeal of a Tennessee high school student pulled from a race for student council president after giving a speech officials deemed disrespectful.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Separatists Kill Officer; Police Fatally Shoot Two Demonstrators
DOC.TEXT: Officials in the northern state of Jammu-Kashmir said Moslem separatists fatally shot a police officer today, and witnesses said police opened fire to disperse Moslem demonstrators in Srinagar, killing two people. The separatists also set fire to government buildings to protest alleged police brutality, officials said. Authorities clamped an indefinite curfew on Srinagar and three other towns and called out the army to prevent further violence, a state government spokesman said. The spokesman, who cannot be identified under briefing rules, said 15 people were killed today and Monday but he did not give any breakdown of the deaths. On Monday, at least 14 people were killed and more than 100 injured when police opened fire on demonstrators in Srinagar and the neighboring town of Sopore, witnesses said. At least one of the injured people died of their wounds today, they said. Chief Secretary Moosa Raza, the state's top civil servant, said an inspector from the intelligence wing of the police was shot and killed by Moslem militants in Bureava, 19 miles west of Srinagar. In Bandipur, 28 miles north of Srinagar, demonstrators set two government buildings ablaze, he said. Scores of people have been killed in the state in recent weeks as police cracked down on Moslems seeking independence for the Kashmir region of the state or union with neighboring Pakistan. Jammu-Kashmir state is the only state with a Moslem majority in India, where 82 percent of the national population of 880 million is Hindu. India and predominantly Moslem Pakistan have fought three wars over Kashmir since both gained independence in 1947. Part of Kashmir is under Pakistan's control. A cease-fire line monitored by the United Nations divides the region into Indian and Pakistani sectors. Moslems comprise 64 percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 5 million people. The Kashmir part of the state is mostly Moslem, while the Jammu section is mostly Hindu. Nationwide, Moslems account for about 12 percent of India's population. Srinagar is the summer capital of the state and Jammu, 95 miles to the south, is the winter capital.

DOC.HEAD: At Least Six Killed In Clash Between Striking And Non-Striking Rail Workers
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE injury figure, ADD transport company official's comment, ADDS that company has not offered wage increase. Pickup penultimate graf pvs, The strike...
DOC.TEXT: Six men were killed and at least 31 were injured today when hundreds of striking and non-striking rail workers battled with clubs, machetes, and other weapons at a train station near Johannesburg, police said. Union spokesmen said they received reports of more than 20 people killed and more than 60 injured. The reports could not be confirmed. Bodies still lay in blood-soaked train cars two hours after the clash. Rocks, sticks and homemade weapons were strewn around the cars and the platform. It was by far the worst incident of violence during the 10-week strike by black workers against the white-led government's transport company. About 10 people have been killed in previous strike-related incidents and several dozen railway cars have been destroyed in arson attacks. The union accused non-strikers of an unprovoked attack on strikers with clubs, knives, machetes and rocks. A police spokesman, Col. Frans Malherbe, said the battle involved about 1,000 black men still working for South African Transport Services who confronted about 800 strikers in Germiston, an industrial town southeast of Johannesburg. The strikers had arrived at the station by train on their way to a union meeting. Malherbe said police officers dispersed the combatants with tear gas after the battle raged 45 minutes. The Congress of South African Trade Unions, a militant labor federation to which the strikers are affiliated, said police should have intervened sooner. But Malherbe said uniformed officers standing by during the early stages of the battle probably were railway security guards, not police. About 25,000 workers went on strike against South African Transport Services in early November, demanding their minimum monthly wage be increased from $225 to $560. The strikers also are demanding formal recognition of their union, the South African Railway and Harbor Workers Union, which has been excluded from contract talks. Negotiations opened last week for the first time since the start of the strike. More than 22,000 strikers have been fired and the union is demanding their unconditional reinstatement. The company has said it would re-hire half the fired workers and allow an arbitrator to determine if any others had been fired unfairly. It has not offered a wage increase. Leon Els, chief spokesman for the transport company, said the clash made it ``imperative'' that the union respond to management's latest proposals. He said the company was taking steps ``at the worker level'' to prevent further clashes. The strike is illegal under legislation that bars industrial action against essential services. The transport company employees a total of about 170,000 people, and runs rail and harbor operations nationwide. Whites hold the vast majority of management positions in the company.

DOC.HEAD: Green Line Skirmishes in Beirut, Truce Holds In Shiite War
DOC.TEXT: Christian army units and Syrian-backed Moslem militiamen clashed today in Beirut, but a cease-fire between rival Shiite Moslem militias held for a second day in south Lebanon. Police said there were no casualties in the 10-minute exchange of rocket-propelled grenades and sniper fire along Beirut's Green Line, which divides the capital's Moslem and Christian sectors. It was the latest violation of a truce between the Christian army and Syrian-backed fighters. The cease-fire, called Sept. 22 by the Arab League, halted six months of ferocious artillery duels between Christian army Gen. Michel Aoun's troops and the Syrian army. That round of fighting in Lebanon's 14-year-old civil war killed 929 people and wounded 2,744. A police spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said four people have been killed and 12 wounded in skirmishes along the three-mile Green Line since Saturday. All but one of the casualties were civilians, police said. In southern Lebanon, rival Shiite Moslem militias withheld fire while an Iranian envoy struggled to arrange a settlement to the inter-Shiite fighting that has killed 94 people and wounded 275 since Dec. 23. Fighting in southern Iqlim al-Tuffah province eased Monday when the pro-Iranian Hezbollah and Syrian-backed Amal militias agreed to a seven-hour cease-fire to allow the Red Cross to evacuate bodies from 17 days of fighting. Iran's deputy foreign minister, Mohammad Ali Besharati, held separate talks with Amal and Hezbollah officials at the Iranian Embassy in Moslem west Beirut, seeking a way to end the groups' war for dominance of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites. In the eastern Bekaa valley, Israel's allied militia, the South Lebanon Army, fired artillery rounds into bases of Syrian-backed Palestinian and leftist Lebanese guerrillas in the villages of Sultan Yacoub, Luci and Kamed el-Louz. Police said two villagers were wounded. The Bekaa has long been a launching pad for guerrilla raids into Israel's self-designated ``security zone'' in south Lebanon. The 2,500-member South Lebanon Army and an estimated 1,500 Israeli troops patrol the enclave along the southern border. Israel set up the buffer in 1985 to guard against cross-border guerrilla raids.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Try to Thwart Defense in Hacker Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Opening arguments begin at 10 a.m.
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors hope to limit evidence about Robert T. Morris' state of mind at the graduate student's trial on charges of setting loose a ``worm'' program that crippled a national computer network. Opening arguments were to begin today in the federal court case. The suspended Cornell University student from Arnold, Md., is the first person brought to trial under the 1986 Computer Fraud and Abuse Act. If convicted, Morris, 24, faces up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Prosecutors allege Morris designed and set loose on Nov. 2, 1988, a program that replicated wildly, immobilizing an estimated 6,000 computers linked to the Internet research computer network, including those at NASA and Air Force facilities. Before a jury was seated Monday, Justice Department lawyers filed a motion aimed at thwarting Morris' expected defense that he did not intend to paralyze the computer network. The government asked U.S. District Judge Howard Munson to limit examination of witnesses on Morris' state of mind, specifically whether he intended cause any loss or damage. ``Evidence that Morris designed earlier versions of the computer virus (which were not launched) are relevant to the charges,'' the government said. ``The evidence of lack of intent to cause loss, or lack of intent to prevent the authorized use of the victim computers, however, is simply not relevant to any issue in this case,'' said the Justice Department papers. Defense attorney Thomas Guidoboni raised the intent question during a pre-trial motion, but Munson rejected Guidoboni's argument that Morris' intentions were pertinent to the legality of the indictment. Morris, who was a first-year doctoral student in computer studies at Cornell, is the son of the chief scientist at the government's National Computer Security Center in Bethesda, Md. A Cornell commission concluded that Morris was guilty of ``reckless disregard'' for creating the program. Although the panel found him responsible, Morris has never publicly admitted creating the worm or unleashing it.

DOC.HEAD: Washington, D.C., Mayor Denies He Ridiculed Jesse Jackson
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs pvs 5th graf, John Brownwell, to make second reference to Brownwell; subs 7th graf, Barry refused, to add that Jackson declined comment
DOC.TEXT: The Los Angeles Times says it has tape recordings of the comments it quoted Mayor Marion Barry making when he ridiculed Jesse Jackson and saying Jackson ``don't wanna run nothing but his mouth.'' Assistant Managing Editor John Brownwell denied in interviews Monday that the newspaper's reporter misquoted Barry in a profile. The Times quoted Barry in the Sunday profile as saying Jackson, a former presidential candidate supported by Barry and now a potential mayoral rival, would become ``the laughingstock of America'' if he ran for mayor of Washington. But Barry told reporters Sunday after attending church, ``I don't understand it. I couldn't possibly have said what they said I said. ... I don't talk like that.'' Brownwell told Washington's WJLA-TV that Barry ``most certainly did make the comments'' and his newspaper ``reported them accurately.'' Brownwell said the reporter who wrote the story used a combination of notes she took while talking to the mayor. Brownell told The Washington Post that Barry made the remarks while talking to the reporter at a local bar. Barry refused Monday to elaborate on his earlier remarks and Jackson declined to comment. ``I'm in the process of reading the article,'' he said. ``I have not read it fully yet. It's a rather long article. After I read it I will put together a very definitive reaction to it.'' Barry was quoted in the article as boasting he was ``invincible'' despite being linked to a series of scandals, and predicting he will get at least 65 percent of the vote in the Democratic mayoral primary this fall. Jackson, who was supported by Barry in his presidential campaigns, moved from Chicago to Washington last year amid speculation he would run for mayor. Jackson has said he would not directly challenge Barry, but he has not flatly ruled out a mayoral bid and some of his remarks have been seen as suggesting Barry should not run for re-election. Sharon Pratt Dixon, former treasurer of the Democratic National Committee who is running against Barry for mayor, said the remarks demonstrated that Barry ``is visibly agitated with Jackson'' and that ``his judgment is not sound.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Head of ACLU Dies at 82
DOC.TEXT: Edward J. Ennis, a former chairman of the American Civil Liberties Union and Justice Department official in charge of enemy aliens during World War II, has died at age 82. Ennis, who died Sunday of diabetes complications at Lenox Hill Hospital, was ACLU general counsel from 1955 to 1969 and president from 1967 to 1977. During his tenure, he called for the impeachment of President Nixon and criticized Nixon's pardon. Ennis was at the Justice Department for 14 years, working as a general counsel to the Immigration and Naturalization Service. As director of the alien enemy control unit from 1941 to 1946, he administered internment and other internal security matters but strongly opposed the internment of about 70,000 Japanese-Americans early in the war. He later testified on behalf of some of the detainees. After graduating from Columbia Law School in 1932, Ennis became an assistant U.S. attorney. He defended the constitutionality of President Roosevelt's New Deal legislation. He is survived by his wife, Marie Joyce. Funeral arrangements were not immediately known.

DOC.HEAD: Communists Say Rough Campaign Ahead; Demonstrations Step Up Pressure
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to ADD East German rightists to compete in elections. Deletes outdated material. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's ruling Communists said today a rough election campaign may be ahead and called for a ``fairness agreement'' among political groups to keep the campaign clean. The Communists, plagued by a wave of resignations, have launched a virtual counteroffensive as they prepare for balloting May 6. Still in control of the nation's media, key meeting places and supplies of such essentials as paper, the Communists have been accused of unfairly exploiting their formidable power. More than 100,000 people demonstrated against them Monday night. The Communist Party newspaper Berliner Zeitung reminded readers today that the various opposition groups are running for the first time, and it claimed many candidates feel the need to virtually shove opponents out of the way. ``All this leads to the fear that it could get especially rough in the coming weeks,'' the Berliner Zeitung said in reference to the campaign. The newspaper's commentary said, however, that such rough going could be kept in check if all sides reach a ``fairness agreement'' specifying campaign conduct. It did not elaborate. ``Experience shows that punches below the belt can't really be avoided through such an agreement, but they can be kept to a tolerable amount,'' Berliner Zeitung continued. The Communists are fighting for their political survival in East Germany, which is plagued by shortages of consumer goods and low worker morale. More than 1,000 East Germans resettle in West Germany each day, joining the 340,000 who reached the West last year alone. East German Communists also reacted angrily to West German television plans to beam election information programs into East Germany. The official party daily Neues Deutschland said that unlike the opposition parties, the Communists will probably by shunned by the West German ``news media armada.'' Opposition groups have accused the Communists of trying to stir up public fears of a resurgence of rightist activity and use it against the opposition parties. In West Berlin, meanwhile, the head of West Germany's extreme rightist Republicans said today that the party's East German members plan to compete in the May election. Republican Party chief Franz Schoenhuber, a former Nazi Waffen SS soldier, told a news conference he estimated the party could receive 10 percent of the vote. The East German leadership has vowed to thwart any attempts by the Republicans or other right-wing extremists to gain a foothold in the country. More than 150,000 people demonstrated Monday night in nine cities to keep up pressure on the Communists. ``Down with the SED!'' protesters in the city of Leipzig chanted, using the initials of the Communist Party. They also called for the ouster of Gregor Gysi, who took over as party chief just one month ago. East Germans ousted hard-line leader Erich Honecker in October in a peaceful popular revolt and have since kept up steady pressure on the Communists to act on promises to build a multiparty democracy. Opposition groups in East Berlin came close to breaking off talks with the Communists on Monday after the government refused to provide full details about whether the dreaded secret police have been disbanded. Opposition delegates ended the day's talks an hour early, demanding unanimously that the government submit a report about internal security at the meeting planned for Jan. 15. Late Monday, the official news agency ADN said that the first indictments against 30 former top-ranking Communists are expected next month, with more investigations being wrapped up in March and April. East Germany has been caught up in a near-frenzy aimed at rooting out corruption and abuse of power under Honecker's leadership. ADN said it could not predict when charges could be expected against Honecker, who also is the target of a criminal probe. ADN said Honecker was undergoing ``stationary medical care,'' a term used to indicate hospitalization. It did not say where the 77-year-old Honecker was being treated.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Stabbed To Death, Accused of Collaborating with Israel
DOC.TEXT: A Palestinian woman was stabbed to death in the occupied Gaza Strip, and slogans that appeared on walls today accused her of collaborating with Israel. Shops throughout the occupied territories were closed by a strike today to mark the start of the 26th month of the Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule. A senior aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Israel needs stronger U.S. assurances that the Palestine Liberation Organization will not be a partner in proposed Israeli-Palestinian peace talks. Yossi Ben-Aharon, director-general of the prime minister's office, also rejected the State Department's call on Israel to rescind its ban on travel abroad by nine pro-PLO activists from the occupied territories, including some believed involved in behind-the-scenes diplomatic efforts. He said there was ``no connection'' between the travel bans and the peace process and said the Palestinians were restricted because they violated security regulations, which he did not specify. Arab reports said masked Palestinians entered the home of Zifra Abu Libda, 36, late Monday and stabbed her repeatedly. They said slogans today on walls in her southern Gaza town of Rafah accused her of collaboration. The army confirmed the death. Her death raised to 167 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs in the uprising. Most have been killed by pro-PLO or Moslem fundamentalist factions for collaboration or involvement in drugs or prostitution. Since the uprising began Dec. 8, 1987, 646 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis, and 43 Israelis have died in the violence. At a government briefing, Ben-Aharon said Israel is ``somewhat uneasy that there is reticence on the part of the United States to say clearly that the PLO will not be involved'' in the peace process. Ben-Aharon said that until such U.S. assurances were given, there was no point in holding a meeting between U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and the foreign ministers of Egypt and Israel. The meeting was to have been the next step in U.S. peacemaking efforts in the Middle East and was to clear the way for preliminary Israeli-Palestinian talks, possibly in Cairo. Israel rejects all contact with the PLO, saying it is a terror organization. Also today, the army said schools for about 320,000 Arab children would open in the West Bank starting Wednesday. Elementary and secondary schools will open Sunday for about 180,000 students in the Gaza Strip, officials said. The schools had been closed for a holiday break, and the army resisted efforts by the United Nations and other groups to resume classes earlier to make up for time lost last year during army-mandated closures. The army closed elementary schools and high schools in the West Bank for much of the 1988-89 school year, contending they were organizing points for the uprising.

DOC.HEAD: Somali President Dismisses Entire Cabinet
DOC.TEXT: President Mohamed Siad Barre of Somalia today fired his entire Cabinet, but officials said he was expected to name an interim government soon. Somalia's Ministry of Information confirmed the dismissals and the anticipated naming of a new Cabinet in a telex message to The Associated Press office in Nairobi. It provided no details and did not say how many seats there are in the Cabinet. Siad Barre, who seized power in a 1969 coup, in recent years has ruled a deteriorating nation beset by tribal rebellions in the north and south, clan warfare, and a bankrupt economy. The president, who is said to be in his 80s, has tried to defuse the growing opposition to his regime by appointing a commission to rewrite the constitution to permit multiparty elections this year. Critics say it is too little too late. Siad Barre's government also has been heavily criticized for alleged human rights abuses, which have prompted Western donors to severely slash aid to the Horn of Africa nation.

DOC.HEAD: ACLU Attacks Violence in Schools
DOC.TEXT: The American Civil Liberties Union, a longtime critic of random sweeps for guns in Detroit schools, now is pushing for locker searches when there is reason to believe a student has a weapon. The local ACLU planned to present its 13-point proposal on stepped-up security tonight to the Detroit school board. ``These aren't all original ideas, but together they constitute a comprehensive approach that can result in less violence and a better learning atmosphere,'' said Leonard L. Grossman, president of the ACLU's metropolitan Detroit branch. ``The ACLU has frequently been looked upon as a bunch of naysayers. We want to be part of the solution as well as raising legitimate constitutional issues.'' Howard Simon, ACLU executive director for Michigan, said endorsing locker searches to confiscate weapons does not contradict the group's stand against random weapons sweeps with metal detectors, a tactic he said doesn't work. Thirty-one guns were confiscated from students between Aug. 28 and Nov. 30, compared with 24 for the same period last year, according to district figures. Simon said the district should intensify individual searches when school security officers have reasonable suspicion that a student has a weapon. The ACLU proposal was developed by a 42-member task force that includes Wayne County Prosecutor John D. O'Hair, several judges, educators and civic and social service leaders. The proposal also calls for classroom lectures on government by legal experts, internships in law offices, alternative schools for students expelled for weapons possession, expansion of a weapons tip hotline and establishment of a committee of students, teachers, administrators, parents and community leaders to review disciplinary codes. School board President Lawrence C. Patrick Jr. said that current efforts to strengthen discipline are working but that he welcomed the ACLU report.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Pictures President Dawn Steel Resigns
DOC.TEXT: Dawn Steel, who attained the highest executive post of any woman in Hollywood history, has resigned as president of Columbia Pictures, saying her creative instincts were underused. The departure of Ms. Steel, 43, had been widely anticipated since Sony Corp. bought the studio in September and brought in Peter Guber and Jon Peters, the producers of ``Rain Man'' and ``Batman,'' to run it. Ms. Steel, who succeeded David Puttnam in 1987, said Monday that she will remain as a Columbia consultant for several months but is looking forward to leaving a job she called ``a gilded cage.'' ``As I seemed to go higher up in the hierarchy, it became more administrative for me and I began to feel like I was selling used cars. It wasn't a creative job for me anymore, which it had been up until that point,'' she said. Ms. Steel had been cut out of decision-making as Guber and Peters assembled their own executive team. Jeff Sagansky, president of Columbia's sister studio, Tri-Star Pictures, left in December to head the entertainment division of CBS. Columbia and Tri-Star had a 16 percent share of the box office last year, or third place, up from seventh in 1988 when the studios combined for 9.3 percent of domestic movie tickets sold. The 1989 mark was set with 42 films, while box-office champion Warner Bros. had 30 films and runner-up Universal had 19.

DOC.SECOND: PM-Bulgaria, 1st Ld-Writethru,a0533,0457*^;ommunist, Opposition Leaders Meet To Try To End Ethnic Strife
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS penultimate graf, `about...' to delete incorrect reference to Slav population. Pickup last, `Some of...
DOC.TEXT: Communist and opposition leaders today met with members of the Slavic majority and Turkish minority to try to end ethnic strife that has swept Bulgaria. Well-informed diplomats, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they heard today's closed-door session was ``very heated.'' The talks are aimed at settling a dispute that arose over the government's restoration of minority rights to ethnic Turks. They are expected to last through the week. Demonstrations against the Dec. 29 decision to restore minority rights erupted Thursday and spread to at least eight cities, including Sofia and Bulgafin's second-largest city, Plovdiv. Slav nationalists rallying in Sofia shouted down government leaders Sunday and demanded they resign. With the decision, the new Bulgarian leadership sought to end a policy forcing the assimilation of mostly Moslem ethnic Turks into Bulgarian culture. The program changed Turkish names into Bulgarian names and denied Turks the right to practice their customs and religion. Party chief and State Council President Petar Mladenov, who replaced ousted leader Todor Zhivkov on Nov. 10, defended the Dec. 29 decision during a meeting Monday with Slav nationalists. According to the BTA news agency, Mladenov told leaders of the Council for the Defense of National Interests that the forced assimilation moves ``affecting the Moslem population were very grave errors.''
