Mladenov reportedly told the meeting that ``one result of these errors has been Bulgaria's complete international isolation.'' The only way to correct these errors and re-establish Bulgaria's international prestige is ``to restore the constitutional rights of all citizens,'' he said. Leaders of the government, independent labor movements, ethnic Turks and the Turkish government have hinted that the nationalist unrest that started last week was likely fueled by local hard-liners still loyal to Zhivkov. Krasniu Petkov, a senior trade union official, had called for all demonstrations and strikes to cease ``during this week of dialogue,'' BTA reported. Petkov said all participants in the talks Monday at the National Assembly supported the call. The nationalists have expressed fear that their own culture will be overshadowed by the culture of the Turks, whose birthrate is growing while that of the Slavs is declining. About 1.5 million ethnic Turks live in the nation of 9 million. Some of the 320,000 ethnic Turks who streamed from Bulgaria to Turkey last summer have returned, but most appear to be watching and waiting to see if Bulgaria's new reform-minded Communist leaders make good on their promise to end the forced assimilation.

DOC.HEAD: 59 Arrested in Protest Against Sodomy Laws
DOC.TEXT: Gay activists demanding repeal of sodomy laws set up inflatable dolls on a brass bed and blocked traffic outside the Capitol on the opening day of the 1990 Legislature. Fifty-nine people were arrested. Four lesbian couples who flung themselves onto the street and began ... amid traffic were among those arrested Monday in the protest against Georgia's 156-year-old sodomy statute. About 50 pickets organized by the Texas-based American Family Association held a quiet counterdemonstration across the street. ``Lesbian and gay activists across this country will go to courthouses, statehouses and jailhouses to change the existing order,'' Sue Hyde of the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force in Washington told about 300 protesters. Ms. Hyde said activists would focus on seven states that ``go out of their way to criminalize gay and lesbian sex'' _ Arkansas, Kansas, Missouri, Montana, Nevada, Tennessee and Texas. ``We make a particular demand today that the seven states ... not only repeal these odious statutes, but also apologize to us for the unpardonable offense of defining us as a sexually criminal class of citizens,'' she said. The protesters also set up a brass bed with male and female inflatable dolls simulating one of the heterosexul and homosexual acts forbidden by Georgia law. Organizers of the protest backed a repeal bill co-sponsored by a state representative, Cynthia McKinney, who is in a legislative dispute with her father over the issue. State Rep. Billy McKinney introduced a bill Monday that would repeal the statute only as it ... bill ``violates family values.'' Father and daughter are Atlanta Democrats. Georgia's sodomy law was upheld in 1986 by the U.S. Supreme Court after being challenged by a gay Atlanta man arrested for having sex in his home. In September, a state judge ruled that the law cannot be applied to consenting married adults. Prosecutors did not appeal that decision.

DOC.HEAD: Shuttle Lifts Off on Satellite-Rescue Mission
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with astronauts beginning experiments; PICKS UP 7th graf pvs, `Liftoff was ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CSB2, CSB4, CSB5, HTN1; LaserColor CSB6
DOC.TEXT: Space shuttle Columbia opened a new decade of spaceflight today as it rocketed into orbit on a daring 10-day mission to chase down and bring back a satellite as big as a bus before it falls to Earth. The 115-ton winged spaceship lifted off with a crew of five at 7:35 a.m., riding a 700-foot column of flame out over the Atlantic on the start of the second-longest shuttle flight yet. Skies were partly cloudy as tens of thousands watched the start just after dawn of the 33rd shuttle mission, during which the astronauts will put a Navy communications satellite in$oorbit on Wednesday and retrieve an 11-ton orbiting science laboratory on Friday. ``I don't think I've ever seenpacleaner countdown and launch,'' said Richard Truly, administrator of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. ``What a marvelous way to start the 1990s.'' The mission is the first of 10 planned in 1990 as NASA continues its recovery from the Challenger explosion that killed seven astronauty ao r'years ago this month. Once in orbit, the astronauts set up their computers for flight, unpacked equipment, remov Liftoff was three weeks behind schedule, delayed last month by launch pad problems and on Monday by low-lying clouds. The launch was timed to put Columbia on the orbital path followed by the satellite the astronauts are tracking. Commander Dan Brandenstein and pilot Jim Wetherbee will guide the shuttle throug@ series of intricate maneuvers to close in on their quarry, which has been orbiting the Earth nearly six years. The satellite, the Lmf Duration Exposure Facility, is the size of a small school bus and is packed wA4wP57 experiments containing a wealth of scientiFi and technological information from its long exposure to space. Once the satellite is caught, mission specialist Bonnie Dunbar will reach out with the shuttle's 50-foot arm to snare the 21,400-pound package, which is 30 feet long and 14 feet in diameter, and stow it in the shuttle's cargo bay. ``It will be like hunting a speck in the sky,'' Brandenstein said recently. ``But NASA has plenty experience doing this type of rendezvous, and Jim and I have practiced it to perfection in the simulator.'' The satellite is 202 miles up, buv@`tmospheric drag has been pulling it to Earth about half a mile each day. If the satellite can't be retrieved, it will fall into the atmosphere and burn up about March 9, its experiments lost forever. Once the satellite is captured, Brandenstein, Wetherbee, Dunbar and mission specialists Marghn Ivins and David Low will concentratq on experiments, with emphasis on materials processing and how the body adapts to weightlessness. The mission is to be 10 hours shorter than the ninth shuttle flight, in 1983, and is a stepping stone for even longer ones. Columbia is being modified to stay aloft 16 days, starting with a 1993 fligHtV Scientists are eager to examine LDEF to learn how various materials and systems withstood the long stay in orbit _ information that will help in designing a permanent space station and the ``Star Wars'' defense system. ``LDEF is a virtual treasure trove of science and technology information,'' said William Kinard, chief scientist for the project. Scientists may reap a big bonus because the satellite has been in space five years longer than intended. The satellite was to have been retrieved 10 months after a shuttle put it into orbit in 1984. But scheduling problems and the 1986 Challenger disaster delayed the retrieval. The satellite cAr ies experiments on materials, propulsion, electronics, optics and other areas. They represent more than 200 investigators, 33 companies, 21 universities, 7 NASA centers and several foreign countries. On board are 12.5 million tomato seeds that will be distributed to students from fifth grade through university level for research into such things as germination rates and genetic changes.

DOC.HEAD: Army Corps of Engineers Closes Monongahela
DOC.TEXT: The Army Corps of Engineers today closed 23.8 miles of the Monongahela River for about 10 days to lower the water and remove one of at least 61 barges torn from their moorings by rushing ice New Year's Day. The closure will mean about 25 vessels a day carrying at least 35,000 tons of coal and gravel will be delayed or forced to find another route, said corps spokeswoman Nancy Mullen. Crews on Monday began draining 17 feet of water from the river between Brownsville and Greensboro, upstream from Pittsburgh, said corps spokesman John Reed. Once the river is low enough, workers will try to free a sunken barge wedged under a floodgate at the Maxwell Locks and Dam near Brownsville. ``It's going to look more like a creek than a river. A good size creek,'' Reed said Monday. The Coast Guard on Monday continued its investigation into the runaway barges. Heavy rain and melting snow had raised the level of the river and sent chunks of ice rushing downriver. One barge leaked as much as 10,000 gallons of gasoline. As of Monday morning, 31 submerged or partially submerged barges were close to the upstream side of the Maxwell Dam and two others were downstream, Mullen said. Salvage workers hired by the companies whose barges broke free will work to remove the remaining barges from the river, Reed said. Water companies in the affected stretch of river have been warned of the pending low-water levels so they can store water and attach flexible hoses to their intake pipes that will reach the water. Reed said it is unlikely any water companies will run dry and that he is not aware of any conservation measures imposed on customers. The corps expects to have a clear channel by next Monday and will allow the water level to rise, probably reopening the river Jan. 19, Reed said. The river was reopened early Thursday after being closed by the Coast Guard for four days shortly after the breakaway.

DOC.HEAD: Would-Be Helper Sprayed in Face wWth Acid
DOC.TEXT: A man who stopped to help a stranded motorist says he was instead sprayed with acid that left an eye swollen shut, turned his face gray and burned holes in his clothes. ``I won't stop to help anymore. It's a sad state of affairs that there are these bizarre people out there,'' said Gary P. Sexton, who believes the incident was a set-up rather than a reaction from a frightened driver. Sexton, 45, a Boeing Co. plumber, was hospitalized at Harborview Medical Center and was to meet with a plastic surgeon to see whether he'll need skin grafts. Sexton said he was driving home alone from work Saturday night when he spotted a utility vehicle with its hood up and emergency flashers on. Sexton rolled down his window and coasted alongside the other driver's window. ``I looked right at him and all of a sudden the hose nozzle came up and right out the window, like a fire extinguisher. I tilted my head down and away when he hit me,'' Sexton said Monday. ``It hit two-thirds of the left side of my face; the top of my head is all shot, turned a different color, gray, now,'' he said. Part of his left eye was burned but will probably heal, he said. ``It just disintegrated the coat I had on my back, just melted it. It just destroyed the inside of my truck, the dashboard and all the plastic in the seat,'' Sexton said. Police said they had no suspect and had not determined what was sprayed. Sexton said it smelled like battery acid. ``The police officer who came to help told me that nowadays you should never stop to help out like that,'' said Sexton's girlfriend, Pam Young. ``Just go by and go to a phone booth and phone 911.''

DOC.HEAD: Mobutu Postpones Angolan Peace Summit
DOC.TEXT: President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire has postponed an eight-nation African summit scheduled to discuss attempts at ending Angola's 15-year-old civil war, the Angolan state news agency reported today. The ANGOP report said Zambian leader Kenneth Kaunda was attempting to set a new date for the summit, which was scheduled Wednesday in Luanda, Angola's capital. Government officials in Zaire earlier said Mobutu felt more time was needed after Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos presented an eight-point plan for ending hostilities. Mobutu, who had proposed cease-fire procedures and offered to serve as a mediator for peace, postponed the summit in a message sent to dos Santos, ANGOP reported. In a New Year's Day speech, dos Santos said Mobutu's peace plan omitted principals agreed to at a June meeting between the Angolan leader and rebel chief Jonas Savimbi. Dos Santos said Mobutu's proposed measures to verify a cease-fire were unsuited to guerrilla war conditions and said the Zairean leader's role as mediator in the Angolan conflict must be strictly defined. Dos Santos offered a plan calling for integration of rebel forces into Angola's army and recognition of the legitimacy of the present government, but suggested free elections could be held in the one-party Marxist state within five years. In a later interview, dos Santos said that although he foresaw individuals being allowed to run against government candidates in the election, he opposed multi-party balloting. Rebels of the U.S.-backed National Union for the Total Independence of Angola rejected dos Santos' proposal in a statement distributed in Lisbon on Monday. The rebel statement called for an immediate cease-fire based on Mobutu's proposals and direct negotiations with the government leading to free, multi-party elections. The meeting with the presidents of Angola, Congo, Gabon, Mozambique, Sao Tome e Principe, Zaire, Zambia and Zimbabwe was first planned for December. Its second postponement came amid reports of heavy fighting in south-east Angola. The U.S. State Department expressed concern Monday at a military offensive by Angolan forces against rebel strongholds in the southeast. The Soviet ambassador in Luanda, Vladimir Kazimirov, denied reports of Soviet advisers in the combat zone, ANGOP reported today. Angola is expected to be featured strongly in talks scheduled Wednesday in Washington between President Bush and Portuguese Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva. Portugal is the former colonial power in Angola and maintains close links with Luanda. The ANGOP report was monitored in Lisbon. The rebels have been fighting to share power since the Marxist government gained control in Luanda after independence in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Amtrak Reports Record Revenues
DOC.TEXT: Amtrak, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, had record revenues of $1.27 billion last fiscal year, the quasi-government corporation reported. That income covered 72 percent of costs for the railroad passenger operation, up from 69 percent a year earlier and the highest revenue-to-cost ratio in the agency's history, Amtrak said Monday. As resently as 1981, Amtrak revenues covered less than half of its costs. The difference between costs and revenues is made up by federal appropriations. The revenues of $1.27 billion were up from $1.1 billion a year earlier, Amtrak reported. The total number of passengers carried was down slightly, from 21.5 million to 21.4 million. But passenger miles, defined as carrying one passenger one mile, rose from 5.7 billion in 1988 to 5.9 billion in the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Court Throws Out Part of Dallas Ordinance Against Sexually Oriented Business
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today threw out part of a Dallas ordinance aimed at cracking down on X-rated moviehouses and other sexually oriented businesses. By a 6-3 vote, the court said the city's licensing ordinance violates the Constitution's free-speech guarantees by creating a ``prior restraint.'' Another part of the ordinance, however, was upheld and some parts were not ruled on by the justices. The court said the city may require licensing for motels that rent rooms for fewer than 10 hours. The invalidated licensing provisions required sexually oriented businesses to obtain a license issued by the city police chief, who had broad discretion to deny one. Under the ordinance, the chief did not have to issue a license until a sexually oriented business had its premises approved by the health department, fire department and building officials. Writing the court's main opinion, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor said, ``Where the licensor has unlimited time within which to issue a license, the risk of arbitrary suppression is as great as the provision of unbridled discretion.'' ``A scheme that fails to set reasonable time limits on the decisonmaker,'' she said, ``creates the risk of indefinitely suppressing permissible speech.'' O'Connor said some businesses regulated by the licensing ordinance _ such as escort agencies and sexual encounter groups _ are not protected by the free-speech protections of the Constitution's First Amendment. But she added, ``It largely targets businesses purveying sexually explicit speech which the city concedes ... are protected.'' The court's vote was splintered, with different alignments on each part of the ordinance. On the licensing requirement, O'Connor was joined by Justices Anthony M. Kennedy, John Paul Stevens, William J. Brennan, Thurgood Marshall and Harry A. Blackmun. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White and Antonin Scalia voted to uphold the licensing requirement. The court upheld the motel-licensing part of the ordinance, and said none of the ordinance's challengers had the proper legal standing to attack a provision barring licenses for people who reside with someone who had such a license revoked or denied. The justices also said the challengers lacked the standing to attack provisions requiring suspensions of licenses for people convicted of certain crimes. The ordinance also imposes strict zoning regulations on sexually oriented businesses, but the court previously turned away challenges to those regulations. Today, the justices told the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals to decide whether the invalidated licensing provisions of the ordinance can be separated from the remaining regulations _ or whether the entire ordinance must be ruled unenforceable because of those licensing provisions. The case is FW/PBS vs. Dallas, 88-2012.

DOC.HEAD: `Hash Bash' Town May Boost Marijuana Fine From $5 to $25
DOC.TEXT: Marijuana use might get more risky this spring in this university city known for its annual Hash Bash _ voters are being asked to decide whether to raise the $5 fine for possession or sale to $25. The city's 1974 marijuana law, in addition to setting the $5 fine, requires that city police ticket rather than arrest pot offenders. City Council voted 9-2 Monday to put the stiffer fine on the April 2 ballot. Mayor Jerry Jernigan has been pushing against the existing law since last year. Residents defeated a proposed repeal of the $5 pot law in 1983 by a vote of 13,977 to 8,660. A Hash Bash rally for legalization of marijuana is held every April 1 on the University of Michigan campus. In 1989, the 19th rally drew about 1,000 high school and college students. Fifteen people were ticketed for possession. Many in the gallery at the Council meeting spoke against toughening the ordinance. ``Affordable housing, health care and other issues await your serious attention. Council fights its theatrical drug war while drug treatment goes unfunded,'' former Councilman Jeff Upton said. City resident Jan Schnell urged approval. ``Across the nation, this city is known for real lenient penalties for pot,'' he said. ``You council members need to know Ann Arbor is a laughingstock because of $5 pot.'' Police records show that in the past 2{ years, 308 tickets were written under the $5 marijuana law.

DOC.HEAD: Bud the Hamster Defies Death
DOC.TEXT: Bud the hamster survived a night in the family freezer to the delight of his 6-year-old owner. ``I thought he would go up to heaven, and my mom would buy me a new one,'' Bradley Snoddy said Friday. Bradley's mother, Mary Ann Snoddy, said she thought Bud, who was curled up in a corner of his cage, was dying of old age. Bud was 4, far beyond the 1{ to 2 years hamsters usually live. She said she called a pet store and was advised to put the animal out of its misery by putting it in the freezer, where it would ``fall asleep and not wake up.'' She wrapped Bud in a cloth and put him in a paper bag in the freezer. ``We had a very rough night. We were totally devastated,'' Snoddy said. ``My son was in tears all night.'' But on Thursday morning, Snoddy said, ``I opened the freezer door, and flop, onto the floor fell the hamster. He sat up on his hind legs, and looked at me like, `Why did you do this to me?''' During the night, Bud had chewed through the bag, dined on an arctic smorgasbord of bread and hash browns and gained a new lease on life, Snoddy said. ``He's just fine. Just the regular, normal hamster that we had before.'' Veterinarian Stephanie Hazen said the Snoddys got bad advice on how to put to death a hamster. ``You can't kill hamsters by putting them in a freezer,'' she said. ``They live for days and days.'' She recommended that people take their dying animals to the Humane Society to be put to death painlessly.

DOC.HEAD: Author, Illustrator Win Prestigious Children's Awards
DOC.TEXT: Author Lois Lowry has won the prestigious John Newbery Medal for children's books, while illustrator Ed Young was awarded the Randolph Caldecott Medal. The awards were announced Monday at an American Library Association meeting. Ms. Lowry, author of ``Number the Stars,'' won the 1990 Newbery Medal for the most distinguished contribution to American literature for children published in 1989. Young, illustrator of ``Lon Po Po: A Red-Riding Hood Story from China,'' won the Caldecott for the most distinguished American picture book published last year. The awards are administered by the Association for Library Service to Children, a division of the library association.

DOC.HEAD: Jet That Lost Engine Had Lavatory Repair Record
DOC.TEXT: The Northwest Airlines jet that lost one of its three engines over Florida last week had a recent history of maintenance problems with its lavatory, federal aviation officials said today. The lavatory of Northwest Flight 5, a Boeing 727, had been repaired 10 times since early November, said Dick Stafford, a spokesman for the Federal Aviation Administration. An unidentified FAA official told The New York Times, which disclosed the situation in today's editions, that the number of repairs was unusual. ``It probably shouldn't have occurred this many times,'' the source was quoted as saying. A Northwest spokesman was not immediately available today for comment, the company's public affairs office said today. In the Times account, spokesman Doug Miller disputed the figure, saying there were only five or six repairs in the last six months. The National Transportation Safety Board has yet to rule on the cause of the accident 35,000 feet in the air, but there are signs that the blue flushing fluid leaking from a valve in the plane's lavatory was responsible. Officials theorize that the liquid may have frozen at higher altitudes, broken free and been hurled into the engine of the Miami-to-Minneapolis flight. The liquid would have caused the engine to vibrate and break off, they theorize, since the 727 engines are supposed to break free to avoid damaging the frame when they vibrate badly. NTSB field inspector Andrew Alston was in Atlanta today to examine the engine and the lavatory, Miami regional director George Prellezo said by telephone. NTSB spokesman Ted Lopatkiewicz said today in Washington, ``We intend to dismantle that lavatory tank what see what the problem is and talk to the people who repaired it last.'' Prellezo said the investigation was ``very simple'' and findings indicate that the problem is limited. ``We don't have a problem with all the airplanes,'' he said. As recently as 1985, engines broke off Boeing 727s in flight, and in each case the problem was traced to a leaking lavatory. As a result, the FAA in 1986 ordered airlines to inspect lavatory valves in 727s every 200 flight hours or replace them with sturdier valves. Newer 727s have redesigned valves that are likely to leak, a Boeing Co. spokesman told the Times. Despite the concern with lavatory leaks, the FAA's Stafford said there were no records to indicate whether the record of repairs on Flight 5 was unusual. Stafford said it was too early to determine whether any fines might be in order.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Shop Wins $1.9 Million From Rank-Smelling Mortuary
DOC.TEXT: A crematorium has been ordered to pay nearly $1.9 million to the owners of a next-door auto shop who couldn't stand the stench. ``It's an outrageous, noxious smell that I don't think any normal person could stand without gagging,'' Larry Hunt, co-owner of the auto shop in Laguna Beach, said Monday. A Superior Court jury voted 11-1 on Friday to award $800,000 for emotional distress. On Monday, it voted unanimously to award punitive damages of nearly $1.1 million against McCormick Mortuary and its operator, Robert McCormick Jr. Mortuary employees refused to comment. Hunt and co-owner Virginia Hunt alleged that the smell and smoke from the crematorium plagued them from 1982 on, bothering customers and workers alike. Sometimes employees got so sick from the stench they were forced to close shop, the Hunts claimed.

DOC.HEAD: Heart-Liver Recipient Back in Hospital
DOC.TEXT: The world's first recipient of a heart-liver transplant, Stormie Jones, was in serious condition today at Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh, where she was undergoing tests, a spokeswoman said. The 12-year-old was admitted three days ago, said Margy Buczynski. The spokeswoman said doctors were awaiting results of a liver biopsy. Buczynski would not give the nature of the girl's ailment but said she was not confined to bed. The White Settlement, Texas, girl has been treated on and off over the past six years for mild episodes of organ rejection. Stormie received a new heart and liver at Children's Hospital in 1984. She had suffered from a rare congenital liver disease that increased the cholesterol in her blood to nearly 10 times normal. Because of the imbalance, she had suffered two heart attacks and underwent two triple coronary bypasses and a heart-valve replacement.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Prime Minister Hails East Europe Reform
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan today welcomed democratic reforms in Eastern Europe and better East-West relations but warned of the Soviet Union's continuing military might. Chancellor Helmut Kohl, welcoming Kaifu on his first visit to West Germany, urged Japan to lower trade barriers. At a luncheon speech in Bonn, Kohl said Japan must ``further improve perceptibly'' its market access for West German business in order to boost trade ``to a level commensurate with the high standard of development of the two economies.'' Japan in recent years has been embroiled in several trade disputes with the United States and the European Economic Community, of which West Germany is the most powerful member. In a speech later in West Berlin, Kaifu called the desire for uniting Germany ``legitimate'' and indicated he would not oppose such a move. Kaifu, on a European tour that will include visits to Hungary and Poland, promised economic aid to both East European countries but said they must also help themselves. He hailed the opening of the Berlin Wall, for 28 years a symbol of the Cold War division of Europe, and said he wanted to ``praise the courage of those in the East who have made this decision.'' East Germany's Communist rulers opened the wall and borders to West Germany on Nov. 9. The Japanese prime minister cautioned that despite warming East-West ties, ``the international situation remains opaque and fluid, and the Soviet Union still is a military superpower.'' ``Deterrence and balance of power continue to be the underpinning for world security,'' he said. On German unification, Kaifu called for ``a framework of peace and stability'' so that the ``legitimate aspiration of the German people to unify the country divided after the war can be realized amicably through the free exercise of their right to self-determination.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Colleges Enjoy No Special Privilege to Withhold Confidential Data
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 7-13, In other action, with other cases.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court ruled today that colleges and universities enjoy no special privilege to withhold confidential data from faculty members who claim they illegally were denied tenure. The court unanimously rejected University of Pennsylvania arguments that ``academic freedom'' confers a privilege of confidentiality for peer review records sought by a faculty member who sued when denied tenure, or a lifetime appointment. The controversy had drawn the attention of numerous universities. The University of Pennyslvania's appeal had been supported by Princeton, Brown, Stanford, Harvard and Yale. All told the court that forcing universities to reveal confidential statements about professors being considered for tenure would inhibit candor by those doing the evaluating. Writing for the court, Justice Harry A. Blackmun said past court rulings extending constitutional protection for so-called academic freedom only applied to government attempts to control or direct the content of speech engaged in by a university. The court refused to recognize what Blackmun called ``an expanded right of academic freedom to protect confidential peer review materials from disclosure.'' The decision also rejected arguments by the university's officials that federal rules of evidence provide such a privilege of confidentiality. In other action, the court: _ Threw out part of a Dallas ordinance aimed at cracking down on X-rated moviehouses and other sexually oriented businesses. By a 6-3 vote, the court said the city's licensing ordinance violates the Constitution's free-speech guarantees by creating a ``prior restraint.'' Another part of the ordinance, however, was upheld and some parts were not ruled on by the justices. The court said the city may require licensing for motels that rent rooms for fewer than 10 hours. _ Said utility companies don't have to pay income tax on deposits charged customers to insure payment of future bills. In the process, it handed the Bush administration a $300 million setback. The court unanimously ruled that an Indiana electric utility, Indianapolis Power and Light Co., does not have to pay taxes when collecting such deposits. The Internal Revenue Service estimates that more than 150 such cases involving over $300 million in potential taxes are pending in lower courts or before the tax agency. The tenure case began with a complaint by Rosalie Tung, an associate professor of management at the University of Pennsylvania, after she was denied tenure at the university's Wharton School. Ms. Tung filed a complaint with the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC) charging she was the victim of illegal discrimination against women and people of Asian descent. The EEOC subpoenaed the university's confidential peer review records for Ms. Tung and five male candidates considered for tenure, but the university refused to provide the documents. It said confidentiality is vital to peer review, which in turn is ``a critical component'' of the school's academic freedom. University officials argued in favor of a balancing test, approved by some federal appeals courts, that would allow the school to keep the information secret unless it is shown to be essential to the claim being made by the faculty member who was denied tenure. The 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in 1988 rejected that argument, and its ruling was upheld today. ``Because we conclude that the EEOC subpoena process does not infringe any First Amendment right enjoyed by (the university), the EEOC need not demonstrate any special justification ... as applied to tenure peer review materials in general or to the subpoena involved in this case,'' Blackmun wrote. The case is University of Pennsylvania vs. EEOC, 88-493.

DOC.HEAD: Divers Recover Weapon from River in Stuart Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with police saying gun fits description, ballistics tests likely; PICKS UP 4th pvs, `Stuart, who ...'
DOC.TEXT: Divers searching for the revolver used in the wounding of Charles Stuart and the killing of his pregnant wife found a gun today in the river where Stuart's brother said he dumped it, police said. ``It fits the description,'' said police spokesman Larry Gillis. ``Hopefully a major piece of the puzzle has fallen into place.'' Police had searched for the gun since Charles Stuart, 29, committed suicide Thursday. Stuart jumped from a Boston Harbor bridge after his brother Matthew implicated him in the slaying of Carol Stuart, whose premature baby died 17 days later. Investigators were expected to perform ballistics tests to see if is the murder weapon. FBI agent Jack DeCourcy said it is possible to detect fingerprints on a gun found in salt water, depending on how long it was submerged, how rusty it was and whether it was found in silt. Stuart, who is white, originally told police he and his wife were shot by a black mugger who forced his way into their car Oct. 23 as they left a childbirth class. Police listening to Stuart's pleas for help over his car phone found him and his dying wife by listening to their sirens over the phone. Matthew Stuart, 23, told authorities last week that he took Mrs. Stuart's handbag, which contained personal items and the gun, from the scene of the shootings and threw the items separately into the Pines River in Revere. Police found the bag Thursday, but the gun had remained a missing clue in the effort to unravel the baffling and racially inflammatory case. Jay Kakas, co-owner of the fur store where Charles Stuart worked, told police a revolver was stolen from the shop's safe, a representative of the store, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Monday. Investigators refused to comment on that report and on rumors of insurance or a romantic relationship as motives. Matthew Stuart also has refused to comment, but his attorney, John J. Perenyi, said his client told family members and friends about the plot. ``There wasn't a lot of support in the family for going to authorities,'' Perenyi said. A brother of Mrs. Stuart said he was appalled that the Stuart family might have joined his family in grieving while keeping secret their knowledge of a murder scheme. ``Can you believe that they came to our house to comfort my parents? That is just mind boggling, that they could sit with us, or allow us to visit Chuck,'' Carl DiMaiti, Carol Stuart's brother, told WLVI-TV. DiMaiti said his family believed Charles was a victim until the shocking revelations about the case that followed his suicide. ``It was such a convincing story and he was such a pitiful victim,'' DiMaiti said. ``He had lost his wife, he had lost his child. They seemed to have a perfect relationship,'' DiMaiti said. ``You know, for us to cry over Chuck, to pray for Chuck's recovery, knowing that Chuck was responsible for what happened to Carol. It's just unbelievable.'' Prosecutors, meanwhile, questioned another brother of Charles Stuart on Monday, as they continued to investigate who else knew about the killing. Michael Stuart met with investigators from the district attorney's office. His lawyer, Richard Clayman, declined to discuss the details of the questions, but he added that his client broke no law. Clayman said he could not discuss what Michael Stuart told him, but he noted: ``I think it's reasonable to conclude there was a terrible family dilemma that existed.'' Legal scholars say that under state law, people who might have suspected Charles Stuart as the killer had no legal obligation to report that to police. In Massachusetts, ``persons are criminally culpable for what they do, for their acts, not for what they know,'' said Frank Chubert, a professor of criminal justice at Northeastern University. Prosecutors, citing a continuing grand jury investigation, declined to say whether more charges will be brought. Members of the black community, who have denounced what they say was a racist investigation into the case, met to discuss a proposed civilian panel to evaluate police conduct. During the investigation, police searched scores of black residences and identified at least two black suspects. Meanwhile, Stuart's casket has been placed in the ground at Woodlawn Cemetery in suburban Everett, where a memorial service was held for him Saturday. The grave, covered with sheets of plywood and a canvas tarpaulin, was marked only with a stick, plot No. 1443 written on it. Several plastic pots, holding wilted red roses and white carnations, lay on their sides.

DOC.HEAD: Protestant Extremists Claim Responsibility for Murder
DOC.TEXT: An outlawed Protestant extremist group claimed responsibility for murdering a taxi driver, saying it was in retaliation for a murder by the Irish Republican Army. The Protestant Action Force said it killed Martin Byrne, 38, according to a report Monday by Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency. Byrne's body was found in his car near a highway Sunday. The group said the killing was in retaliation for the death of Harry Dicky, a Protestant taxi driver who was killed by an IRA bomb Jan. 2. The IRA claimed Dicky was involved in paramilitary activities. The Protestant Action Force said it was also retaliating for the shooting death of Robert Metcalfe, 40, at his home in October. Nearly 2,800 people have died in two decades of sectarian fighting in Northern Ireland, and 1,900 of them have been civilians. The IRA, which is waging a guerrilla campaign to end British rule in Northern Ireland and unite the province with the Republic of Ireland, has been responsible for about half of the deaths, according to official figures. Protestant paramilitaries have been responsible for about one-fourth of the deaths, while about 12 percent of the deaths were attributed to the security forces. The Protestant Action Force is a cover name used by the Ulster Volunteer Force, an illegal organization that emerged in the 1960s.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyers Clash Over Public Schools' Authority to Exclude Religious Meetings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers clashed before the Supreme Court today on whether public high school officials should have broad authority to exclude Bible-reading and other religious clubs from school facilities. Allen E. Daubman, a lawyer for an Omaha, Neb., school system, asked the court to limit the scope of a 1984 federal law requiring a public high school to permit meetings of student religious groups when it sanctions such other activities as chess and scuba diving clubs. A broad interpretation of the law ``stifles the efforts of educators to structure a program that is relevant and provides benefits to the students,'' Daubman said. But Solicitor General Kenneth W. Starr, the Bush administration's chief courtroom lawyer, said Daubman's position undermines the 1984 Equal Access Act. Congress' ``primary thrust was to protect religious liberty,'' Starr said. ``It's quite clear the purpose of the act was to eliminate discrimination against religious groups.'' Jay Alan Sekulow, representing a group of students who tried to form a Bible-reading club at Westside High School in Omaha, agreed. ``The act would become a nullity by administrative fiat'' if the Omaha school officials prevail, Sekulow said. The court is expected to issue a ruling by July in the case. Hanging in the balance, some school groups say, is whether religion and prayer will return to public schools. The justices challenged both sides to give a clearer explanation of when the federal law applies to religious clubs. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist said Daubman seemed to be arguing for total discretion for school administrators. He said the lawyer's position ``allows any school district to totally avoid the act.'' But Starr, in a legal brief submitted to the court before today's arguments, said equal access for religious clubs does not violate the separation of church and state mandated by the Constitution's Establishment Clause. ``Exclusion of religion, and the message it conveys, would iitself contravene the Establishment Clause, by sending the clear message that the state favors irreligion,'' Starr said. School officials barred the Bible study group despite the 1984 Equal Access Act that says public high schools accepting federal aid must not discriminate against groups based on ``the religious, political, philosophical or other content of the speech at such meetings.'' The act requires access for religious clubs if other ``non-curriculum-related student groups'' are allowed to meet. Numerous religious, educational and civic organizations have lined up on opposing sides. The National School Boards Association, for example, said the aim of the 1984 law is ``to bring religion and prayer back to the public schools.'' The association opposes the statute as unconstitutional. But the Campus Crusade for Christ said ``a voluntary student club in which ideas with religious content and significance will be spoken'' should not be discriminated against by school officials. Students at Westside High sought in 1985 to organize a Christian Bible study club. Officials refused to approve it and suggested the students meet instead at a church next door. The student group was led by Bridget Mergens, now married and the mother of a 13-month-old girl. Mrs. Mergens Mayhew planned to be in court today to hear arguments in the case she triggered. The 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last year overruled a federal judge and said the club must be allowed to meet on school premises. The appeals court noted the high school has approved some 30 other extracurricular organizations for such activities as chess, scuba diving and community service. The clubs meet on school grounds after class hours with a faculty member helping supervise. The Supreme Court, which banned organized prayer in public schools in 1962 and 1963 rulings, said in 1981 that state-run universities cannot ban student groups from using campus facilities for religious worship and study. The justices have never decided whether the same rule should apply to public high schools. The 8th Circuit Court rejected the idea that high school students, because they are more impressionable than college students, should be given more protection from student religious groups that may appear to be sanctioned by school authorities. The appeals court said Congress ``considered the difference in the maturity level of secondary students and university students before passing the Equal Access Act. We accept Congress' fact-finding.'' The case is Westside Community Schools vs. Mergens, 88-1597.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico Ends Year With 19.7 Percent Inflation
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Corrects inflation rate. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Mexico's inflation rate was 19.7 percent last year, the country's lowest since 1978, the government announced. Thus, Mexico ended the year meeting its goal of keeping inflation at 18 percent to 20 percent, the government said in a report Monday. Inflation was 51.7 percent in 1988 after a reaching 159.2 percent in 1987. Although the government recently renewed a Feb. 29, 1988 wage-price freeze with business and labor leaders, there are concerns that inflation could again rise after the freeze expires later this year. Protests are common by workers who complain that wage increases do not keep up with prices.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Utility Companies Don't Have to Pay Tax on Deposits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts graf 12, A deposit, with Justice Department quote.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court handed the Bush administration a $300 million setback today, saying utility companies don't have to pay income tax on deposits charged customers to insure payment of future bills. The court unanimously ruled that an Indiana electric utility, Indianapolis Power and Light Co., does not have to pay taxes when collecting such deposits. The Internal Revenue Service estimates that more than 150 such cases involving over $300 million in potential taxes are pending in lower courts or before the tax agency. Writing for the court, Justice Harry A. Blackmun said the deposits do not amount to advance payments for electric service, and therefore are not income for tax purposes. Although Indiana Power and Light does receive some economic benefit from the deposits, he said, ``IPL's right to retain the money is contingent upon events outside its control.'' ``That the utility's customers, when they qualify for refunds of deposits, frequently choose to apply those refunds to future bills rather than taking repayment in cash does not mean that any customer has made an unspoken commitment to do so,'' Blackmun said. The electric company's policy, as amended in 1976, requires some customers to deposit up to twice their estimated monthly bills for electricity. The company requires the deposits from new customers whose creditworthiness was in doubt and existing customers with a record of late payment of their bills. The utility pays 6 percent annual interest on the deposits to customers if it holds the money for at least a year. A deposit is refunded if the customer meets a credit test or if the customer's bill is paid on time for nine straight months or for 10 out of 12 months. The U.S. Tax Court and the 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that the company need not pay taxes on the deposits, and today's decision upheld those rulings. Justice Department lawyers had argued that the 7th Circuit court was wrong, and noted that another federal appeals court, the 11th Circuit court, had ruled the opposite way. Today's decision resolves that conflict in favor of the utility companies. ``A deposit to secure the payment of future income is essentially indistinguishable from an advance payment for future goods or services, and therefore is taxable as income upon receipt,'' the Justice Department argued. The case is Commissioner, IRS vs. Indiana Power and Light, 88-1319.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Leaders Reportedly Had Big Taste For Hunting
With AM-Romania, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Former senior Communist officials used to fly by helicopter to their favorite hunting grounds, where they shot deer from the comfort of their limousines, the state news agency CTK reported Tuesday. Prominent guests in government hunting grounds, often known as environmental reserves, included Cuban leader Fidel Castro and the late Soviet leader Leonid I. Brezhnev. Former Foreign Minister Bohuslav Chnoupek, former Parliament Chairman Alois Indra, ex-chief Ideologist Jan Fojtik and former Interior Minister Jaromir Obzina were among those who, together with their entourage, ``managed to kill 2,000 pheasants and hares per day,'' CTK said. Former Premier Lubomir Strougal also was among the hunting devotees, as was veteran Communist hard-liner Vasil Bilak, who liked to hunt in his home region of Slovakia, CTK reported. The news agency quoted unidentifed Hunters' Association officials as saying that if Westerners has been allowed to hunt, instead of the Communist elite, the country could have gotten hundreds of thousands of dollars in hard currency. The top officials were said to have flown by helicopter to the hunting grounds and sometimes shot animals while seated in their limousines with the windows rolled down, CTK said. CTK reported that Castro, hunting in the Slovak Tatra mountains, ``managed to kill two chamoix, whose killing is illegal all year around.'' ``Brezhnev used to enjoy looking at dying animals,'' the Hunters' Association sources were said to have told CTK. ``During one presidential hunt at Lany (west of Prague) Brezhnev made a film recording of the last moments of a dying deer.'' ``We have learned they did nothing to respect the traditions and ethics of hunting. They shot at animals even from windows of their cars,'' the report said. Other former Communist leaders in Eastern Europe known to have enjoyed hunting in their own countries include the late Janos Kadar of Hungary and ousted leaders Erich Honecker of East Germany and Todor Zhivkov of Bulgaria.

DOC.HEAD: Former Head of Field Museum Of Natural History
DOC.TEXT: E. Leland Webber, president emeritus of the Field Museum of Natural History, has died of cancer at the age of 69. Webber died Sunday at Evanston Hospital. ``I have never worked with anybody I enjoyed more,'' said Willard Boyd, who succeeded Webber as president of the museum in 1981. ``He was so positive about doing things in new ways. He was not bound by the past.'' Webber went to work for the Field Museum in 1950, and was named director and later president in the early 1960s. Under his leadership, the museum renovated its Northwest Coast Indian, Eskimo and jade collections and built its popular Pawnee earthen lodge and ``Place for Wonder,'' a hands-on exhibit for children. He began a special traveling exhibit program, which brought in shows including ``The Treasures of Tutankhamen'' and ``The Great Bronze Age of China.'' In 1979, then-Egyptian President Anwar Sadat awarded Webber his country's Order of the Republic. ``His primary accomplishment was to put the museum into the public domain, both in terms of programming and financing,'' Boyd said. After retiring, Webber became chairman of the Field Foundation of Illinois Inc., a philanthropic organization that aids institutions in health, welfare, education and cultural affairs. Webber is survived by his wife, Joan, two sons, a daughter and a granddaughter. A memorial service was set for Friday in Kenilworth.

DOC.HEAD: Smoking Package Contained Matches
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with package containing matches that accidentally ignited. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Bomb squad officers blew up a smoking parcel delivered to a city building today, finding only a jar of peanuts, a bottle of after shave and matches that had accidentally ignited, authorities said. ``Apparently, due to friction they had rubbed together and some of the matches had ignited in the box and that had resulted in the smoke and the sulfur smell,'' county spokesman Mark Kurea said. Last month, a white federal judge in Alabama and a black lawyer in Georgia who worked for the NAACP were killed by mail bombs. A group calling itself Americans for a Competent Federal Judicial System claimed responsibility and threatened to assassinate two more NAACP officials. Kruea said he knew of no threats against any county agencies but added: ``We're pleased that we took the precautions that we did given the circumstances and the history of actual bombing incidents.'' The box had been taken outside the Spartanburg County administration building and about 30 people were evacuated after smoke and a sulfur smell were discovered coming from the parcel, authorities said. The state fire marshal's arson squad blew it up. Inside were several boxes of wooden matches and other items, authorities said. The box was addressed to an inmate at the non-existent Spartanburg County Prison and delivered by mail truck, said Kruea, who believed the package was meant for one of the three state prisons in the county. The building houses the sheriff's department, postal service, police and fire departments and other offices.

DOC.NOTE: For Release at 6:30 p.m. EST
DOC.HEAD: South's Share of Blacks Reverses Century-Long Decline
DOC.TEXT: For the first time in more than a century the share of blacks living in the South is increasing, the Census Bureau reported Tuesday. The proportion of blacks living in the South grew from 52.2 percent in 1980 to 55.9 percent in 1988, reversing a decline that had been under way for more than 100 years. While the new census study did not investigate the reasons for this reversal, two factors are likely involved, according to census statistician Claudette Bennett. One is that fewer blacks are leaving the South than in the past, while the second is movement of blacks back into the region both in search of jobs and as part of the general movement of all types of Americans into the Sun Belt states. In recent years the employment growth that has taken place in the country has occurred disproportionately in the South, noted William P. O'Hare, director of policy studies at the private Population Reference Bureau. Blacks had traditionally been drawn out of the South by jobs in heavy industry in the North, but most had maintained family and kinship ties in the Southern states, he commented. Such ties, explained O'Hare, make it easier to return south. However, the current trend is not exactly a return flow, O'Hare said in a telephone interview. Historically, blacks moved out of the rural South to urban North. The flow now is to urban areas in the South, not back to people's rural roots, he said. While the share of blacks in the South grew by 3.7 percentage points between 1980 and 1988, the region with the largest loss was the Northeast, slipping from 18.6 percent to 16.5 percent of blacks. The Midwest dropped from 20.5 percent to 19.1 percent of blacks over the period, while the West was nearly unchanged, sliding from 8.6 percent to 8.5 percent. The 1880 national census found 90.4 percent of blacks living in the South, and a century ago in 1890 that had slipped only slightly to 90.3 percent, according to calculations based on historical records kept by the Commerce Department. By the turn of the century, the South's share of blacks had declined to 89.7 percent. It has dropped steadily in this century as blacks moved out of the rural areas and smaller cities of the South in search of jobs in the Northern and Western industrial centers. Overall, the new study concluded that there were 29.3 million blacks in the United States as of March 1988, up 13.6 percent since the 1980 census. That represented 12.2 percent of all Americans, up from 11.7 percent in 1980. The median age for blacks is 27.3 years compared to 33.1 years for whites. That compares to median ages in 1980 of 24.8 for blacks and 30.8 for whites. Among blacks, there were 88 males for every 100 females, compared to 96 white males for every 100 white females. The large differential among blacks may be related to the lower mortality rates for women and also to the fact that the census misses more black males than females in its counts, the report said. The percentage of blacks completing four years of high school increased from 75 percent of those aged 25 to 34 in 1980 to 80 percent in 1988. By comparison, the figure for whites held steady at 87 percent over that period. Despite the gain in high school graduates, however, the report found that the share of young blacks who had completed college increased only from 12 percent to 13 percent between 1980 and 1988. Black women were slightly more likely than whites to be in the labor force in 1988, 58 percent to 56.4 percent. For men, 76.9 percnt of whites and 71 percent of blacks were in the labor force. The new census report does not include estimates of the black populations of individual states. However, the bureau defines the South as including Alabama, Arkansas, Delaware, District of Columbia, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maryland, Mississippi, North Carolina, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Virginia and West Virginia. DOC.HEAD: U.S. Delegation Says Sanctions Should Remain
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. congressional delegation said Tuesday that government reforms have failed to address black voting rights, and U.S. economic sanctions should remain in place, or even be toughened. The three-member group, led by Rep. Howard Wolpe, D-Mich., acknowledged that ``there have been some positive developments'' since President F.W. de Klerk assumed power in August. The delegation, which included Rep. Alan Wheat, D-Mo., and Rep. Constance Morella, R-Md., cited the release of some political prisoners and government approval of opposition rallies. But the delegation added, ``we could find no evidence that the government has yet made any decision that it would in fact accept a democratic government elected by all the people.'' De Klerk says he wants to negotiate a new constitution that will bring blacks into the national government within five years. However, he opposes black majority rule and and envisions a mechanism that would give whites veto power on major policy decisions. Under the country's apartheid policies, South Africa's 5 million whites control the government and the economy and maintain separate schools and neighborhoods. The 28 million blacks have no voice in national affairs. The U.S. delegation spent six days meeting opposition figures and government leaders, including de Klerk. The Americans said they would give him a ``reasonable time period'' to initiate ``fundamental reform.'' They said such reforms must include the release of all political prisoners, lifting bans on anti-apartheid organizations, removing soldiers from black townships, lifting the 43-month-old state of emergency and ending trials considered ``political.'' The group said current sanctions should remain in place and they would push for tougher measures if de Klerk does not move ahead with major reforms. A 1986 U.S. bill barred the importation in the United States of South African coal, steel and agricultural products, imposed banking restrictions, and cut direct air links between the two countries. Wolpe is chairman of the Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Africa and has pressed for sanctions against South Africa. The Bush administration has indicated it will oppose any tightening of sanctions as long as de Klerk appears to be moving toward reform.

DOC.HEAD: Mount St. Helens, Redoubt Erupt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with school closings in Alaska, airline flights canceled. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Mount St. Helens trembled after its biggest outburst in four years, and Alaska's Redoubt Volcano shot steam and ash in its largest eruption since it reawakened a month ago, forcing schools to close today. Despite Mount St. Helens' eruption and renewed earthquake activity, scientists said they do not believe the volcano is entering a more explosive phase. Seismic levels rose Monday at the Washington volcano for unexplained reasons, said Chris Jonientz-Trisler of the University of Washington Geophysics Center. Foul weather kept scientists from flying into the crater by helicopter to take measurements, gather ash samples and replace monitoring equipment lost in the volcano's ash burst Saturday. Ash collected Sunday was examined under a microscope and found to be pulverized rock from previous eruptions from the 8,366-foot peak rather than freshly erupted matter, said Dan Dzurisin, aciting scientist in charge of the Cascades Volcano Observatory. Saturday's burst, which was not preceded by earthquakes, sent ash 90 miles to the east and destroyed two seismometers and two tilt meters in the crater. Jonientz-Trisler said earthquake signals Saturday indicated the outburst might have resulted from groundwater reaching superheated rock beneath the volcano and turning to steam or from gas released by cooling molten rock. The quakes Monday, small but sharp and occurring at an undetermined depth, resemble some that were recorded last August but were never explained, she said. The latest quake pattern does not resemble any that preceded previous eruptions, she said. ``We're not especially alarmed,'' she said. The latest eruption was the largest since a series of small explosions in 1986. On May 18, 1980, a cataclysmic explosion from the volcano leveled 230 square miles, killed 57 people and sent up an ash cloud that circled the globe. In Alaska on Monday, Redoubt Volcano hurled a plume of steam and ash almost eight miles into the air before activity subsided in the afternoon. Scientists said the patterns preceding the eruption were very different from previous blasts from the volcano 115 miles southwest of Anchorage. Most of the ash was carried over the Kenai Peninsula and out over the Gulf of Alaska. Flights from Anchorage to Kenai and Homer were canceled immediately. Other flights were canceled as darkness fell and the ash cloud spread over the gulf. The ash plume missed for the most part the major population concentrations around Kenai and Homer. But the grit was sufficiently heavy for officials to close schools today in Kenai, Soldotna, Nikiski and Sterling. Officials said they were concerned about the effect the ash might have on ventilation systems and didn't want students tracking ash into the buildings. The fishing community of Kasilof south of Kenai was coated with a quarter-inch of ash. Don Rivers, owner of a Kasilof grocery, said it was the heaviest ashfall there since the 10,197-foot peak sprang back to life Dec. 13. ``People are pretty much just holing up,'' said Rivers. ``People are starting to get used to it.''

DOC.HEAD: Singapore Airlines Planning $5.29 Billion Purchases
DOC.TEXT: Singapore Airlines is holding talks with major manufacturers to buy airplanes and engines worth $5.29 billion, an airline spokeswoman said Tuesday. The aircraft and engines would be delivered starting in 1994, said the spokeswoman, speaking on condition of anonymity. In the January issue of the airline's monthly magazine, Outlook, airline chairman Joe Y. Pillay said the carrier hopes to make an announcement early this year about new purchases. The airline is evaluating competing candidates, he said. The investment outlay for the last six years of the 1990s be in excess of $5.29 billion, ``an enormous sum for a medium-sized airline. We are reasonably confident of our ability to generate the cash needed from our operations,'' he said. ``With the new aircraft, we shall be able to replace older aircraft, mount additional flights to the points we now serve, inaugurate services to new points and operate more non-stop flights,'' he said. In March 1986, Singapore Airlines, which is partly government owned, ordered 20 Boeing 747-400 jets costing $3.3 billion. Delivery of these aircraft is to be completed before 1994.

DOC.HEAD: Family Says Surgery To Correct Clubfeet Violates Religious Beliefs
DOC.TEXT: The parents of a boy born with deformed feet have withdrawn an agreement to allow corrective surgery _ even if the county joins in a ceremony to relieve the family of responsibility for interfering with God's will. ``They feel that even an agreement by way of a settlement would visit punishment on them because they would nevertheless be deciding to consent to the surgery. They'd rather have the court order it done,'' said Rudy Petilla, a lawyer for the boy's father. ``I understand that if the kid himself strongly says `I want it,' they would go ahead,'' Petilla said. But 6-year-old Kou Xiong has sided with his parents, Hmongs from the hill country of Laos, who argue that the Fresno County Social Services Department lawsuit to force the surgery violates their religious beliefs. The Hmongs believe that God intended the boy to have club feet and that the family would be punished for interfering with God's will. Ger Xiong and his wife, Houa Vue, last week proposed a ceremony to direct any ill consequences of tampering with their son's feet at the agency insisting on the operation, and not the family. The ceremony would include burning incense, slitting a hen's throat and sprinkling its blood on ceremonial papers that would later be burned. However, the family changed their minds Monday after speaking with religious advisers over the weekend, Petilla said. ``The parent's religious beliefs are genuine and they are here in the United States where their freedom of religion is guaranteed,'' said Ralph Avila, attorney for the boy's mother. Lawyers for the family say they are not convinced that the surgery will improve the boy's condition appreciably. ``The surgery is an elective surgery. It's not a matter of life and death. The child's not in immediate danger,'' said Petilla, indicating that the surgery could be postponed at least several years with the same chance for success. Susan Anderson, a deputy district attorney representing the boy, said she plans to petition the court to allow a child psychologist to evaluate how the boy would react to the surgery.

DOC.HEAD: Routine Check Finds Stolen Matisse Works in Car's Back Seat
DOC.TEXT: Eight stolen works by the French artist Henri Matisse were recovered Tuesday when police pulled over a man for a routine check and found the art rolled up on the back seat of his car, police sources said. Franck Cochet was held for questioning in the theft of the five oil paintings, two drawings and one engraving, which were valued at $12.5 million, the sources said. They were reported missing Dec. 29. Cochet, 24, was recognized by police officers who knew him from previous theft and drug cases, police sources said. When they waved over his car for a routine check, Cochet and a woman in the passenger seat tried to flee but were stopped. The woman later was cleared. The officers were stunned when they unrolled the art works found on the car's back seat and found the Matisse works, the sources said. The works, including the well-known paintings ``View Over Collioure Port,'' ``Woman in Brittany'' and ``Devilacqua,'' were taken from the empty apartment in Nice's posh Cimiez district in the hills overlooking the Mediterranean where Matisse lived until his death in 1954. The theft was discovered by the artist's daughter-in-law when she visited the vacant apartment Dec. 30 for the first time since November.

DOC.HEAD: Brothers Split Huge Crystal
DOC.TEXT: Two brothers who found an 80-pound semiprecious gem could not agree on a way to sell it, so they had it chopped up, apparently seriously devaluing it. ``I didn't want to see that big stone busted,'' said Dennis Holden, who found the gem with his brother Ronald Holden Jr. in October at a quarry they leased in Buckfield. ``I tried to stop him from getting it out of the bank.'' Dennis Holden said his brother wanted to bring in partners. Ronald Holden said setting up a corporation was the only way to properly market the gem, which contained a single crystal measuring nearly 13 inches across and weighing about 115,000 carats. At the time of their find, the brothers estimated the gem to be worth $1 million. Experts were reluctant to put a value on it, although now that it has been chopped up, stonecutter James Mann said the brothers will be lucky to get $60,000. Mann said that this week he struck a deal to sell two pieces from Dennis Holden's share of the rock for $16,000 to a museum at Harvard University. State geologist Woodrow Thompson said the morganite crystal, a transparent, rose-colored variety of beryl, should not have been cut. ``I personally, and many other people, would have preferred that it be kept intact,'' Thompson said. ``It was a splendid mineral specimen.'' Dubbed the ``Rose of Maine,'' the gem was chopped up in early November at the home of Paul Bennett, who owns the mine the Holdens leased. The Holdens, from the town of Norway, each kept chunks weighing about 17 pounds. Bennett got a 14-pound piece, as well as a 4-pound piece and a 4-carat piece of tourmaline.

DOC.HEAD: Monarch Butterflies May Lose Winter Home
DOC.TEXT: A roosting site for monarch butterflies may be lost to development in the community that calls itself Butterfly Town, USA. The City Council has approved a rezoning plan for the privately owned property. But voters will first be given a chance to decide whether their town 70 miles south of San Francisco should buy the 2.7-acre site. The property is one of only two winter butterfly roosting sites left in the city, which celebrates the orange and black butterfly with a parade every October. Molesting a monarch is a crime that carries a $500 fine. ``We've got to buy that piece of land,'' said Ro Vaccaro, president of the local Friends of the Monarchs. ``We don't want to change our name to `Bulldozer Town, USA.''' Monarchs from across the West migrate annually to 100 to 200 winter roosting sites dotting the Pacific coast. Pacific Grove's two sites are the best known, and monarchs have become the city's main tourist attraction. This year, the site slated for development attracted all the monarchs. The other site, in a city park, failed to attract a single cluster. On Wednesday, the City Council voted 4-3 to allow property owner Edna Dively to divide the land into six lots as long as she gives the city 1.5 acres of prime monarch roosting habitat on the property. No development can take place before voters are allowed to decide whether to buy the property. The election could be in June or November. Council member Bud Nunn, who voted against the plan, fears the worst. ``This development uses up some of the best part of the habitat, and I don't think the butterflies are going to survive it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Shiite Moslem Militias Express Willingness to Stop Fighting
DOC.TEXT: Two rival Shiite Moslem militias said Tuesday they were ready to stop fighting, and one suggested there be talks between militia leaders following battles that killed 94 people in three weeks. An Iranian mediator sent to work out a solution said the battle between the pro-Iranian Hezbollah and the Syrian-backed Amal militias was ``nearing its end.'' In Beirut, Christian troops battled Syrian-backed Moslem militiamen along the Green Line separating the city into Christian and Moslem sectors. No casualties were reported in the 10-minute exchange, but police expressed alarm over the continued violations of a truce declared in September. The truce halted six months of fighting between soldiers of Christian army Gen. Michel Aoun and Syrian troops and their allies. But serious clashes broke out Saturday in Beirut, and four people have been killed. Syria has 40,000 troops in Lebanon, and Aoun declared a ``war of liberation'' in March to drive them out. In south Lebanon, meanwhile, Hezbollah and Amal fighters held their fire for a second day as Iran's deputy foreign minister, Mohammad Ali Besharati, tried to arrange a permanent settlement. ``It is nearing its end. A cease-fire will be proclaimed soon and the warring factions will withdraw to their original lines,'' Besharati said after a two-hour meeting in Moslem west Beirut with Amal chieftain Nabih Berri. Berri said he told Besharati that Amal would adhere to the cease-fire if Hezbollah agreed to withdraw from all territory it conquered during the previous 17 days of fighting. Hezbollah said in a statement it was ready to stop shooting and begin simultaneous talks for a coexistence that would ``turn all the guns against the Israeli enemy.'' Tehran radio, monitored in Nicosia, said the two sides agreed to exchange prisoners at the same time as a Hezbollah withdrawal. The militia fighting has killed 94 people and wounded 275 since it broke out Dec. 23. Amal and Hezbollah called a seven-hour cease-fire Monday to allow Red Cross workers to remove corpses from the battlefield. The two factions have been vying for control of Lebanon's 1.2 million-member Shiite community for more than two years. Amal disclosed Tuesday that Sheik Mohammed Siklawi, a prominent Hezbollah cleric who defected to Amal last week, was Hezbollah's ``naval operations commander.'' Amal spokesmen say Siklawi defected because he refused orders to mount a naval attack on the Amal-held oil terminal of Zahrani south of the port city of Sidon. Hezbollah confirmed that Siklawi was its naval operations chief. It charged Amal kidnapped him, and it denied plans of a seaborne attack. In east Lebanon's Bekaa valley, police said two villagers were wounded when Israel's allied militia, the South Lebanon Army, poured artillery fire on bases of Syrian-backed Palestinian and leftist Lebanese guerrillas. The area has long been a launching pad for guerrilla raids into the Israeli-controlled zone in south Lebanon. The 2,500-member, predominantly Christian SLA and an estimated 1,500 Israeli troops jointly patrol along the southern border.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Say Prospective Employers `Snoop'
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 80 percent of American workers surveyed for a poll released Tuesday say prospective employers have tried to ``snoop'' into their personal lives by asking prying questions during job interviews. The results demonstrate the need for tougher privacy laws, such as tighter restrictions on how employers use information compiled by direct mail firms, said Linda Golodner of the National Consumers League, which conducted the poll. For instance, technological advances allow all sorts of information _ from the type of beverages a person buys at a grocery store to their drug prescriptions _ to go into computers available to employers, the group said. The poll asked 1,007 adults whether employers had a right to ask if a job applicant lives with a non-family member of the opposite sex, has elderly parents, about religious preference, plans to have children, smoking off-the-job, the nature of after-work hobbies and marital status. The poll, which had a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points, said 79 percent of the respondents had been asked at least one of those questions in a job interview. ``In job interviews, Americans say employers routinely snoop into the privacy of job applicants by asking questions that have no relationship to job performance,'' Ms. Golodner said. Nearly two out of three respondents, or 65 percent, had been asked their marital status; 46 percent their off-the-job activities; 23 percent their religious preference; and 16 percent whether they smoked away from work. An overwhelming majority of respondents considered most of the questions off-limits during interviews. For example, 87 percent thought it was inappropriate for an employer to ask whom they were living with and 74 percent didn't think it was an employer's business whether they smoked away from the job. Only the question on marital status was considered by a majority _ 52 percent _ as an appropriate question for an employer to ask. More than 80 percent thought employers, when making hiring and firing decisions, should not consider outside activities such as gambling at a race track, holding an unusual second job such as a bartender or participating in a political demonstration. In addition, the poll showed that 81 percent did not think a business should refuse to hire an overweight person and 76 percent thought the same rights belonged to smokers. The National Consumers League is a private advocacy group concerned with workplace and marketplace issues.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Troops Surround Peruvian Embassy After Reports Noriega Aides Inside
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New thruout to UPDATE with Peruvian denial that Noriega aides inside. CORRECTS spelling of Cordova and Tason. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos PAN1, NY12
DOC.TEXT: U.S. troops today surrounded the Peruvian ambassador's residence, where government officials said two of Manuel Antonio Noriega's top associates _ one an alleged torturer _ had taken refuge. An official of the Peruvian Embassy denied the men were inside the building. They were identified as Capt. Gonzalo Gonzalez, commander of the Machos de Monte company that provided security for Noriega's headquarters, and Lt. Col. Luis Cordova, identified by Noriega's foes as one of the men who interrogated and tortured prisoners of the overthrown regime. The two were considered the most-wanted of the former Noriega officials sought since the American invasion that ousted the military leader Dec. 20. In a telephone interview today broadcast by a radio station in Lima, Peru, Manuel Tirado, the third secretary at the embassy, said a number of Panamanians had taken refuge at the residence of the charge d'affaires, Luis Sandiga. But he said neither Gonzalez nor Cordova was there. Tirado did not identify the Panamanians in the residence or say how many were there. President Alan Garcia of Peru was one of the strongest critics of the U.S. invasion, which killed more than 300 U.S. and Panamanian soldiers. The number of civilian deaths remains unclear. After the invasion, Peru recalled its ambassador from Washington and threatened to boycott a drug summit next month with President Bush. U.S. troops surrounded the ambassador's residence in suburban El Cangrejo, near the downtown banking district, at noon Monday. Foreign Minister Julio Linares said Cordova was inside. Another government source said Gonzalez was also inside along with Noriega secretary Marcela Tason, her son and another high-ranking former government official. Tirada refused comment on whether Tason was inside. Linares said he would ask the Peruvian mission and other embassies in Panama for official confirmation and identification of Noriega associates who had requested asylum. A small detachment of American soldiers remained outside the embassy through the night. Noriega holed up in the Vatican Embassy for 10 days before surrendering to U.S. troops Jan. 3 and being flown to Miami for prosecution on charges of trafficking in Colombian cocaine. In developments Monday: _ The government said it was studying whether it would allow Noriega's family safe passage to the Dominican Republic. His wife Felicidad, three daughters and son-in-law, a Dominican, have taken refuge in the Cuban Embassy. Linares said he ``had passed the request for safe conduct to the Ministry of Government and Justice, and if there is no complaint against them they will get consent.'' _First Vice President Ricardo Arias Calderon said the country's Security Force would include specialized military units, but that they would be limited to a few hundreds soldiers and not be big enough to threaten the government. Civilians in the government installed Dec. 20 in the early hours of the U.S. invasion have tried to limit the size of any new security force to avoid danger of coups. The armed forces ruled Panama from 1968 until Noriega's overthrow and have been an important political factor since Panama was founded. _President Guillermo Endara sent a letter to President Bush asking for financial aid to create 24,000 new jobs and for loans to compensate businesses looted by rampaging crowds following the U.S. invasion. Looters caused an estimated $1.5 billion in damage. _More than 600 members of the U.S. 82nd Airborne Division left Panama and returned to Fort Bragg, N.C. In all, about 26,000 U.S. troops took part in the invasion, slightly more than double the number normally stationed in Panama. Arias would not specify when further U.S. troop withdrawals would occur, but said he expected them to be gradual over the next few weeks. _The daily La Prensa, closed nearly two years ago by Noriega, resumed publication with an editorial that assailed the Organization of American States for voting to ``deplore'' the U.S. invasion. It said the United States had freed Panama ``from a barbarian, corrupt and demented tyranny that would have led the country to total ruin with serious risk to the operation of the Panama Canal'' and to the political stability of other Latin American countries. Arias said Noriega followers were still at large and believed to be armed, creating the danger of urban or other guerrilla activity. ``We have confiscated more than 79,000 weapons,'' said Arias, who also is minister of government and justice. ``There are indications there are more weapons stashed away.'' ``We also do not know how the drug-dealing Mafia will react. Noriega had put the resources of this country at their disposal.'' Arias said the 11 p.m. to 5 a.m. curfew would continue for now. The curfew is enforced mostly by patrolling U.S. military units accompanied by one or two members of the Panamanian security force. On Sunday night more than 300 people were arrested for violating the curfew.

DOC.HEAD: $35 Million Lottery Winner a News Conference No-Show
DOC.TEXT: A prankster had no qualms about claiming she held the ticket to a $35 million lottery jackpot. The bona fide winner was the shy one. Antonio Bueti, a 49-year-old auto assembly line worker from suburban Bedford Hills, failed to show up today at a news conference presenting him as the winner of the largest unshared lottery jackpot in New York history. ``I would like to say I think I've seen them all now.
