Nielsen Co. ratings for the week ended Jan. 7 by a wide margin and CBS took over second place again from ABC. The network averages: NBC 15.8, CBS 13.4, ABC 12.1. A ratings point represents the percentage of the nation's 92.1 million television homes tuned to a show. For the season to date, NBC leads with an average of 14.8. ABC is second with 12.9 and CBS is third with 12.2. Here's the Top 10: NBC's ``The Cosby Show'' and ``Cheers'' tied, ABC's ``Roseanne,'' NBC's ``The Golden Girls,'' CBS' ``60 Minutes,'' NBC's ``A Different World,'' CBS' ``Murder, She Wrote,'' NBC's ``Empty Nest'' and ABC's ``Wonder Years'' tied, CBS' ``Designing Women.'' CBS' ``Murder in Black and White,'' the third movie with Richard Crenna in the same role as a New York police detective, was 20th. Its Sunday competition, the NBC miniseries ``Drug Wars: The Camarena Story'' did not do nearly as well. The opening episode of the three-part show was in a three-way tie for 34th. Two new series had premieres last week. ABC's ``Father Dowling Mysteries'' was 46th and CBS' ``Max Monroe: Loose Cannon'' was 58th. Here's how the other bowl games fared: ABC's Rose Bowl tied for 28th, NBC's Fiesta Bowl 61st and ABC's Sugar Bowl 75th. Fox Broadcasting Co.'s ``Married ... With Children'' tied for 43rd place. CBS took first place among the evening news shows away from ABC for the week. ABC fell to second place by a tenth of a point. ``The CBS Evening News'' was on five days last week, while ABC and NBC did not have Monday shows. The ratings: CBS 12.0, ABC 11.9, NBC 11.0. The lowest-rated show was ABC's ``Mission: Impossible.'' Here are the five bottom network shows: ABC's ``Saturday Night With Connie Chung,'' ABC's ``Life Goes On,'' CBS' ``Tour of Duty,'' ABC's Sugar Bowl, ABC's ``Mission: Impossible.''

DOC.HEAD: Nursing Aide Pleads To Murder Of 75-Year-Old Patient
DOC.TEXT: A former nursing assistant with AIDS who confessed killing seven elderly patients, then said the confessions were bogus, pleaded guilty Tuesday to murdering one of those patients and was sentenced to life. Jeffrey Feltner, 27, who has said he gave bogus confessions to draw attention to poor conditions in nursing homes, pleaded guilty to first-degree murder in the death of a 75-year-old woman after prosecutors played recordings of his previous statements about the deaths. ``Feltner heard his taped confessions and after hearing the evidence entered a plea of guilty,'' said assistant state attorney David Damore. A jury had been seated for his trial just the day before. Feltner confessed numerous times during a year-long investigation of the seven suspicious retirement home deaths, police said, adding that the victims were smothered. Feltner was sentenced to life with a mandatory minimum of 25 years. He could have faced the death penalty if convicted of first-degree murder in February 1988 of a 75-year-old resident of the New Life Acres retirement home in Melrose, a North Florida city 20 miles west of Palatka. ``It was an excellent and wise move on his behalf,'' said Feltner's attorney, Howard Pearl. ``But he denies killing anyone. His statements would have damaged him. I felt it was time for damage control.'' Feltner still faces murder charges in nearby Volusia County in the death of an 83-year-old woman and attorneys were trying to work out a plea in that case. Prosecutors did not press charges in the remaining five deaths; in four of those cases the bodies had already been cremated. Asked the motive for the killings, Damore replied: ``You would have to ask Jeffrey Feltner. Obviously you have a person with a very troubled mind.'' Pearl said Feltner has acquired immune deficiency syndrome and is receiving treatments with the drug AZT. ``He wants to be treated for AIDS,'' said Pearl. ``He wants to recover his health.'' After he was arrested last summer and charged with killing a Volusia County patient, Feltner wrote a letter to his father and stepmother in Michigan explaining that he had not killed anyone, but had devised a plan that would help officials notice poor nursing-home conditions. ``I wanted to spend what time I have left to do something that everyone would be proud of but like always, I messed up,'' Feltner wrote. ``When I went to work in the nursing homes and saw the abuse they were getting I told myself that I would try and help them,'' he wrote. ``Everything I tried to do did not work so I had to say that I killed some people, hoping that they would see the abuse that they were getting.'' Feltner's father and stepmother, Kasper and Norma Feltner of Michigan, have said they believe he is innocent.

DOC.HEAD: Freeze Reduces Acreage for Harvest in Florida, Texas
DOC.TEXT: The freezing Christmas weather that ripped into winter vegetable areas of Florida and Texas sharply reduced acreage to be harvested for broccoli, celery, lettuce and tomatoes, according to an Agriculture Department report Tuesday. Overall, farmers are expected to have about 191,000 acres of seven selected winter vegetables for harvest this season, down 8 percent from a year ago, the report said. No production estimates were given in the report. In Texas, for example, no carrots are expected to be harvested, although carrot acreage is up in California and Florida. Celery for harvest in Florida is down 14 percent from a year ago, however, and the sweet corn acreage was reported down by 35 percent. The Texas lettuce acreage was reported to be cut 79 percent from last winter, while the Florida tomato acreage is down 32 percent. But the Florida harvest of winter strawberries is expected to be from 5,400 acres, up 2 percent from last year. ``Growers saved most plants from the Christmas weekend freeze by forming ice caps on plants with overhead sprinklers,'' the report said. ``The freeze will lower yields because fewer pickings will be made. Virtually all plants are expected to survive if temperatures remain moderate for the next few weeks.'' Looking at the carrot situation, most of Florida's crop was destroyed, although growers ``are expected to replant most, if not all, of the lost acreage,'' the report said. Part of the severely damaged crop in the Rio Grande Valley of Texas may be salvaged by hand harvesting ``if the price is high enough.'' Department analysts have said that while citrus and fresh vegetable prices are expected to rise in the first quarter, overall consumer food prices in 1990 are still expected to go up a modest 3 percent to 5 percent, compared with an average of 5.7 percent in 1989, the sharpest gain since 1981. One reason is that vegetable fields can be replanted quickly so that there's a minimum lag in supplies, they said. In a related report, the government's Joint Agricultural Weather Facility said Florida vegetable farmers enjoyed warm weather in major producing areas during the week of Dec. 31-Jan. 6. ``Planting and replanting was active under nearly ideal weather conditions,'' the report said. ``Harvest continued, but supplies of most crops were reduced.'' The joint facility, which is operated by the Agriculture and Commerce departments, said freeze damage in Texas ``became more evident'' in the Rio Grande Valley. ``Lettuce and celery were severely damaged, and onions also suffered some loss,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Gather to Mourn and Rejoice; Anti-U.S. Protest Held
LaserPhotos PAN5,6
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Panamanians celebrated the downfall of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega at a memorial Mass Tuesday, and about 150 others marched in the first anti-American demonstration since the Dec. 20 invasion. Both events commemorated the Day of the Martyrs, a national holiday in memory of 23 Panamanians who died in anti-American riots in 1964. The throng of 8,000 at the outdoor Mass in suburban El Dorado were more in a mood to celebrate than to mourn the dead, shouting ``Viva Panama!'' as priests, nuns and religious workers asked ``Jesus to guide me and help me build the new society.'' Archbishop Marcos McGrath presided before an audience that used colorful umbrellas to protect themselves from a hot morning sun followed by rain. Those attending included President Guillermo Endara, first and second vice presidents Ricardo Arias Calderon and Guillermo Ford and papal nuncio Sebastian Laboa. ``The hatred and rancor sown in the past cannot and should not characterize the future,'' said McGrath in his homily, dubbing the day one of ``Reconciliation, Conversion and Recontruction.'' Meanwhile, about 150 people held the first demonstration against the U.S. Army assault, gathering at Santa Teresa church in Maranon, a low-income neighborhood less than a mile from Noriega's former Defense Headquarters, for a Mass celebrated by six priests, including three Americans. ``Endara, Arias Calderon and Ford will be remembered by future Panamanian generations as oligarchs in the service of a foreign power,'' said a pamphlet distributed by the tiny Socialist Workers Party, which opposed Noriega the six years he was in power. The marchers included university students and labor leaders who said they had also opposed Noriega but condemned ``the savage Yankee invasion that cut an open wound in our national sovereignty.'' Noriega often presented himself as Panama's defender against U.S. aggression and representative of a generation with a mission to gain control of the Panama Canal, which will be taken over by Panama on Dec. 31, 1999. The Day of the Martyrs commemorates one of the flashpoints of Panamanian nationalism, the Jan. 9, 1964 riots that left 23 Panamanians and four U.S. soldiers dead. The riots began in a dispute over whether the Panamanian flag should fly at Balboa High School. ``It's a day of profound deep thought so none of these things happen ever again,'' second vice president Ford told a reporter. U.S. troops searching for Noriega henchmen continued to surround several embassies including the Peruvian ambassador's residence, where Peru said it granted diplomatic asylum to a top Noriega security aide and 11 others. The security aide, Capt. Gonzalo Gonzalez, was granted asylum along with Noriega's secretary, Capt. Marcela Tason; his top press spokesman, Maj. Edgardo Lopez Grimaldo, and Maj. Heraclides Sucre, a commander of the elite Battalion 2000. Peruvian charge d'affairs Luis Sandiga denied Panamanian charges that the residence was sheltering Lt. Col. Luis ``Papo'' Cordova, one of Noriega's most-wanted associates. The only security at the El Dorado Mass was a handful of bodyguards around the new Panamanian leaders, while dozens of unarmed firemen and young men and women from the Scouts of Panama cordoned off the crowd with ropes. Under huge Panamanian and Vatican flags, about 80 priests donned white robes over blue jeans to assist McGrath in communion. The archbishop, presiding from a podium in front of a looted dress shop stacked with undressed mannequins, asked those who plundered stores throughout Panama City to return the goods, make financial amends or provide community service. ``Do it,'' he said. ``Take it upon your soul to remove that stain from your home, community and your conscience.'' ``We are all a little to blame for all the evil which befell us,'' said McGrath. ``Everyone should recognize that in their hearts. If we don't do that, the errors of the past will be repeated.'' The dozens gathered for the protest marched 20 blocks in silence to the Amador cemetery, near the joint U.S.-Panamanian installation at Fort Amador, where some of the 1964 victims are buried. The Rev. Jose Luis Medina said Panamanians were ``confused'' and that's why they were celebrating the American invasion. ``We must accompany these people, be patient with them,'' he said. The Rev. Diego Caffley, a Philadelphian who has been in Panama 17 years, said Panamanians should ``help recreate true nationalism, not the phony nationalism of the old regime.'' The crowd waved Panamanian flags and banners reading ``The Fatherland is in Mourning,'' and broke up after about 10 minutes at the cemetery. At the huge El Dorado Mass, Panamanians waved white lace handkerchiefs in the rain and sang the national anthem as the Mass ended. Asked if he forgave Noriega and the Dignity Battalion henchmen who beat him after the May 7 presidential election, Ford said: ``Look I'm a Catholic and if you repent, I forgive. But I don't Know if Mr. Noriega has repented.'' Noriega, imprisoned in Miami, faces U.S. drug trafficking charges that carry penalties totaling 145 years in jail. Officials say about 600 Panamanian soldiers and civilians died during the U.S. invasion that ousted Noriega. Twenty-three U.S. soldiers also died in the invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Urban League Says Switch Military Dollars to Help Minorities
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with assessment quote, inserting new 3rd graf
DOC.TEXT: The president of the National Urban League said Tuesday that reduced East-West tensions represent a ``narrow window of opportunity'' to switch military dollars to help blacks, whose economic progress was stalled during the military buildup of the 1980s. Government and business leaders should use the money to develop an urban Marshall Plan and investment bank to help close the economic gap between whites and blacks and ensure American competitiveness in the 21st century, said league president, John E. Jacob, as the civil rights group released its annual assessment on the status of black Americans. Jacob said in the overview of the report that ``the state of black America remains critical,'' despite a year of hope that began with a new administration and ended with changing world conditions that might shift national concern and resources to domestic issues, ``At a time when we hear policymakers talk of a new Marshall Plan and a new economic development bank for eastern Europe, we need to press for an urban Marshall Plan and an urban investment bank that invests in our own people and in our own cities,'' Jacob said at a news conference. The plan would be aimed at bringing ``the people at the margins of our society into the mainstream to become producers in a productive society,'' Jacob said. Jacob said money for the plan could come from cutting the $300 billion defense budget in half to $150 billion. He said a government investment of $50 billion to help minorities rise would demonstrate a ``national will and commitment.'' He recommended using $100 billion to reduce the federal deficit. President Bush has said that if there is a ``peace dividend'' it will go to lowering the federal deficit and not to expanding social programs. And he told high school students in Denver on Dec. 8 that the notion that Congress might make ``drastic slashes in the defense budget and then take the money in what's called a peace dividend'' was ``crazy.'' ``I will not acquiesce in that,'' Bush said. ``The Eastern European change is very exciting and can lead, through arms control agreements, to agreed lower levels of defense,'' Bush said then. ``Even though that's happening, I think it would be imprudent to make reckless cuts in our defense.'' Previous League reports decried efforts to dismantle social programs in the Reagan era and spoke of increased racism in the 1980s, but Jacob said increased access to the Bush administration made him optimistic about government response to his organization's new recommendations. ``We spent $2 trillion in the past ten years on defense because we were locked into a wartime mentality that now has no basis in fact,'' said Jacob, citing recent events in East Europe. ``The end of the Cold War must mean the start of a renewed drive to bring America into the 21st century by investing in its people and its economy,'' he added. The League's urban Marshall plan would include emphasis on developing effective education, jobs and training, health care and housing programs for minorities and women. Jacob said minority and female workers would make up the largest portion of new workers during the 1990s. The original Marshall Plan was a U.S. aid program that helped Europe recover from the devastation of World War II. The country's need for more skilled and technologically adept workers to compete in current global markets represents an opportunity for blacks, said Jacob, who warned that others might support efforts to import workers from elsewhere. ``America simply will not be able to compete with the Japanese and the Europeans unless America develops the human resources, and the only ones we currently have are those who are being squandered among the minorities,'' he said. Jacob did not offer specifics for the plan, but included in the League's report, ``The State of Black America _ 1990,'' are 12 chapters of discussions on such topics as recent Supreme Court civil rights decisions, black-on-black crime and the election of the nation's first black governor, L. Douglas Wilder in Virginia. Jacob said U.S. businesses also had a vested interest in black educational and economic progress, citing a recent incident involving a New York firm that was forced to test 57,000 people before the company found 2,000 people qualified for jobs it needed to fill.

DOC.HEAD: Human Rights Group Reports Massacre Of At Least 200 Liberians
DOC.TEXT: At least 200 Liberian civilians were massacred in northern Liberia, and eyewitnesses fleeing the country attribute the killings to government forces, a human rights group reported Tuesday. The killings are the result of a Dec. 24 attempt to topple President Samuel K. Doe, according to Africa Watch. The organization is a division of the private Human Rights Watch that monitors abuses around the world. President Felix Houphouet-Boigny of neighboring Ivory Coast reported that between 8,000 and 10,000 Liberians fled into his country in recent days, the group said. ``Africa Watch has also received reports of a shoot-to-kill policy instituted by President Doe, who has instructed troops fighting rebel forces to shoot on sight any persons engaged in suspicious activities,'' the organization said. Its statement also said three Liberian villages along the border with the Ivory Coast _ Kahnplay, Boutuo and Lepulah _ were destroyed in the fighting. Doe, a former army sergeant who seized power in a 1980 coup, told a rally in Monrovia on Saturday that government troops were searching for more rebels. He ordered his countrymen to turn in the dissidents, whom he said were based in the Ivory Coast. This is the second coup attempt against Doe in four years, although he has accused opponents of plotting additional overthrows which he foiled. Critics say he concocted some of the alleged plots in order to eliminate rivals. The State Department said it did not have any information or comment about the coup attempt and the reported killings. Human Rights Watch last week accused the Bush administration of failing to use its leverage with Doe to speak out against his violations. Liberia, founded by former American slaves in the 19th century, is the largest recipient of U.S. aid per capita in sub-Saharan Africa and a strategic ally of the United States. It is the only nation in western Africa that allows U.S. military planes to refuel, and the administration's Voice of America has transmitters there. ``We believe such factors cannot justify funding and silently condoning abuses by the Liberian government,'' said Human Right Watch.

DOC.HEAD: Turkey, Bulgaria End Talks on Ethnic Turks' Rights
With AM-Bulgaria
DOC.TEXT: Foreign ministers Mesut Yilmaz of Turkey and Boiko Dimitrov of Bulgaria ended a second session of talks on the rights of ethnic Turkish Moslems in Bulgaria and said a joint communique would be issued Wednesday. Neither minister would say much about Tuesday's meeting, nor would officials from Kuwait, which is mediating the dispute. However, sources close to the talks said Turkey seemed inclined to accept as sufficient redress the new Bulgarian government's reversal of the assimilation campaign pursued by ousted Communist leader Todor Zhivkov. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Dimitrov gave assurances the new administration in Sofia would not yield to pressure of widespread demonstrations in Bulgaria against the reversal. They implied that the issue of more than 300,000 ethnic Turks who fled Bulgaria last year and sought refuge in Turkey now was going to be left as an issue between Turkey and the refugees. Some have been returning after the new Bulgarian decisions, but many have so far preferred to remain in Turkey. Under the assimilation policy, ethnic Turks could not speak their mother tongue or practice the Moslem religion and were forced to adopt Bulgarian names. ``The two ministers conducted in a constructive and frank spirit a detailed and comprehensive review of the relations between Bulgaria and Turkey and means of normalizing these relations in the future,'' their brief statement said. It said the two ministers on Tuesday ``also expresed their government's desire to improve their relations on a sound basis of mutual benefit with a view to reaching better understanding.'' The statement said both sides would hold a meeting toward this end at the opening session of an international ``open atmosphere'' conference in Ottawa on Feb. 22-25. During a break in the working sessions, Yilmaz and Dimitrov described the talks as positive, but gave no details. The first round of talks under Kuwaiti auspices were held in October. At that time, Turkey pressed for guaranteed rights of the refugees as well as the rest of the Turkish minority in Bulgaria. It also sought a settlement of the refugee problem within its borders, possibly with the financial help of other Moslem countries. Foreign Minister Sheik Sabah al-Ahmed of Kuwait inaugurated the second session at Bayan Palace, eight miles south of the city center. Kuwait is involved as president of the 46-member Organization of the Islamic Conference. In another development Tuesday, Bulgaria's ambassador in Britain, Dimitar Zhulev, said his government will hold an inquiry into the 1978 murder of Georgi Markov, a Bulgarian emigre believed to have been murdered in London by a poisoned umbrella. Zhulev told Foreign Office Minister William Waldegrave that Markov had been reinstated as a posthumous member of the Union of Bulgarian Writers that restored his professional status. British investigators concluded that Markov, who worked for the British Broadcasting Corp.'s Bulgarian service, was killed by poison injected through an umbrella tip as he waited for a bus on Sept. 29, 1978. ``I think that this really has to be cleared up before we can see a new Bulgaria because it is a stain on its reputation,'' Markov's widow, Annabel, said in an interview with BBC-TV. Mrs. Markov has gone to Bulgaria seeking more information on the case. Waldegrave, a personal friend of the Markovs, last month asked Bulgarian authorities to open up the books on the case.

DOC.HEAD: Results for 1990 Integra, Lumina and Eclipse Announced
DOC.TEXT: Drivers of the 1990 Mitsubishi Eclipse hatchback and Chevrolet Lumina sedan run a ``possible'' risk of head injury in a collision, federal safety officials said. No comparable risk was found for drivers of the 1990 Acura Integra sedan, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration also said. The risk of head injury to passengers was less than probable. So was the risk of chest injury to drivers and passengers, also when data were available. NHTSA's report Monday on crash tests of the three vehicles was the first for the 1990 model year under the New Car Assessment Program. The vehicles were tested by driving them head-on into a fixed barrier, creating the same conditions as a head-on collision between two identical vehicles at 35 miles an hour. The test results apply only to occupants using seat belts and, in certain cars, air bags. The tests are conducted using dummies that represent an average-sized adult male. According to the NHTSA index, a score of 750 or lower means head injury is unlikely; 750-1,250 means head injury is possible; and anything higher means head injury is likely. Chest injury numbers above 60 indicate that chest injury is likely. The lower any of the numbers, the lower the potential for injury. But for purposes of comparison vehicles have to be of the same type and weigh within 500 pounds of each other. The Integra and Eclipse are both light vehicles in the 2,500-2,999 pound range. The Integra had a driver head injury rating of 585, passenger head injury rating of 637 and a passenger chest injury rating of 42. No information was available on driver chest injuries. The Lumina, which rates as a heavy vehicle at 3,632 pounds, had a driver head injury rating of 1,200, with no data on passenger head injuries. The driver chest injury rating was 58, and there was no data on passenger chest injuries. The report marks the first time the agency categorized vehicles by weight, specified the occupant protection system and used the categories ``unlikely,'' ``possible,'' or ``likely.''

DOC.HEAD: Group Proposes Quality Education for Minorities
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf pvs, The QEM, with 2 grafs to delete erroneous reference to $27 billion cost and to insert projected cost of one recommendation; subs 15th graf pvs, _Establish longer, to edit.
DOC.TEXT: Educators concerned with the plight of minority students offered Tuesday a wide-ranging plan to restructure American education, including one proposal to stop grouping elementary school students by age. ``Improving education is the most important challenge facing America if we are to maintain our ability to compete in the world and sustain our standard of living,'' said Ray Marshall, former secretary of labor who is chairman of the Action Council, a part of the Quality Education for Minorities Project. ``With minorities comprising 70 percent of the enrollment in the top (largest) 25 U.S. school districts and 40 percent of the new entrants into the work force over the next decade, it is clear that success in the education of minorities is synonymous with continued economic success for America,'' said Marshall, a professor at the University of Texas at Austin. The QEM Project, which is based at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and directed by Shirley McBay, dean for Student Affairs at MIT, is funded by a $1.2 million grant from the Carnegie Corp. Fifty-eight major changes are recommended for the nation's educational system. The entire list of recommendations would cost billions of dollars and officials estimate it would require $37 billion alone for one recommendation, that each student attend school for 12 straight months every three years. Key recommendations contained in the group's national study, ``Education That Works,'' would ``radically transform'' elementary and middle-school education so that students no longer compete with their peers but work more in groups and teams. Project officials describe the study and the ``action plan'' as the ``first comprehensive, national strategy prepared by and for minority Americans to improve the entire educational system.'' More than two years were spent gathering information that reflect the experience and ideas of five minority groups _ Alaska Natives, American Indians, Afro-Americans, Mexican-Americans and Puerto Ricans. One recommendation was to eliminate the practice of grouping students by their abilities and their ages while in elementary school. ``Many alert and curious minority youngsters arrive in kindergarten eager to learn, yet are channelled into school structures that sap their curiosity and numb their minds,'' said the report. ``By the third grade, they begin to fall behind and may be at a grave disadvantage educationally before they leave elementary school.'' Instead, the study called for a system of grouping and grading students based on their mastery of specific skills, or combination of skills. ``This approach lends itself particularly well to cooperative learning and team teaching,'' the report said. Middle schools, the report said, should be redesigned into small learning communities ``so that minority students would have the opportunity to establish key relationships with teachers and other adults who can help the youngsters foster belief in their own potential as well as in the value of education itself.'' High schools should replace the general curriculum with a ``core academic curriculum'' jointly developed by representatives of the local community, business, higher education, and ethnic organizations. In this way, students can move from high school to either college or the workforce. Other recommendations were to: _Establish longer school days and years to prevent summer learning losses and pay teachers for the additional time. _Improve the image, pay and benefits of the teaching profession. _Make student achievement the main criterion against which teachers and administrators are judged. _Respect and value the culture of each child in the curriculum.

DOC.HEAD: Official: Nations Rejecting Damaged Tanker May Cause New Oil Spill
DOC.TEXT: The head of Iran's tanker operations said Tuesday that its damaged ship in the Atlantic was in danger of spilling more oil in rough seas because Spain would not allow it into their territorial waters, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported. Mohammed Souri, managing director of the National Iranian Tanker Co., also explained the reasons behind the Dec. 19 explosion that caused the Khark 5 to spill what oil experts said was 19 million gallons of oil off Morocco. He said a piece of the ship's superstructure tore off in 100 mph winds and slammed onto the deck, sparking an explosion in a tank. The explosion caused several other blasts, including a fire that salvage crews were summoned to extinguish, Souri said. The crew was forced to abandon ship 400 miles north of the Canary Islands. Salvage officials said the blasts punched a hole in the side of the ship, allowing crude to leak into the sea. Souri however said the amount of oil spilled was not known. The spill threatened to seriously damage the fisheries and beaches of the Moroccan coast, but oil experts said the area's warm waters and rough seas broke up virtually all of the spill. Souri accused Morocco of exaggerating the incident. ``The Moroccan government ... has launched a wide-scale propaganda tirade and called for financial aid from some countries with the aim of hollow financial claims,'' IRNA reported him as saying. Souri said the Spanish government, instead of dispatching war ships to shadow the tanker, should allow the tanker into one of its ports so the oil on board could be transferred to a supertanker. Salvage officials said 53 million gallons of light Iranian crude oil remain on board. The Iranian official said rough weather was hindering the transfer and risked a renewed spill. ``If the ship was allowed to discharge its crude into another ship, the amount of pollution would be greatly less than it is now,'' Souri said. Spanish maritime officials on Monday said three tugs were towing the Khark 5 to calm seas off the Cape Verde Islands in order to safely transfer the oil. They said the voyage could take 10 days. Smit Tak, the Dutch salvage company in charge of the operation, said the ship had not leaked since last Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Prof `Delighted' By Ruling; Penn Worries Of Candid Tenure Reviews
With AM-Scotus Rdp
DOC.TEXT: A former University of Pennsylvania professor praised a Supreme Court ruling Tuesday that ordered the school to disclose information she claims will show she was denied tenure because of discrimination. ``I'm very delighted with the decision,'' said Rosalie Tung, now a business professor at the University of Wisconsin. ``I fought for the principle and I'm glad that I won it.'' Penn and its supporters expressed concern the decision might chill tenure review of academics by their peers. Ms. Tung, then an associate professor of management at Penn, complained after she was denied tenure in 1985 at the university's Wharton School of Business. She filed a complaint with the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission charging she was the victim of illegal discrimination against women and people of Asian descent. Her complaint said her qualifications were equal to or better than those of five male faculty members who received more favorable treatment. Unanimously rejecting ``academic freedom'' arguments, the court said colleges and universities enjoy no special privilege to withhold peer review records used in awarding tenure, a lifetime appointment. Penn claimed confidentiality in the tenure process was necessary to ensure candor by reviewers. ``If there is a `smoking gun' to be found that demonstrates discrimination in tenure decisions, it is likely to be tucked away in peer review files,'' Justice Harry Blackmun wrote for the court. Sarah Burns, of the National Organization for Women Legal Defense and Education Fund, agreed ``the critical issue is `Are there any smoking guns?''' ``If the university can withhold those documents, then the university may be able to hide the very evidence that can prove discrimination,'' said Ms. Burns. Ms. Tung, who declined to say if she wants to return to Penn, said documents the EEOC sought in her case were obtained by a Penn grievance commission that determined she was discriminated against because of race and sex when she was denied tenure. Penn general counsel Shelley Green denied that claim. ``There is absolutely no finding of discrimination in that report,'' Ms. Green said. ``It is our hope that faculty members will still participate and provide forthright evaluations of candidates for tenure,'' Ms. Green said. ``We worry that this will discourage some participation. ``We are concerned people will just not be as forthcoming if people know there is no confidentiality.'' Sheldon Steinbach of the American Council on Education, which along with Princeton, Brown, Stanford, Harvard and Yale had backed Penn, said the decision could make the tenure review process less candid. ``The decision may drive portions of the process underground. For example, phone conversations may play a larger role,'' he said. Ms. Burns said the case involves ``very core material'' to determine whether there was a principle reason to promote or not promote someone. Ms. Burns also said not all universities guarantee confidentiality of reviews to evaluators. ``We are thrilled,'' said Lorry Halloway, a Washington lawyer who represented various organizations opposed to Penn's non-disclosure policy. Had the court ruled otherwise, she said, proving discrimination by an institution of higher learning would have been much more difficult. ``That's why this case was so important,'' she said. ``We were optimistic, but this (unanimous decision) is terrific,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrilla Chief Calls Flight 103 Bomb Charges Blackmail
DOC.TEXT: Radical Palestinian guerrilla leader Ahmed Jibril said Tuesday that Western accusations that he engineered the bombing of a Pan Am jumbo jet over Scotland were a deliberate attempt to blackmail Syria. Jibril, a former Syrian army captain, heads the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command. He was blamed in the Dec. 21, 1988, explosion of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie that killed 270 people. ``We believe that this campaign is aimed at blackmailing Syria and President Hafez Assad because the United States and (President) Bush believe the time is ripe to settle scores with countries and movements hostile to imperialism,'' Jibril told a hastily arranged news conference in west Beirut. He said the United States and France also hold Syria responsible for the 1983 suicide truck bombings of the U.S. Marine base and French paratroop headquarters in Beirut that killed 241 U.S. servicemen and 58 Frenchmen. ``But they do not want to face Syria outright so they did it indirectly by trying to implicate us in the (Lockerbie) bombing,'' Jibril said. ``We say it loud and clear that ... Assad is not a Noriega and Syria is not a banana republic,'' he said, referring to last month's U.S. invasion of Panama and the arrest of former dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega. Asked if he condemns the Lockerbie bombing, Jibril replied, ``We condemn all acts that lead to the killing of civilians and innocents. ``But by the same token I want to ask, hasn't Bush in his recent attack on Panama willfully killed children, women and infants?'' An estimated 600 Panamanian soldiers and civilians died in the U.S. invasion, as did 23 Americans, most of them soldiers. He dismissed as ``just fabrications'' reports that his group and Iran plotted the Lockerbie attack together. Jibril and other Syrian-backed radical guerrilla groups broke ranks with Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization over PLO recognition of Israel's right to exist. Jibril rejected a call by another breakaway leader, Kahled Fahoum, for a reunification of all dissident factions with the PLO. ``We will talk to Arafat only when he retracts the concessions he has made to Israel and the United States,'' he said. Another Syrian-backed dissident, Col. Saeed Mousa, also rejected Fahoum's call on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: New Mexican to Pentagon Post
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Tuesday he will nominate Colin Riley McMillan, a New Mexico oilman and banker, to be assistant secretary of defense for production and logistics. McMillan, 54, of Roswell, N.M., is chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Permian Exploration Corp. and chairman of the board of First Federal Savings Bank of Roswell. If confirmed by the Senate, he would succeed Jack Katzen in the Pentagon post.

DOC.HEAD: Mob Sacks Old Panamanian Defense Headquarters Building
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A mob on Tuesday stripped bare the three-story green and gray Defense Force headquarters, a hated symbol of the power Manuel Antonio Noriega once wielded. Hundreds descended on the complex embracing Noriega's former office, surrounding military barracks and intelligence building, damaged by heavy fire from U.S. tanks the night of the invasion. U.S. soldiers watched from a short distance away as Panamanians tore apart walls with sledge hammers and hauled away window frames, sheets of plywood, footlockers and tin sheets. U.S. engineers plan to raze the buildings later. Some Panamanians built fires in the concrete patio next to cars destroyed during the bombing and the fire that followed the Dec. 20 invasion. On one wall, in big letters there was a Noriega declaration that read: ``Every man must at one time in his life decide whether he dares go for victory, risking everything, or sit down and watch the victors walk by.'' On another wall, someone had written: ``Pineapple face; coward.'' It referred to a nickname describing Noriega's pock-marked face. Noriega fled the night of the invasion, went into hiding and four days later, on Christmas Eve, asked for asylum in the Vatican Embassy. On Jan. 3 he surrendered to the U.S. Army and was flown to Miami to face federal drug trafficking charges. In front of the old building, young men approached visitors offering old Defense Forces shoulder patches, pictures of Noriega with other officers, letters and other Noriega memorabilia. One opened a large folder and offered a collection of European pornographic magazines along with pictures of Noriega. ``Make me an offer for this,'' he said, offering the entire package. ``Let them (the military) pay, too,'' said Pedro Ayala, who said he had come from a nearby town. ``My brother and I lived in El Chorrillo. He lost everything,'' said Ricardo Aparicio, 26, dressed in fatigue pants. Most of El Chorrillo, a block away from Defense Forces headquarters, burned down during the attack. ``The boots (military) used to run everything. They ruled. Not now, it's over,'' Aparicio said, leaning on a sack of various items he and a friend had taken. ``We all lost something. Let them lose something, too.''. A perspiring friend who identified himself only as Fidel dropped rolls of copper wire and telephone wire near Aparicio's sack. ``There is nothing left,'' he said. ``People just swept everything.''

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Newspaper Defends Planned U.S. Operation to Interdict Drugs
DOC.TEXT: Support solidified Tuesday for a U.S. task force to stop drug smugglers in the Caribbean when the country's largest circulation newspaper said critics are rejecting Colombia's strongest ally in the drug war. The daily El Tiempo said in an editorial that lack of information from the American and Colombian governments had led to misinformation and hysteria. ``In a war, allies cannot be rejected; they must be sought,'' it said. Foreign Minister Julio Londono Paredes has criticized U.S. plans for the task force, led by the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy, to increase air and sea patrols in international waters off Colombia. He said Monday, ``Any type of interference on the high seas would need the authorization of the Colombian government, especially of the minister of defense. Obviously, it wouldn't be acceptable in national territory.'' Secretary-General German Montoya and other government officials called Londono's position ``very hard-line,'' leading to widespread speculation that a rift has developed between the foreign minister and President Virgilio Barco. Londono late Monday denied a radio report he planned to resign after failing to persuade Barco to condemn the U.S. plan, according to El Tiempo. Colombia's ambassador to the United States, Victor Mosquera Chaux, said in an interview late Monday broadcast by Radio Caracol that the Bush administration did not plan to search Colombian ships without permission from the Bogota government. Barco has made no comment about the planned operations. El Tiempo said fears of U.S. intervention in Colombia were heightened by the U.S. invasion of Panama last month. El Tiempo's editors wrote, ``A feeling near dread has emerged so that at least part of public opinion already hears the stomping of Marines' boots in the streets. For this reason, we demand more explicit information from the Colombian and U.S. governments.'' It said the news media were responsible for much of the misinformation about the U.S. action, originally reported as an attempt to enter Colombian waters and blockade its coast. U.S. officials said repeatedly any operations will take place in international waters. El Tiempo also blamed ``diehard leftists'' and ``juvenile minds'' for contributing to the row. The daily, which often takes pro-U.S. stands on issues, repeated its criticism of the U.S. invasion of Panama, but said the Caribbean operations do not pose a similar threat to Colombia. It noted that the Vienna Convention, signed by Colombia and the United States, allows ships of either country to stop and search vessels suspected of carrying narcotics in international waters. ``What the United States is offering is to set up a net of vigilance in international waters,'' El Tiempo said. ``It is incredible that such logical and realistic measures could create a psychosis of illegal intervention and invasion.'' But Maria Jimena Duzan, a columnist for Bogota's El Espectador, called the proposed U.S. operation ``a unilateral act that directly assaults (Colombian) national interests.'' She said Washington was following a failed policy of trying ``to militarize'' Colombia and other South American drug-producing countries. She addressed herself to President Bush. Referring to his administration's invasion of Panama to capture its leader, Manuel Antonio Noriega, she wrote, ``You used 30,000 troops to invade a country in search of one drug trafficker, who almost got away.'' She said Colombia shot and killed a major drug trafficker, Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha, in an operation ``carried out by only 15 men.'' The Medellin cartel leader died in a Dec. 15 gunfight with police in northern Colombia. In the Uraba region of northern Colombia, seven people were killed and three wounded when attackers fired on a house, the Antioquia state government said Tuesday. A communique, citing initial police reports, indicated the killings occurred Sunday in Necocli, 300 miles northwest of Bogota. Leftist guerrillas and right-wing death squads are active in Uraba, bordering Panama. Death squads have been blamed for previous killings of peasants who work on banana plantations and of union leaders who organize them.

DOC.HEAD: Radicals Bow to Khamenei Warning, But Unrest Reported
DOC.TEXT: Radical parliamentarians Tuesday bowed to a warning from Iran's spiritual leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei to back the government, Tehran Radio said, while the opposition reported the arrest of a senior cleric critical of the regime. The lawmakers' move appeared to dampen a barrage of criticism of President Hashemi Rafsanjani's policies the last few weeks that brought into the open a power struggle between himself and former Interior Minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi. Tehran Radio, monitored in Nicosia, quoted Parliament speaker Mahdi Karrubi, a key radical, as saying: ``Today, when an excellent force is in charge of the executive, all of us have a revolutionary and religious duty to help him solve the difficulties to the best of his ability.'' Karrubi, addressing the 270-member Majlis, or parliament, stressed: ``We are always ready to cooperate with the government, and I assure you that any criticism ... will be entirely ... to the benefit of the Islamic order.'' The Majlis has been debating Rafsajani's five-year development plan, which calls for foreign investment to revitalize the economy, and has yet to approve it. Khamenei, who is allied to Rafsanjani, Monday issued a sternly worded statement warning after weeks of parliamentary sniping at Rafsanjani's six-month-old government that he will not tolerate any effort by ``any individual, faction or group'' to undermine the Islamic Republic. Parliament is dominated by radicals who oppose the policies advocated by Rafsanjani, leader of Tehran's more pragmatic faction. These center on restoring relations with the West and securing foreign investment to revitalize the war-ravaged economy. Hard-liners believe foreign involvement will undermine the Islamic revolution. Khamenei, who advocates free enterprise, stressed that ``any act or word which shakes the spirit of confidence of the people toward the government and authorities, and creates even the slightest doubt in their support, is ... a national treachery.'' Khamenei succeeded the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini as Iran's spritual leader following the revolutionary patriarch's death June 3. Constitutionally, he has the last word on questions of state and religion. His warning Monday was the second he has issued in two weeks, pointing to official concern at the increasing attacks on Rafsanjani's government by the radicals. Khamenei intervened last month after Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati, a top Rafsanjani aide, was summoned to the Majlis to explain why his ministry had arranged a visit by Romanian President Nicolae Ceausescu to Tehran in December while his countrymen were in revolt and being massacred by his secret police. Khamenei urged parliament to drop the issue and ``support the government at this sensitive juncture.'' But parliament defied him and ordered Velayati to appear for further questioning. In Monday's warning, Khamenei said that as supreme leader he must be obeyed and that anyone who failed to do so were ``traitors'' to the revolution and religion. He said he would punish those who questioned his leadership. Karrubi reassured Khamenei Tuesday that if ``the spiritual leader considers an issue prudent, the Majlis will surely abide by it, and is duty-bound to accept it,'' the radio reported. But the Iraq-based Mujahedeen-Khalq, or People's Holy Warriors, reported Tuesday that Ayatollah Hussein-Ali Montazeri, until last year Khomeini's designated successor, was briefly arrested last week for criticizing the president. In a statement telexed to The Associated Press from its Baghdad headquarters, the main Iranian oppostion group said Montazeri was seized Jan. 6 from his house in the holy city of Qom, but released hours later amid mounting tension in the city. The Mujahedeen report could not be independently confirmed. But violence flared in Qom and Montazeri's home province of Isfahan last April after Khomeini ditched him as heir apparent for criticizing his policies. The Mujahedeen report claimed that Montazeri's criticism of Rafsanjani and Khamenei had been welcomed by other senior clerics at odds with the leadership. Last week, Montazeri branded Rafsanjani and his allies ``traitors'' following reports that Israel bought 2 million barrels of oil worth $36 million from Iran in November in an apparent effort to secure the release of Israelis held by Iranian-backed militants in Lebanon. Iran denied that, but the U.S. State Department confirmed the deal had taken place.

DOC.HEAD: Ask Soviets For Help In Investigation, Senators Say
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration should ask the Soviet Union whether bodies or wreckage from Korean Air Lines Flight 007 washed ashore in areas off-limits to U.S. searchers after the jetliner was shot down, three senators say. In a letter to Secretary of State James A. Baker III, Sens. Nunn, D-Ga., Carl Levin, D-Mich., and Edward Kennedy, D-Mass. urge that a formal request for assistance be submitted to the Soviets. ``The Soviet government's response to such an inquiry would be helpful in our efforts to gain as much information as possible about the fate of KAL 007,'' the letter said. A Soviet fighter plane shot down the unarmed passenger jetliner after it strayed off course and entered Soviet airspace on Sept. 1, 1983. All 269 people aboard, including 63 Americans, were killed. The CIA and the Defense Department reported that a two-month search failed to locate any wreckage or bodies, the letter said. The Pentagon believes most of the wreckage was within 12 miles of the coast of Moneron Island, an area the Soviets sealed off after the crash, the letter said. ``Since U.S. vessels were not permitted to freely search the area whee KAL 007 was thought to have crashed, we request that the State Department initiate a formal inquiry with Soviet government officials to determine whether any wreckage or bodies were located by Soviet search teams or by anyone who might have been permitted by Soviet authorities into the restricted area around Moneron Island,'' it said. State Department spokesman Dave Denny said the letter was being reviewed. The letter, dated Jan. 4 and made public by Levin's office Tuesday, asks that the inquiry be made by Wednesday. Levin first proposed asking the Soviets for help, spokesman Willie Blacklow said. He said Michigan residents who had relatives on the jetliner were pressing to learn more about the tragedy. ``They're very anxious,'' Blacklow said. ``President Reagan promised them an investigation and they haven't gotten it.'' With the improvement in U.S.-Soviet relations, the Soviets might be more forthcoming, Blacklow said. ``Clearly the times have changed ... so perhaps we could get something accomplished now.''

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Work On Seismic Equipment at Alaskan Volcano
DOC.TEXT: Scientists spent Tuesday installing new seismic devices on the flanks of Redoubt Volcano and repairing a monitor damaged in an eruption last week. Schools were closed because of an eruption Monday. The mountain remained active, but there were no significant eruptions following Monday's blasts, which pushed ash and steam eight miles into the air. The ash plume turned daylight to darkness and blanketed parts of the nearby Kenai Peninsula with up to three-quarters of an inch of ash. In Washington state, scientists monitoring Mount St. Helens detected little seismic activity Tuesday, but said they're not ready to declare the volcano has returned to its slumber following weekend earthquakes. Mount Redoubt's latest eruption occurred with little warning. Scientists at the Alaska Volcano Observatory said their most sensitive monitor was damaged in a violent eruption last week, so they may have missed the telltale increase in earthquake activity which signalled previous eruptions. Unlike previous eruptions, there was no dome built up over the eruptive vent prior to Monday's eruption. That prompted scientists to warn that similar violent eruptions could continue to occur without warning. The volcano 115 miles southwest of Anchorage had been dormant for more than two decades before the latest sequence of eruptions began Dec. 13. Monday's ash plume mostly missed the major population concentrations around Kenai and Homer, but the grit was heavy enough for officials to close schools Tuesday in Kenai, Soldotna, Nikiski and Sterling. No deaths or injuries were reported as a result of the volcanic activity, but air travel and holiday mail have been snarled by the almost continuous eruptions. At Mount St. Helens, the weekend earthquakes sent a plume of ash 90 miles to the east, surprising scientists. ``It looks quiet right now, but I can't say it's going to stay calm,'' said Chris Jonientz-Trisler of the University of Washington Geophysics Center in Seattle, 100 miles north of Mount St. Helens. ``It doesn't look at the present time like any eruption is imminent,'' she said. ``One thing we've learned, though, is anything can change.'' Bad weather again prevented flights over the mountain, said Cliff Hall, an operations staffer with the Cascade Volcano Observatory. ``We're unable to look at what's happened because of the rain and wind and clouds,'' Hall said. Scientists speculated that steam emissions seen coming from the volcano were caused by groundwater reaching superheated rock beneath the volcano and turning to steam, or from gas released by cooling molten rock. Ash expelled by the volcano over the weekend was tested and found to be pulverized rock from previous eruptions rather than freshly erupted matter. The volcano's last major eruption occurred on March 19, 1982. A cataclysmic explosion on May 18, 1980, killed 57 people, devastated 230 square miles and sent up an ash cloud that circled the globe.

DOC.HEAD: Committee Calls for Alaska-Siberia Park
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union should establish an international park astride the Bering Strait, a study committee told the two governments Tuesday. Certain details of such a park still need more study, according to an announcement by the Interior Department of the joint report to Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan and V.G. Sokolovsky, First Deputy Chairman of the State Committee for Protection of the Environment. The committee of officials from both countries did not propose boundaries for what land should be protected as parks, and said each nation should designate appropriate sites and manage them under its own laws and regulations. The National Park Service, the Interior Department agency whose representatives formed the U.S. component of the committee, has said the 2.8-million acre Bering Land Bridge National Preserve should be the U.S. park under the arrangement. The Soviets are considering several areas. The proposal is ``a shared chance to preserve Eskimo and other native lifestyles as well as evidence of the rare geological, archeological and biological heritage of this region.'' Other recommendations of the committee call for enhanced authority for the parks to cooperate with each other and for joint research and public information facilities. The department said it hoped a Beringian Heritage International Park can be approved by both governments in time for the 75th anniversary of the National Park Service in 1991. The Bering Strait, about 50 miles wide, separates Alaska and the Siberia region of the Soviet Union and connects the Pacific and Arctic oceans. It is believed the avenue by which North and South America were populated by overland migrations from Asia in prehistoric time when sea levels were lower. It is named for Vitus Bering, a Danish explorer in the service of Russia, whose voyage through the strait in 1728 proved to the modern world that Asia and North America are not connected by land.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Insists on Explicit U.S. Promise to Ban PLO from Talks
With AM-US-Mideast
DOC.TEXT: The top aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, Yossi Ben-Aharon, said Tuesday the United States must give Israel an absolute promise the PLO will be excluded if proposed peace negotiations are to proceed. He spoke in reaction to Washington's postponement Monday of a meeting with Israeli and Egyptian foreign ministers. Ben-Aharon, director general of Shamir's office, told a news conference: ``We want a categoric American statement that the PLO will not be involved in the process. ``We feel somewhat uneasy that there is reticence on the part of the U.S. government to say clearly that the PLO will not be involved.'' Israel says Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization is a terrorist group and refuses to negotiate with it. In Baghdad, Iraq, on Tuesday, Farouk Kadoumi, the PLO's foreign minister, said the United States was not a fit peace broker because it was ``totally biased toward Israel.'' Egypt's foreign minister, Esmat Abdel-Meguid, said in Cairo Tuesday after a 90-minute meeting with Arafat that adequate preparations should precede the proposed Mideast peace negotiations. He told reporters, ``Egypt is eager for establishment of the dialogue, and to guarantee its success, adequate preparations should be made. We cannot go to a meeting that would result in failure.'' U.S. officials acknowledged Monday that because of unresolved differences Secretary of State James A. Baker III has not invited the Israeli and Egyptian foreign ministers. The tripartite meeting had been expected to convene this month to set the stage for a Palestinian-Israeli dialogue in Cairo on Israel's proposal for elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. ``It is absurd to have a meeting if the meeting produces nothing,'' State Department Spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Monday. Shamir told reporters Tuesday during a tour of northern Israel he was not surprised. ``He (Baker) is interested that this meeting bring about positive results,'' Shamir said. ``We have to arrive at an agreement, and as long as there is no agreement, I suppose that the convening of this meeting will be postponed.'' Last Friday, Israeli newspapers published a draft letter from Baker suggesting that Baker was unwilling to meet Israel's demand for rigid guarantees on the PLO's role and other issues. Ben-Aharon told reporters, ``We are trying to make it absolutely clear to our friends in the United States that we are not seeking any kind of a cover, fig leaf, for indirect exchanges, contacts with the PLO. We don't want the PLO involved in this process.'' He rejected a U.S. call that Israel rescind its travel ban on nine pro-PLO activists from the occupied territories, including those most active in behind-the-scenes diplomatic efforts. Ben-Aharon said the restriction was because of violation of security regulations and had ``no connection'' with the Palestinians' involvement in the peace process. The State Department said Monday the ban ``sends the wrong signal to Palestinians who favor dialogue as an alternative to continued confrontation.'' Israel TV said Shamir and Foreign Minister Moshe Arens are not ruling out participation of deportees allowed to return to the occupied lands. It said Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin is considering letting ``some'' deportees return where they could be viewed by Shamir and Arens as residents of the West Bank and Gaza. The move would be a compromise with the PLO demand that Palestinians from both inside and outside the territories should take part in the talks. Arab reports said Arab assailants on Tuesday killed a Palestinian woman they said collaborated with Israel, and soldiers wounded 25 Palestinians during a general strike in the occupied territories. Merchants closed shop, public transportation halted and workers stayed home to mark the beginning of the 26th month of the Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule. Israeli soldiers or civilians have killed 646 Palestinians during the rebellion; 43 Israelis have died in the violence, and 167 Palestinians _ suspected of collaboration or involvement in drugs or prostitution _ have been killed by fellow Arabs.

DOC.HEAD: New Panamanian Envoy to UN Presents Credentials
With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Panama's new U.N. ambassador on Tuesday presented his credentials to the United Nations secretary-general in a ceremony aimed at putting to rest conflicting claims to the post. Both Eduardo Vallarino, the choice of the U.S.-installed government in Panama and President Guillermo Endara, and Mirla Bellavita, his rival from the ousted regime of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, have contested the seat. U.N. legal officials noted, however, that the acceptance of credentials by Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar was a formality and did not exclude the possibility of a challenge to Vallarino's credentials in the General Assembly. The next likely time for a challenge, U.N. officials said, would be the special General Assembly session on drug trafficking, set for mid-February. At that time, they said, the Credentials Committee of the General Assembly may be asked to consider Panama's credentials, in light of the overthrown government. Vallarino, 52, a longtime member of the opposition in Panama, had been in exile in the United States since 1987. In Panama he had been president of the Panama Association for Business Executives. While in the United States, he was an associate member of the Kennedy Center for International Studies in Boston and also served on the Panama Commission for Human Rights.

DOC.HEAD: Former President Turns 77, Hometown Celebrates With Holiday
DOC.TEXT: Richard M. Nixon's 77th birthday was a bi-coastal observance Tuesday, with city workers in his hometown getting a paid holiday while the former president planned a quiet family dinner. The Nixon Presidential Library and Birthplace Foundation used the occasion to invite reporters on a brown-bag lunch tour of the nearly completed $20 million library. It will be dedicated in July. On the East Coast, Nixon worked on a book due in April. ``President Nixon spent the morning putting the finishing touches on the galley proofs for his new book, `In the Arena,' paying special attention to new sections about (Soviet leader Mikhail) Gorbachev, China and Eastern Europe,'' Nixon spokesman John Taylor said from Nixon's office at Woodcliff Lake, N.J. Taylor said Nixon and his wife, Pat, planned to have dinner in New York City with members of the family. He said he was unaware of any unusual gifts. Profits from the book, whose full title is ``In the Arena: A Memoir of Victory, Defeat and Renewal,'' which Nixon calls the most personal he has ever written, will go to the library foundation. Simon & Schuster declined to disclose how much Nixon was getting for the book, his seventh. Hugh Hewitt, director of the library foundation, presided over the tour of the library, a Spanish-style building he described as a ``window'' into the career of the nation's 37th president. There will be ``full and fair treatment'' of Watergate, Hewitt said. The Nixon library 30 miles southeast of Los Angeles will be the first of two presidential libraries to open in Southern California. The Ronald Reagan Presidential Library opens next year in Simi Valley, 75 miles away. Unlike other presidential libraries, the 45,000-square-foot Nixon library won't be supported by tax dollars. The former chief executive insisted on it. For about 100 city workers in the community of 40,000, Tuesday was a paid day off. The Yorba Linda City Council voted in September to make Jan. 9 a holiday in honor of its most famous citizen. ``Fifteen years have elapsed since President Nixon's resignation and history has shown the importance of his presidency, particularly with respect to his brilliance in foreign policy,'' the holiday resolution said.

DOC.HEAD: Peru Says It Grants Asylum to High Noriega Aide, 11 Others
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 8th, `Panama has' UPDATING with foreign minister saying Cordova was refused refuge after entering residence. Picks up 9th, `Peru listed...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Peru said Tuesday it granted diplomatic asylum to a top Noriega associate who is on the U.S. most-wanted list and to 11 others who took refuge in the Peruvian ambassador's residence in Panama City. U.S. troops have ringed the residence since Monday afternoon. Foreign Ministry spokesman Jose Torres told The Associated Press that Gonzalo Gonzalez, identified by Panamanian authorities as a former captain and chief of security for deposed dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega, has taken refuge in the residence and been granted diplomatic asylum by the Peruvian government. Torres said the 12 would be allowed to come to Peru if they wished, but no discussions had taken place thus far about where they would go. ``It is supposed that they will try to go to some friendly country, perhaps Peru,'' Torres said. ``If they want to come here, we will accept them.'' Torres denied that another Noriega associate, former Lt. Col. Luis Cordova, considered with Gonzalez to be the most-wanted men on the list of former Noriega officials, was also at the residence. Panama has said Cordova, who is alleged to have tortured prisoners of the government ousted by Noriega, also is in the ambassador's residence. Foreign Minister Guillermo Larco Cox said Cordova had sought refuge in the residence, but Peruvian officials refused. Larco Cox said Cordova was considered unwelcome and left the residence ``of his own will.'' Larco Cox did not say if Cordova was apprehended by American troops or if he left before they surrounded the residence. Peru listed the others granted asylum as Capt. Marcela Tason, Noriega's secretary, and her husband Ulises Rodriguez; Capt. Narcisa Castillero and her daughter Patricia Ceutte; Maj. Heraclides Sucre, his wife Daisy Batista, three children, and his mother Judith Medina; and Maj. Edgardo Lopez. The government issued a communique Tuesday saying Peru has notified Panamanian authorities of its decision granting them diplomatic asylum. Peru also released a statement Tuesday saying it registered a protest with the U.S. ambassador in Peru, Anthony Quainton, concerning the presence of U.S. troops around the ambassador's residence. It complained the action creates ``an unnecessary climate of tension and impedes the normal development of activities of our mission in Panama.'' The communique condemned the U.S. intervention and called for withdrawal of troops. Peru recalled its ambassador to Panama, Mario Castro, in May after Noriega annulled elections won by Guillermo Endara. Castro resigned his post Dec. 26 in a break with the Garcia government over its response to the U.S. intervention. The government has not named a replacement for Castro, who returned to Panama Monday to collect his belongings from the residency. President Alan Garcia has roundly criticized the U.S. invasion, and refused to recognize the Endara government. Garcia first said he would not attend next month's drug summit with President Bush in protest, but said Sunday he would go if U.S. troops are first withdrawn. The summit is scheduled for Feb. 15 in Cartagena, Colombia. Presidents Virgilio Barco of Colombia and Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia are to meet with Bush to discuss strategies to fight the drug trade in the United States and South America. Garcia ordered the Panamanian flag raised at the government palace the day after the invasion, and officials said it will continue to fly there as long as U.S. troops remain in Panama. The same day Garcia ordered joint operations with U.S. anti-narcotics agents suspended. The operations resumed six days later.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0647 to restore AP logo in lede
Romania Asks U.S. For Trade Privileges
DOC.TEXT: The new government said Tuesday it would seek Most Favored Nation trading status with the United States as well as restoration of other privileges and ties. Ousted dictator Nicolae Ceausescu had renounced the U.S. trade agreement in February 1988, when it appeared the U.S. Congress would not renew it because of human rights abuses by Ceausescu's regime. The Foreign Ministry said it was ``empowered to nullify the abusive and unilateral Feb. 29, 1988, declaration of the former regime which gave up the granting by the U.S.A. of the most favored nation clause.'' The ministry said a decision Monday to lift all travel restrictions on Romanians paved the way for Romania and the United States to resume the trade privileges, which exempted from some customs duties Romanian products arriving in the United States. Washington granted the privileges to Romania in 1975 when Ceausescu was courted by the United States as a Communist maverick. They were tied to human rights, including free travel and emigration under the 35-nation Helsinki Final Act. Washington increasingly grew critical of Ceausescu's suppression of free speech, religious practice and political organization. In breaking the accord, the dictator said the U.S. pressure on him to honor human rights pledges violated the principles of foreign relations. Ceausescu was toppled last month in a popular uprising. The provisional government convicted he and his wife, Elena, of ``grave crimes'' and executed them Dec. 25. Romania estimated the lost trade privileges cost it $250 million in export revenues from the United States, which totaled $775 million in 1987. The Romanians sell wooden furniture, small engines, leather, textiles, gasoline and aluminium products to the United States. The governing National Salvation Front also asked for diplomatic ties with the European Community and membership in international satellite organizations. In Brussels, Belgium, a European Community Commission spokesman said the EC's external relations commissioner, Frans Andriessen, will discuss the request with Romanian authorities in Bucharest on Sunday. Romania and Albania are the only East European nations with which the EC has no diplomatic ties. The state news agency Rompress said the international satellite organization Intelsat would allow Romania to join, and that the country was trying to join other such organizations. Ceausescu had rejected Romania's membership in the organizations ``because he was not interested in linking Romania to Europe and the whole world,'' Rompres said. The news agency also reported that leaders of a 1987 protest of the Ceausescu dictatorship were allowed to return from internal exile. The leaders were deported to other parts of the country following the Nov. 15, 1987, protest in Brasov, which involved at least 10,000 people. Rompres said 74 people returned to the truck manufacturing enterprise in Brasov, but it was not clear how many had been banished. Rompres on Tuesday also gave details from the trial of a member of Ceausescu's security forces who was sentenced to nine years in prison in the first announced conviction resulting from military tribunals set up by the interim government. The defendant, identified as Ioan Bundea, a police major in Sibiu, was sentenced in the Transylvanian city after being found guilty of attempted murder, the report said. Rompress said Bundea had opened fire on a group of five army officers Dec. 22 battling Ceausescu security forces, injuring one of them. The report, which did not provide further details, said other such trials were scheduled in Sibiu this week. Captured members of security units who battled the army face a maximum life sentence.

DOC.HEAD: Shining Path Assassinate Ex-Defense Minister, 1st Cabinet Killing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 10th `Officials blamed' with no claim of responsibility but attack similar in style to previous Shining Path assaults. Picks up 11th, `Shining Path...'
DOC.TEXT: Shining Path rebels shot and killed a former defense minister Tuesday morning in a shopping center parking lot, making him the highest-ranking official to be slain in 10 years of guerrilla war in Peru, officials said. Enrique Lopez, shot at close range as he was parking his car in the Lima suburb of San Isidro, was the first cabinet-level official killed in the escalating guerrilla violence that has claimed the lives of hundreds of federal and local officials. A spokesman for the Interior Ministry, who asked not to be identified, said four men with submachine guns pumped at least 10 bullets into Lopez at 10 a.m. two miles south of downtown Lima. He said Lopez was alone in the vehicle. Lopez, rushed to a nearby military hospital, died in surgery, officials said. Reporters at the scene said Lopez's car was riddled with bullets. Witnesses told officials the four gunmen fled in an automobile. Police blocked streets and highways throughout this capital city and rounded up dozens of people for questioning. Witnesses interviewed by The Associated Press said Lopez had an office in the shopping complex, and usually arrived the same time every day, often accompanied by a bodyguard. Lopez was Peru's named the country's first defense minister by President Alan Garcia, taking office in 1987 when the ministry was formed. He had served as minister of the army until the armed forces were joined under one ministry that year. He was replaced last May by army Gen. Julio Velasquez. Officials blamed the attack on the fanatical Shining Path, a radical Maoist terrorist group that has been fighting to topple Peru's elected governments since 1980. While no group claimed responsibility for the killing, police said the attack bore similarities to those of the shadowy terrorist group, the Shining Path. Shining Path began its attacks in the Andean highlands last decade but in the last year has increasingly conducted assaults in the capital, Peru's largest city. Speaking to reporters at the government palace, Garcia said, ``We have lost an extraordinary man.'' Garcia said Lopez had the right to a military guard, and said he didn't understand why Lopez was alone when he was attacked. ``It pains me and I regret that he was alone in spite of the situation of war we are living in,'' Garcia said. The Senate observed a minute of silence Tuesday afternoon honoring Lopez. And the Democratic Front, a coalition of center-right parties supporting front-running presidential candidate Mario Vargas Llosa, issued a statement condemning the assassination. The government says more than 17,500 people have died in the 10 years of violence, including police, soldiers, rebels, government officials and civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Casino Officials and Experts Scoff That Most Decks Not Shuffled Enough
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Bayer did ...,' to CORRECT that Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass., sted Boston.
DOC.TEXT: Blackjack players shouldn't gamble on a study indicating that casinos don't shuffle playing cards enough for a good mix, casino officials and card players said Tuesday. They scoffed at a computer study that shows shuffling a deck seven times decreases bettors' changes of predicting the next card. More shuffling means less betting time, and casino officials said that would have a greater effect on their bottom line. ``We have to weigh everything out,'' said Howard Dreitzer, senior vice president of casino operations at Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino. ``If it takes an extra five minutes to shuffle, what we would lose at the tables?'' In November, Atlantic City's casinos took in about $44.3 million from the blackjack tables, about 20.5 percent of the casinos' $215.7 million winnings, acccording to the Casino Control Commission figures. Most casinos in Atlantic City combine eight decks of cards and shuffle the whole pack twice by hand to get their mix. In blackjack, players try to get cards totaling as close to 21 as possible without going over. But the two researchers who conducted the computer study said a deck needs to be shuffled seven times to prevent astute cardwatchers from figuring what the next card might be. Dave Bayer, a mathemetician and computer scientist at Columbia University in New York, described the seventh shuffle as a mere follow-up to card players' nagging doubts that the deck is never properly shuffled. Bayer did the study with Persi Diaconis, a statistician and mathematician at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass. Fewer shuffles than seven increase the probability that the cards are not mixed properly, Bayer said in a telephone interview from New York. But shuffling more than seven times does increasingly little to improve randomness. ``It's a recreational math problem, but it applies to a whole lot of people,'' Bayer said. ``People had an intuition that something was not right.'' Dreitzer said his casino is satisfied with two shuffles of eight decks. ``Random is a concept,'' he said, laughing at the idea that ``we could shuffle a deck of cards all day if we wanted to.'' Dave Brogan, a self-professed card counter and the placement coordinator for the Professional Dealers School in Atlantic City, said that even if players were able to master where cards might be, they would have to have a dealer who shuffled the cards exactly the same every time. ``I've got dealers that can shuffle the deck twice better than others who shuffle it five and six times,'' he said. Bayer credits Diaconis, also a magician who likes card tricks, with watching amateur and professional dealers' shuffling patterns for years to assemble the data that led to the computer study. Bayer said six decks of cards needs to be shuffled 12 times, but that most casinos don't want to waste time shuffling the cards. Alyce Parker, a spokeswoman for Harrah's Marina Hotel Casino, said the two shuffles required of dealers at her gaming hall are enough to ensure a good mix. ``Two makes sure the security precautions are there,'' she said. Wayne G. Marlin, a spokesman for the state Division of Gaming Enforcement, said regulators leave it up to the casinos to determine how many times a deck needs to be shuffled to determine randomness. An automatic shuffling machine is under consideration by the Casino Control Commission, but has yet to be approved, said commission spokesman Tom Flynn. Bayer advises amateurs not to bank on his formula. ``There are people who can take advantage of non-randomness,'' Bayer said. ``But it takes incredible patience and there are better ways to make money.''

DOC.HEAD: Cult Leader Refuses To Waive Extradition
LaserPhoto GO2
DOC.TEXT: A cult leader refused Tuesday to return voluntarily to Ohio and answer charges in the ritualistic slayings of a family of five. Jeffrey Lundgren, 39; his wife, Alice, 38; and their eldest son, Damon, 19; all pleaded innocent through their attorneys to Ohio fugitive complaints, triggering formal extradition proceedings that could take at least 90 days. ``Sometimes I wish it wasn't so drawn out but it does work eventually,'' said John Hewicker, a San Diego County deputy district attorney. The Lundgrens were chained together at the waists as they made their first court appearance since their arrests in nearby National City on Sunday. Alice Lundgren and her son held hands. None of them spoke during the hearing. Milly Durovic, the attorney representing Jeffrey Lundgren, declined to discuss her client's refusal to return to Ohio voluntarily. Municipal Court Judge Timothy Tower ordered the three held without bond. Prosecutors in Ohio will have to petition California Gov. George Deukmejian for the defendants' forced return to stand trial for the slayings of Dennis and Cheryl Avery and their three young daughters.
