A self-proclaimed ``prophet,'' Lundgren was a lay minister in the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints in Ohio before he was ousted for radical teachings. He persuaded other members to follow him and the splinter group went to live on a farm in Kirtland, 30 miles east of Cleveland. Five bodies were unearthed on the farm last week. Investigators believe the Averys were killed in April just before Lundgren and his followers moved to a farm near Holden, Mo. Cult members had scattered by New Year's Eve when an informant told authorities about the slaying. The Lundgrens were arrested outside a motel in National City, which is about five miles south of San Diego, by federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms agents and police. Three other Lundgren children _ Kristen, 10, Caleb, 9, and Jason, 15 _ also were taken into protective custody and have been released to the custody of other family members, ATF agent Scott Parkhurst said after Tuesday's hearing. Federal agents continued looking in Southern California for the last two of the 13 people indicted in the slayings of the Averys. The 13, who federal and local authorities say belonged to a religious cult, were charged with aggravated murder, kidnapping or conspiracy to commit aggravated murder. Lake County, Ohio, prosecutor Steven C. LaTourette, has said the Averys apparently were killed as a sacrifice that would cleanse cult members' souls and allow them to travel to the wilderness. But Dale Luffman, president of the northeast Ohio chapter of the Reorganized Church, said the Averys may have been killed because of disputes over money, sex or fear the Averys would leave the cult. The Reorganized Church, based in Independence, Mo., has roots and some beliefs in common with the Salt Lake City-based Mormon Church but is separate. The Mormon Church is based on revelations that Joseph Smith said were brought to him in the 1820s by a heavenly messenger. After Smith's death in 1844, the church split into factions, the largest of which is the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. The Reorganized Church was founded by Smith's son Joseph III and claims to be a continuation of the original church. The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints issued a statement from its Salt Lake City headquarters on Tuesday disassociating itself from Lundgren. ``Jeffrey Lundgren and his wife and son ... have never been members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints,'' said Bruce L. Olsen, managing director of public communications for the Mormon Church. ``We deplore the tragedy and extend our sympathy to survivors of the victims.''

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Kill Part-Time Soldier in Sectarian Shooting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with details, identity, Sein Fein leader charged with conspiracy, others. No pickup. Olven 3rd graf is correct
DOC.TEXT: Two gunmen shot to death a part-time soldier of the Ulster Defense Regiment militia Tuesday inside his shoe shop in Castlederg, 70 miles west of Belfast, police said. A small bomb exploded in the shop as police arrived and one officer was hospitalized suffering from shock, police said. Belfast police headquarters said in a statement that the victim, Olven Kilpatrick, 32, had been a part-time member of the Regiment since 1975. No group immediately claimed responsibility but police said they believe the Irish Republican Army fighting British rule in Northern Ireland did the shooting. The slaying of Kilpatrick was the third death this year in Northern Ireland's sectarian strife that has claimed at least 2,776 lives since the violence began in 1969. In an unrelated development Tuesday, Danny Morrison, vice president of Sinn Fein, legal political arm of the outlawed IRA, was charged with conspiracy to murder, false imprisonment and IRA membership, police said. Morrison was one of nine people arrested after police and troops raided a house in Andersonstown, an IRA stronghold area in west Belfast, late Sunday. The domestic British news agency Press Association quoted unnamed security sources as saying that a man who had been abducted two days before was found in the house during the raid and was taken into protective police custody. After being charged by police Tuesday, Morrison remained in police custody awaiting a court appearance. Police gave no other details. The mainly Roman Catholic IRA wants to unite predominantly Protestant Northern Ireland with the 95 percent Catholic Republic of Ireland under socialist rule.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Work On Seismic Equipment at Alaskan Volcano
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING a0735 to fix spelling of `volcanoes' in slugline.
DOC.TEXT: Scientists spent Tuesday installing new seismic devices on the flanks of Redoubt Volcano and repairing a monitor damaged in an eruption last week. Schools were closed because of an eruption Monday. The mountain remained active, but there were no significant eruptions ollowing Monday's blasts, which pushed ash and steam eight miles into the air. The ash plume turned daylight to darkness and blanketed parts of the nearby Kenai Peninsula with up to three-quarters of an inch of ash. In Washington state, scientists monitoring Mount St. Helens detected little seismic activity Tuesday, but said they're not ready to declare the volcano has returned to its slumber following weekend earthquakes. Mount Redoubt's latest eruption occurred with little warning. Scientists at the Alaska Volcano Observatory said their most sensitive monitor was damaged in a violent eruption last week, so they may have missed the telltale increase in earthquake activity which signalled previous eruptions. Unlike previous eruptions, there was no dome built up over the eruptive vent prior to Monday's eruption. That prompted scientists to warn that similar violent eruptions could continue to occur without warning. The volcano 115 miles southwest of Anchorage had been dormant for more than two decades before the latest sequence of eruptions began Dec. 13. Monday's ash plume mostly missed the major population concentrations around Kenai and Homer, but the grit was heavy enough for officials to close schools Tuesday in Kenai, Soldotna, Nikiski and Sterling. No deaths or injuries were reported as a result of the volcanic activity, but air travel and holiday mail have been snarled by the almost continuous eruptions. At Mount St. Helens, the weekend earthquakes sent a plume of ash 90 miles to the east, surprising scientists. ``It looks quiet right now, but I can't say it's going to stay calm,'' said Chris Jonientz-Trisler of the University of Washington Geophysics Center in Seattle, 100 miles north of Mount St. Helens. ``It doesn't look at the present time like any eruption is imminent,'' she said. ``One thing we've learned, though, is anything can change.'' Bad weather again prevented flights over the mountain, said Cliff Hall, an operations staffer with the Cascade Volcano Observatory. ``We're unable to look at what's happened because of the rain and wind and clouds,'' Hall said. Scientists speculated that steam emissions seen coming from the volcano were caused by groundwater reaching superheated rock beneath the volcano and turning to steam, or from gas released by cooling molten rock. Ash expelled by the volcano over the weekend was tested and found to be pulverized rock from previous eruptions rather than freshly erupted matter. The volcano's last major eruption occurred on March 19, 1982. A cataclysmic explosion on May 18, 1980, killed 57 people, devastated 230 square miles and sent up an ash cloud that circled the globe.

DOC.HEAD: Rescuers Free Whale Beached in Mud
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with whale freed, other details; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Wildlife rescuers wrapped a sling around the tail of a 40-foot-long whale beached in mud and towed it back into the Gulf of Mexico at high tide Tuesday. ``We got real lucky, a surge of water came in just when we needed it,'' said Pete Juneau, a state marine biologist. ``If we hadn't moved it then, we wouldn't have moved it. We figured we'd have to euthanize it.'' The animal, identified by biologists as a Bryde's whale, was freed about 24 hours after it was spotted by oil company employees in a helicopter. It was stranded in a remote area near an industrial area used by shrimpers and offshore oil workers. The animal lay in as little as 6 inches of water at low tide, flipping its tail and rocking itself in an apparent effort to get to deeper water, witnesses said. After high tide brought in 4 feet of water, rescuers wrapped a canvas sling around the whale's tail and slowly towed it into deeper waters. It began swimming alongside the boat as rescuers removed the sling. Workers kept the whale in sight until it was roughly 3{ miles offshore, said Gina Barron of the Texas Marine Mammal Stranding Network in Galveston. ``It looked pretty good,'' said Barron, summoned to the scene by Louisiana wildlife officials. ``We stayed with it for quite a while. We monitored its respiration. It was breathing about every 1{ minutes, which was good. It was swimming strongly and didn't appear to have water in its lungs.'' Shallow water and deep, thick mud had hampered the rescue on the central Louisiana shore in Vermilion Parish about 20 miles south-southwest of Intracoastal City. ``It's all marsh and real rough. You can't walk to it. We had people try that and they sank up to their waists in mud,'' said James Manning, assistant administrator of the Wildlife and Fisheries Fur and Refuge Division. Wildlife officials observed the animal from aboard a skiff and an oil crew boat on the gulf. At one time, five helicopters with reporters and photographers hovered over the whale. Rescuers returned to port Tuesday evening hoping their effort wasn't in vain. ``I'm not going to say it's safe,'' said Harry Blanchet, a biologist with the Louisiana Department of Wildife and Fisheries. ``There has to be a reason it came in in the first place. You can never tell, but I'll tell you one thing, if it doesn't make it, you're going to see some grown men cry.''

DOC.HEAD: Polish Students Win Eviction of Communist Party from Headquarters
DOC.TEXT: Students in Bialystok ended an occupation of local Communist Party headquarters in that northeastern city after officials promised the building will be turned over to the university, PAP said Tuesday. The news agency said students of the Independent Students Association (NZS), a nationwide pro-Solidarity organization, removed protest banners and cleaned up the rooms after a settlement was reached. Parties to the agreement were NZS; the mayor of Bialystok, a city 120 miles from Warsaw; regional officials; and the local Citizens' Committee, which operates as the Solidarity trade union's political arm, the agency reported. The Communist Party's lease will terminate on Jan. 31 and the building will be turned over the university in Bialystok, a branch of Warsaw University. The party has decided to dissolve itself and form a new party. Debate about future party rights to buildings has gone on since Solidarity's Tadeusz Mazowiecki was elected prime minister on Aug. 24, ending more than four decades of Communist control of the government. PAP also reported a Solidarity local stopped work for two hours Tuesday at a mine in Jastrzebie, southern Poland, where labor unrest 18 months ago set in motion the changes under way in Poland, to demand reform of mine management. The local said it wants to negotiate a new pay structure and wants a ban on hiring new administrative staff at the mine, which employs about 8,000 people. PAP did not say how many miners took part.

DOC.HEAD: First Living-Donor Transplant Recipient Leaves Hospital
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 4 grafs at end with heart-liver transplant recipient suffering liver virus; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The nation's first recipient of a liver transplant from a living donor is being checked daily at the University of Chicago Medical Center after being released, a spokesman said Tuesday. Alyssa Smith, 22 months old, was released Monday and spent the night at the nearby Ronald McDonald House with her mother, Teresa Smith, who donated part of her liver to her daughter in the historic Nov. 27 operation, hospital spokesman John Easton said. Alyssa is to return daily to a clinic so doctors can monitor her progress, Easton said. ``It's a way for her to have some of the comforts of home and still be under the watchful eye of physicians,'' Easton said. Doctors hoped Alyssa would be able to return home to Schertz, Texas, early next week, Easton said. The Ronald McDonald House is designed to provide housing for families of hospitalized or recovering children. Meanwhile, 16-month-old Sarina Jones of Millington, Tenn., who on Dec. 8 became the second living-donor transplant recipient, was listed in serious condition at the hospital, Easton said. ``It's too soon to predict when she will be released, but she's doing well,'' he said. ``Her liver continues to function very well, she's eating solid food and has actually put on a little bit of weight.'' Easton said that starting next month the University of Chicago Medical Center plans to perform two living-donor liver transplants a month. In Pittsburgh, another transplant pioneer, 12-year-old Stormie Jones, remained in serious condition Tuesday with a mild liver virus, but a biopsy showed no evidence of organ rejection, said Children's Hospital of Pittsburgh spokeswoman Margy Buczynski. ``She's up and around and looking really good,'' Buczynski said. Stormie, who became the world's first recipient of both a transplanted heart and liver in 1984, was admitted to the hospital Saturday. The White Settlement, Texas, girl has been treated off and on for mild episodes of organ rejection since the transplant, performed at Children's Hospital. Last year, she began receiving a new Japanese drug known as FK-506 that is believed to be 50 to 100 times more powerful than the anti-rejection drug cyclosporine.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Junkie Found Innocent of Needle Distribution
DOC.TEXT: An ex-junkie who later attended Yale University was found innocent Tuesday of a charge he illegally doled out clean needles and syringes to drug addicts to prevent the spread of AIDS. Jon Parker, 35, was acquitted after a one-day, non-jury trial in Boston Municipal Court. He is founder of a 50-member group called the AIDS Brigade, comprised of former Yale graduate students and ex-addicts and convicts. It was formed about five years ago and distributes AIDS education materials, bleach and needles in Boston, New York, New Haven, Conn.; and New Jersey. Parker testified in his own defense, saying the distribution program was aimed at saving the lives of drug addicts at risk for the deadly acquired immune deficiency syndrome by sharing contaminated needles. ``I would say that if I could save one life, then we should do that,'' he said. Parker said before his trial began that he hoped to change a requirement for a prescription to buy hypodermic syringes. Mayor Raymond Flynn endorsed a needle exchange program that was rejected by the City Council last year. Critics of needle exchange programs say it encourages drug use. Parker was also criticized for being too much of a renegade to properly conduct AIDS prevention. Last year, the nation's first full-scale, government-sponsored needle exchange program to fight the spread of AIDS was approved by the Tacoma-Pierce County Board of Health in Tacoma, Wash. Addicts meet AIDS Brigade workers in dingy restaurants and on street corners to get their sets of needles, known as ``works.'' Among those who testified in support of Parker's program were a British physician in charge of a needle exchange program in Liverpool, England, and a pediatrician from Boston City Hospital who is the mayor's adviser on AIDS. The adviser, Dr. George Lamb, warned that within a year the rate of AIDS infection in Boston will increase to about 10 out of 100 people. Dr. Alan Parry of Liverpool cited what he said was his program's consistent success in AIDS prevention, saying police there carry leaflets advertising the program. Parker has said he is uniquely qualified to bring AIDS prevention to the streets because of his background. He shot heroin as a teen-ager and robbed drug stores for money and supplies. At 17, he served time in jail, earning a high school equivalency diploma behind bars. In 1974, a month after his release, he was caught violating parole and was allowed to check into a drug rehabilitation center. In the years since, Parker has held a variety of jobs. He drove a cab and endured a few bouts as a boxer to pay his way through Hampshire College in Amherst. He studied biology at Hampshire College, then went to Yale's School of Epidemiology and Public Health.

DOC.HEAD: Married and Expelled Teen-ager Asks for School Reinstatement, Apology
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-10, ``School officials ...,'' with 7 grafs to UPDATE with further comment from principal, ADD that student was expelled same day article appeared in newspaper; picks up 11th graf, ```Who do ...'
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager expelled from a Roman Catholic high school for marrying said Tuesday she wants an apology and to be readmitted with all student privileges, including the right to go to the senior prom. Dressed in her school uniform and carrying her books in a backpack, Elizabeth Valeri, 17, told reporters gathered behind the nuns' residence at Maria High School that she believes her expulsion last week may be discriminatory. ``I want some kind of apology because I have not been doing anything bad,'' she said. ``I want to be accepted back in school.... I want prom, I want graduation, I want it all.'' Elizabeth talked to reporters after her new husband, Xavier, 20, drove her to the residence for tutoring sessions arranged so she won't miss exams scheduled at the end of this week. The school's principal, Sister Grace Ann, has said the tutoring was being provided with the assumption that Elizabeth will soon be enrolled in another school. Elizabeth's attorney, Robert Shindler, said later that he sent a letter Tuesday to the principal threatening a lawsuit unless the senior is readmitted and gets the apology she seeks. ``I want her back in the school where she has been for the last 3{ years,'' Shindler said, though he added that he's also trying to find another Catholic school that might accept Elizabeth. It is up to each school under the umbrella of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago to set policy on married students, said Brother Donald P. Houde, an archdiocese spokesman. The controversy was touched off last week after the bride and groom appeared in a picture in the Chicago Sun-Times as the first couple to marry in Cook County in 1990. She said she was told that day that she was being dismissed for breaking school rules. Sister Grace Ann has said Elizabeth was expelled because she broke school rules forbidding students to marry. The principal said Tuesday evening that the marriage didn't set the right example for other students. ``Maria High School endorses and encourages the sacrament of marriage within the Catholic Church and by men and women who are properly prepared and who have reached the age of majority,'' Sister Grace Ann said in a statement. ``Marriage outside the church and prior to high school graduation, while legal, does not constitute an appropriate example for other students here at Maria.'' She said Monday that it would be difficult to discipline married students since they theoretically are not responsible to their parents anymore but to their spouse. ``Who do we deal with? That's the question,'' Sister Grace Ann said. Sister Grace Ann also said that unwed mothers are allowed to return to Maria after giving birth, partly to help discourage abortion. ``That's a different lifestyle than a married student,'' Sister Grace Ann said. ``This school is a school for single women, not a school for married women.'' Shindler said he is seeking a ``written, formal apology'' for ``the expulsion, the notoriety, the embarrassment, the treatment'' that Elizabeth received from the school. For her tutoring sessions, Elizabeth has been asked to enter through the back door of the nun's residence, Shindler said. ``She is being treated almost like a leper,'' he said. ``I didn't do this to hurt anyone and I don't feel that I should be treated this way,'' Elizabeth said. She also said her lifestyle has not changed significantly, because she still will live at her family's house, while Xavier will live at his for a while. ``It's just a boyfriend-girlfriend relationship,'' she said. ``They are rules, but are they discriminatory _ that is the question,'' she said. Asked why she didn't wait until after graduation to marry, Elizabeth said: ``Why should I wait? I am not doing anything wrong. ``I just don't feel guilty,'' she said. ``I love him and he loves me.'

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Group Protests at CDC; 50 Arrested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `A few ...,' with 4 grafs to ADD quotes by CDC spokesman, counterprotester; picks up 9th graf, `In addition ...'
DOC.TEXT: About 150 backers of an AIDS protest group tried to block entrances to the federal Centers for Disease Control and the street in front of it Tuesday, charging that the CDC underreports AIDS cases. About 50 people were arrested, said police Maj. Jim Wilson. He said some would be charged with criminal trespass and some with damaging government property. Fourteen people who climbed onto a building overhang were arrested by DeKalb County officers, who removed the ladder they had used to scale the building. The group, the Aids Coalition to Unleash Power, or ACT UP, contends that the CDC, where much of the nation's AIDS research is done, underreports AIDS-related illnesses and does not use a broad enough definition of the AIDS virus. ``It's far too narrow. It's out of date,'' said Chip Rowan, a protester from Atlanta. ``They are seeing it (AIDS) in the clinics, cervical cancer and TB. It's not news to the people in the clinics. It's news to the people in the CDC.'' Protesters waved signs reading, ``AIDS Won't Wait, Expand the Definition,'' and ``CDC: Inaccurate, Inadequate and Intolerable.'' The group also claimed the CDC gives incomplete information about ways the AIDS virus can be contracted. CDC spokesman Don Barretth said the protestor's claims were incorrectly leveled at the agency. He said the CDC has met with ACT UP members before, and hopes to do so again in a less confrontational setting. A few counterprotesters carried signs reading, ``Gay is Not OK'' and ``You Don't Have to Be Gay.'' One, Mark Weaver, executive director of the Family Association of Texas, accused ACT UP members of strong-arm tactics. At one point, he was mobbed by ACT UP members who taunted Weaver and his supporters. ``They want to be heard,'' Weaver said after the protestors left him, ``but they don't want anyone else to be heard.'' In addition to blocking streets and entrances to the CDC complex near Emory University, demonstrators pounded on doors and ran a banner up the CDC flagpole. DeKalb County officers, many wearing latex gloves, did not start making arrests until protesters climbed onto the building. On Monday, about 300 homosexual activists converged on the Capitol in Atlanta to protest Georgia's 156-year-old sodomy law and to urge the repeal of similar laws in other states. Police said 63 people were arrested at that demonstration, sponsored by the National Gay and Lesbian Task Force.

DOC.HEAD: Disneyland Planning Major Expansion for the '90s
DOC.TEXT: A bigger, flashier Disneyland _ possibly including an ``Indiana Jones'' stunt attraction and a 1930s-style Hollywood movie lot _ are on the drawing boards, Disney officials said in a report published Tuesday. Officials are keeping a tight lid on their plans, reportedly the most ambitious since the park's opening in 1955, until Friday, when Disney Chairman Michael Eisner is scheduled to make an announcement. ``It involves the next 10 years, but I can't tell you anymore,'' Disneyland spokesman Bob Roth said in the report published in the Orange County Register. ``Obviously he (Eisner) wants to make the announcement.'' Last week, Disneyland President Richard Nunis showed the plans to several park employees. The employees said the plans include a stunt attraction based on the ``Indiana Jones'' movies that could go near the park's Thunder Mountain Railroad ride and the Hollywood back lot, which apparently would be similar to one at Florida's Disneyworld. Employees said other attractions would be based on the Muppet characters, which Disney bought the rights to last year, and the Roger Rabbit cartoon character. A new Muppet movie is also a possibility, the employees were told. ``They said none of this was guaranteed,'' said Disney employee Christy Bauer. ``But I got the impression that it was probably going to happen because everything was really detailed.'' Disney has about 78 acres available for expansion in Anaheim, including about 30 acres within the park. Anaheim City Manager Bob Simpson said he hadn't heard of any proposed expansion. ``We've been talking about expanding Disneyland for years,'' he said, ``but everybody agrees that nothing can be done until we do something about the traffic in the commercial-recreation area.''

DOC.HEAD: Canadian MP Called Absent-Minded, Cleared of Shop-Lifting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: dollar value is U.S.
DOC.TEXT: A judge on Tuesday acquitted Parliament member Lorne Nystrom of shoplifting, agreeing with Nystrom he was absent-minded but not dishonest when he failed to pay for two disks used to clean contact lenses. The merchandise was valued at less than $7. Judge Brian Lennox, who heard the case without a jury, noted that the New Democratic deputy from Saskatchewan said he absent-mindedly dropped the cleaner into his pocket and ``I am satisfied, on the basis of his evidence alone, that it is true.'' Mindy Gosman, a security guard at Shopper Drug Mart, said she saw Nystrom take the disks from a package last Nov. 29 and that he later paid for two toothbrushes but not for the cleaner. Nystrom, 43, expressed relief the highly publicized case was behind him. ``It's something I wouldn't wish on anybody,'' he said. ``It's more horrible than I can even describe, because it was so public, in terms of my friends and my family and my party.'' His lawyer, Clayton Ruby, has a reputation as one of the highest priced criminal lawyers in Canada. Ruby refused to estimate his bill but said, ``It's not going to be crippling.'' Nor would Ruby estimate the cost of lining up an array of expert witnesses, some of whom were flown in. The theft charge against Nystrom carried a maximum penalty of six months in jail and a fine of $1,700.

Many consumers and businesses may see cheaper borrowing costs by next month following a long-awaited drop in banks' prime lending rate, which fell to the lowest level in 14 months. The cut, to 10 percent from 10.5 percent effective Monday, marks the first reduction in nearly half a year and reflects the overall declining cost of money that banks have enjoyed recently due to more liberal credit policies by the Federal Reserve. The central bank moved to ease interest rates late last year to help forestall a feared economic downturn. Lower rates spur growth by encouraging businesses and consumers to borrow money. Banks use the prime as a benchmark for interest rates on a wide range of borrowing by consumers and small- and medium-size companies.

A congressional committee's eight-day trip to Hawaii comes in the dead of winter, but the congresswoman who arranged the excursion denies it's another political junket to a warm, tropical locale. ``We do have problems in paradise,'' Rep. Patricia Saiki, D-Hawaii, said after the first hearing in Hawaii on Monday by the House Committee on Merchant Marine and Fisheries. The memorandum from the chairman of the committee says the purpose of the trip is to examine national ocean and coastal policy. One day's itinerary, however, details a different type of January excursion: ``9:30 a.m. Depart hotel for Sand Point Container Yard to tour Matson Navigation Facilities _ approximately two hours; 11:30 a.m. Return to hotel. Afternoon free; 5:30 p.m. Depart hotel for cocktails and dinner John Dominis Restaurant. Dress: Aloha Casual.''

Art Buchwald's victory over Paramount Pictures about rights to ``Coming to America'' was hailed as a triumph for writers, but the studio feared the court decision could mean a rash of bogus lawsuits. ``I am very, very happy,'' Buchwald said in a telephone interview after a judge ruled Monday that Paramount must pay him for the script idea he claimed was the basis for the hit Eddie Murphy movie ``Coming to America.'' ``This thing is not only an important thing for me,'' Buchwald said. ``I think it's really important for writers.'' Superior Court Judge Harvey A. Schneider ruled that ``Coming to America'' was ``based upon a material element of, or was inspired by'' a synopsis Buchwald wrote entitled ``King for a Day.''

Gov. Madeleine Kunin wants Vermont to become the first state to ban all disposable diapers, but her plan is being trashed by some including day-care operators who want no part of a mountain of cloth. ``The time has come to be responsible and to find the way to say yes _ yes to required statewide recycling, to bans on certain polluting products, to changes in lifestyle,'' Kunin said in her state of the state speech last week. Only Nebraska has banned disposable diapers, but it allows the sale of diapers that are biodegradable, even though such products aren't believed to break down in the depths of oxygen-starved dumps. Kunin, whose proposal would ban disposable diapers by 1993, noted that while the usable life of a disposable diaper may be a few hours, they won't decompose in dumps for hundreds of years _ or several generations of babies later.

DOC.HEAD: Debt on the Rise
DOC.TEXT: Bit by bit and painfully, Americans began to find some techniques for restraining government-sector debt during the past decade. Meanwhile, private sector debt took off. The latter could become the big financial challenge of the 1990s for households, farms and businesses. For some, there are indications the bill burden already may be too heavy. Companies bought with debt find themselves strained in a weakening economy. Farmers have seen the price of land _ collateral for their loans _ decline. Many households have big mortgages. Many banks have bad real estate loans. The comptroller of the currency has warned about a growing number of tardy consumer loans, which include most personal, automobile and credit card debt. Earlier, the American Bankers Association issued a similar statement. The matter is being watched by regulatory officials and, of course, by the Federal Reserve, but those who have studied the growth attribute it more to changing lifestyles than any specific economic cause. Research by the Conference Board, a private-sector research group, shows private-sector assets of $29 trillion in 1988 after a rise of 6.7 percent a year since 1980. But liabilities rose 10 percent on average to $7.4 trillion. That still left the private sector with a net worth of $21 trillion, but unless the pattern changed in the past year, which is unlikely, net assets are continuing to erode. The Conference Board report shows that assets of non-financial corporations rose 60 percent to $6.4 trillion from the beginning of 1980 and the end of 1988, but that liabilities rose 111 percent to $2.7 trillion. Those figures brought the corporate liability-to-asset ratio to 42 percent in 1988 from 32 percent in 1980. The report said interest payments consumed half the corporate pretax dollar in 1988, against 30 percent in 1980 and 10 percent in the 1960s. Conference Board economist Eva Culen said one danger in such ratios is that big interest bills limit corporate flexibility in recessions, ``raising the specter of additional unemployment and plant closings.'' While a proliferation of bank credit cards probably boosted the household debt levels in the 1980s, the biggest dollar increase was in home mortgage debt, which rose 30 percent from 1980 as a proportion of assets. The value of houses rose sharply in the decade of the '80s, and constituted nearly half the total tangible assets of households, which also include cars, land, furniture, equipment and inventories. But mortgage debt rose even faster. Regulatory officials have been restrained in their comments, but they are concerned. Referring to the rising level of delinquency on consumer loans, Comptroller of the Currency Robert L. Clarke said this week his office was seeking to determine ``precisely what this implies for the overall condition of the national banking system.'' The American Bankers Association said the number of consumers 30 days or more behind in loan payments soared to a 10-year high in the third quarter of 1988. Delinquences rose to 2.88 percent from 2.3 percent three months earlier. Declining interest rates have taken some of the pressure off borrowers, but lower rates also reflect a weakening economy that eventually could be expressed in terms of rising unemployment and shortened workweeks. Meanwhile, consumer borrowing appeared to surge during the Christmas selling season. The Federal Reserve reported this week that consumers borrowed $4.24 billion more than they paid off in November. That increase, the biggest rise in outstanding consumer debt in nine months, was said by some observers to reflect growing consumer confidence. For some regulators, however, is was a warning sign.
DOC.NOTE: End adv PMs Wednesday, Jan. 10.

DOC.HEAD: Program Officials' Convention to See More Games, Less Controversy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to correct to May 1988, sted last May
DOC.TEXT: The electronic circus is coming to New Orleans next week. Consider some attractions. ``What a Dummy.'' ``The People of Beverly Hills Vs. Zsa Zsa Gabor.'' ``Monopoly.'' ``Trump Card.'' ``TV Personals.'' A few game-show revivals also will be there _ ``Name That Tune,'' ``Joker's Wild,'' and ``Tic Tac Dough.'' So will a former presidential candidate's debut in syndicated TV: ``Jesse Jackson _ Voices of America.'' These are but a few of the 100 new shows afoot when the convention of the National Association of Television Program Executives starts Monday in the Big Easy. The city anticipates 9,000 conventioneers will be on hand for this annual festival of show-selling to local stations. But convention officials don't expect a return this year of what last year was the Big Controversy at NATPE _ ``tabloid TV.'' The term refers to syndicated shows like ``A Current Affair'' and ``Geraldo,'' which report on and discuss tales of the tawdry, the unseemly, and even the somewhat salacious. ``That kind of overwhelmed the whole thing,'' says NATPE chairman Lon C. Lee, vice president and program manager of NBC-owned KCNC-TV in Denver. ``I don't think you'll see that this year.'' Rather, he says, there'll be a lot of discussion about new game shows and, generally speaking, ``I think you're going to see a much broader selection of shows than in the past.'' There still will be magazine and so-called information shows being offered in syndication to local stations at the convention, but they'll be of ``a softer kind than `Oprah' or `A Current Affair' type of programming,'' one sales executive says. ``The new stuff is what I call kinder, gentler programming,'' explains the executive, Michael Levinton, programs vice president for Blair Television, a national sales representative for 147 TV stations. One example of what he means would be ``Only Yesterday,'' a proposed weeknight information series created by former ABC News executive Av Westin. It would be anchored by John Palmer, who left NBC News last month after 26 years there. Each half-hour episode would be a two-part show, the first part nostalgia, the second a given major story of yesteryear told by a person who witnessed it, says Westin, who left ABC News last summer after 20 years there. Westin now is senior vice president of reality-based programming at King World, a major company that may make ``Only Yesterday,'' and syndicates ``Inside Edition,'' and such hits as ``Wheel of Fortune'' and ``The Oprah Winfrey Show.'' When at ABC News, Westin dispatched ``20-20'' crews to cover one NATPE convention. But this will be the first he ever has attended. This time, he's part of King World's bid to sign up stations for ``Only Yesterday.'' ``Part of the continuing education of Av Westin in television continues,'' he wryly says. ``The essential difference is at a network, you could declare you were going to put a program ... and you instantly have 209 stations. ``In the world of syndication, King World can declare anything it wants. Then it's got to go out and sell it to 209 station managers.'' If one understands that each has his or her own idea on what will work in a given market, he says, ``then in a way it becomes a very fascinating challenge.'' Westin says he probably won't know until after the week-long convention ends whether ``Only Yesterday'' will go into production. Neither Levinton nor NATPE chairman Lee thinks the costly flop of ``USA Today on TV'' will have an adverse effect on other syndicated news and information series being offered next week. The series was unique in that 156 stations bought it in 1988 without seeing a pilot episode. ``I think they (station executives) perceived that this was a bad attempt in a category that still is critical to stations,'' Levinton says. Lee, whose station didn't buy ``USA Today on TV,'' jokes that ``station buyers have very short memories.'' They may vow never to buy a show without seeing a sample first, he says, but ``of course we'll forget that lesson somewhere down the road.''

Elsewhere in television... HISTORIC FIRST: THE SEQUEL _ On Jan. 18, ABC's ``PrimeTime Live'' will have Sam Donaldson and Diane Sawyer reporting from within the Kremlin. The program, ABC says, ``will have access never before granted a television audience.'' In May 1988, the ``CBS Evening News'' reported from within the Kremlin, which, a CBS release said then, is ``the Soviet stronghold forbidden to Western cameras for more than 20 years.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wed PMs, Jan. 10

DOC.HEAD: Michael Landon Stars in Family Drama With Art Carney
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Monday in 5th graf is Jan. 29.
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Michael Landon sat on the floor in the tiny, darkened editing room and watched two key dramatic scenes in the NBC movie ``Where Pigeons Go To Die.'' On the monitor screen, Art Carney as ``Da'' lies motionless in a hospital bed as his 10-year-old grandson, played by Robert Hy Gorman, tells him about the performance of Dickens in a homing-pigeon race. The boy is thrilled when his grandfather, who's had a stroke, mumbles a few words. Then, the boy watches from hiding as he sees for the first time that his own father, played by Cliff De Young, loves ``Da'' as much as he does. It's an emotional moment, and even the editors, who've seen it dozens of times, watch silently. Landon directed the movie, which airs Monday, and adapted the screenplay from the book by R. Wright Campbell. He also narrates and plays the adult grandson who returns 40 years later to sell his grandfather's house and is overwhelmed by memories. It's the first thing Landon's done since completing the NBC series ``Highway to Heaven'' last year. After more than 30 years in television without a letup (``Bonanza'' 1959-73, ``Little House on the Prairie'' 1974-83 and ``Highway to Heaven'' 1984-89), Landon took six months off to travel and relax. ``I was having dinner one night with Melissa Sue Anderson, who was on `Little House,' and her fiance,'' he said. ``She said she'd read `Where Pigeons Go To Die' and thought I might like it. I did and I bought the book. It had been around for a while. It had once been optioned with John Wayne in mind for the grandfather. ``I loved the simplicity of the story. I loved the way the boy's love of his grandfather is tied in with his pet homing pigeon. I like the way the narration brings the story together. There are no big-deal things going on _ just some little things, like the way the boy sees his father shave his grandfather and sees his love, too.'' Landon said he felt particularly lucky that he was able to get Art Carney, who won an Oscar for his role in ``Harry and Tonto'' in 1974. ``I'd always thought of him for the part of the grandfather,'' he says. ``He's a lovely guy to work with.'' The movie also brings Landon together with composer Leonard Rosenman, who wrote the score. ``He wrote the music for `East of Eden' and I've been humming it for 20 years,'' Landon said. Landon's producer, Kent McCray, and his wife, Sue McCray, his casting director, sent a recording of the ``East of Eden'' theme to Switzerland and had a special music box made. Landon collects music boxes. The movie was filmed on location in Lawrence, Kan., and in Kansas City. Landon said he's worked so often with animals that he had little trouble with the pigeons, cat and hawk in the movie. He left it up to his long-time animal trainer, Gary Gero, who went to Kansas early to get the pigeons acquainted with the area. ``A pigeon is not exactly the Albert Einstein of the animal world,'' Landon said, ``but Gary was able to get them to do some remarkable things. He set up the big pigeon race where hundreds of pigeons competed. ``He's extremely kind to the animals. I never want any animal put in jeopardy and he feels the same way.'' Landon, a former national high school champion javelin thrower, began his long career as the title character in ``I Was a Teen-age Werewolf.'' A number of television roles followed and then he was cast as Little Joe Cartwright in ``Bonanza.'' He began writing when the show was ready to shut down temporarily because it didn't have a script. He wrote the script over a weekend and later wrote many more episodes and began directing on the popular family western. He wrote and directed most of the episodes of ``Little House on the Prairie'' and ``Highway to Heaven.'' His son, Michael Landon Jr., played Little Joe's son in a next generation ``Bonanza'' movie. He's currently studying at the American Film Institute. Landon has seven grown children, two of them adopted. He and his third wife, Cindy, have two young children. Last month the family moved into a new 10-bedroom Malibu mansion at the end of a canyon about one mile from the ocean. Few people in television have been as productive as Landon. He lists among his hobbies ``writing scripts.'' Even on his six-month rest, when he visited Tahiti and Hawaii, he still did some writing and edited ``Highway to Heaven'' for syndication. At present, there's no new series in Landon's future. ``I like working on different projects,'' he said. ``I'm now negotiating to set up my company at a studio. I've got a few projects in mind, but nothing has been signed yet. ``I won't say never to another series. If something good comes along it would be fun to get the crew together again.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, Jan. 26-28

On Show: Gallery and Museum Exhibits and Shows
DOC.TEXT: Frank Lloyd Wright was a radical man, a man with a Utopian vision. From the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York with its spiral ramp to the Kaufmann House in Bear Run, Pa., built into a waterfall, he was an architect and decorator who saw the beauty of open space and married machinery to aesthetics. He believed architecture was organic, a bridge between people and nature. He set no limits for himself, as is seen in a new exhibit of his drawings at the Phoenix Art Musueum. The show, ``Frank Lloyd Wright Drawings: Masterworks From the Frank Lloyd Wright Archives,'' features 303 original works dating from 1887 to the 1950s. The works are on loan from the Archives at Taliesin West, a national historic landmark in Scottsdale, Ariz., and cover residential buildings, religious structures, high-rises, civic and cultural buildings, hotels, resorts and commercial structures as well as graphic and decorative design. ``Many of these drawings have not been seen for 50 years and probably will not be seen for another 50,'' said Bruce Brooks Pfeiffer, director of the Archives for the Frank Lloyd Wright Foundation. The exhibit also includes notes the architect made on his drawings years after he created them. ``The longer he lived, the more he returned to his earlier drawings to make notes and comments on them, sometimes working on the architectual lines themselves as well as adding text,'' Pfeiffer said. The exhibit runs from Jan. 13 to April 8. Another Wright exhibit currently is running at the Seattle Art Musueum: ``Frank Lloyd Wright: Preserving an Architectual Heritage.'' The exhibit includes more than 70 pieces of furniture, stained glass windows, light fixtures and other decorative works. It runs through Feb. 25 before traveling for two years to museums in Chicago, Buffalo, Denver, Philadelphia and Dallas.

DOC.TEXT: The nation's leading commercial banks dropped their prime lending rates a half percentage point to 10 percent, marking the first reduction in nearly half a year and paving the way for many cheaper business and consumer loans. The move Monday reflects the overall falling cost of money that banks have enjoyed in recent weeks due to more liberal credit policies by the Federal Reserve. The central bank moved to ease interest rates late in 1989 to help forestall a dramatic economic downturn.

The Supreme Court set the stage for a key ``affirmative action'' ruling, agreeing to study the special preferences the federal government gives to television and radio stations owned by women and minority members. The justices said Monday they will use a Florida case to review the Federal Communications Commission's policy of treating such ownership as a favorable factor when awarding licenses. In another case, the high court refused to force a revival of the ``fairness doctrine,'' under which the federal government could require radio and TV stations to present all sides of controversial issues.

The board of directors of ailing Campeau Corp. met as speculation grew that the company would seek refuge for its retailers in bankruptcy court. Campeau spokeswoman Carol Sanger declined Monday to discuss what the board would consider at its meeting at company headquarters in Toronto. Industry sources and retail analysts said it seemed probable that the Canadian retail and real estate company would file for protection from creditors on behalf of its U.S. retail divisions, Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp.

President Bush struck a combative stance for the 1990 congressional session, complaining ``it is past time'' for lawmakers to approve a capital gains tax cut and other White House proposals left hanging last year. Saying a capital gains bill would be a top priority, Bush declared Monday, ``I am sick and tired of the demagogues who call this a tax cut for the rich. It means jobs, it means savings and it is good for all Americans.'' Many Democrats in Congress have opposed a reduction on grounds the chief beneficiaries would be the wealthy.

Jeff H. Reynolds, who is seeking control of financially struggling Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd. in return for a $197 million investment, has a business address that is a mail-drop. His company, Weatherby Investments Inc., does not appear to be traded publicly as he contends, officials said Monday. The 28-year-old Texan, little known on the investment scene, said in a news statement last week that he was negotiating with Bond Holdings, the Australian holding company. The release listed an answering service as a contact number.

Eastern Airlines is in negotiations that may result in compensation for assets transferred to parent Texas Air Corp., a move that helped ignite a crippling strike ten months ago. The special examiner in Eastern's bankruptcy proceeding has been holding talks that could lead to restitution by Texas Air for assets that could amount to millions of dollars, sources said Monday. Attorney David I. Shapiro, the examiner appointed by the federal bankruptcy court, noted in a document submitted recently to the court that he has negotiated with Eastern on a possible settlement related to the transferred assets.

UAL Corp. shares fell after a deadline set by a major shareholder for the company to come up with a new employee buyout plan arrived without any apparent progress. The stock fell $2.87{ a share Monday to $156.62{ on the New York Stock Exchange. The investor group Coniston Partners said last month that it would press for a recapitalization of UAL unless the United Airlines parent presented a buyout plan, preferably one involving employee stock ownership, by Monday.

Senate Banking Committee Chairman Donald Riegle, one of five lawmakers facing ethics investigations in the Lincoln Savings and Loan affair, is launching a television campaign aimed at limiting political damage back home in Michigan. Sen. Dennis DeConcini of Arizona, meanwhile, is shelling out $190,000 for newspaper ads and TV commercials in his state. The other three senators are defending themselves in a variety of forums but have yet to pay for newspaper or broadcast access to voters, spokesmen said Monday.

A decade of merger mania closed with a year that gave birth to some prominent double-barreled corporate nameplates, including Time Warner Inc., Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. and Bridgestone-Firestone Inc. And a man whose name seems to be everywhere got another entry in the corporate lexicon as Trump Shuttle replaced the Eastern Airlines Shuttle. The number of corporate name changes declined 14 percent last year to 1,600 from a record 1,864 in 1988, according to a survey released Monday by Anspach Grossman Portugal Inc.

News of a long-awaited cut in the bank prime lending rate helped inspire a moderate rally in the stock market Monday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 21.12 points to 2,794.37. The dollar fell sharply. Gold prices also slipped. Most bond prices declined. Futures prices for both frozen pork bellies and orange juice were up the limit; grains were mostly higher; precious metals and oil products were lower.

DOC.HEAD: Mergers Produced a Host of New Corporate Names in 1989, Survey Shows
DOC.TEXT: The number of corporate name changes declined last year, but 1989 saw the creation of some prominent double-barreled corporate nameplates, including Time Warner Inc., Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. and Bridgestone-Firestone Inc. And a man whose name seems to be everywhere got another entry in the corporate lexicon as the Trump Shuttle replaced the Eastern Airlines Shuttle. The number of corporate name changes declined 14 percent last year to 1,600 from a record 1,864 in 1988, according to a survey released Monday by Anspach Grossman Portugal Inc. Nevertheless, the 1989 total was the third highest in the 20 years that the corporate identity consulting firm has conducted its annual survey, and was almost four times the 422 name changes in 1980. Mergers and acquisitions were the reason for 799 name changes or 50 percent of the total, reflecting the continued restructuring of corporate America. In the decade's first year, only 25 percent of name changes stemmed from mergers and acquisitions, the firm said. Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. made one of the year's most publicized matches, but mergers in the pharmaceutical and accounting industries also produced some predictable names. SmithKline Beckman Corp. and Beecham Group PLC got together to make SmithKline Beecham, Bristol-Myers Co. and Squibb Co. produced Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., and Deloitte Haskins & Sells and Touche Ross became Deloitte & Touche. ``While these new names are the result of combining well-known names, if history is any guide many of these will later be shortened,'' said Joel Portugal, a partner in the consulting firm. Other name changes illustrated the boom in foreign acquisitions of U.S. companies. Stauffer Chemical Corp. became Rhone-Poulenc Basic Chemicals Inc.; Pennwalt was changed to Atochem and Westinghouse Elevator was reborn as Schindler Corp. But Bridgestone Corp. apparently saw extra mileage in a brand it acquired in 1988. It rechristened itself last year as Bridgestone-Firestone Inc. Divestitures, sales of assets, spin-offs and leveraged buyouts led to 388 name changes, or 24 percent of the total, and corporate reorganizations and changes to a holding company structure accounted for 120 changes, or 8 percent. Ramada sold off its hotels and motels and retained its gaming operations under the new name of Aztar Corp., NWA Inc. became Wings Holdings Inc. after the Alfred Checchi buyout, and F.W. Woolworth Co. streamlined its name to Woolworth Corp. when it became a holding company. Another 258 companies or 16 percent of the total changed names for reasons other than a merger, sale or reorganization. Among the most prominent was Gulf & Western Inc., which restyled itself as Paramount Communications Inc. The greatest number of name changes occurred among manufacturing and industrial companies, with 464 or 29 percent of the total. It was the first time in the survey's history that industrial companies made more name changes than financial institutions, which accounted for 366 or 23 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Rates Fall on Short-Term Treasury Securities
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities fell in Monday's auction. The Treasury Department sold $7.8 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.57 percent, down from 7.64 percent last week. Another $7.8 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.44 percent, down from 7.52 percent last week. The rates were the lowest since three-month bills sold for 7.55 percent on Dec. 4, 1989, and six-month bills averaged 7.43 percent on Dec. 18, 1989. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 7.83 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,808.60 and 7.84 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,623.90. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for 1-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable-rate mortgages, rose to 7.82 percent last week, up from 7.80 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Bond and Campeau: Two Stories of Great Visions and Poor Judgment
LaserPhoto NY9
DOC.TEXT: It was the heyday of corporate takeovers and two businessmen had visions of greatness. One, an Australian, saw himself atop a global brewing empire, while the other, a Canadian, expected to become the most powerful retailer in the biggest consumer nation in the world, the United States. But their dreams clouded their judgment, allowing both men to delude themselves and ignore obvious signs of trouble. Today, Alan Bond and Robert Campeau are seeing their businesses slip away. Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd., with interests in brewing, media, natural resources and real estate around the world, has $6 billion in debts. Its Australian brewing companies have gone into receivership and its American brewer, G. Heileman Brewing Co. of La Crosse, Wis., has had to cut a deal with its own creditors. Alan Bond did manage to win a reprieve last week, when an Australian court turned down a government request to liquidate his company. But he is still battling banks and receivers. Meanwhile, it is widely expected that Campeau Corp.'s sagging U.S. retail divisions, Allied Stores Corp. and Federated Department Stores Inc., will be forced to seek bankruptcy court protection because they cannot make payments on $7 billion in debt held by banks and bondholders. Last week, Robert Campeau lost 29 percent of his stock in Toronto-based Campeau Corp. when two of his private companies defaulted on bank loans. To some extent, both men were victims of economic circumstances: Interest rates surged in Australia, taking a toll on Bond Corp.'s business, and retail sales slumped in the United States, leaving Campeau Corp. with little cash to meet its loan payments. But analysts who have followed the two companies say Alan Bond and Robert Campeau would never have landed in such trouble if they hadn't spent so much on the firms they acquired. When Bond bought Heileman for $1.22 billion in 1987, he wanted the company so badly he paid a price that, even then, analysts said was too high. Heileman already had been losing market share and sales for a year. But when Bond launched his bid, he had a vision of the future, which he described in a letter to Heileman management: ``Together Bond Brewing and Heileman would be the fourth largest brewer in the world, enabling it to exploit markets beyond either of our own reaches.'' It didn't turn out that way. Heileman has sold its profitable baking division and closed several plants, but still has $850 million in debts. And Bond Corp. said recently Heileman's cash flow was not likely to be enough to make principal payments on its long-term debt this year. Heileman is just part of Bond Corp.'s problems. Bond has conceded that another acquisition, of part of the Australian firm Bell Group Ltd., has also resulted in sharp losses. Robert Campeau was equally blind to the obvious. When the real estate developer bought Federated for $6.6 billion in early 1988, the entire U.S. retailing industry had been in a slump for more than a year, and no one knew when it would turn around. But Campeau confidently shrugged off questions about whether the company could handle its debt if sales didn't recover. Business didn't pick up, and Federated and Allied consistently posted losses after they were acquired. Then, last September, Campeau Corp. exploded a bombshell: It could not make the payments on some of the high-yield junk bonds that it issued to help finance its acquisitions. The news devastated the junk bond market and almost brought the takeover business to a standstill. Robert Campeau was forced to give up control of his company to another Canadian developer, Olympia & York, in return for an infusion of cash. He was also forced to put Federated's Bloomingdale's chain up for sale. Ironically, Bloomingdales's was the chain upon which Campeau hoped to build his retail empire. Bond and Campeau have both had notoriety in their personal lives as well as in their business dealings. Bond is better known than Campeau in the United States _ perhaps not by name, but by his stunning defeat of San Diegan Dennis Conner during the 1983 America's Cup race, the first time the United States had ever lost yachting's biggest prize. In 1987, when it came time to defend the cup, Bond's entry failed to make it to the finals. Conner defeated another Australian yacht and reclaimed the cup. Later that year, Bond won a battle of a different sort, paying the highest auction price ever for a work of art: He was the anonymous bidder who paid $53.9 million in 1987 for Vincent Van Gogh's ``Irises.'' As it turns out, Bond went into debt for that acquisition, too. The auction house Sotheby's recently revealed that it had loaned Bond $27 million toward the purchase price. Campeau was barely known in the United States even after he bought Allied in late 1986. It was his two-month battle for Federated that won him notice, although even after he had defeated R.H. Macy & Co. Inc., many Americans still didn't know his name. They did know, however, that a Canadian had bought Bloomingdale's. In Canada, where Campeau made his fortune as a developer, he is quite well-known as a big party-giver in social circles in Toronto. He has had many friends in the Canadian government, including the popular former Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Will Push for Big Changes in Final Round of Trade Talks
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills says the Bush administration will push for widescale changes as it enters the final year of negotiations aimed at rewriting the rules of global trade. She said Monday that eliminating trade-distorting agricultural subsidies, which are costing billions of dollars worldwide, remained a top priority but that the farm issue was only one of several areas in which the administration is making efforts to expand opportunities for U.S. exporters. ``I have a political imperative to get reform across the board,'' she told a news conference. The Bush administration hopes to use the global trade negotiations, known as the Uruguay Round, as a way of expanding export opportunities for U.S. farmers and businesses and thus resume shrinking the country's trade deficit, currently stuck above $100 billion annually. The negotiations, involving the 96 member countries of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, are due to conclude in December. Hills said, however, that she hoped an agreement in at least one key area, the rules guaranteeing market access, can be worked out well in advance of the final deadline. She said that resolution of this topic is possible because ``there is no East-West or North-South split (between countries). There are problems for everyone in the package and benefits for everyone in the package.'' Hills also listed a U.S. initiative to write rules covering about $1 trillion in annual global trade that is either not now protected by GATT rules or for which the current protection is inadequate. She said the United States wanted GATT rules written to protect trade in services, such as banking and insurance, and to strengthen protection for intellectual property rights, an area in which some studies have indicated that U.S. companies are losing between $40 billion and $60 billion annually because of piracy by foreign companies. ``These are all areas where American entrepreneurs in the 1990s and beyond are going to be super-competitive,'' Hills said. On the subject of America's huge trade deficit with Japan, which accounts for more than half of the total U.S. imbalance, Hills gave qualified praise for a recently announced Japanese package of measures aimed at reducing the country's huge trade surpluses. The program, drawn up by Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry, features a plan to offer tax incentives that would reward Japanese companies that increase their imports 10 percent or more from the previous year's levels. ``We will have to wait and see how that tax credit affects the behavior of buyers, but it shows a certain resolve on the part of MITI and we are grateful for that,'' Hills said. Hills is scheduled to meet in Washington this week with her Japanese counterpart, Hikaru Matsunaga, the head of MITI, who will also hold talks with Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher and Michael Boskin, chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers.

DOC.HEAD: Consumers Sank $4 Billion Deeper In Debt in November
DOC.TEXT: Americans took out $4.24 billion more in consumer credit than they retired in November, the largest increase in their outstanding debt in nine months, the Federal Reserve said. Some analysts said the jump, announced Monday, reflected overall consumer optimism despite pockets of sluggishness in the economy. ``It presents a clear picture that consumers are back on track even if they had slowed down earlier in the year,'' said Michael K. Evans of Evans Economics Inc. ``They're starting to spend again. We also saw this in the Christmas sales which were pretty good.'' The Fed said consumer credit in November advanced at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 7.2 percent on top of a 5.4 percent gain in October. It was the highest level of consumer debt since last February when $5.38 billion was posted. Consumer credit includes all consumer loans except mortgages. The pace of auto loans slowed to a 2.2 percent increase, or $519 million, on an annual basis reflecting the November slump in the automobile industry resulting from an absence of sales incentives and the presence of price increases for 1990 models that took effect in October. Auto loans increased 4.1 percent in October, but analysts said that reflected a lag in credit applications made in September but not approved until the following month. Auto sales remained depressed until late December when car buyers took advantage of incentives that expired at year's end. ``Consumers didn't like the prices and knew they would come down,'' Evans said, describing the situation in the auto industry as a pricing problem, not an economic one. The category of debt that includes credit cards jumped to a 17.2 percent annual rate of growth from a 6.6 percent rate in October. Total revolving debt rose $2.8 billion, compared to $1.08 billion the previous month. Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate rose $1.33 billion, an 8 percent annual rate of growth, compared with a gain of $1.17 billion or 7.1 percent in October. Mobile home debts outstanding fell again, down $424 million or 22.2 percent. The rate of increase in these debts had fallen for seven consecutive months until a one-month gain in September. The various changes left total consumer debt in November at a seasonally adjusted $711.8 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Boesky Partnership Liquidated, But Mountain of Litigation Pending
DOC.TEXT: Partners of Ivan F. Boesky's main arbitrage fund are getting $248 million in liquidation proceedings, but attorneys promise to continue pursuing a mountain of lawsuits involving the fallen speculator. More than two dozen shareholder lawsuits and other litigation against Boesky, his defunct partnership CX Partners LP and affiliated entities are pending in U.S. District Court in Manhattan. The agreement between CX Partners and its 46 investors was reached after more than three years of discussions dating to Boesky's November 1986 settlement of insider trading charges with the Securities and Exchange Commission. While the agreement is the first major resolution of a Boesky civil matter, it doesn't mean lawyers are ready to settle other litigation. ``It's going full-steam ahead,'' said David Berger, a lawyer for shareholders in some class-action lawsuits against Boesky parties. ``We will be proceeding with depositions and preparing to go to trial,'' added George Reycraft, who represents the limited partners in the Boesky fund. Boesky and the entities he once controlled were inundated with lawsuits after federal authorities disclosed his alleged insider trading activities. Most of the lawsuits are by shareholders who were selling stock at the time Boesky and his associates were buying. Also pending in the case that rocked Wall Street is completion of an SEC plan to use $50 million paid by Boesky to reimburse individual investors who can prove they were defrauded by his trading. Under the agreement liquidating CX Partners, formerly known as Ivan F. Boesky & Co., most of the limited partners received 100 percent of their investment, said David R. Herwitz, the partnership's liquidating trustee. The total equity investment in the fund, which Boesky formed in March 1986 to buy stocks of potential takeover targets, was $338 million. Its value dropped to $285 million when Boesky was charged and has since grown to $335 million thanks to interest, Reycraft said. But Boesky and his wife surrendered all their interests in the enterprise and some partners did not receive full compensation. People familiar with the case said the Boeskys' interest in the fund totaled just under $10 million. The limited partnerships included insurance companies, financial institutions and individual investors. Some future disbursements to the partnerships are possible, Herwitz said. Guinness PLC, the largest holder in the fund with a $100 million stake, received just $37 million of its claim, Reycraft said. Monday's settlement included an agreement with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which had an $8 million equity stake in the Boesky fund and owned $20 million of its debt. Reycraft said Drexel received the full $20 million for the debt but no interest or any of its equity investment. Under the agreement, Drexel will be dropped as a defendant in the Boesky-related lawsuits, he said. But Reycraft said the limited partners planned to proceed with litigation against Boesky and others, including former Drexel financier Michael Milken and admitted securities felons Dennis Levine and Martin Siegel. Boesky, 52, is due to be released in April from a Brooklyn halfway house, where he is completing a three-year prison term. Boesky pleaded guilty to one count of violating federal securities laws and paid $100 million to settle charges he led a network of illegal trading using inside information. The government is using $50 million of the money to compensate investors who can prove they were victimized by Boesky's trading. SEC officials had set Jan. 15 target date to establish a plan to distibute the money. ``We are working toward achieving a plan for distribution of the money but that may or may not have anything to do with an investors' settlement,'' said John H. Sturc, an SEC associate enforcement director. Herwitz, a Harvard law professor, said he expected some of the lawsuits consolidated before U.S. District Judge Milton Pollack to be resolved soon. ``Some of these lawsuits will be reduced, abated or limited,'' Herwitz said. ``Part of what is happening is people are going to try to save a dollar or two on litgation costs.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Men Settle SEC Inside Trading Charges
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission says two Connecticut men have settled insider trading charges stemming from Emhart Corp.'s tender offer for Stanadyne Inc. One of the two, who allegedly traded on inside information obtained when the other opened somebody else's mail, agreed to pay almost $20,000 in fines and penalties, the SEC said Monday. The misappropriated information concerned a 1988 tender offer for Stanadyne, a Windsor, Conn., pump and faucet maker, by Hartford-based Emhart, which makes tools and machinery. Stanadyne was acquired by FSLI Acquisition Corp. in February 1988. The SEC accused Thaddeus Pencikowski, 37, of Farmington, Conn., of making $9,093 in alleged illegal profits after buying 750 shares of Stanadyne common stock Jan. 8, 1988, with confidential information allegedly supplied to him by Bruce J. Warren, also 37, of Plainville, Conn. Both men settled the civil charges without admitting or denying wrongdoing. Pencikowski's lawyer, Vincent Dowling, was not in his office when called for comment. Warren's lawyer, Steven Sach, declined to comment until he spoke with his client. ``No financial penalty was sought for Mr. Warren, who did not trade for himself,'' said Harry J. Weiss, an attorney with the SEC's Enforcement Division. According to the SEC, Warren agreed to receive a Stanadyne director's mail while the director was away. Warren's computer graphics company and the director's office were in the same building, which was owned and managed by Pencikowski. The SEC accused Warren of violating a ``duty of trust and confidence'' to the Stanadyne director when he revealed to Pencikowski the contents of a letter concerning the Emhart offer. ``The complaint alleged Mr. Warren misappropriated information from the director and then tipped Mr. Pencikowski,'' said Weiss. Pencikowski allegedly bought 750 Stanadyne shares at $26.50 per share on Jan. 8 and sold them for $39 a share on Jan. 11, 1988 _ the day the Emhart offer was made public. According to the SEC, Pencikowski agreed to disgorge $10,847 in alleged illegal profits plus interest as well as a penalty equal to his alleged profits of $9,093. Both men also agreed to the entering of a court order barring them from breaking securities laws.

DOC.HEAD: Examiner, Eastern in Financial Settlement Talks
DOC.TEXT: A burning issue behind the strike against Eastern Airlines _ the transfer of some Eastern assets to parent Texas Air Corp. _ is now the subject of negotiations that could result in compensation being paid to Eastern. The special examiner in Eastern's bankruptcy proceeding has been holding talks that could lead to restitution by Texas Air for assets that could amount to millions of dollars, sources said Monday. Attorney David I. Shapiro, the examiner appointed by the federal bankruptcy court, noted in a document submitted recently to the court that he has negotiated with Eastern on a possible settlement related to the transferred assets, which include planes, routes and other crucial segments of an airline operation. Shapiro declined to comment on the matter Monday, as did Texas Air spokesman Art Kent in Houston. But sources familiar with the talks, who asked not to be identified, said the discussions were continuing. The unions representing pilots, ground workers and flight attendants, who struck Eastern last March 4, have long accused Texas Air Chairman Frank Lorenzo of siphoning off valuable Eastern assets to its sister carrier, Continental Airlines, and to Texas Air. The unions have demanded that a special trustee be appointed to run Miami-based Eastern, replacing Lorenzo and top management. The strike virtually shut down Eastern and forced it to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection March 9. Eastern pilots and flight attendants abandoned their sympathy walkouts shortly before Thanksgiving, but the Machinists union remains on strike. A union advocate charged Monday that a financial settlement wouldn't be adequate to compensate Eastern for assets that he said Lorenzo stripped from the airline. ``It is not a sufficient cure for that simply to pay some bucks,'' said Bruce Simon, an attorney for the Air Line Pilots Association. ``There should be a trustee.'' Shapiro, a Washington attorney, has been conducting an extensive financial investigation of Texas Air, Eastern and Continental since early September. Shapiro and more than 20 associates have been interviewing current and former officers of the companies, union leaders and others. Shapiro is looking into past transactions between Texas Air and its two main subsidiaries. They include the transfer of the System One computerized reservation system from Eastern to Texas Air in April 1987 for about $100 million. If the examiner's investigation found that price to be inadequate, for example, he might ask Texas Air to pay Eastern the difference between what it already paid for System One and a fair market price, the sources said. Shapiro has told the court his inquiry has shown there may be a conflict of interest stemming from Eastern and Continental having the same owner. He recently said the key question is whether Lorenzo has been treating the three companies as one airline. Last month, Shapiro said he and his staff had interviewed about 70 people and examined more than 200,000 documents. Eastern has complained that the investigation's objectivity has been compromised because a large part of the work has been delegated to Eastern's unions. ``We may pursue it further,'' Eastern spokesman Robin Matell said Monday, referring to the complaints. He declined to comment, however, on the issue of negotiations with Shapiro on a possible settlement. Shapiro recently said he has received a list of complaints from Eastern's attorneys that contend the investigation has been almost prosecutorial. The examiner said the magnitude of the task has led him to delegate some work, such as interviews, to union attorneys but that practice hasn't hurt objectivity. After having received several extensions, Shapiro is scheduled to report on his investigation to U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland in New York on Feb. 15. A hearing on the trustee issue also is scheduled for that day.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Board To Explore Recapitalization As Deadline for Buyout Passes
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp. has instructed its financial adviser to explore the merits of recapitalizing the airline company, a move that could mean flying with a heavy debt load and increasing internal turbulence. The move Monday came under pressure from Coniston Partners, a New York investment concern that owns 11.8 percent of UAL's stock and has threatened to make a run at taking control of the company's board of directors. Under this threat, Coniston said it wanted the company recapitalized if there was no revised buyout proposal put together by Monday. UAL, the parent of United Airlines, issued a statement after the close of markets Monday saying that ``no employee ownership plan has been put forth. ...'' It said company directors told their financial adviser, First Boston Corp., to come up with a proposal for the next UAL board meeting on Jan. 25. UAL said in its statement that among the proposals it wants studied is a plan that would involve an ``exchange offer of UAL debt securities for a significant portion of UAL's outstanding stock.'' UAL spokesman Rob Doughty would not say how many of the 21 million outstanding shares might be involved in any recapitalization. Nor would he expand in any other way on the company's brief statement. There was no immediate response from the pilots union, which led earlier attempts to put together an employee buyout. But the union, as well as UAL Chairman Stephen Wolf, has been known to oppose recapitalization, partly because of the extra debt it might entail. Wolf reportedly told the pilots union that he might resign if the company was forced to recapitalize. Three years ago, the airline went through a recapitalization that added about $3 billion in debt. However, within a few years this was cut in half with surplus revenue and proceeds from sales of non-airline businesses. Over the past year, takeover talk has taken the Chicago-based company for a bumpy ride. A pilot-management plan to buy the company for $6.75 billion, or $300 a share, failed last fall when banks refused to finance it. Since then, the value of a share of the company's stock has been nearly cut in half. Last month, Coniston said it was dissatisfied with progress being made toward a sale or restructuring of the company. It said that if there was no sale and if a recapitalization proved unsatisfactory, it might revive its threat to seek shareholder consent to oust 13 of UAL's 15 directors and take control of the board. Officials of the investment concern could not be reached for comment on UAL's decision to explore recapitalization. There was no answer at Coniston's New York office late Monday. UAL said that if the board approves a recapitalization, it would be implemented ``as promptly as practicable thereafter.'' The statement said the board remains open to ``any appropriate acquisition proposal from employees or any other party.'' UAL stock traded as high as $294 a share amid the buying frenzy that followed the plot-management group's offer last summer. The stock closed Monday on the New York Stock Exchange at $156.62{, down $2.87{.
