DOC.HEAD: London Shares Little Changed At Midday
DOC.TEXT: London shares fought back from early lows to stand little changed by midday Tuesday, helped by the return of light buying interest and a more positive lead from the futures market. At noon London time, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 0.1 point, or 0.004 percent, at 2,431.2 points, but much improved from a morning low of 2,420.5 points, a loss of 10.8 points. The market opened lower after sharp losses earlier in Tokyo. With little buying interest emerging in the first two hours of official trading, market makers swiftly knocked prices lower. But, by around 11 a.m., a stronger trend in the stock index futures market helped the market turn around. ``We have seen a small, technically-inspired rally,'' one dealer said. Most action, however, remained focused on blue-chip stocks. Volume came to 312.7 million shares by midday, compared with 209 million shares at the same time Monday.

DOC.HEAD: JVC Announces Digital Sound for VHS Videos
DOC.TEXT: JVC has developed a method for recording high-quality digital sound on VHS videotapes, a company official said today, which should allow future Super VHS machines to match or surpass compact disc players in sound quality. ``Digital sound is the wave of the future, so we have developed a digital audio recording method for VHS,'' the official said. Digital recording allows greater dynamic range and lower noise levels than conventional analog methods. Current VHS videocassette recorders use frequency modulation (FM), a non-digital method, to record high-fidelity sound. The new machines will record both FM and digital audio, making the tapes and equipment compatible with earlier VHS machines, JVC said. Prototypes using the new technology have been developed, but no date has been set for marketing, said the official, speaking on condition of anonymity. The price is expected to be higher than for current Super VHS equipment. Super VHS, introduced in 1987, uses special tapes and circuitry to provide higher-quality pictures than normal VHS. Currently, VHS machines record video and FM audio signals on two different layers of the videotape's magnetic coating in a technique called depth multiplexing. The digital sound information will be recorded on the same layer as the FM signal, JVC said. The company, whose formal name is Victor Co. of Japan, is the original developer of the VHS format and a member of the Matsushita Group, which makes Panasonic and Technics products. The JVC official said the new technology would allow direct recordings from other digital sources such as satellite broadcasts. Japan's public broadcasting network, the Japan Broadcasting Corp. (NHK), broadcasts television programs with digital sound directly from a stationary satellite. However, direct digital recordings from compact discs will not be possible without an adapter. The company said it expects a wide range of applications for the new technology, from general consumer goods to professional equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Bridgestone-Firestone Seeking Hundreds of Employee Buyouts
DOC.TEXT: Bridgestone-Firestone Inc. has given hundreds of workers nationwide until Jan. 31 to decide whether to vacate their jobs in a company cost-cutting move, a company spokesman said. The company confirmed Monday that it has begun a voluntary program to reduce the number of white-collar employees. Bridgestone-Firestone is the ninth-largest employer in Akron with 1,825 employees. After steady declines since 1977, the number of Firestone Akron workers has increased slightly the last two years. Company spokesman Bob Troyer would not say whether there is a reduction goal. However, he said that Bridgestone-Firestone ``hoped'' the departures would alleviate the possible need for layoffs. Troyer said salaried employees are being offered two weeks of pay for every year of service with the company. An employee with 15 years of experience, for example, could receive 30 weeks of pay spread out over 30 weeks. Firestone facilities included in the buyout program are in Akron and Brook Park, Ohio; Russellville, Ark.; Decatur, Ill.; Des Moines, Iowa; Oklahoma City; Wilson, N.C.; and Noblesville, Ind.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Announces New Regional Super-Discount Fares
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines says it will offer one-way tickets to and from Texas cities for as low as $9 to fill seats that otherwise would go empty. The airline said response was brisk and at least two other carriers were considering today whether to follow the low fare lead. ``It's a whole lot more productive to put somebody in a seat at $9 or $19 than to have that seat go empty,'' said John Nelson, Continental's executive vice president of marketing. The announcement Monday came just days after Continental announced it was raising fares by 4 percent. Dubbed ``TexSavers,'' the new fares are good on Tuesday and Wednesday for travel between all Texas cities Continental serves, except El Paso, and for travel between Houston and New Orleans, Oklahoma City and Tulsa. The fares are expected to increase the Houston-based carrier's revenue by about $3 million to $4 million a month, Nelson said. The lowest fare available _ $9 one-way _ will be for travel from Houston on Tuesdays and Wednesdays to New Orleans and throughout Texas, except El Paso, Nelson said. The cost for travel between Oklahoma City and Tulsa from Houston is $19 one way, and the cost for Texas flights involving El Paso is $39 one way. Travel on the Thursday-through-Monday flights from Houston to New Orleans and throughout Texas except El Paso is $19 one-way, $24 one-way for Oklahoma City and Tulsa. One-way fare between El Paso and another Texas city is $49. Unrestricted fares are marked at $39, $59 and $79. The new fares require a 21-day advance purchase, are non-refundable and are subject to availability. Nelson said 5,000 seats a day on 112 flights have been earmarked for the new fares. ``We are having one of the busiest nights ever in Texas,'' Continental spokesman Ned Walker said Monday night. ``Calls are coming in from consumers for these fares. The phones are ringing off the wall. No one's ever seen fares like this in Texas.'' He said the new fares are effective indefinitely. Problems with booking the low fares after the first two-day period resulted from ``some of the other carriers having a minor glitch in loading fare information into computers. ``That will be resolved in the next two days,'' said Walker. ``These fares are real.'' Southwest Airlines, a no-frills regional carrier based in Dallas, may be the competitor most affected by the fare cuts. The majority of Southwest's business comes from connecting Texas cities with each other and surrounding states. Southwest is considering the fares but has not decided whether it will match the cuts, said spokesman David Brown. Officials at Fort Worth-based American Airlines also said they were studying the reductions. ``We were deluged with calls from travel agents. The agents said that they were not able to book the $9 fares after the first Tuesday-Wednesday period,'' said Brown. ``I am not saying that it (the Continental announcement) is a sham, and only for two days, but it is highly unusual that a carrier would make this kind of an announcement and then have those flights only available for that limited a period,'' he said. Southwest last week lowered fares for people over 65, putting a $79 cap on one-way fares, although some are as low as $19. On Dec. 19, Southwest put a $99 cap on one-way, advance-purchase fares. The new rates come a week after the airline announced a 4 percent increase in fares across the country due to higher fuel costs. Nelson said Continental, a subsidiary of Houston-based Texas Air Inc., is implementing the new fares to encourage travelers to fly instead of drive on their next trip. Eastern Airlines, Continental's sister carrier, last week announced fare cuts of up to 45 percent to 65 cities and eliminated the usual cancellation penalties. Eastern said Monday it also was raising some fares 4 percent to help cover fuel costs, but its new discount fares are exempt from the increase. Continental and Eastern are the main subsidiaries of Houston-based Texas Air Corp., the nation's largest airline company.

DOC.HEAD: Mellon President Gets Top Post At First Fidelity
DOC.TEXT: Mellon Bank Corp. President Anthony Terracciano has been chosen to head New Jersey's largest banking company, First Fidelity Bancorp. of Newark, effective Feb. 1. Tearracciano's appointment, announced by both companies on Monday, ends a year-long search for a chairman to replace Robert R. Ferguson Jr., who is set to retire on Feb. 28. Ferguson will continue to serve as a First Fidelity director. A career banker, Terracciano, 51, worked for Chase Manhattan Bank for 23 years before joining Mellon as president in 1987. In a written statement Monday, Terracciano said he was assuming his new post ``with the knowledge that Mellon's momentum will not be interrupted.'' ``Mellon is, simply, on a solid course,'' he said. Pittsburgh-based Mellon, one of the nation's largest bank holding companies, has assets of around $31 billion. Through its subsidiaries, it provides wholesale, middle market and retail banking as well as a number of service products, including trust and investment, data processing and cash management. First Fidelity is the parent company of First Fidelity banks and Morris Savings bank in New Jersy, and of Fidelity Bank and Merchants banks in Pennsylvania. The company has around $30 billion in assets and about 500 offices in New Jersey and Pennsylvania.

DOC.HEAD: New Court Documents Outline Case Against Bean Traders
DOC.TEXT: A court document filed by prosecutors outlines the government's case against a soybean trader accused of cheating customers out of $150,000 in dealings at the Chicago Board of Trade. Martin Dempsey, 52, is accused of shifting more than $60,000 in trading losses to FBI agent Richard Ostrom, who worked undercover as a corrupt bean trader, using the name Richard Carlson, a document filed Monday indicates. Dempsey, of suburban Glen Ellyn, Ill., repaid the losses through embezzled customer funds funneled to Ostrom through illegal prearranged trades, according to the document filed with U.S. District Judge George Marovich. The document claims Dempsey stole ``more than $150,000...through agent Ostrom and other accomodating traders.'' Dempsey has pleaded innocent to charges against him. In the document, prosecutors revealed for the first time that seven months before his indictment in August, Dempsey admitted engaging in illegal trading. Dempsey is among 18 soybean traders and one clerk from the Board of Trade's bean pit who were indicted in the federal probe, which netted indictments against a total of 48 people from the CBOT and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the world's largest commodities exchanges. Five bean traders and the clerk pleaded guilty. Dempsey and 12 others are scheduled to go on trial on June 12, and the 30-page document filed Monday outlines the government's case against the 13. Ostrom, armed with undercover tape recordings of trading pit action, is expected to testify in the soybean trading case.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet-led Trading Bloc Faces Overhaul As Communist System Crumbles
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Soviet proposal for change in trade practices. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union today proposed that the Comecon trading bloc begin trading on a hard currency basis at world prices next year to end four decades of isolation from the world economy. The proposal came on the first day of a private meeting of Soviet and Eastern European leaders, joined by leaders of Mongolia, Vietnam and Cuba. East European leaders welcomed the idea but said it should be implemented slowly. Comecon officials who briefed reporters after the session said the Soviets suggested hard currency trading at world market prices begin in 1991, replacing trading in the non-convertible Soviet ruble. Members of the 10-nation Soviet-led trading bloc, founded in 1949, have agreed that a radical overhaul is needed if the group is to survive and keep pace with changes under way in Eastern Europe, where democracy is taking hold and members are abandoning central planning. Vladimir Dlouhy, a reform Communist who chairs Czechoslovakia's state planning commission, told reporters the Soviet proposal would be ``a disaster'' if introduced immediately and said a transitional period is essential. Poland's non-Communist premier Tadeusz Mazowiecki said the transition period for fuels and raw materials should run until 1995. Other trade should be carried out on the basis of bilateral agreements, Mazowiecki said. Moscow's East European allies traditionally have relied on Soviet raw materials as their chief source of fuel and raw supplies for their industries. Today's meeting was the first since last month's ouster and execution of Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu and the decline of Communist power elsewhere in Europe. ``Comecon is an obsolete organization. It has never worked and doesn't work now,'' Romania's interim Premier Petre Roman said Monday. ``Comecon must adjust and change if it is to continue.'' Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov told reporters after an initial closed-door session: ``There is no danger of Comecon falling apart.'' His assessment of the future of the 10-nation group was partially shared by Czechoslovak Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus, who told reporters, ``Comecon will survive in one form or another.'' Klaus has warned that his country would unilaterally cancel its Comecon commitments unless its transactions are based no longer on the Soviet ruble but on a convertible currency that can be freely exchanged on the world market. That view is shared by Romania's new leaders, who have closed ranks with Hungary's reformers and Poland's Solidarity-led government in calling for an end to trade based on fixed quotas and prices, barter and the ruble. Founded in 1949, Comecon _ the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance _ provided Josef Stalin's Soviet Union with a mechanism for extracting favorable trade agreements from client states. Forty-one years later, the Soviet Union under Mikhail S. Gorbachev has cut loose Warsaw Pact states it once kept in the fold by force and Comecon will thus crumble if the trade relationships within it are not reforged. Trade relationships within Comecon had been based on agreements between state-owned industries in centrally planned economies that did not work. Comecon must now either adjust to the dismantling of such economic systems _ already well under way in Poland and Hungary _ or perish. The meeting's agenda included coordination of economic plans for the next five years, which would at the outset create a conflict. Ryzhkov has presented an orthodox, centrally planned program for the next five years for the Soviet Union, while most East European countries are abandoning central planning in favor of the free market. Critics say the trade bloc has recently been nothing more than a means for its member states to survive the free-market evils of an increasingly competitive world economic system. The bloc has not been held together by Socialist solidarity, they say, but by members' inability to earn enough hard currency to buy energy and raw materials from anywhere but the Soviet Union. Now, all that is changing, as East bloc countries led by Hungary embark on extensive trade with the West. Hungary announced last week it would cut its exports to the Soviet Union by 20 percent. Czechoslovakia and Poland last week decided to establish bilateral trade agreements and link their currencies, the crown and zloty, bypassing the ruble.

DOC.HEAD: Bristol-Myers Squibb Takes Fourth-Quarter Charges of $690 Million After Taxes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, `The large ...' to CORRECT figure to $740 million from $790 million.
DOC.TEXT: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. today announced it is taking two fourth-quarter charges that will total about $690 million after taxes as it continues the process of blending two big pharmaceutical companies. The larger charge, an estimated $740 million before taxes, will be taken as part of a plan to integrate newly merged businesses and reorganize on a worldwide basis. It will cover the costs of reducing the number of plants and employment levels. It also will be used to pay for employee relocations and related expenses, the company said in a news release. A company spokesman said a small percentage of the work force will be cut but exact numbers were not yet known. There will be an additional fourth-quarter charge of $115 million for the costs of professional fees and other expenses related to last year's merger of the formerly separate companies Bristol-Myers and Squibb. The union was completed in October after stockholders approved an $11.5 billion tax-free stock swap between the two companies, creating the second largest pharmaceutical concern behind Merck & Co. The two charges will reduce after-tax income by about $690 million, the company estimated. Financial results for the fourth quarter, which ended Dec. 31, are due to be released later this month. Company spokesman Dan McIntyre said he couldn't say whether the charges would cause Bristol-Myers Squibb to report a loss for the fourth quarter. The two predecessor companies had combined profit of $1.1 billion, or $2.10 a share, through three quarters of 1989. That was up 14.4 percent from $961.5 million, or $1.83 a share, in the first nine months of 1988. Combined sales totaled $6.8 billion, up 6.5 percent from $6.4 billion in 1988. Chairman Richard L. Gelb said Bristol-Myers Squibb is on the way to realizing the benefits of the merger that was announced in July. He said the coordination of sales and marketing activities and the performance of the combined pharmaceutical research and development effort promised to fulfill the business opportunities that were anticipated. Bristol-Myers Squibb expects that savings from joining administrative and manufacturing functions will provide resources to invest in various businesses and to help offset the per-share earnings dilution that the merger caused, Gelb said. McIntyre, a company spokeswoman at the New York headquarters, said the extent of the employment cuts hasn't been determined yet. The company has about 53,000 employees. He said it was anticipated that reductions would amount to a small percentage of the work force. A freeze on new hiring has been in place since the merger was announced over the summer. Bristol-Myers makes Excedrin and Bufferin pain relievers, household products and numerous prescription medicines. Squibb makes and markets a wide variety of prescription drugs and has an extensive research and development operation.

DOC.HEAD: British Aerospace Strike To Force Airbus Production Halt
DOC.NOTE: EDS: UPDATES with new 3rd graf and 8 final grafs to ADD Airbus announcing record sales for 1989; ADDS new graf after 5th graf pvs `The British ...' with information about current work week; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A nine-week strike by workers at a plant owned by British Aerospace PLC will force Airbus Industrie to shut down its production lines in the coming days, the head of the European commercial aircraft consortium said Tuesday. Jean Pierson predicted that thousands of workers at plants in Britain, France, Spain and West Germany will be laid off temporarily because of the strike at the British Aerospace plant at Chester, England, which makes wings for the Airbus family of commercial jets. Pierson, meanwhile, also announced that Airbus had record sales in 1989 of 421 aircraft worth a total of $34 billion, Pierson said the consortium already has cut back the rate of production of its A320 short-to-medium range jet to 1.2 a month from a peak of seven a month in early November. If this hadn't been done, the assembly line at Toulouse in southwest France would have been shut down at the end of November, he said. Pierson told a press conference that if he had known the British Aerospace strike would last so long he would have shut down the assembly line sooner. The British Aerospace workers are striking over their demands for a 35-hour work week. British Aerospace management is refusing to negotiate until the strikers go back to work. The standard work week for manual workers at British Aerospace is 39 hours, but they work on average an extra six hours a week in overtime to meet production schedules. Airbus Industrie's chief executive criticized management for allowing the strike to drag on. ``Part of the art of good management is in being able to handle labor relations,'' he said. Pierson said problems created by the strike will tarnish the consortium's credibility as well as have financial repercussions for the Airbus partners, Aerospatiale of France, Messerschmitt-Boelkow-Blohm GmbH of West Germany, British Aerospace Plc and Construcciones Aeronauticas SA of Spain. Airbus Industrie currently has four A320s and a similar number of wider-bodied A310s on its production lines at Toulouse. Even if the strike ends now, he said, the consortium faces two months without any new wing assemblies. The situation could have consequences for Airbus's market share, Pierson said, noting that customers are being told they will have to wait longer before taking delivery. Pierson acknowledged that 1989 was an exceptional year for the commercial aircraft industry, and predicted that the rhythm of new orders would moderate in 1990. He said the consortium expects to take in orders for between 270 and 300 planes in 1990, well up from the 167 aircraft sold in 1988. Stuart Iddles, senior vice-president for the group's commercial operations, said it was difficult to get a clear picture of the market prospects for 1990 because of uncertainties over the start-up of programs at McDonnell Douglas Corp. and Boeing Commercial Aircraft Corp. in the United States. But he said it was likely that Airbus Industrie would be able to expand its market share to close to 30 percent in 1990 from 22.5 percent in 1989 and 16 percent in 1988. Boeing was the only other manufacturer with a bigger market share last year. Airbus Industrie's 1989 revenue was approximately $5 billion, Pierson said, adding that the consortium showed its first-ever profit from financial operations of $60 million. The Airbus chief executive confirmed that an independent report commissioned by the consortium recommended the final assembly of the A320 narrow-bodied short-to-medium airliner should remain at Toulouse, in southwest France. This could put an end to a yearlong controversy over West Germany's efforts to get the A320 production line transferred to Hamburg. The Airbus supervisory board has requested supplementary information from the report's authors, and the issue will be decided when the board meets on Jan. 26 in Toulouse.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Corp. Comments On Preliminary Talks With Texan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dollar figures are U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Bond Corp. said Tuesday it has held preliminary and very tentative talks with a young Texas businessman who is seeking control of the financially struggling company in return for a $197 million investment. ``It's really wait-and-see,'' said an official spokesman at company headquarters in Perth of the offer by Jeff H. Reynolds. ``We've had some preliminary contact for some time in the form of some phone calls and correspondence,'' said the spokesman, who asked not to be named. ``I am not in a position to say more. He's there, we're here. When things are clearer...if there are more substantive talks, then we can comment.'' Reynolds, who says he heads a firm called Weatherby Investments Inc., is an apparent newcomer on the international investment scene. He has said he planned to visit Australia to talk to Bond and was prepared to take out citizenship here to seal a deal, thereby overcoming any obstacles over foreign investment in Australian media. The 28-year-old Texan said in a news release last week that he was negotiating with Bond Holdings, Bond Corp.'s Australian holding company. However, little is known about Reynolds or his companies, which U.S. officials said Monday did not appear to be publicly traded as he contends. Bond Corp. was founded by Alan Bond, a former America's Cup winner and multimillionaire entrepreneur whose dealings span brewing, natural resources, property and media. The company is reeling under debts of almost $6 billion and is fighting legal battles that have included placement of the brewing interests into receivership. Among those battles was an attempt by the State Government Insurance Commission of Western Australia (SGIC), which claims it is owed money by Bond, to liquidate the entire company. Last Friday, the Supreme Court of Western Australia rejected the SGIC's petition. Late Monday, Bond Corp. Holdings Ltd. launched a counter-action claiming unspecified damages over the SGIC's failed attempt to liquidate Bond Corp. Bond Corp's wholly owned subsidiary Bond Brewing Holdings Ltd. is continuing a legal fight in the Supreme Court of Victoria State to have a decision to appoint receivers set aside. Any money awarded as damages in the SGIC claim would help Bond Corp. overcome its immediate debt problems. Bond has been selling off assets to reduce debts. Elsewhere, Bond Corp. subsidiary Bell Resources Ltd. (BRL) was questioned late Monday by the Australian Stock Exchange about Bond Corp's intended sale of its brewing assets to BRL. BRL said it could not comment on a proposed timetable of events because of the current legal action in the Supreme Court of Victoria.

DOC.HEAD: McCaw To Distribute New Shares
DOC.TEXT: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. said Tuesday it plans to distribute new shares of stock as part of its agreement last month to acquire LIN Broadcasting Corp. McCaw, which will buy a 50.1 percent interest in LIN for $3.38 billion, made the disclosure in a registration statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. McCaw, the nation's largest cellular telephone company, will pay $154.11 per share to buy 21.9 million shares of LIN, a New York-based cellular phone, publishing and broadcasting company. LIN, in turn, will buy $425 million of McCaw's stock and distribute it as a dividend for LIN shares not purchased in the tender offer. McCaw said it had extended its tender offer to expire at noon on Feb. 27, but that could be extended further if all conditions of the offer have not been satisfied. About 13.8 million LIN shares have been tendered so far, McCaw said.

DOC.HEAD: Mercedes and Kodak Are Top Quality, Volvo Drivers Most Loyal, Survey Says
DOC.TEXT: American consumers believe Mercedes and Kodak stand for top quality, although Volvo drivers are more loyal to their cars, a study of brand perceptions says. Coke and Pepsi are dead even in terms of perceived quality, but the Pepsi generation seems more satisfied with its cola. And while Toyota owners are among the most loyal of any brand-name devotees, the average American feels that Buick offers more quality. Total Research Corp., a Princeton, N.J.-based market research firm, surveyed consumers age 15 and older in 1,000 households for their attitudes on 91 brands in categories ranging from cars to candy bars. The study of brand recognition and quality perception, also known as brand equity, found that Campbell soup was the most recognized brand, with 98 percent of those surveyed having some feeling about Campbell. Hallmark greeting cards and McDonald's restaurants followed closely with 97 percent recognition. Mercedes and Kodak topped the list of perceived quality with an average rating of 84 from consumers with a feeling about the brands. The ratings are on a scale ranging from zero for poor or unacceptable quality to 100 equals extraordinary quality. Other brands rating at or above 80 in perceived quality included Fisher-Price toys, Hallmark, Levi's jeans and IBM personal computers. But in the rank of perceived quality among users of a given brand, Volvo came out on top with a rating of 98, topping Mercedes at 94. The survey also indicated strongly polarized views about Toyota. The Japanese carmaker came in third in quality ranking among brand users with a rating of 93. But among consumers who recognize the brands, Buick had a higher perceived quality rating than Toyota, 69 to 66. Among other conclusions, Total Research said consumer response toward Advil showed strong growth potential, with a quality perception among users of the pain reliever higher than quality perceptions among consumers who recognize the brand. Other brands with a similar growth profile included Volvo, ESPN sports cable network, Estee Lauder and Revlon cosmetics, American Express, Fuji film and Magnavox. Kellogg's Corn Flakes showed the classic signs of a declining brand _ highly recognized but average in perceived quality and lowly rated in user satisfaction. Others showing a declining profile included Nestle's Crunch, Sears stores, Holiday Inns, Blue Cross-Blue Shield insurance, Schick razors and Lipton soup. Coke and Pepsi both made the top 10 of most recognized brands, but Pepsi drinkers gave their cola a quality rating of 88 while Coca-Cola drinkers rated their brand slightly lower at 85. The survey also found that consumers still love International Business Machines, even if stock market investors don't. IBM personal computers ranked second behind Kodak in terms of consistency of consumers' quality ranking. At the other end of the scale, MTV, the music cable channel, had the least consistent quality ranking, as well as the lowest quality rating among consumers.

DOC.HEAD: Weather Forecast, Slack Export Demand Drag Down Grain Prices
DOC.TEXT: Grain futures prices closed lower and soybeans were higher Tuesday in quiet trading on the Chicago Board of Trade, as weakness in the wheat market spilled over into other markets. The action in the wheat pit was disappointing the Soviet Union did not reappear in the market after making an overnight purchase of 480,000 metric tons of wheat, said analyst Dale Gustafson of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in Chicago. The National Weather Service's six- to 10-day forecast, released Monday, also dragged down wheat prices. The forecast called for improved chances of rain in hard red winter wheat growing areas. Gustafson said the weak tone of wheat spilled over into the rest of the market. Corn prices fell due to slack demand, with analysts noting that commercial houses were on both sides of the market and for small amounts. Soybean futures were higher as the transportation problems created by December's cold weather cleared up. A lack of additional export business and overnight selling by farmers weighed on prices, analysts said. At the close, wheat was 1{ cents to 3{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $4.07 a bushel; corn was a { cent lower to a \ cent higher with March at $2.38{ a bushel; oats were a { cent to 1\ cents lower with March at $1.50 a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 3 cents higher with January at $5.70} a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Profit Up Sharply In 4th Qtr Due To Sale of Financial Unit
With AM-Time-Warner, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Paramount Communications Inc. said Tuesday its fiscal fourth-quarter profit jumped nearly ninefold to $1.23 billion, reflecting gains from the $3 billion sale of its financial services unit to Ford Motor Co. Earnings also rose for the entire fiscal year, which ended Oct. 31, as the box office success of movies like ``Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade'' helped offset the cost of an unsucessful bid for Time Inc. Paramount, which changed its name from Gulf & Western Inc. in June, said per-share net income for the final quarter was $10.28. That compared with earnings of $144.0 million, or $1.12 per share, the same time a year ago. Fourth quarter revenue rose to $968.8 million from $935.6 million. Paramount said the quarterly results included a $1.2 billion gain from the sale of Associates First Capital Corp., the nation's third-largest independent finance company, to Ford for $3.35 billion, and $279.4 million of earnings from the unit's operations. For the year, Paramount earned $1.47 billion, or $12.21 a share, on revenue of $3.4 billion. That was nearly four times higher than the previous year's net income of $384.5 million, or $3.21 per share, on $3.1 billion in revenue. The annual results reflected a $48.3 million after-tax charge for costs incurred in Paramount's failed bid for Time, which has since merged with Warner Communications Inc., and an $84.3 million charge from publishing operations for the adoption of new accounting procedures. They also included a one-time gain of $7.4 million from the sale of two small units of the publishing subsidiary Prentice Hall. Paramount Chairman Martin S. Davis said fiscal 1989 was ``a transition year.'' ``We completed the restructuring we launched in 1983 and emerged as a strong communications company with operations solely in entertainment and publishing,'' he said in a statement. ``Armed with substantial cash and significant borrowing capacity ... we have the financial strength to fuel the global growth of our businesses,'' he said. Davis said Paramount recorded its second-best operating income in fiscal 1989 due to the popularity of movies such as ``Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade'' and ``The Naked Gun: From the Files of Police Squad'' in U.S. markets, and ``Coming to America,'' ``The Accused'' and ``Crocodile Dundee II'' in foreign markets. Theater operations posted increased operating income, primarily reflecting a gain froom the January 1988 sale to Warner of 50 percent of the company's domestic theater circuits. Television operations declined modestly, reflecting an expected decrease in series syndication income compared with fiscal 1988, which included the availability of ``Webster'' in domestic syndication. Publishing operations, excluding the charge, posted lower results as modest gains in higher education, school and international operations, were more than offset by declines in consumer and supplementary education publishing and profesional information. Consumer publishing posted lower operating income due to higher expenses despite brisk sales of such paperback best sellers as ``Rock Star'' by Jackie Collins and ``It's Always Something'' by Gilda Radner. The Madison Square Garden unit suffered declining operating income due partly to the closing of the facility for renovations last summer.

Prices fell on Wall Street today after the stock market was unable to sustain the moderate gains it chalked up Monday. Five minutes before the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 22.61 at 2,771.76.

DOC.HEAD: Restructuring To Cost Control Data $210 Million More
DOC.TEXT: Restructuring costs at Control Data Corp. for 1989 will surpass $650 million when an expected $210 million charge is booked for the fourth quarter, the computer company said Monday. Lawrence Perlman, Control Data's president and chief executive officer, said the write-offs will lead to a loss in the fourth quarter, adding to the net loss of $484 million in the first nine months of 1989. Exact results will be announced at the end of this month. About half of the expected fourth-quarter charge of $210 million will stem from VTC Inc., a small computer-chip subsidiary that has never been profitable in its five-year history, said Nancy Foltz, a company spokeswoman. Control Data said it expects to sell Bloomington-based VTC this year. The subsidiary, which employs about 400 people, produces computer chips for several high-security government computers. Other fourth-quarter charges stem from foreign currency adjustments from the sale or discontinuation of some overseas holdings and the writing down of some intangible assets, the company said. Previous write-offs were due largely to the shutdown in the second quarter of Control Data's supercomputer subsidiary, ETA Systems, and the streamlining of the company's mainframe computer business. Those moves cost the company $476 million. But the restructuring costs in the second and fourth quarters will be offset by a restructuring gain of $18.9 million booked in the first quarter from the sale of assets and the settlement of a lawsuit. In the third quarter, the sale of the company's disk drive subsidiary, Imprimis, resulted in a restructuring gain of $8.5 million after sale proceeds of $33.7 million were offset by charges of $25.2 million. Perlman also Control Data's banks have agreed to waive the effect of some of the fourth-quarter charges so that the company can meet the net worth test specified in its credit agreement. The agreement defines specific quarterly operating earnings the company must meet. Perlman said Control Data expects operating profits in the fourth quarter to improve from the third-quarter level of about $20.6 million. But he did not give specifics. Since 1984, Control Data has been hit with $1.4 billion in write-offs. The company managed a net profit of $1.7 million in 1988 and $19 million in 1987, but lost a total of $832 million in 1986 and 1985.

Prices fell in dull trading on Wall Street today as the stock market was unable to sustain Monday's mild rally. Analysts said the market could not find a direction in the absence of any news. No economic indicators are scheduled to be released until the end of the week, and many traders were also waiting for fourth-quarter earnings reports before making any major commitments. The market drifted for much of the session, with the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials trading in a narrow range. Then, during the last half-hour, a burst of program trading steepened the market's losses, and the average finished with a decline of 28.37 at 2,766.00. On Monday, when the Dow Jones average rose more than 21 points, most of the gain was also attributed to late program trading.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: program trading.
DOC.TEXT: Declining issues outnumbered advancers by about 5 to 3 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 548 stocks rising, 959 falling and 461 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 155.21 million shares, against 140.11 million in the previous session. The NYSE's composite index fell 1.98 to 193.35. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index slipped 1.18 to 380.44.

DOC.HEAD: General Foods To Warn Viewers of Taste Test Fiction
DOC.TEXT: The maker of Sanka acknowledged Tuesday that a national ad appearing to show an impromptu taste test for the decaffeinated coffee was really staged with actors mouthing prepared lines. General Foods USA said it will alter its ad following an agreement with a Massachusetts state official who criticized the ad as misleading. ``Viewers have come to expect that participants in any taste test are real consumers stating their honest opinions, and not paid actors extolling the product with comment supplied to them by the advertiser,'' said Mary Ann Walsh, the state's secretary of Consumer Affairs and Business Regulation. The ads, which air nationally, will have the word ``dramatization'' superimposed at the bottom of the screen for three seconds as the commercial begins, according to the agreement between Walsh and General Foods. ``We really do not think that any changes in the commercial are required, either by testimonial guidelines or for the protection of the consumer,'' said General Foods spokesman Cliff Sessions. ``But in a spirit of cooperation we are adding the caption, and to avoid any possibility of viewer confusion.'' Set in a New Jersey railroad station at 7:14 a.m., the commercial features people stopping at a table set up with Sanka cups and containers. ``This is great,'' says one person. ``What is this?'' others add. ``Delicious.'' ``You know this smells really good.'' Says another: ``No way, this isn't Sanka.'' Federal guidelines apply to commercials that identify the person approving the product, or those which make competitive claims, Sessions said. Sessions said the Sanka ad does neither. General Foods, Young and Rubicam, the company's advertising agency, and all three networks approved the ad before it aired, Sessions said. General Foods is located in White Plains, N.Y., and parent company Philip Morris Cos. is based in New York City, as is Young and Rubicam. Nevertheless, Walsh took on the food company because the ads air frequently in Massachusetts, she said. Walsh's office phoned the Federal Trade Commission's local office about the case, but continued to negotiate with General Foods on its own. Bill McDonough, a staff attorney for the FTC's regional office in Boston, said action by state officials on a case often can preclude federal involvement. ``We feel as long as somebody does it, that's the main thing. If we found a state has acted, and there is action by the advertiser, it wouldn't be necessary for us to act,'' McDonough said. The ads have been running for about six weeks. Sessions declined to comment on how long the campaign would continue.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Up
Precede LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended mixed Tuesday against key foreign currencies in active, choppy trading. Gold gained after falling in Europe and strengthening in Asia. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $404.20 a troy ounce, up $1.20. Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold at $405.60, up $3.80. Robert Ryan, a currency trader with the Bank of New York, said the dollar started out sharply higher amid concerns that ethnic unrest in some of the Soviet Union's republics would force Mikhail S. Gorbachev to resign. But it moved off its highs for the day on profit-taking and other technical factors, he said. The dollar is often seen as a safe haven for investors in times of political instability. Dealers said the dollar also gained some support from comments by the West German central bank president, Karl Otto Poehl, that there would be no further realignment of exchange rates within European currencies. Italy devalued the lira on Friday within the European Monetary System and traders said more realignments would have further strengthened the West German mark to the detriment of the dollar. In Tokyo, where trading ends before Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose to 144.97 Japanese yen from 144.52 yen Monday. It traded at 145.20 yen in London, and at 144.92 yen in New York, up from 144.15 yen. The dollar was weaker against the British pound. Sterling cost $1.6540 in London, up from Monday's $1.6530, and $1.6585 in New York, up from $1.6535. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Monday's quotes, included: 1.6730 West German marks, up from 1.6685; 1.5145 Swiss francs, down from 1.5245; 5.7025 French francs, up from 5.6965; 1,251.25 Italian lire, up from 1,250.00; and 1.16035 Canadian dollars, unchanged. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Monday: 1.6823 West German marks, up from 1.6685; 1.5260 Swiss francs, up from 1.5235; 5.7305 French francs, up from 5.6920; 1.8970 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8880; 1,257.75 Italian lire, up from 1,249.00; and 1.1610 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1599. Gold bullion fell in London to $403.50 an ounce from $404.75 late Monday. The closing bid in Zurich was $403.50 an ounce, down from $404.05. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 70 cents to close at $402.26 an ounce. Silver prices declined. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.234 a troy ounce, down a penny from Monday. Silver fell in London to $5.24 an ounce from $5.28.

DOC.HEAD: McGraw-Hill Buys TAB Books
DOC.TEXT: McGraw-Hill Inc. said Tuesday it has acquired TAB Books Inc., a non-fiction book publisher, for an undisclosed sum. TAB Books, based in Blue Ridge Summit, Pa., publishes books in 12 fields including computing, electronics, aviation, engineering and several how-to subjects. It will become part of McGraw-Hill's professional publishing division, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Perk Up
DOC.TEXT: Petroleum futures prices rose Tuesday as the energy market rebounded from three days of heavy selling. Wholesale unleaded gasoline made the most dramatic comeback on the New York Mercantile Exchange while prices of crude and home heating oil ended with more moderate gains. The contract for February delivery of unleaded gasoline regained 2.40 cents and finished at 60.88 cents a gallon. The contract had skidded 8.75 cents over the three previous sessions. Contracts for delivery during March, April and May closed with increases of 1.03 cents, 1 cent and 1.40 cents, respectively. Among other refined products traded on the New York Merc, No. 2 heating oil for February delivery rose 0.72 cent to 65.05 cents a gallon, offsetting a portion of Monday's drop of 3.50 cents. March heating oil added 0.47 cent to 59.87 cents a gallon and later delivery months posted similar gains. The February contract of West Texas Intermediate, the leading grade of U.S. crude oil, went up 45 cents to $22.07 per 42-gallon barrel after falling $1.46 on Monday. Other delivery months also ended higher. Andrew Lebow, a senior broker and analyst at E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc., said the rebound came as a sort of reflex action after the big three-day sell-off sparked by warmer weather and profit-taking. ``It seemed to be a good old-fashioned short-covering rally after the steep declines we've seen in recent days,'' he said. Short covering involves buying back a commodity that previously has been sold.

DOC.HEAD: Georgia-Pacific Mounts New Attack on Great Northern Board
SUBS 3 grafs for penultimate graf pvs `Great Northern... to UPDATE with comment, details; PICKS UP last graf pvs, `Georgia Pacific previously...
DOC.TEXT: Georgia-Pacific Corp. asked a federal judge Tuesday to cut the number of votes needed to fire directors of Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. in the proxy battle between the rival paper companies. Great Northern has resisted Georgia-Pacific's unsolicited $3.8 billion tender offer, saying it is illegal on antitrust grounds. Atlanta-based Georgia-Pacific has said the Great Northern board should be fired because its members are trying to protect their own high-paying jobs at the expense of shareholders. Georgia-Pacific Chairman T. Marshall Hahn Jr. said in court papers that the rival company'sboard provisions are ``manifestly designed to insulate incumbent directors from the wishes of the company's shareholders.'' Georgia-Pacific asked U.S. District Judge Gene Carter to reduce the number of shares needed to oust the Great Northern board from three-fourths to two-thirds. Georgia-Pacific contends that Great Northern is in violation of Maine corporate law by requiring the higher number. Stephen Hill, a spokesman for Great Northern, which is based in Norwalk, Conn., but incorporated in Maine, said the latest Georgia-Pacific filing ``has no merit.'' Materials filed with the motion included a list of 16 potential candidates that Georgia-Pacific would like to see on Great Northern's board, 10 of whom are Georgia-Pacific executives. Hill said Great Northern would issue a proxy statement soon ``that will tell our side of the story.'' Georgia-Pacific previously had solicited shareholders to call a meeting to oust Great Northern's board. A meeting is set for March 2.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Overturns Warner Insurance Licensing Decision
DOC.TEXT: Massachusetts' highest court ruled Tuesday that the courts and not the state should decide whether a subsidiary of Fireman's Fund Insurance Cos. can sell insurance in Massachusetts. The complex case stemmed from a 1987 decision by Fireman's Fund to withdraw from Massachusetts, primarily because of concerns over sagging auto insurance profits. That move came without prior notice. Fireman's Fund allowed its Massachusetts insurance license to expire and it also withdrew from the Commonwealth Automobile Reinsurers, the high-risk pool for auto insurance. The state Insurance Division advised Fireman's Fund it could not unilaterally abandon the Massachusetts market on less than one day's notice and filed suit in Superior Court. On Nov. 13, 1987, Fireman's Fund, the auto insurance pool and the state Insurance Division signed a settlement agreement that ended the suit filed by the state and a countersuit filed by the insurance company. The insurance commissioner said at the time that Fireman's Fund could not return to Massachusetts without state approval, and the company did not dispute that point, Supreme Judicial Court Justice Ruth Abrams said in Tuesday's decision. The settlement also contained language that said Fireman's Fund would stop selling insurance in the state and provided for a $45 million payment to the insurance pool. Following the settlement, Fireman's Fund dismantled its Massachusetts operation. But on Sept. 29, 1988, a wholly owned subsidiary, National Surety Corp., a party to the settlement agreement, bought Warner Insurance Co., an Illinois insurance corporation licensed in Massachusetts to write most insurance, but not auto policies. After a hearing, the Insurance Division revoked Warner's license, contending the purchase violated the settlement agreement. The insurance company appealed, and argued that the Superior Court was the proper forum for the dispute to be resolved. The Supreme Judicial Court agreed. ``The insurance statutes do not give the commissioner authority to make a binding interpretation of a contract to which he is a party or to determine conclusively whether the other party has violated that contract,'' Abrams wrote. The Supreme Judicial Court sent the case to the Superior Court for further action. Abrams said if there was no violation, the revocation of Warner's license was not proper. If there was a violation, she said, the Superior Court might conclude that a proper remedy would be for either Fireman's Fund to sell Warner or for the revocation of Warner's license to stand.

DOC.HEAD: Time, Warner Officials Ready to Officially Merge Companies
DOC.TEXT: Three years after officials of Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. first talked about combining their businesses, the two companies are sealing their $14 billion merger and forming the world's largest media concern. But the Time Warner Inc. that will be created when the deal officially closes Wednesday is vastly different from the company Time Chairman J. Richard Munro and Warner Chairman Steven J. Ross once envisioned. Time Warner is expected to have $11.4 billion in revenue this year, putting it ahead of the West German firm Bertelsmann AG as the world's biggest media company. But the new company will be burdened with nearly $11 billion in debt, mostly as a result of the merger, which supplanted Time and Warner's initial plans for a debt-free stock swap. Its high leverage is expected to put a crimp in some of Time Warner's plans. ``It would have been a hell of a company if they didn't have all the debt,'' said Fred Anschel, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. Peter Appert, an analyst with C.J. Lawrence-Morgan Grenfell, said the debt load makes Time-Warner ``a more risky proposition in a slowing economic environment, particularly if interest rates move up.'' Analysts predict Time Warner earnings will be depressed for at least two years while it reduces its debt, but they generally expect the company ultimately to flourish. Although Appert was concerned about the company's debt, he also said, ``I think the company will do quite well.'' Said Anschel: ``The businesses they're in are strong cash-producing businesses'' and Time-Warner should be able to pay down its debt as long as it remains well-managed. Warner brings properties that include its highly-successful Warner Bros. film and television studios, Warner Bros. and Atlantic records divisions, Warner Cable business and its publishing arm, which includes Warner Books and DC Comics. Time's main businesses are magazine publishing, including Time, Sports Illustrated, and People magazines; book publishing, including Time-Life Books Inc. and Book-of-the-Month Club Inc.; and cable television, including Home Box Office Inc. and American Television and Communications Corp. Last March, Time and Warner announced that after two years of on-again, off-again talks, they would merge in an exchange of stock. But on June 6, less than three weeks before shareholders were to vote on the merger, Paramount Communications Inc. launched a $10.7 billion hostile offer for Time. The bid, later raised to $12 billion, forced Time and Warner to transform their stock-swap deal into a $14 billion tender offer by Time for its would-be partner. Paramount also took Time and Warner to court in Delaware in an unsuccessful attempt to stop the Time-Warner combination. On July 24, the Delaware Supreme Court upheld a lower court ruling allowing the merger to proceed. Time's tender offer expired hours later, and in the so-called front end of the offer, Time paid $70 in cash for about half of Warner's 200 million outstanding shares. Time also changed its name then to Time Warner Inc., but Warner Communications remained a separate entity pending Wednesday's closing of the deal. At the closing, Warner shareholders were to be issued securities for the balance of their holdings and Warner stock was to be delisted from the New York Stock Exchange at the end of the day. Munro and Ross will serve as co-chairmen and co-chief executive officers of the merged company. After both eventually retire, N.J. Nicholas Jr., Time Warner's president, is expected to head Time Warner. Many observers have questioned whether the two-chairman idea can work, especially with the strong personalities involved. Munro and Ross say that since they negotiated the deal and weathered the Paramount storm together, they can run the company side-by-side. Anschel predicted that ``at least for a couple of years it's going to work _ unless something comes up where they start disagreeing.'' But there are likely to be few rough spots right now, Anschel said, because Munro, Ross and Nicholas agree that ``the first priority is to reduce their debt.'' To some observers, a big uncertainty is the price of Time Warner stock. During its fight against Paramount, Time asked shareholders to reject the $200 a share cash offered in the Paramount bid, and profit in the longterm as Time Warner stock rises. Analysts expected the stock _ which closed at $116.75 a share Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange _ to rise, but it may take some time. ``If they demonstrate that they're making progress in terms of cash flow and debt reduction, I think the stock will rise gradually,'' said Dean Witter's Anschel. Appert also said he expected the stock to make money over time, but not in the near term.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Prices Climb in Volatile Trading
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices climbed Tuesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange in trading that saw heating oil prices swing wildly before finishing with a modest gain. On other markets, soybeans were higher while grains fell; livestock futures were mostly lower and pork futures mixed; and precious metals were mixed. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 16 cents to 45 cents higher with the contract for delivery in February at $22.07 cents a barrel. Heating oil was .45 cent to .72 cent higher with February at 65.05 cents a gallon. Unleaded gasoline was 1 cent to 2.4 cents higher with February at 60.88 cents a gallon. Analyst Bob Baker of Prudential Bache Securities Inc. in New York said heating oil futures were up about 250 points before turning negative and then closing with a modest gain. Meanwhile, gasoline prices climbed steadily to post a strong gain. Baker attributed the volatility in the heating oil market to speculative trading and the entrance of bargain hunters. Expectaions that the American Petroleum Institute's weekly inventory data would show a decline in distillate and gasoline stocks helped boost prices. After the close of trading, the API released data showing gasoline stocks were down 6.4 million barrels and distillate stocks down 423,000 barrels. Crude oil stocks were up 418,000 barrels. Tuesday's trading reversed three days of selling spurred by easing concern over cold weather and reports OPEC production surged beyond the levels set last year by the cartel. Grain futures prices closed lower and soybeans were higher in quiet trading on the Chicago Board of Trade. The action in the wheat pit was disappointing because the Soviet Union did not reappear in the market after making an overnight purchase of 480,000 metric tons of wheat, said analyst Dale Gustafson of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. in Chicago. The National Weather Service's six- to 10-day forecast, released Monday, also dragged down wheat prices. The forecast called for improved chances of rain in hard red winter wheat growing areas. Corn prices fell due to slack demand, with analysts noting that commercial houses were on both sides of the market and for small amounts. Soybean futures were higher as the transportation problems created by December's cold weather cleared up. A lack of additional export business and overnight selling by farmers weighed on prices, analysts said. Wheat was 1} cents to 3\ cents lower with March at $4.06} a bushel; corn was 1 cent lower to a \ cent higher with March at $2.38} a bushel; oats were a } cent to 1\ cents lower with March at $1.49{ a bushel; soybeans were } cent lower to 2 cents higher with January at $5.70{ a bushel. Livestock futures were mostly lower and pork futures were mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade. Weaker wholesale prices and lower cash prices put pressure on cattle futures, according to analyst Tom Morgan of Research Corp. in Arlington Heights, Ill. Pork belly futures continued the rally that began last week when the U.S. Agriculture Department issued a quarterly hogs and pigs tally that showed far fewer animals than traders expected. Live cattle were .05 cent to .20 cent lower with February at 76.47 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .25 cent lower to .15 cent higher with January at 84.65 cents a pound; hogs were .32 cent lower to .10 cent higher with Feburary at 51.30 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .10 cent to .90 cent higher with February at 55.60 cents a pound. Precious metals futures were mixed on New York's Commodity Exchange. Gold traded in a narrow range, before finishing higher as the value of the dollar showed signs of weakening, said analyst Craig Sloane of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. in New York. Silver declined in sluggish trading. Gold was $1.20 higher with February at $406.20 a troy ounce; silver was 1 cent to 1.6 cents lower with March at $5.298 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Technology Transfer Restrictions Eased
DOC.TEXT: The government has relaxed rules on technology transfers, removing obstacles to importation and lifting limits on royalties, according to published reports Tuesday. Commerce Secretary Jaime Serra Puche said the revised regulations are aimed at encouraging modernization of technology used in Mexican businesses and reducing obstacles to acquiring that technology abroad. He said previous regulations had left Mexican business investment in technology ``as much as 90 percent less than that in other, more developed countries.'' President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has made modernization his slogan. In little more than one year in office, he has lifted most restrictions on foreign investment, stepped up the program of returning state-owned business to the private sector and continued opening domestic markets to imports in an effort to force the long-protected local industries to compete. Among other measures, the new rules, which took effect Tuesday, eliminate the 3 percent to 6 percent limit on royalties, allowing companies to make any payment agreement they wish, newspapers said. The new regulations also are designed to increase patent protection and assure foreign companies that their products will not be pirated. Protection of intellectual property rights has been has been a major irritant in U.S.-Mexico relations. The regulation broaden provisions for protection of ``industrial secrets,'' letting companies extend the period of confidentiality on transferred technology. Other provisions reduce the paperwork involved in registering patents and trademarks. Claudio X. Gonzalez, a presidential adviser on foreign investment, said the changes should allow Mexico to attact more foreign investment and better technology and make the country more competitive abroad.

DOC.HEAD: New Civil Charges Filed in Business Week Insider Trading Scandal
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday accused two California men of illegally trading on confidential information from advance copies of Business Week magazine. The defendants are William N. Jackson, of Long Beach, Calif., a former employee of a Business Week printer, and Brian J. Callahan, of Anaheim, Calif., a former broker in the Anaheim office of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. The civil complaint, filed in federal court in Los Angeles, seeks $39,000 in alleged profits from the two men and fines triple the profit of $117,000. The SEC, in a news release from its New York office, said the case was the fifth civil action _ three of which have been settled _ alleging trading on information in advance copies of Business Week. Criminal charges also were filed in some of the earlier cases. According to the complaint, Jackson had access to advance copies of the magazine through his job at R.R. Donnelley & Sons Co., which printed Business Week at a plant in Torrance, Calif. Jackson allegedly traded on 49 companies mentioned in the magazine's ``Inside Wall Street'' column between July 1987 and July 1988 and shared the information with his brothers, the SEC said. Jackson and his brothers allegedly made $19,506 in profits. The complaint said Callahan approached Jackson about opening an account at Prudential-Bache in April 1988, after learning that Jackson had advance information from Business Week. The SEC said Jackson told Callahan the names of companies mentioned in upcoming issues of the magazine. Callahan allegedly purchased securities of seven companies, earning a profit for himself of $1,148 between April 1988 and July 1988. The complaint said he also used the information to place orders for his customers, who profited by at least $18,535. The SEC alleged Callahan benefited by his customers' trading because he earned commissions. The case is not the first involving employees of R.R. Donnelley. In August, a former salesman at the company's Torrance plant, Shayne A. Walters, pleaded guilty to criminal charges and settled SEC civil charges that he traded on advance copies of Business Week. Walters awaits sentencing. Also, William Dillon, a former broker for Merrill Lynch & Co., was sentenced to six months in prison for similar charges. The government charged that he paid various employees at an R.R. Donnelley plant in Connecticut for advance copies of the magazine.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico on Brink of Final Agreement With Banks
DOC.TEXT: Mexico and its creditor banks are on the brink of completing a debt renegotiation that will allow the country to resume growth after years of stagnation, Mexico's top debt negotiator said. ``It's like an aircraft at the end of the runway. You move your flaps. You're committed,'' Angel Gurria said. Gurria, assistant treasury secretary for international financial affairs, said more than 98 percent of nearly 600 commercial banks have signed on to the debt renegotiation package, terms of which were agreed upon last July. The package should be ready for a formal signing before the end of the month, said William R. Rhodes, the Citibank banker who has led bank creditors in the negotiations. The renegotiation would cut $7.5 billion from Mexico's $48.5 billion commercial bank debt and knock nearly $2 billion from the country's annual interest bill of $9 billion. ``We're less than $1 billion away from actually having all the money there committed,'' Gurria said in an interview last week with The Associated Press. ``Of the $1 billion, we know where $800 million stands.'' Mexico is the first country to renegotiate its debt since Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady outlined a new U.S. policy offering to forgive some debt if countries make serious efforts to reform their economies. Under Mexico's package, creditor banks have three options: forgiving 35 percent of the principal of their loans; leaving principal intact but reducing the interest rate to 6.25 percent, below market levels; or providing new loans equal to 25 percent of the bank's existing loans to Mexico. Gurria said 42 percent of the banks have agreed to the principal reduction, 48 percent will lower interest rates and the remaining 10 percent will provide new loans. The number of banks opting for the third option is lower than negotiators had hoped. As a result, Mexico and the banks are about $300 million short of the money needed to guarantee repayment of debts, a key part of the plan, according to a banker involved in the negotiations, who requested anonymity. That gap won't delay the completion of the package, though, he said. ``A $300 million shortfall is manageable,'' the banker said. Gurria said completion of the package requires formal approval by boards and committees of some creditor banks. The creditor banks still have ``a couple of weeks'' to study the documents before signing them, he said. Mexico's $96 billion foreign debt, which includes debts to foreign governments, is the second-largest among developing nations after Brazil's $110 billion. Brazil has not paid interest on its debt for months. Mexican officials have said the agreement will allow Mexico to pay 2.7 percent of its gross national product to service foreign debt, instead of the 6.3 percent it has paid out in recent years. Agreement on the terms of the renegotiation last July was a key to restoring confidence in the Mexican economy, which grew 3 percent last year after seven years of recession or stagnation. Inflation was held to 19.7 percent in 1989, down from 159 percent in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Corp. and Campeau Corp. at a Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, is a description of the businesses of Alan Bond and Robert Campeau:

Headquarters: Perth, Australia. Principal businesses: brewing, media, real estate, natural resources and mining. Major U.S. business: G. Heileman Brewing Co. of La Crosse, Wis. Total indebtedness: $6 billion. Status of company: Bond's brewing interests in Australia are in receivership. Heileman has worked out an agreement with its own creditors. Bond has begun negotiations with Texas businessmen Jeff Reynolds, who offered to invest nearly $200 million in Bond Corp. in return for control of the corporation.

Headquarters: Toronto. Principal businesses: retailing, real estate. Major U.S. businesses: Allied Stores Corp., Federated Department Stores Inc. Total indebtedness: $7 billion. Status of company: Campeau is negotiating with creditors to extend its payment schedule and is trying to sell its Bloomingdale's chain to raise cash. It is widely expected that Allied and Federated will be forced to file for protection from their creditors under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code.

DOC.HEAD: Late Program Selling Sends Stocks Broadly Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS percentage of Wilshire index in 16th graf.
DOC.TEXT: A late burst of program selling sent prices into a broad decline on Wall Street Tuesday, capping an otherwise lackluster session. Stocks had meandered lower for much of the day in the absence of any news to stimulate trading, but computerized sell orders in the last half-hour increased the market's losses. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 28.37 to 2,766.00, wiping out a more than 21 point gain the previous session that was also largely attributed to program trading. Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by about 5 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 565 up, 959 down and 461 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 155.21 million shares, up from 140.11 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 187.94 million shares. Analysts said the market lacked the support necessary to sustain Monday's moderate gains, which followed the major banks' lowering of their prime lending rates from 10.5 percent to 10 percent. Traders were unable to look to any economic indicators for guidance. The next scheduled government reports are December producer prices and retail sales, both to be announced on Friday. Analysts said many traders were also waiting for companies' fourth-quarter earnings to be announced before making any major commitments. ``They're waiting for numbers or some sign that the market's going to make a sustained move in either direction,'' said Michael Metz, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Co. He described the market as having ``no sense of urgency.'' One standout in Tuesday's trading was UAL, which shot up 7] to 164 after the parent of United Airlines said it was considering a recapitalization. Bristol-Myers Squibb fell ~ to 55{. DOC.HEAD: Japanese Trade Official Disputes Preception Nation Is Closed Economy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT spelling of trade minister's first name.
DOC.TEXT: Japan's top trade official on Tuesday disputed the perception that Japanese markets are closed to foreign business and blamed the United States' high budget deficit and low savings rate for worsening for the nation's trade problems. ``The openness of the Japanese manufacturing market is comparable with the United States already,'' said Hikaru Matsunaga, minister of international trade and industry. U.S. industry and government officials contend that access to Japan's market is limited severely and is a key contributor to the U.S. trade deficit. The Japanese government last month outlined a package of tax incentives, tariff eliminations and other measures that officials said was aimed at reversing past trade policies and making Japan an importing powerhouse in the 1990s. Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry expects to the measures to eliminate discrepancies between the costs of products in Japan and abroad, make the Japanese distribution system more efficient, and lead to the breakdown of the ``keiretsu'' system in which many Japanese companies are clustered in tightly knit groups. All of those issues are on the table in the U.S.-Japan negotiations to deal with such alleged ``structural impediments'' to trade. Matsunaga said in a speech to business leaders that Japan's imports of manufactured goods already had increased 39 percent in 1988 and imports from the United States grew 34 percent. ``I hope that the facts of this rapid increase in Japan's imports are understood and will inspire foreign businesses to challenge the expanding Japanese market, which in fact holds immense potential benefits for them,'' he said through an interpreter. Matsunaga visited Dallas before heading to Washington, where he will meet with government trade officials, including U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills and Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher. Matsunaga attributed much of the U.S. trade deficit to ``macroeconomic'' policies, including low savings incentives and the budget deficit. ``I am expecting to see the United States making efforts to cut its budget deficit and strengthen its industrial competitiveness, and to enhance supply capacity,'' he said. ``I'm sure that measures to raise the savings rate ... would be extremely beneficial.'' The Bush administration is considering a proposal for providing tax breaks on savings. The high Japanese rate of savings often is cited as a factor in that nation's relatively cheap supply of capital. Matsunaga, who described Japan as a free market, also criticized what he said is an increasing move toward protectionist policies in the West. He said he is especially concerned that Europe will become a closed market in 1992, when internal trade barriers within the Common Market are eliminated.

DOC.HEAD: New Wide-Body Passenger Jet To Get First Test Flight
DOC.TEXT: McDonnell Douglas Corp.'s MD-11, a new wide-body jetliner based on the DC-10, is scheduled to make its maiden flight Wednesday, six months behind schedule but with the aerospace giant's hopes flying high. The first test flight of the MD-11, the first new tri-jet introduced since McDonnell Douglas' DC-10 and Lockheed' L-1011 two decades ago, will take place only if weather is clear at Long Beach Airport. The 350-passenger MD-11 is just one of several aircraft programs on which the St. Louis-based aerospace and defense company has run behind schedule, including the 150-passenger MD-80 jetliner and the C-17 military cargo plane. Many of McDonnell Douglas' problems stem from the worldwide boom in commercial aircraft orders, which also has overtaxed production at rival Boeing Co. The MD-11 is ``quite important to McDonnell Douglas,'' said Lawrence Harris, and aerospace analyst with the Bateman Eichler Hill Richards brokerage in Los Angeles. ``The successful certification of the MD-11 will generate a significant portion of Douglas' revenues over the next several years,'' he said. The company has 118 orders and 194 options for MD-11s, which Harris said will cost about $90 million each. Under the most optimistic schedule, the company could have the plane tested, approved and 10 jets delivered by the end of the year, he said, but that is unlikely. The maximum non-stop range for the standard MD-11 is up to 8,039 statute miles with 323 passengers and bags. The planes include the quieter, more energy efficient high-bypass engines made by General Electric Co., Rolls Royce and Pratt & Whitney. Customers will be able to choose the engine maker; the engines on the plane to be tested Wednesday were made by GE. The MD-11 is about as long as two-thirds of a football field, and several companies have expressed interest in a stretch version that would be 35 feet longer, about the size of a Boeing 747. No decision has been made on whether to produce the longer version, spokesman Keith Takahashi said Tuesday from the company's Douglas Aircraft division in Long Beach, where the plane is made. The MD-11 looks much the same from the outside as the DC-10, although minor streamlining changes have been made in the tail, the end of the wings and the stabilizers. The avionics, cockpit and interior are new. It will compete against the A-330 and A-340 jetliners being manufactured by the European consortium Airbus Industrie, which also carry about 350 passengers and cost about the same. Boeing's 777, to be introduced in the mid-1990s, will also compete with the MD-11s. ``McDonnell Douglas is counting on the Douglas unit to generate profit growth in the years ahead because of the likelihood of a flattening defense budget and the significant commercial backlog that exists for both the MD-80 and the MD-11,'' said Harris, the Bateman Eichler analyst. He said 1990 would be a transitional year for McDonnell Douglas, whose earnings fell during the first nine months of fiscal 1989. ``It's still an open question as to how many (MD-11s) can be delivered, and the bottom line will be affected by development expense,'' which could rise if test flights reveal serious problems, Harris said. The program for the smaller MD-80 appears to have ``turned the corner'' into profitability, he said. Meanwhile, the C-17 program is still in development amid close scrutiny. The Air Force recently moved the first flight of the C-17 fron the end of this year to mid-1991.

DOC.HEAD: New Division To Promote Specialty Line
DOC.TEXT: Ralston Purina Co. said Tuesday it will establish a new division designed exlusively to serve its specialty pet food segment and provide a greater push for its premium Pro Plan pet foods. Pro-Visions Pet Specialty Enterprises will market Pro Plan products to pet shops, feed stores and veterinary offices, Ralston Purina said. Scott R. Harris, the new division's managing director, said Pro-Visions will unveil a new line of pet food for special dietary uses that will be distributed through veterinarians. The new product line, Clinical Nutrition Management, is expected to be available by midyear. It results from a multimillion-dollar research and development program, in part at veterinary universities, to meet special dietary needs of dogs and cats with specific health conditions. Ralston Purina is the world's leading producer of dry dog food and dry and moist cat food. It also owns Continental Baking Co., the nation's largest wholesale bakery, and is the nation's leading manufacturer of batteries with its Eveready and Energizer labels. Ralston Purina sales totaled $6.6 billion in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Suzuki To Set Up Joint Venture Car Plant in Hungary
DOC.TEXT: Suzuki Motor Co., Japan's largest minicar producer, said Tuesday it has reached an agreement with Hungary to set up a joint venture car plant near Budapest. The agreement will be signed in Budapest on Friday between Suzuki Motor President Osamu Suzuki and Hungarian representatives, company officials said. Masabumi Yayoshi, a Suzuki spokesman, said the project would make his company the first Japanese automaker ever to open operations in Eastern Europe. Suzuki first bagan discussing the project with Hungarian authorities in 1985, he said. The $138.9 million plant in Esztergom, 25 miles north of Budapest, will produce Suzuki Swifts, small passenger cars based on Suzuki's Cultus, Yayoshi said. Capitalized at $71.4 million dollars, the joint venture company would be owned 50 percent by Autokonszern, a Hungarian firm, 30 percent by Suzuki Motor and 10 percent each by the Washington-based International Finance Corp. and C. Itoh and Co. Ltd., one of Japan's three largest general trading firms. IFC is a World Bank affiliate that finances private projects. Yayoshi said production would begin in 1992, expanding from 15,000 cars in the first year to 50,000 cars in the third. Annual capacity eventually would reach 100,000 cars, enabling Hungary to export some to other countries, he added. Ministry of International Trade and Industry officials said they hoped the project would help promote economic relations between Hungary and Japan. The announcement came just before Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's scheduled visit to Budapest next week. Some Japanese news reports have said Kaifu, on an 11-day, seven-nation European tour, would promise up to $1.95 billion of Japanese assistance to Eastern European countries, including $700 million for Hungary and Poland. Suzuki already has a total of 50 minicar and motorcycle plants abroad, in the United States, Britain, Spain, Canada, South Korea and 23 other countries.
